webTitle: Pompey plump for Pulis work ethic

fields.headline: Pompey plump for Pulis work ethic
fields.trailText: Portsmouth are expected to name Tony Pulis, the Bristol City manager, as successor to Alan Ball, whom they fired as manager last month.
fields.body:
Portsmouth are expected to name Tony Pulis, the Bristol City manager, as successor to Alan Ball, whom they fired as manager last month.

Colin Todd, who was interviewed, withdrew from the reckoning yesterday, saying he "would have loved the job" but was "no longer interested". He criticised the Pompey chairman Milan Mandaric's handling of the matter.

Pulis met Mandaric for further talks yesterday and is poised to agree a 3-year deal. Having led Gillingham to the Second Division play-offs last May, he joined Bristol City but has yet to sign the five-year contract he was offered. City, having first objected, last night cleared the way for Pulis to leave, though they will demand compensation.

Mandaric is delighted at the prospect of Pulis joining the club. Portsmouth lie third from bottom of the First Division, having won one of their last 16 league games and spent around £4m on players.

Mandaric said: "Pulis strikes me as someone who is tireless, dynamic and achieves things the old-fashioned way, through hard work. I want the kind of guy with the Portsmouth philosophy of hard work and commitment in his blood."

webTitle: Roma under fire over Rolexes for referees

fields.headline: Roma under fire over Rolexes for referees
fields.trailText: Italian referees are said to have accepted gold Rolex watches and other expensive Christmas presents from football clubs, reviving suspicions of bribery and match-fixing.
fields.body:
Italian referees are said to have accepted gold Rolex watches and other expensive Christmas presents from football clubs, reviving suspicions of bribery and match-fixing.

Fifa and Uefa, the world and European authorities, have demanded a report into the controversy which this week engulfed Serie A.

The Italian football federation ordered referees to return "inappropriate" gifts after Roma admitted giving watches worth a total of £8,000 to two officials. La Gazzetta dello Sport claimed the club had also given Rolexes to 37 other referees. Roma issued a statement defending the gifts as legitimate and insisting it was not the only one to hand out presents. "AS Roma notes that the gifts had a lower value than those sent by other clubs."

Internazionale was revealed to have given each referee a muscle exerciser worth £500 but rumours swept the league of other clubs' more lavish presents.

Luciano Nizzola, federation president, said officials should return gifts "that cannot be considered normal gifts that accompany the end-of-year festivities".

The federation was unimpressed by Roma's claim to have bought a bulk batch of Rolexes at a discount. Nor were Italian newspapers. "Better to appear stingy than corrupt," mocked Corriere della Sera.

Roma fuelled the row by claiming the revelations were leaked to coincide with last Sunday's match against the league champions Milan, which ended in a 2-2 draw.

"AS Roma notes that, considering this was a gesture of normal courtesy that was never questioned in previous years, it seems particularly unpleasant that the supposed scandal was exposed a month after the gifts were sent and in particular on the very eve of the Milan-Roma match."

Roma said the revelations concerned "an episode of absolute and well-documented transparency" which had been recorded in the club's accounts.

Before the story broke Franco Sensi, Roma's chairman, hinted that a conspiracy was afoot when he was referred to a sports judge for comments after the 3-1 win over Bari on January 6.

After Antonio Carlos Zago and Alessandro Rinaldi received yellow cards which ruled them out for the Milan game, Sensi said: "Against Milan, they never let us play with a full side. It's strange, we always get a couple of players stopped every time."

webTitle: Prenton Park Two told to take a break

fields.headline: Prenton Park Two told to take a break
fields.trailText: Rob Harris and Tony Green, the referee and his assistant at the centre of the fiasco at Prenton Park last Saturday, will not be asked to officiate at another match until the referees' committee of the Football Association delivers its report on the farcical ending to the FA Cup fourth-round tie between Tranmere and Sunderland.
fields.body:
Rob Harris and Tony Green, the referee and his assistant at the centre of the fiasco at Prenton Park last Saturday, will not be asked to officiate at another match until the referees' committee of the Football Association delivers its report on the farcical ending to the FA Cup fourth-round tie between Tranmere and Sunderland.

However, the fourth official David Unsworth, whose job it was to indicate which player Tranmere intended to replace and inserted the number of Clint Hill, who had just been sent off, rather than the winger Andy Parkinson, is not affected by the ruling as he is a Football League official.

Harris, who was stood down from last Tuesday's tie between Gillingham and Bradford City, allowed Tranmere to defend a Sunderland free-kick with 11 men before realising the mistake, but restarted play with a goal-kick after the home side had been reduced to 10 men rather than recommence with a retaken free-kick.

"The issue of the regulations governing referees is a matter for the FA, but we feel that it would be better for everyone concerned to take this step while the investigation is concluded," said Mike Lee, a Premier League spokesman.

Tranmere were faced with an anxious 48-hour wait before the FA announced that the 1-0 result would stand.

 Tottenham's Tim Sherwood has been charged with making obscene gestures at the Newcastle United crowd during his club's 2-1 defeat there in November. The midfielder has 14 days to respond to the charge. However, David Ginola, also reported to Northumbria police by the home fans after the game, has escaped sanction.

 Liverpool's Robbie Fowler is to have his second ankle operation of the season next week and is expected to be sidelined for two more months. It was first operated on in October but the injury flared up after he appeared as a substitute, and scored, in a 3-1 win over Wimbledon after Christmas.

 Henrik Larsson of Celtic is to play out his career with a steel pin in his right leg. The 28-year-old striker is recovering from a double fracture suffered at Lyon in October and will not play again this season. He will also miss Sweden's participation in Euro 2000.

"The bone needs to heal and I have a pin in the leg from around the knee to the ankle," he said. "I can't feel the pin but I can feel the screw. However I intend to keep the pin until I finish playing."

webTitle: OK, I didn't figure in Rio but I'm still No1 with the under-10s

fields.headline: OK, I didn't figure in Rio but I'm still No1 with the under-10s
fields.trailText: Monday
fields.body:
Monday

I 've got the flu. Deffo. No question. The pain going off in my head is like that pain you get when Gary Newbon's on the telly. And worse, he's interviewing Alan Shearer.

"Alan, great goal," me head's going. "Well, you might say that Gary, but that's what I'm paid for ... chicken and beans... I'm a steelworker's son, you know."

Ow, me bleedin' head. Worse, me legs have gone all like concrete, like Jo Brand's squatting on me cruciates. And she's got Dawn French in for company. Then, just as I can't feel worse, the bleedin' mobe starts up right by me bed. It's playing Better Best Forgotten by Steps, what Wattsy programmed in saying it was the last word in designer chic and guaranteed to attract the girls. As it happens, he's right. It went down a bomb with a group of under-10s fetching up in their school holiday at the training ground looking for autographs.

"Oi, Dazz," says one nine-year-old, as Rodney bells me as I try to make me way through the masses (there was seven of them) to the Jeep. "Steps? Puhlease. That is, like, so not happening."

"Less lip," I says. "Do you want me autograph or not?"

"Like, what would a girl want with Darren, like, Tackle's autograph?" says the girl. "Use it to make herself barf?"

I wouldn't have minded, but she was my daughter.

Anyhow, back to this morning. It is, of course, Rodney on the dog.

"What you want, Rodds?" I groans. "I've got the flu."

"The flu is it boy?" he says. "Little bird tells me DT was out last night getting leathered toasting Gary Neville. From what I heard, he said he'd drink a pint of vodka and Red Bull for every mistake the geezer made in Brazil. Must have been a big night then."

Now it's all beginning to come back to us. Not flu then. Bollocks.

"What I'm basically trying to tell you in a nutshell, boy, is this," says Rodds. "I've got you half a long 'un for doing a story with Men's Health magazine. They want you for a feature they're doing on the new start for the new millennium. You know, diet, training, fitness, six pack, buns of steel, how to keep it up all night, usual mullarkey. Photo shoot tomorrow. So you'd better pull yourself together and be there, boy."

Tuesday

I turns up at the photographer's studio and the nonce with the camera is in a right ferret.

"Ooh, so nice of Sir to grace us with his presence," he says. "And a mere two hours late for the appointment."

Hasn't the geezer heard of footballer's time?

"Still," he says. "At least I can see our superstar is already made up."

"You what?" I says. "You saying Darren Tackle goes round in make-up?"

"Ooh, so she's telling me it's au naturel , is it?" he says. "Hadn't realised the pasty-faced, pinched-cheek, Angela's Ashes look had caught on in these parts."

"All right, all right," I says, catching a sight of me not altogether tanned features in the mirror. "It's not every footballer what gets to winter in Rio you know."

I offers to pop round to Tanz'n'Ears, the new beauty and piercing salon on River Street for half an hour on the sunbed, but the geezer says it's not necessary.

"No dear, seriously, you're absolutely perfectomondo as you are."

"Yeah, but it's health and that, innit," I says. "I mean, you know, I am prepared to admit I is a bit pale."

"Didn't they explain to you, dearie?" he says. "It's a celebrity before and after shoot we're doing. And you're the before."

Wednesday

H alfway round one of Demo's cross- country training runs, I'm getting this terrible pain in me chest. Nothing for it, but to tell Demo I'll have to pack it in.

"You'd better call for back-up, Deems, ambulance or summat," I pants. "I'm in it deep, innit."

"Bleedinell Dazz," he says as I collapse to me knees. "We've only done 200 yards. Can't you walk back?"

It was that, plus the nonce photographer, plus Rodds complaining about me getting caned at the weekend, what acted as a sort of wake-up call to yours truly.

You know, at the end of the day, football is a hell of a job: good money, outdoor life, plenty of free time, nine-year-old girls know who you are. It's worth doing whatever's necessary to make sure the career lasts. Taking steps to keep the good times rolling is the only professional course.

So I've decided. It is, if you will, Darren Tackle's first new year's resolution for the new millennium. And it's this: never, ever again will I go on one of Demo's runs. Blimey, I've got a career to think of here.

webTitle: Chelsea tune in to Weah's world

fields.headline: Chelsea tune in to Weah's world
fields.standfirst: The Liberian proves an immediate hit with players and supporters
fields.trailText: Earlier this week, when Milan fans heard that George Weah might be leaving, they headed for the training ground to beg him to stay.
fields.body:
Earlier this week, when Milan fans heard that George Weah might be leaving, they headed for the training ground to beg him to stay.

After the big man scored that debut fairytale winner for Chelsea on Wednesday night, the Milan captain Paolo Maldini called him on the phone.

"He said, 'look, we need you back, we miss you'," said Weah. "'What happened here is not our fault but without you in the team it is difficult. Not because you are going to score five goals per game but you are somebody who puts a lot of fun into the team. We are very sad and we hope you come back soon'."

There is little doubt that George Weah is a popular guy. Modest, appreciative, generous, patient; he also works for Unicef plus various charities and subsidises the Liberian national team. And he is not a bad footballer either.

It could be said that Milan rarely let decent players leave and that at 33 Weah is past the peak which brought him the accolade of world footballer of the year in 1995.

But his arrival at Chelsea on loan until the end of the season has certainly re-galvanised the players and their supporters after a disappointing early-season in the Premiership. His sheer presence has lifted spirits but from a purely practical point of view, Weah's late winner against Tottenham was crucial.

It lifted Chelsea to sixth in the table and keeps alive their hopes of finishing in the top three. Without that powerful header past Ian Walker three minutes from time, Chelsea would be contemplating the onerous task of trying to break down Leicester's workhorses on Saturday with a heavier heart.

The giving side of Weah's nature can no doubt be ascribed to his childhood, which saw him brought up by his grandmother. But Weah credits his football upbringing to a more familiar personality, the man he says was like a father to him, Arsène Wenger.

The Arsenal manager took Weah under his wing when, in 1988, he arrived at Monaco young and raw from Africa. And Weah has never forgotten it.

"It was one of the best things for me, meeting Arsène," he says. "It was very difficult for me in the first two months. I was getting a lot of criticism and I was tempted to go back because it was so cold.

"But he gave me confidence. He told me, 'look, you are a good player. Just work hard and you will make it. You are fast and have the technical skills. You just need to work on the tactical'. So he worked with me on the training pitch, he taught me the European mentality and also how to be a professional.

"A lot of African players had come to Europe and did not make a good career because they were hanging out, going to the disco, coming back in the morning. Arsène did not stop me going out but told me what my priorities were.

"Arsène did a lot for me and is responsible for my career today. So I say thanks to Arsène, and I always smile when I say that because he did such a great job for me."

There was speculation that Wenger might be interested in taking Weah on loan to Arsenal. But Milan only offered him Marseille or Chelsea as options after making it clear he was surplus to their requirements.

The snub hurt him after five happy years at the San Siro, but he had suffered worse. "My mother and father had a problem and they abandoned me and my brother when I was one and my brother two."

The young Weahs were handed to grandma Emma who brought them up in a country torn by civil war. When, at the age of 19, George was offered a playing contract in nearby Cameroon he took it for one reason. "My grandmother was doing everything for me, so I decided to give a helping hand to my family because they offered me $30,000 (£18,900) to go to Cameroon.

"I said I'll go and give the money to my grandmother. I signed a three-year contract and in six months had the chance to go to Monaco."

He is reunited with his mother now and they are good friends. He also has a wife and three children, one adopted. Another boy, already named Timothy, is due in March. The family all agreed that as he had played in France for Monaco and Paris Saint-Germain, it would be an experience to try England rather than take up Marseille's offer. And he says he is happy to be here.

Although he would have liked to stay in Italy - and may return in the summer - it is not in his make-up to be the sort of prima donna that would treat Chelsea with a lack of interest or, as Jürgen Klinsmann did at Tottenham, demand a guaranteed first-team place.

"I came to Chelsea to play," he says. "I always want to play. But 90 minutes, 30 minutes, it's not a matter of the time, it's about what you can do for the team. Even if it is for five minutes. I came as an ordinary player like all the others, and I have to work with them and see what we can do."

And after delivering Wednesday's winning goal, fate has another appointment pencilled in for Weah. If Chelsea beat Nottingham Forest in the fourth round of the FA Cup, and Arsenal do likewise to Leicester, the two London giants meet in the fifth round. Yes, Weah versus Wenger.  Chelsea are hoping to sign Georgia's Under-21 captain Rati Aleksidze from Dynamo Tbilisi. Aleksidze was on trial at Stamford Bridge three years ago, and though he is out of contract the Bosman rule does not cover non-EU nationals. Tbilisi may want around £5m for the player, should a work permit be granted.

fields.headline: Top storey awaits the Cottage
fields.trailText: Fulham was the place to go when you didn't have time to get to Tottenham and couldn't find a parking space to see Chelsea - a friendly and eccentric little club with spectacular views of the Thames.
fields.body:
Fulham was the place to go when you didn't have time to get to Tottenham and couldn't find a parking space to see Chelsea - a friendly and eccentric little club with spectacular views of the Thames.

If you were bored by events on the pitch, the sight of rowers paddling along the river was pleasing, if unspectacular.

But Fulham have given us all a wake-up call in recent months and they made Tottenham fans feel a bit sick the other week when they made their team look like a bunch of over-paid under-achievers live on TV. As a result, I found myself willing them to beat Leicester in the Worthington Cup on Wednesday evening.

Slowly but surely Fulham are winning us over. They are no longer the joke team characterised by their former chairman Tommy Trinder but now a football club first and a prime piece of real estate second.

Most of England's football clubs are squeezed into residential areas but few can match Craven Cottage for location: expansive views over the river, terraced houses worth up to £700,000, and within walking distance of Bishop's Park, Fulham Palace, Chelsea and Putney. Football club or not, they are a massive opportunity.

The old stadium, including the quaint cottage itself, very nearly succumbed to demolition men and yuppie apartments in 1987, and the new owner Mohamed Al Fayed is continuing conversations with the local authorities to build a 30,000-seat stadium incorporating flats with a view.

Fortunately, football remains top of the agenda and the swelling crowds at the Cottage are proof that where there's a bulging bank balance there's a way. Two seasons ago the average gate was about 6,000. Now there are 7,000 season-ticket holders.

Fulham have always had a reputation for unpredictability and eccentricity, in the boardroom and the boot-room. The 1999-2000 model remains great fun for supporters but now it's getting serious. When the Harrods owner opened his hamper and produced Kevin Keegan and Ray Wilkins as the new management team, there was talk of jumping two divisions and winning a place in the Premier League.

I n came Paul Peschisolido, Barry Hayles and Geoff Horsfield, and the arrival of Chris Coleman, who dropped two divisions and left Blackburn for £2.1m, proved the true catalyst for a change in how fans viewed the club.

Keegan departed last May, with promotion to the First Division secured, and Paul Bracewell was given the keys to the manager's office on the top floor of Harrods.

Apart from a blip before Christmas, Fulham's recent performances have been remarkable and their efforts against top-flight clubs over the past 12 months have proved that they will soon be ready to strut their stuff on the catwalk.

Last season they beat Southampton twice and Aston Villa, when Villa were top of the pile. This season Tottenham and Wimbledon have been the scalps in the knock-out competitions.

The coaching staff is more Eddie George than Al Fayed. Bracewell, capped three times, is remembered for his loyalty and determination by fans of Everton, Sunderland and Newcastle. Arthur Cox, Frank Sibley and Alan Smith offer long experience of football and management. Viv Busby, a member of the Fulham team that lost the 1975 FA Cup final, and Peter Bonetti, a member of the England team that lost the 1970 World Cup quarter- final, are also on the staff.

They would probably prefer to push for promotion quietly and without too much fuss. Well, there's little chance of that. Everyone, including the property developers, is now watching the football rather than the view.

webTitle: West Indies unveil fiery next generation

fields.headline: West Indies unveil fiery next generation
fields.standfirst:
West Indies U-19s 196 - England U-19s 98
West Indies beat England by 98 runs
fields.trailText: We have seen the future of West Indies cricket - and it is fast and hostile.
fields.body:
We have seen the future of West Indies cricket - and it is fast and hostile.

England Under-19s were beaten by 98 runs here at the Sinhalese Sports Club yesterday. After restricting the West Indians to a relatively modest 196, the English batsmen crumbled to 98 all out in the face of some inspired bowling and fielding.

With West Indies cricket in disarray after their elders' shambolic tour of New Zealand, the youth side's per formance is a welcome ray of hope for Caribbean supporters. On the evidence of their first two matches here at the World Youth Cup, both of which they have won, the battery of fast bowlers that sustained West Indies dominance of the 70s and 80s has not yet run flat.

The pace of Andy Richardson, Carlitos Lopez and Jermaine Lawson was simply too much for England's young batsmen.

Michael Carberry, who was consistently beaten by the steep bounce and movement that Richardson's smooth and rhythmical action generates, was the first to go, caught behind after an involuntary waft outside off stump.

Ian Bell perished soon after, his off stump the victim of an unplayable outswinger. David Harrison then made it 54 for three when he was caught behind off Lawson's first ball.

The flustered middle order threw their wickets away. Tim Phillips, having seen off the quicks, smashed a wide long hop to short fine leg. Three others were run out by direct hits.

England had done well in the field, though. West Indies, who won the toss and surprisingly batted despite overcast conditions, were immediately in trouble when Tim Murtagh had Brenton Parchment caught behind with the day's second ball. A brilliant diving catch by Bell at first slip then left West Indies perilously placed at 12 for two.

England then dropped three catches while the West Indies captain Ryan Hinds made a fine 69 but the last five wickets fell for 13 runs. England have to beat Zimbabwe tomorrow if they are to make the last eight.

webTitle: Donald's killing fields await edgy England

fields.headline: Donald's killing fields await edgy England
fields.standfirst: Pace bowler on a mission as South Africa seek 3-0 win in Test series
fields.trailText: So, when Allan Donald walks on to the field at Centurion for the final Test starting today, will it be the last hurrah for a great fast bowler? Time catches up with them all and Donald is no exception.
fields.body:
So, when Allan Donald walks on to the field at Centurion for the final Test starting today, will it be the last hurrah for a great fast bowler? Time catches up with them all and Donald is no exception.

He is 33 now and his body is creaking. The left ankle that has absorbed the impact of 13,216 Test-match deliveries gives him gip and every hamstring twinge feels like another piece is falling off.

Stung, one can bet, by the notion that Shaun Pollock is ranked the world's leading bowler, he has conjured 22 wickets this series, where his partner, with 16, has been unable. If his new-ball work has been lacklustre at times then some of his later spells have been inspirational. Maybe he has not been at his absolute best but second best for Donald is better than most.

Donald is South African cricket. He has played in 60 of the 67 matches since his country's return to Test cricket at Bridgetown in April 1992 when he was already 25. In that time he has taken 290 wickets and the lure of claiming the 10 that will take him to the magic 300 mark in Tests, even if it does not influence his retirement decision, is tantalising.

It may, after the next few days, no longer be an issue, for Centurion in its four-year history as a Test ground has become Donald's killing fields: he took two for 92 in the only innings of the rain-spoilt inaugural Test against England there but since then a further 22 in three matches at 12.73 (24 at 15.5 overall), including three five-wicket hauls. Pollock's record there by comparison is six wickets at 32 apiece in three matches. Ten in the match for Donald is a distinct possibility, not least because his second-innings record at Centurion - 11 at 8.9 with two of them five-wicket hauls - is phenomenal. There will be no respite for England later in the game.

To assist him Donald will have what Nasser Hussain described yesterday as "a pitch with a good covering of white grass. The new ball will bounce and it may get slower and lower later. There will be a bit more for the opening bowler than in the three previous matches. Unless I've read it wrong it will be more of a South African pitch. There'll be more bounce with the new ball and we have to show some character and fight. That applies to the bowlers as well as the batsmen."

It will put Hussain in a quandary when he comes to select his final XI this morning. In the absence of Andy Flintoff his options are several: play seven batsmen and four bowlers or six batsmen plus the all-rounder Gavin Hamilton; and then choose between a four-man pace attack, with Alan Mullally replacing Phil Tufnell, and the three pacemen from Cape Town - Darren Gough, Andy Caddick and Chris Silverwood - with Tufnell's slow left-arm.

Hussain has to decide where his main wicket-taking poten- tial comes from and from whom he will gain most control. Yesterday, in the damp - and surprisingly chilly - atmosphere, the option of seven batsmen and four seamers was looking favourite.

Whichever England side takes the field, though, each player will be under scrutiny. "This is a big match," said Hussain. "In Port Elizabeth and Durban I was proud of the team and we were aware of the pride that people had in us. In Cape Town, though, we stuffed up.

"I would hate to come to Centurion and end up losing the series 3-0. But what concerns me more is the manner in which we play. After five days here I want people to say once more that they were proud of the way we played."

Some, though - Mark Butcher, Chris Adams and, even though he has scarcely had a fair crack, Darren Maddy - should they make the side are going to have to play above themselves if their careers are going to be extended into next summer.

Hussain is focused on where the team is heading. "The point of the tour was to win matches, of course it was," he says, "but it was to find out about people too. And after a tour and five Tests we have found out a bit more than we knew before we came away. This goes for everyone. Next summer, however, we will be taking things further on. We know as much as we need to about the squad of players out here."

South Africa, strictly on the strength of their pace bowling, will go into the match as favourites, knowing that since the England washout four years ago, they have won all the three subsequent matches at Centurion - against Australia, Sri Lanka and West Indies - by a distance and inside four days.

They will be playing without Jonty Rhodes, injured this time rather than dropped, and will therefore be giving a first cap to the Border captain Pieter Strydom, at the age of 30. The rest of the side will be unchanged.

webTitle: Cronje low on runs but ending on a captaincy high

fields.headline: Cronje low on runs but ending on a captaincy high
fields.trailText: South Africa's captain Hansie Cronje had declared that he did not know whether to laugh or cry as a result of his team's series win over England.
fields.body:
South Africa's captain Hansie Cronje had declared that he did not know whether to laugh or cry as a result of his team's series win over England.

After a week's reflection Cronje must have laughed all the way to Centurion Park, both from a team perspective and his own point of view. The doubts still linger over his batting form - he has had a poor series with no signs that it is getting any better - but any worries over his place and his captaincy have been emphatically silenced.

There has been a wave of support from his players and some distinguished old boys such as the former Test wicketkeeper Dave Richardson, and the loyalty and honesty of their backing has emphasised the regard in which Cronje is held by those who have played for him.

On his own admission Cronje was unhappy with his batting in the World Cup last summer, and he vowed to make this home summer series a big one for himself.

It has not happened but successive series wins over Zimbabwe and England have highlighted his view that most players need to be judged on more than one aspect of their games.

Even before this series Cronje said somewhat prophetically: "If you are not winning you can understand that there will be pressure. If you're judging a person on only one discipline it can be a little unfair.

"We play a game where most of us are all-rounders and you've got to be judged on your bowling, your fielding and your batting, and in my case captaincy."

Wise words, and as long as South Africa keep winning then Cronje will be held in high esteem regardless of his failings with the bat.

Cronje has much cause to be optimistic that his form will return over the next couple of months. He is South Africa's best player of spin and has a fine record against all of its top exponents, Shane Warne included. He has also excelled against India, which is where his team are heading next.

He averages over 50 against them in Tests, and will be relishing thoughts of taking on Anil Kumble and company on the dusty tracks of the sub-continent. It should be just what he needs to regain confidence.

Prior to this series it looked increasingly likely that it would be his last in charge. He had an offer to coach Glamorgan, which would have made him unavailable for the tour of Sri Lanka in July, and he was only appointed for the first two Tests against England.

There was also his reported disgruntlement about the board's policy of selection rota tion for some one-day tournaments in an attempt to broaden the spectrum of players available for internationals, a policy which hampered chances of short-term success but which was admirably designed with long-term interest in mind.

In September Cronje again emphasised his worth by captaining a below-strength squad to victory in a four-nation tournament in Kenya. South Africa did not play their full-strength squad until the final as part of that rotation policy and Cronje played a key role in it when facing India, coming in at 18 for three and immediately dominating the spinners.

Perhaps that win provided him with a clear indication of the direction that the remainder of his career should take. He turned down the Glamorgan offer and the board subsequently made him captain for all five Tests against England.

"I've always said that whatever's best for South African cricket is the way I will go," he responded. "If I'm part of South African cricket and part of the set-up, if they want me there, I'll do it with pleasure."

With this series in the bag Cronje now needs runs for his own peace of mind. If he does not make them here he will just aim to make India pay - again.

webTitle: Counties to lose Murali and Shoaib

fields.headline: Counties to lose Murali and Shoaib
fields.trailText: Lancashire are resigned to losing their spin wizard Muttiah Muralitharan because of his international commitments with Sri Lanka.
fields.body:
Lancashire are resigned to losing their spin wizard Muttiah Muralitharan because of his international commitments with Sri Lanka.

Pakistan are planning a tour of Sri Lanka in June and if it goes ahead, Lancashire will have to tear up Muralitharan's contract and search for a new overseas star. The same tour could also mean that Nottinghamshire will drop the Pakistan fast bowler Shoaib Akhtar as their overseas player.

Coincidentally both players have been at the centre of controversies over their bowling action.

Murali is contracted to Old Trafford for the next two years after his sensational introduction to county cricket last season when he earned 65 wickets in six championship games. But the deal stipulated that he would have to be available for at least 10 championship matches - and the Pakistan tour, coupled with South Africa's visit to Sri Lanka, would make that impossible.

"We are waiting for word from Pakistan," said Lancashire's cricket secretary Dave Edmundson. Lancashire expect to make a decision over the weekend. A possible alternative to the 27-year-old Sri Lankan is the Australian leg-spinner Stuart MacGill.

Nottinghamshire have approached their former overseas player, the New Zealand all-rounder Chris Cairns, as a potential replacement for Shoaib.

"We are very concerned that Pakistan have now arranged three tours during the English summer - in addition to the one we already knew about - and we are awaiting confirmation from the cricket board about how this will affect Shoaib's availability," said Mick Newell, Nottinghamshire's assistant cricket manager.

If all Pakistan's potential tours are finalised, Shoaib would be available for as few as five championship and six National League matches, which clearly would be unsustainable.

Pakistan's three-Test series in the West Indies, which finishes in late May, is a long-standing arrangement. But that will now be immediately followed by the Asia Cup in Dhaka until June 5, and the potential tour to Sri Lanka until the end of July. The Sahara Cup, in Toronto, would also rob Nottinghamshire of Shoaib for the last week of the season.

"If Shoaib is available under the conditions that we signed him, he remains our first choice, but we are obviously concerned. We have spoken to Chris Cairns but this is purely plan B, so that we are not left without an overseas player."

Newell insisted that the dispute over Shoaib's bowling action, which the International Cricket Council's illegal deliveries panel will again scrutinise next month, had no bearing on the contract issue.

webTitle: Final to tell tale of two cities

fields.headline: Final to tell tale of two cities
fields.trailText: They are so near, yet so far. Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo are only 300 miles apart, share a language, a history, a government and a culture - yet they are two separate worlds.
fields.byline: Alex Bellos in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
They are so near, yet so far. Rio de Janeiro and Sao Paulo are only 300 miles apart, share a language, a history, a government and a culture - yet they are two separate worlds.

When the Rio football club Vasco da Gama play Corinthians of Sao Paulo tonight in the final of the World Club Championship, it will put on a global stage the rivalry between Brazil's great urban centres.

The antagonism between the cities, however, goes way beyond the today's sporting duel. It has been one of the dominant themes of the economic and political development of the country.

Cariocas, as the 10m natives of Rio are called, consider themselves almost a different race from Sao Paulo's 17m paulistas.

"We are different in absolutely everything. In his heart of hearts, the carioca hates everything about the paulista - not just the person, but the accent, the way they dress, everything," says Tutty Vasques, a newspaper columnist in Rio. "We are completely incompatible."

Sao Paulo is where the money is. It is a fast-paced, concrete, modern city that feels on a par with Europe and the US. Paulistas have a work ethic that is the legacy of the poor Italian and Japanese agricultural immigrants.

Whereas Rio, hotter and more humid, is slower and more informal. It is blessed by stunning scenery - beaches, mountains, a lagoon and primary rainforest that creeps into people's back yards.

However, in the late 90s, bonded by financial crises, paulistas and cariocas perhaps emphasised their similarities more than their differences. But the language of both cities remained entrenched in obvious antipathy.

In Rio, when two men are in the front of a car and two women in the back, it is called a "paulista" - a reference to the alleged fact that paulistas are useless at seduction. The carioca option would have the men next to the women.

It is this historic dislike that organisers of tonight's tilt at the famed Maracana know will result in capacity ticket sales.

webTitle: TV rivals jostle for soccer club stakes

fields.headline: TV rivals jostle for soccer club stakes
fields.trailText: Arsenal and Aston Villa are in talks to sell shares to TV companies in return for large cash injections.
fields.body:
Arsenal and Aston Villa are in talks to sell shares to TV companies in return for large cash injections.

At least three television companies - cable firms Telewest and NTL together with ITV broadcaster United News & Media - are courting the London club, while its Midlands rival has just granted NTL a period of exclusivity in order to thrash out the details of a deal. NTL, the UK's biggest cable TV company, already owns 9.8% of Newcastle United.

Both clubs are considering selling 10% stakes in return for their media rights, and they are likely to command prices at up to double their market value. Arsenal, for instance, whose shares are traded on Ofex, is valued at some £160m but it is likely to demand up to £30m for a new 10% shareholding. The same size stake in Aston Villa, which has a full stock market listing, is worth only £5m but a source close to the club said: "They would want a substantial premium to deliver value to shareholders."

If the deals go ahead, eight top clubs will have agreements with media companies.

Arsenal has jealously guarded its independence but does not want to miss out on the windfall payments and shop window for their brand that the media groups offer.

Since BSkyB launched its £623m full takeover bid for Manchester United - which was blocked by the government - Arsenal has been courted by BSkyB's rivals. At one point it was in talks that would have handed control to Carlton Television, but Carlton ultimately balked at the £300m price Arsenal directors were demanding.

But United News & Media, which has also been linked with Arsenal and is in the process of merging with Carlton, is still in talks. A source close to UN&M's chief executive, Lord Hollick - a long-standing Arsenal fan - said: "They are still involved. They have been talking to Arsenal for some time and that might or might not include owning a stake in the club."

Telewest, which is in the middle of a merger with programme provider Flextech and is believed to be talking to Arsenal, has no current football affiliations. But a spokesman said: "If there were opportunities to explore in a football club then we would do so, eagerly."

No Arsenal directors were available for comment last night, but Aston Villa confirmed its negotiations with NTL, which is also in the throes of a merger, with rival cable operator Cable & Wireless Communications.

Shares in Villa, which were floated at £11 in 1998, rose 25p to 450p.

webTitle: Blatter: United gave no boost to World Cup bid

fields.headline: Blatter: United gave no boost to World Cup bid
fields.trailText: After all the pressure exerted on Manchester United to help England's 2006 World Cup bid, the team left Brazil last night with leading figures divided over whether they have strengthened the Football Association's hand.
fields.byline: Jon Brodkin in Rio de Janeiro
fields.body:
After all the pressure exerted on Manchester United to help England's 2006 World Cup bid, the team left Brazil last night with leading figures divided over whether they have strengthened the Football Association's hand.

The bad news was that Fifa's president Sepp Blatter insisted their World Club Championship participation had changed nothing. "This competition has no influence on the decision for the 2006 World Cup," he said, "nor has the performance of any of the teams representing countries which are on the bidding list."

"All competitions which have been organised so far, and which will be organised in the future, have no impact and no influence on the decision."

Bobby Charlton, a United director and part of England's bid team, begged to differ. "The mere fact that Manchester United were here created so many headlines and has done so much good that only a fool would say they have not contributed to the success of this tournament and the success of our bid," he said.

"If Manchester United had refused an offer to come to a Fifa-organised function when it was the first opportunity to take part then I think it would have been an insult to Fifa which we probably would have had to live with for a while."

Charlton believes United's FA Cup sacrifice has been noted. England's campaign director, Alec McGivan, said that making way for Bayern Munich would have been damaging: "The German bid team are here but without a football side, and for us it's been a huge difference to have Manchester United as a participant. The German bid people are just sort of tagging along behind."

England's campaigners claimed another boost when Blatter publicly distanced himself from South Africa.

"I have said the World Cup should go in rotation around the continents," he explained. "I have identified one continent but I have never identified one candidate."

Morocco are also bidding for the 2006 tournament.

Nevertheless, the Fifa president's comments fall well short of a rejection of South Africa's candidacy. He will preside over the decision-making committee on July 5-6.

Security fears are the biggest threat to South Africa's hopes. Charlton insisted Fifa needed no reminding of the problems and McGivan said it was "very aware of it as an issue". Fifa's inspection team will visit South Africa from March 7-12. "Security is a very important matter," Blatter said.

The tournament ends tonight with an all-Brazilian final between Vasco da Gama and Corinthians. Vasco's striker Romario needs one goal to reach the 700 mark. The competition's future will be clarified by Fifa at the end of March.

webTitle: Sunderland recovery will be bad news for bookies

fields.headline: Sunderland recovery will be bad news for bookies
fields.standfirst: Sam Delaney, our stand-in in the stands, backs Phillips to make an impact and doesn't buy any of this Weah hoop-la
fields.trailText: Sunderland's sorry form over the past month came as no surprise to many. It's rare that such a meagre squad has anything more than fleeting pretensions to the Premiership throne and, by New Year, it looked as though the time for Peter Reid's team was up. Little wonder, then, that both Corals and William Hill are offering 9-2 on them winning at Arsenal this Saturday.
fields.body:
Sunderland's sorry form over the past month came as no surprise to many. It's rare that such a meagre squad has anything more than fleeting pretensions to the Premiership throne and, by New Year, it looked as though the time for Peter Reid's team was up. Little wonder, then, that both Corals and William Hill are offering 9-2 on them winning at Arsenal this Saturday.

However the bookies may regret overlooking one crucial factor: the return of Kevin Phillips. The Mackems' poor form coincided almost exactly with the loss of their top-scorer through injury - with him back in the side they are more formidable opponents. Add to this the fact that he will be partnered by the fit-again, former Gunner Niall Quinn (and that Arsenal are missing Adams, Upson, Overmars, Bergamp and Kanu) and not sticking a tenner on Sunderland would seem absurd.

Leicester City, still euphoric from their dramatic Worthington Cup Victory over Fulham, may well catch swaggering Chelsea on the hop at Stamford Bridge. The arrival of George Weah has buoyed a club suffering from much self-doubt over recent weeks - and the bookies are so impressed that both Corals and William Hill are offering just 14-1 on him scoring a hat trick on Saturday. By all accounts, though, they snatched a win on Wednesday night in a game dominated by Spurs and, despite his goal in the same game, Weah is a 33-year-old cast off in drastic decline. Expect him to be upstaged by the returning Tony Cottee - Ladbrokes offer 9-2 on the Leicester win.

For a hat trick of away win successes, back resurgent Derby County to defeat the terminally average Middlesborough. The home side have lost their most important player- Christian Ziege - and gained their least important - Paul Gascoigne - in the run up to this match and Derby are undefeated in their last two games away from home. William Hill offer 100-30 on the Rams to win.

A better than average bet on first scorer this weekend is Ian Taylor of Aston Villa. He dominated the midfield against West Ham on Tuesday and, when the same fixture takes place on Saturday, may well continue the scoring form that saw him put two past Shaka Hislop. Corals offer 12-1.

webTitle: England's main fault? They tried too hard

fields.headline: England's main fault? They tried too hard
fields.trailText: It was all so promising. Hussain won the toss on an overcast, damp afternoon against a weakened South Africa who were without Rhodes (hamstring) and Donald (gout), with a novice batsman (Strydom) and led by a walking wicket. But England's four seamers - perhaps overexcited by these resounding odds - tried just that little bit too hard. South Africa, despite losing wickets at regular intervals had raced to 155, off 45 overs, by the close.
fields.body:
It was all so promising. Hussain won the toss on an overcast, damp afternoon against a weakened South Africa who were without Rhodes (hamstring) and Donald (gout), with a novice batsman (Strydom) and led by a walking wicket. But England's four seamers - perhaps overexcited by these resounding odds - tried just that little bit too hard. South Africa, despite losing wickets at regular intervals had raced to 155, off 45 overs, by the close.

Throughout this Test series, at least one bowler per Test has done what the selectors feared Tudor would do, ie misfire horribly. Today Chris Silverwood was the chief offender, trying to bounce out Lance Klusener, and bowling too wide and too short. His 7 overs went for 45. Meanwhile, Alan Mullally had the most flattering set of figures since WG Grace claimed to be a size 8. Poor Tudes - how much worse could he possibly have been? At least Gough looked more happy with himself, though he is still no-balling too often for comfort (another fault the selectors hold against Tudor).

To compound matters, England were not at their most coltish in the field. Maddy, who was chosen for this Test ahead of Ramprakash, Hick and Solanki, had a particularly miserable day - dropping Cullinan on 34 (at square leg, where he also dropped him when fielding as a substitute at Cape Town) and fluffing the run-out of Strydom before he'd scored. It is slightly unfortunate that Ramps, Hick and Solanki all have hands like slops buckets.

In theory England are in a good position. But South Africa, as England will be sick to the back teeth of being told, could turn their batting order upside down and be almost as proficient. At 155 for 6, their position is ominously similar to the second Test at Port Elizabeth, when they were 146 for 5 - whereupon Klusener clubbed his way to 174 and the total ballooned to 450. Tonight, he is 22 not out., and his eye, though never knowingly not in, is looking sharper than ever - he has already pulled Silverwood for an obscenely large six.

Play starts early tomorrow - 7.55am GMT. It's vital that Gough and Caddick catch the worm.

webTitle: Schreiber: The man who would topple kings

fields.headline: Schreiber: The man who would topple kings
fields.standfirst: A German businessman's revelations have prompted a string of investigations, and he may have only exposed the tip of the iceberg
fields.trailText: Multinational businessman Karlheinz Schreiber, whose donation disclosures are at the root of the scandal rocking German politics, is one of the most intriguing figures to have been thrust into the floodlit glare of the international stage.
fields.body:
Multinational businessman Karlheinz Schreiber, whose donation disclosures are at the root of the scandal rocking German politics, is one of the most intriguing figures to have been thrust into the floodlit glare of the international stage.

His revelations have set off a string of investigations - by prosecutors, politicians, police and journalists - which have entangled Germany's pre-eminent statesman, Helmut Kohl, and Mr Kohl's successor as the leader of the Christian Democrats (CDU), Wolfgang Schäuble.

But Mr Schreiber is also a central figure in another probe involving sums of money vastly greater than any shown to have been given to Germany's conservatives.

When he was arrested in Toronto last August, the Mounties found Mr Schreiber, who holds dual German and Canadian nationality, was carrying a bag containing the equivalent of £12,500 in nine currencies.

Dubbed the "King of Schmooze" by the Canadian press, the silver-haired Mr Schreiber has forged an astonishing network of powerful connections on both sides of the Atlantic; his bail was arranged with the help of two former Canadian cabinet ministers - one from each of the main parties.

Though often described as an arms dealer, Mr Schreiber is in no sense a professional in the business of weapons trading. Born in Bavaria in 1934, he grew to maturity in the tough, bleak environment of devastated, post-war Germany. He left school at 16 and went to work in a department store, but was soon trading on his own account, importing carpets from what was then Persia.

At a press conference earlier this week, Mr Schäuble provoked chortles when he said that he had been introduced to Mr Schreiber as someone whose firm put the lines on autobahns - yet it was true. In the late 1950s or early 1960s, Mr Schreiber took a stake in a company near Munich that specialised in paving and road marking.

He later acquired control. Firms such as these depend almost entirely on public-sector contracts. So, from an early stage in his business career, Mr Schreiber coveted political contacts and goodwill.

In the mid-70s, he went international. Opec had just sent oil prices soaring and Mr Schreiber expanded into the booming, petroleum-rich Canadian province of Alberta. It was not long before he had moved on from roads to real estate. He founded several property investment companies and persuaded a number of leading figures in Alberta's ruling Progressive Conservative party to sit on his companies' boards.

His influence later grew to the extent that, as a friend of the late Franz Josef Strauss, then head of the Bavarian government and chairman of Airbus Industrie, Mr Schreiber helped to broker a $1.5bn sale of 34 Airbus jets to Air Canada in 1988.

It was not just the biggest aircraft order in Canada's history, but it also the cause of one of the country's most explosive political controversies.

In 1995, with the RCMP digging into the circumstances surrounding the deal, a government lawyer wrote to the Swiss authorities asking them for help. The letter alleged that Mr Schreiber had used a Zurich bank account to pay the former prime minister, Brian Mulroney, a C$5m (£2.1m) kickback.

Mr Mulroney sued and two years later won an apology and a settlement of C$2m. The government also apologised to Mr Schreiber, but did not offer him any compensation.

When the RCMP arrested Mr Schreiber in August, it was for a different, though related, reason. The security force was acting on an arrest warrant issued by prosecutors in Bavaria, who accused Mr Schreiber of failing to pay tax of DM25m (£8m) on commission it said he received from deals he brokered in the late 80s and early 90s. One was for the sale of German armoured vehicles to Saudi Arabia.

Mr Schreiber's disclosure that he handed more than DM1m in cash to the CDU in the same year was the match that lit the fuse under Germany's Christian Democrats.

Though the personalities and circumstances of the two men are quite different, Mr Schreiber's role in German politics is starting to resemble that which Licio Gelli, head of the powerful P2 Masonic lodge, once played in Italian affairs.

Unlike Gelli, Mr Schreiber has never been convicted of any offence. But, as with Gelli, there is a pattern of affinity with the political right.

Mr Schreiber, moreover, has shown that, like Italy's "puppet master", he is the keeper of many explosive secrets. And, as he battles to avoid extradition from Canada to his native Germany, he has let some of those secrets filter out to devastating effect.

What remains to be seen is how much more he can - and indeed wants to - reveal.

Last November, he said: "I promise it will become very nasty."

So far, he has been as good as his word.

What remains to be seen is how much more he can - and indeed wants to - reveal. Last November, he said: "I promise it will become very nasty." So far, he has been as good as his word.

fields.headline: Joe Ashton's letter of resignation
fields.standfirst:
Joe Ashton MP's letter of resignation to Alan Sykes, secretary, Sheffield Wednesday.
Ashton resigns from Wednesday board
fields.trailText: Dear Alan,
fields.body:
Dear Alan,

Further to our telephone conversation this morning I am formally, by fax, submitting to you my resignation as a vice-president of Sheffield Wednesday.

Having been a season ticket holder for 40 years and a shareholder for 25 years, it is something I do with great regret, especially following the newspaper revelations of a private meeting four Sheffield area MPs had at the Charterhouse Bank in the City of London yesterday.

However, as you know following the heated exchanges I had with the chairman at Stamford Bridge and Villa Park and other games recently, I can no longer support the board in its current policies either financial or football. Following the 8-0 defeat at Newcastle I told several members of the board that drastic action was necessary to stay in the Premier League and I have continued to say so ever since. Unfortunately no sign of any action was forthcoming.

Consequently, it is better if I return to the terraces where I came from and where I can express my opinions in an open way in a genuine debate on the future of Sheffield Wednesday.

I hope you will communicate this letter to the board of directors.

Yours sincerely,
Joe Ashton MP.

fields.headline: Ashton resigns from Wednesday board
fields.standfirst: Joe Ashton's letter of resignation
fields.trailText: Joe Ashton has tonight resigned from his position as vice-president of Sheffield Wednesday. The MP for Bassetlaw had, along with three other local MPs, has been in dispute with the board and earlier today called for the resignation of manager Danny Wilson. He claims he will now "return to the terraces".
fields.byline: By Football Unlimited staff and agencies
fields.body:
Joe Ashton has tonight resigned from his position as vice-president of Sheffield Wednesday. The MP for Bassetlaw had, along with three other local MPs, has been in dispute with the board and earlier today called for the resignation of manager Danny Wilson. He claims he will now "return to the terraces".

In a statement Ashton said: "I have formerly submitted by fax my resignation as a vice-president of Sheffield Wednesday. Having been a season ticket holder for 40 years, a shareholder for 25 years and a director for nine years, it is something I do with great regret.

"However, following the heated exchanges I have had with the chairman at Stamford Bridge and Villa Park and at other games recently, I can no longer support the board on its current policies, either financial or football."

Ashton, along with Education and Employment secretary David Blunkett, Bill Michie and Clive Betts, met yesterday with investment company Charterhouse, who hold a 36% stake in Wednesday, when concerns were voiced over the club's plight.

The MPs spoke with Charterhouse executive and Wednesday director Geoff Arbuthnott over the company's future role. Charterhouse have no say in the day-to-day running of the club however, and it now appears as if they are also looking to instigate changes. The quartet have made it clear they blame Wilson for the Owls' demise and now want him out. Their feelings towards the Wednesday manager were made clear by Ashton's fellow MP Betts ahead of tomorrow's relegation clash with Bradford at Hillsborough.

Betts said: "Any other Premiership club would have sacked the manager by now. He has had some money but he hasn't spent it well.

"I don't think anybody who watches Wednesday believes that the potential of the players has been realised.

"(Chairman) Dave Richards' perseverance with Danny is a wrong decision. When you are looking pretty certain to be relegated you look at all your options to change things. I don't dislike Danny Wilson. I was in favour of his appointment. But you judge people on results.

Richards himself has remained quiet, but speaking on behalf of the board of directors, secretary Alan Sykes said: "I am staggered and saddened to learn of the MPs' brutal attack on Danny Wilson and their call for him to be sacked.

"In the very week that the manager urged for solidarity among supporters and players, I find it difficult to believe that they have made such a personal attack just 24 hours before probably our most important game to date. These comments do nothing to help our cause."

fields.headline: Stravinsky: The Rake's Progress
fields.trailText: In our series on building a classical library, Andrew Clements selects the definitive recording of Stravinsky's The Rake's Progress
fields.body:
None of Stravinsky's earlier 'operatic' works , Le Rossignol, Renard, Mavra, Oedipus Rex, Persephone,can be unconditionally classifed as a fully fledged opera all of them in one way or another stretch the boundaries of the genre or compress its components to suit a specific dramatic purpose. But there is no ambiguity about The Rake's Progress, composed in the years after the second world war, and first performed in Venice in 1951 , a work in three full acts, with a libretto by WH Auden and ChesterKallman, based on Hogarth's series of engravings of the same name.

In the curve of Stravinsky's development, The Rake's Progress is a crucial work, effectively signalling the end of his neoclassical period. It doesn't feel like a transitional work, but it is the effortless appropriation of the stylisation of 18th-century opera, complete with a reliance upon set-piece arias and recitatives, and the use of a classically proportioned orchestra, gives no hint of the plunge into serialism that Stravinsky would make in the following years. The text (one of the first that Stravinsky set in English) is sometimes awkwardly literary, but familiarity smoothes out the occasional rough edges, and even behind the masks of time-travelling, real emotion emerges, a work that can seem like an elaborate conceit packs a real punch.

As with so much of Stravinsky's output, the composer's own interpretation serves as the starting point for any evaluation of subsequent accounts, and in this case there are two studio versions that he conducted, the second of which, made in London in 1964, with Alexander Young as Tom Rakewell (Sony Classical), stands up the better now. But the casting is still uneven and though there is much about the performance that is genuinely revelatory, vocally and sonically the best of its successors are more recommendable.

The versions by the composer's longtime assistant Robert Craft (Music Masters) and Seiji Ozawa (Philips) don't really make the grade, and a first choice rests between those conducted by Riccardo Chailly (Decca), Kent Nagano (Erato) and John Eliot Gardiner (Deutsche Grammophon). All have a quicksilver precision about the orchestral playing, but Chailly's is let down by Cathryn Pope's pallid Anne Truelove, and Gardiner's is spoilt, amazingly enough, by Bryn Terfel's Nick Shadow, which is blustering and declamatory where it should be insidiously persuasive, to that extent that not even Ian Bostridge's rapturous Tom Rakewell can compensate. That leaves Nagano's from the Lyons Opera in 1995, which, with Dawn Upshaw and Jerry Hadley in the leads and a beautifully judged Nick Shadow from Samuel Ramey, has a perfectly balanced line-up. Upshaw is more vulnerable and touching than any other Anne, and Hadley has done nothing better on disc.

Key Recording: Nagano, Erato 0630-12715-2 (two CDs)

fields.headline: The best waterfront scene
fields.standfirst: Summer of Sam
fields.trailText: The Bronx, 1977. Beside the East River, the guys from the neighbourhood round on their unfortunate junkie acquaintance Woodstock (Saverio Guerra) after he attempts to sell them "broken" lobsters stolen from the bay. As they send a barrage of abuse and the occasional kick in his direction, Ritchie (Adrien Brody) appears in their midst sporting spiked hair, a Union Jack T-shirt and a padlock around his neck. His accent is a wildly unsuccessful attempt at Cockney. "Oi, you ain't Bruce Lee," he exclaims, "so stop kicking Woodstock."
fields.body:
The Bronx, 1977. Beside the East River, the guys from the neighbourhood round on their unfortunate junkie acquaintance Woodstock (Saverio Guerra) after he attempts to sell them "broken" lobsters stolen from the bay. As they send a barrage of abuse and the occasional kick in his direction, Ritchie (Adrien Brody) appears in their midst sporting spiked hair, a Union Jack T-shirt and a padlock around his neck. His accent is a wildly unsuccessful attempt at Cockney. "Oi, you ain't Bruce Lee," he exclaims, "so stop kicking Woodstock."

The guys stare at him, incredulous.

"Holy shit, is that Ritchie?"

"What the hell happened to you, you freak?"

"Noice outfit. Where'd you get it, off the dead?"

Ritchie smiles beatifically.

"What's 'appening guys?"

Joey T (Michael Rispoli) the group's ringleader, stands eye-to-eye with his one-time old friend.

"Don't give me that 'what's happening guys' bullshit. You come back to the neighbourhood, looking like a fucking freak, sounding like a British fag, and we're supposed to be OK with that?"

Ritchie pauses for a second.

"You're feckin' right. So, how's the wife and kids, JT?"

"I got divorced. Moved back in with my mother."

A timorous Woodstock approaches, still clutching his bag of sub-standard lobsters.

"A dollar each?"

Mayhem breaks out once again.

See also: River's Edge, The City Of Lost Children, The Usual Suspects

Don't see also: On The Waterfront

Pointless trivia: "Making films", Spike Lee once remarked, "has to be one of the hardest endeavours known to humankind. Straight up and down, film work is hard shit."

fields.headline: Incompetence, Insult and Injury
fields.trailText: KNOCK THE VOTE
fields.body:
KNOCK THE VOTE

Who said democracy was dead? Well the Fiver actually, when it was trying to recruit members for its fledgling organisation - Footballing Emails for Autocracy. But it's all been made to look like the rubbish it is by the decisive action of four Sheffield MPs, who have used their electoral mandate to call for the sacking of Sheffield Wednesday boss Danny Wilson.

Instead of tackling issues such as unemployment or the gradual diminishment of the local cutlery industry (where have all the knives gone?), Joe Ashton, Bill Michie, Clive Betts and Education and Employment secretary David Blunkett were instead in talks today with investment group Charterhouse. Charterhouse own 36% of Wednesday, and were the MPs' first stop when they wanted to know how Wilson threw away three points at Upton Park last November.

Mr Betts, the honourable member for Attercliffe, immediately went on the record regarding Wilson, whom he appears to consider an honourable member. "Any other Premiership club would have sacked the manager by now," said Betts. "He has had some money but he hasn't spent it well. I don't dislike Danny Wilson. I was in favour of his appointment. But you judge people on results."

Surprisingly enough, Wednesday chairman Dave Richards doesn't agree. Richards, who has backed Wilson to the hilt this season said: "I am staggered and saddened to learn of the MPs' brutal attack on Danny. These comments do nothing to help our cause." Indeed, but the argument is unlikely to stop here. In fact you can soon expect questions to be tabled in parliament, and maybe even a penny put on income tax - for the express purpose of buying out Andy Booth's contract.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

OPERATION!

Things are looking up for miserable, depressed, lonely Nic Anelka. He's been admitted to hospital.

The sad lad caught knee-knack during Real's recent 3-2 win over Real Casablanca, and an operation soon followed. Thanks to Spanish newspaper Marca, you can watch all of "La operación de Anelka" simply by going here!

Next week: The Fiver presents a Quicktime movie of man-on-man muscle massage in the Barcelona dressing room.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

IT'S OH SO QUIET

After a long flight, Manchester United returned from Brazil today looking tired and drawn. You would too if you'd worked as hard as they did against South Melbourne. But despite having flown the flag for English football, United's reception was slightly on the underwhelming side.

As the Red Devils marched through the foyer at Manchester Airport, they found themselves greeted by a rapturous crowd of under 50 people. In fact, a representative of the Chris Evans Untempered Admiration Society said they'd had more people at their last meeting, which was held in a shoe box.

So no matter how often David Beckham waved an invitation, from none other than Money Martin Edwards esq, to sit down this summer for a quick spot of contract negotiation, nobody paid the slightest bit of attention. Even though talks are to start at £60,000-a-week. According to reports.

And did anyone rush up to congratulate United skipper, heartbeat, engine room and pulley system Roy Keane at being awarded the Carling Player of the Month Award for his blockbusting performances during December? Did they heck. Mainly because they were scared they might be bitten. But all the same, it's a terrible show. They can't win all the time, you know.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

QUOTE OF THE DAY

"I will make sure that, when talking to the national press, I will do so straight-faced and be as bland as possible.'' -Poor old victimised Martin O'Neill, who told the press after Leicester's midweek Worthington Cup victory that, "I have known people get over Aids more quickly than Ian Marshall got over his hamstring trouble." Apparently, he won't be doing it again.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

PREVIEWS-U-LIKE

Arsenal v Sunderland
He Is Emmanuel Petit has flu, Tony Adams, Dennis Bergkamp and Marc Overmars are injured, and Kanu is playing for Nigeria in the African Nations Cup. So much talent unavailable... but don't cry, little Arsene, because here comes Ray Parlour. Hey, we said don't cry! Peter Reid may well gloat, as Sunderland will be at full strength - Niall Quinn, Kevin Phillips, Steve Bould, Michael Gray and Kevin Kilbane are all back in the squad.

Chelsea v Leicester City
Gianfranco Zola, dropped for the first time in his Chelsea career on Wednesday, has been whining like a stuck pig. "There is no way I can be happy if I am not playing. After everything I have done for Chelsea I don't think I deserve this treatment," he whelped. Whether it's done him any good in his battle with George Weah, Chris Sutton and Tore Andre Flo for a starting place we don't know. Not sure why we mentioned it really. And we don't know much about the Leicester team, but we know what we like. No, hold on... we know Neil Lennon won't be in it.

Coventry City v Wimbledon
Mustapha Hadji and Youssef Chippo are away giving it some for Morocco in the African Nations Cup, so it's a chance for Tomas Gustafsson and goal-scorin' window-breakin' Leeds-lovin' Noel Whelan. Otherwise it's as you were for Cov. Wimbledon will field several players who have played top-flight football for years but wouldn't be noticed on the street if they were naked with £50 notes tied to their appendages.

Everton v Tottenham Hotspur
Everton's Richard Gough picked up a bit of rust on his zimmer frame against Birmingham, so Dave Watson and his shiny callipers stand by. Willem Korsten could make his first appearance for Spurs - if you're going to the match feel free to punch anyone who says, "Actually I think you'll find he didn't sign from Leeds, technically it was Vitesse Arnhem." Oyvind Leonhardsen, Steffen Freund and Mauricio Taricco are all missing, which is bad news if you're a Spurs fan. So is Les Ferdinand, which isn't.

Middlesbrough v Derby County
Old warhorses Paul Ince, Paul Gascoigne and Gary Pallister are all back for Boro after narrowly avoiding being boiled down for dog food. But have pity for Colin Cooper, Keith O'Neill and Christian Ziege - they're all in the stands, well within sniffing range of Bryan Robson's latest shiny leather coat. Meanwhile, goal"scorer" Mikkel Beck is back in the Derby side, ready to make a fool of himself against his old club. Again. Dean Sturridge is hamstrung but Seth Johnson is back after serving a ban.

Newcastle United v Southampton (Sunday)
Bobby Robson has admitted that he has a "difficult team selection" to make as Robert Lee, Didier Domi and Stephen Glass are all available to play. It's a shocker, principally because Bobby has remembered the names of three players all at once, without any help. Mind you, if that's stunning news, you should listen to this. Southampton's Claus Lundekvam is doubtful for this game after he damaged his back picking up... a frying pan. Christ, J (Mr) on a bike.

Sheffield Wednesday v Bradford City
If the Fiver could render a club crest with a jagged split down the middle to represent 'crisis' for you, it would. But it can't, so the words "Sheffield" and "Wednesday" will have to do. Danny Wilson can include the returning Andy Booth, Simon Donnelly and Phil Scott, if he wants to. Bradford's top goalscorer Lee Mills - six, count 'em! - has an ankle injury which leaves him rated 50-50, but Paul Jewell can welcome back David Wetherall after a one-match ban which was awarded to him for misbehaving in a rule-breaking way. Watford v Liverpool
Watford, who are looking to humiliate Liverpool (no.38 in a series of 573), will field new £1.5m record signing Heidar Helguson but not necessarily from the start. Sweet little Michael Owen should be back for Liverpool after a hamstring scare (no.54 in a series of 47,386). Robbie Fowler, Jamie Redknapp, Erik Meijer and Veggard Heggem are crocked however and Rigobert Song is Camerooning in the African Nations Cup. David Thompson could be dropped from the squad - he's been sent off in a reserve match again, the little nut.

West Ham United v Aston Villa
Trevor Sinclair and Paulo Wanchope are both back for the unhappy Hammers, but Shaka Hislop has flu, Marc-Vivien Foe has gone to the African Nations Cup and John Moncur and Steve Potts are out. Little Benito Carbone could be back for Villa who, if they win here for the second time in a week, will tip Harry Redknapp into full-on depression. Julian Joachim and Paul Merson will be alongside Carbone, helping his bid to send the West Ham manager to a dark place.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

THE RUMOUR MILL

Chris Sutton is believed to have found an admirer in George Graham. The Spurs manager is ready to take the three-goal striker off Chelsea's hands, although he doesn't think Chelsea are ready to sell.

Corinthians winger Felipe has expressed an interest in playing for Manchester United. "I would be interested in a move to England and Manchester United are a great football club," he said. The 22-year-old Brazil international would be available for £10m.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

NEWS IN BRIEF

Portsmouth have appointed Tony Pulis as their new manager.

Celtic have conceded defeat in their battle to gain a transfer fee for John Collins' move to Monaco in 1996.

Giovanni van Bronckhorst has pledged his future to Rangers despite being the subject of a £7m bid from Atletico Madrid. "I am not leaving Rangers," he said.

West Ham captain Steve Lomas has escaped a suspension but received a formal warning and was fined £6,000 at an FA disciplinary hearing. He had been charged for comments allegedly made on his way off the pitch after the Hammers' goalless draw at Chelsea last November.

David Beckham is the 10-1 outsider to win the Fifa world player of the year award behind Barcelona's Rivaldo, the 1-3 favourite, and Gabriel Batistuta (2-1). The result will be announced on January 24.

* * * * * * * * * * * * *

TONIGHT'S TV AND RADIO

BBC1: Match Of The Day - Live! (9.30pm, 1.10am)
The final of the World Club Championship between Not Manchester United and Not Manchester United.

BBC2: Ten Minute Match (6.45pm)
Clips from 1977, when Manchester United could be bothered with trifles like the FA Cup.

Match Of The Day - Live! (6.55pm)
The third-place play-off between Not Manchester United and Not Manchester United.

Sky Sports 1: Hold The Back Page (11pm, 4am)
So many words, so little meaning.

Sky Sports 2: Friday Night Football (7pm, 12.30am SS1, 4.30am)
Stoke, Preston, sleeping giants, so much potential, tradition, loyal fans, history, cliché, drone, blah.

Eurosport: Football - Live! (7.30pm)
The final of the Tournament of Maspalomas. What?

Radio 5 Live: 5 Live Sport (7pm)
5 Live sits down to supper. Meanwhile, Judas talkSPORT jingles a purse containing 30 pieces of exclusive broadcasting contract.
