It is 3,000 pages long and one of the great works of modern fiction. Critics say we must read it - but few of us ever do. Now A La Recherche Du Temps Perdu is creeping up the bestseller lists. Stephen Moss (on his fourth attempt) finds out why Proust is back in vogue; below, Esther Addley hears from those who managed the Marcel marathon
fields.trailText: It is 3,000 pages long and one of the great works of modern fiction. Critics say we must read it - but few of us ever do. Now A La Recherche Du Temps Perdu is creeping up the bestseller lists. Stephen Moss (on his fourth attempt) finds out why Proust is back in vogue; below, Esther Addley hears from those who managed the Marcel marathon
fields.body:
Proust's A La Recherche Du Temps Perdu (or, in English, How Can I Possibly Find the Time to Read This) is the cornerstone of modern literature; it is also a book few people have actually read. Proust wrote it after the death of his mother, when he withdrew from society to his famous cork-lined room to reflect on memory, art and guilt. He spent the next two decades there, emerging only occasionally and usually at night. This is very much the method to employ if you intend to read his masterpiece.

For 80 years, with the honourable exceptions of Terence Kilmartin, Alain de Botton and Michael Portillo, we have been meaning to read Proust but not quite managing it. We know it is important; we know that the way he treats time, cuts between past and present, and replicates the workings of the mind changed the art of novel-writing forever; we know his baroque style, those endless, loopingly lyrical sentences, piling metaphor upon metaphor, going on for page after page, losing themselves in the folds of his boundless imagination, one sub-clause giving way to another like endless waves breaking on a beach beneath a lowering November sky, the peeling paint on the neat row of beach huts redolent of a lost innocence that somehow... sorry; we know his style is extraordinary, enveloping, captivating. Yet still we do not read him; or, rather, we try and, more often that not, we fail.

That may now be set to change; there are signs that this is Marcel's moment. The catalyst is Raul Ruiz's film of the last part of the novel, Le Temps Retrouvé, which has just been released to critical acclaim. The history of the film-hating Proust on screen has been patchy: Visconti, René Clement and Joseph Losey all failed to get their projects off the ground; Volker Schlöndorff's film of the first volume (Swann in Love) was widely panned; and Percy Adlon's Céleste was more biopic than film of the book. Ruiz has gone some of the way to disproving the adage that great books make lousy movies.

Better still, this week the book jumped 3,000 places in the Booktrack bestseller list. Admittedly, that represents just 217 copies in a flat post-Christmas market and it only sits at number 544 in the fiction list; but it is a big book, a major investment, a lot of book tokens. A spokeswoman for Booktrack ("I've heard of Proust but I've never read him") is convinced there is a trend: "It wasn't even in the top 5,000 in December, but it's suddenly appeared."

There are other straws in the wind: the success of De Botton's How Proust Can Change Your Life and of Phyllis Rose's The Year of Reading Proust; a major Proust exhibition in Paris; a controversial comic-book version by Stephane Heuet; a biography by Jean-Yves Tadie, due in July; the final volume of a new edition of his letters out this month; and an unlikely-sounding Proustian guide to gardening. The Proust industry is working overtime; the figures show a modest boost in sales of the novel; all that remains now is to find the time to read it.

The film has presumably helped sales of the book, but it only opened last Friday and may not alone account for the increase. De Botton identified another factor: "It is a new century and people are saying, 'I'll finally conquer Proust before I die.' " You didn't manage it in the last millennium, but the slate is wiped clean; you've been given another chance; you can have your cake and eat it.

Reading the book, as De Botton pointed out, can be a seminal experience. Harold Pinter spent a year reading it to write a screenplay for Losey's aborted film (his screenplay was published in 1978 and the National Theatre plans to stage it next year); far from being time lost, he sees it as time exquisitely well spent. Clive James learned French just to read it in the original. San Francisco boasts a Marcel Proust Support Group, which holds an annual wake for the master at which Prousties wax their moustaches, dunk madeleines and take turns lying in a coffin (whether they actually read the book is not clear).

Proust has always had influential champions - the finishers, the re-readers, members of the Marcel Proust Support Group (Hampstead branch), dinner-party Proustians who spend hours dissecting various translations, Harold Bloom ("Proust defeats his critics") - but they have been outnumbered by the life's-too-shorters, those for whom there are no longueurs longer than Proust's. Even Proust's brother, a doctor, was less than convinced. "The sad thing is that people have to be very ill or have broken a leg in order to read A La Recherche Du Temps Perdu," he said.

A straw poll of a dozen of my Guardian colleagues unearthed seven who had never set off; one who had started in English and stopped; one who had started in French and in English and stopped both times; two who had happily dipped with no apparent intention of reading the whole thing (three, six, seven, eight, nine or 12 volumes, depending on how you slice it; 3,000-plus pages; 1.3m words; not many sentences but that hardly helps); and one, hero of heroes, who had spent the best part of a year reading it, to the exclusion of pretty well anything else. Now he swears by it (not, like many, at it) and plans to read it in French.

Here, I have to make an admission. I have tried to read Proust several times without ever getting very far; further than Alan Coren, who took five years to read 53 pages and has now given it up in protest at the French ban on British beef, but not very far. In the middle of December I fell victim to millennial angst and began again: I am now further in than ever before and enjoying it. I am still only at the edge of the forest but I want to proceed along these strange, circuitous paths to the interior; I think I can do it.

I am reading it in an old Penguin edition: three volumes, 1,000 pages each. This is not a good idea: heavy, intimidating and the yellowing pages fall out. Go for something smaller, more easily digestible. The six-volume Vintage paperback edition is ugly - this should be a lovingly, leisurely experience after all; the Chatto & Windus edition which was published in 1995 (same text, lavish design) is still theoretically in print, but isn't much in evidence; the hardback American Modern Library edition (same text again, DJ Enright's revision of Kilmartin's revision of Scott Moncrieff) is available, though it's double the price of the far-from-vintage Vintage; and it is published in French in seven paperback volumes (a more rational arrangement) by Gallimard. Penguin will re-enter the lists in two years with a new translation by a team of academics. Advice to potential buyers: avoid the big and the badly produced; think madeleine, not Black Forest gateau.

Even with my hard-to-swallow old Penguin, this time I know I will persist: I will reach the end, enjoying the journey for its own sake but also thankful, when I reach my destina tion, to have gained a kind of literary absolution. A few years back, Waterstone's conducted a poll to determine which books people felt most guilty about not having read. A La Recherche Du Temps Perdu was an easy winner. How wonderful, at the dawn of a new century, to be free of that feeling, finally to have finished Proust.

That just leaves The Old Testament, the Koran, the Mahabharata, The Divine Comedy, The Decameron, The Scarlet Letter, Tristram Shandy, Clarissa, The Pilgrim's Progress, some of Borges, most of Freud, all of Goethe, Moby Dick properly, Billy Budd at all, Homer and Virgil seriously, Cervantes comically, Pessoa, Hugo, Balzac (how many novels?), Horace, Pliny (older and younger), Dumas (père and fils), Descartes, Kant (oh yes you kan), Confucius, Lao Tzu, Cao Xueqin's The Story of the Stone, Gogol, Goncharov, early Nabokov, late Conrad, Vasari's Lives of the Artists, Machiavelli's Discourses, Schopenhauer's aphorisms, Kierkegaard's ramblings, Augustine, Aquinas, Stendhal, Montaigne (there to be climbed), Racine, Rabelais, Gérard de Nerval's ephemera, Heine's phemera, Hegel on aesthetics, Walter Benjamin, Nietzsche, Thoreau, Emerson (not to mention Lake and Palmer), Dos Passos, Willa Cather, Edith Wharton, Pascal's Pensées... I could go on, but I have a book to read.

'I exclaimed with delight and read bits out to people'

Lisa Jardine, historian
"I read the whole thing in French in 1966, as an undergraduate. I couldn't put it down, I thought it was fab. I don't know if it was a 60s thing, but we all felt it captured how we remember the past. It's why I became a historian. It's not difficult, just long. I think the stuff about it being turgid comes out of London drawing rooms. It's a really important read if you are French, or you want to show off at parties."

David Lodge, novelist and academic
"I have only read the first two volumes. It's one of those gaps one is slightly ashamed of, and thinks of making up on a desert island. Life was too short at the time, and still is. But I don't think the novel changes drastically, so you can take a sample of the work and get a good impression of the rest. To read him in French is a huge labour, which I quail at. I feel you never really experience a writer when you read him in translation."

Doris Lessing, novelist
"He's not a difficult writer, he's one of the funny writers. I have been reading him for years and have never found him dense or difficult. He must have had the plan of this novel in his mind for years, an achievement in itself. I don't accept that parts of the novel are difficult, not at all. You can't read Proust over the weekend - he needs application, but he's a revelation. It's not like watching Neighbours on television."

Sebastian Faulks, novelist
"I have read Proust, but skipped bits. I just found them too boring. The most boring bit was this interminable account of the military training of Saint-Loup. Some of the stuff on the genealogy of the main families I also found tedious. But the bits I enjoyed gave me more pleasure than any other book. The first time I read it, in France in 1984, I exclaimed with delight and read bits out to people. It does exert a spell."

Penelope Lively, novelist
"I have certainly enjoyed him. I revisit him every 10 years. There are highlights, of course, and passages you don't read so closely, but that applies to a lot of literature. I'm reading a lot of Trollope at the moment, and it certainly applies to that. I have never found him difficult. It's the length, of course, there's an awful lot to get through. But I have never read the volumes in sequence. I've skipped about from one to another."

Malcolm Bradbury, novelist
"Certainly I read Proust in college, at a time when he was enormously fashionable. This was the time we were beginning to think our way through modernism. I read him with enormous interest, though he's certainly a slow read that you come to with trepidation. His reputation has risen and fallen but that's true of a lot of big modernist writers. I think it's wonderful that there's this renewal of interest. I am certainly an admirer."

fields.headline: England take six on rain-shortened first day
fields.trailText: England have failed to make the most of a rain-shortened first day in the fifth and final Test against South Africa at Centurion Park, Pretoria. After winning a crucial toss in overcast conditions, Nasser Hussain had no hesitation in asking South Africa to bat, and when play finally got under way at 2.15pm local time, the bowlers were licking their lips. At one point, they reduced South Africa to 55 for 4, before some poor bowling allowed them to reach 155 for 6 by the close. Lance Klusener was 22 not out, with Shaun Pollock on nine.
fields.body:
England have failed to make the most of a rain-shortened first day in the fifth and final Test against South Africa at Centurion Park, Pretoria. After winning a crucial toss in overcast conditions, Nasser Hussain had no hesitation in asking South Africa to bat, and when play finally got under way at 2.15pm local time, the bowlers were licking their lips. At one point, they reduced South Africa to 55 for 4, before some poor bowling allowed them to reach 155 for 6 by the close. Lance Klusener was 22 not out, with Shaun Pollock on nine.

The pitch had been sweating under covers all morning, and Darren Gough took advantage of the lavish seam movement it offered as early as the first over when he got one to leave Gary Kirsten and take his outside edge on the way to Chris Adams at second slip for a duck. England were delighted to see the back of Kirsten, whose last two Test scores had been 275 and 80, and South Africa were 1 for 1.

Klusener brought up the 150 with a firm-footed slap off Gough through the covers for 4, and the batsmen accepted umpires' offer of bad light five runs later.

While 155 for 6 doesn't look like a great score, it may prove to be a useful one on this wicket. The weather forecast is variable over the next few days, which means conditions will remain loaded in the bowlers' favour. And it will be a minor miracle if South Africa let England score at 3.5 an over, as they were allowed to do today.

webTitle: Media sale nets Chris Evans a £75m 'divvy'

fields.headline: Media sale nets Chris Evans a £75m 'divvy'
fields.standfirst: Mega-rich radio and TV star vows that deal on Ginger company will make no difference to the way he works or to his life
fields.trailText: The radio DJ turned media magnate Chris Evans yesterday earned himself £75m by selling his radio and television group for £225m, but declared he would still get up at 4am to present his Virgin breakfast show.
fields.body:
The radio DJ turned media magnate Chris Evans yesterday earned himself £75m by selling his radio and television group for £225m, but declared he would still get up at 4am to present his Virgin breakfast show.

Evans's Ginger Media Group, which incorporates the Virgin Radio station and his television production arm, Ginger Television, was sold to the Scottish Media Group, owners of Scottish Television and the Glasgow Herald.

With a personal wealth already estimated at £30m, Evans yesterday said the deal would make no difference to his life.

He will continue to present the Virgin breakfast show and his Channel 4 series TFI Friday.

The money he described as "a bit of a divvy".

Although SMG insists it sees earnings growth in Ginger aside from Evans, analysts and rivals have questioned the value of the company without its star proprietor, a question which SMG has answered by ensuring he cannot walk away with his multi-million pound haul.

Nearly half of the £75m Evans will earn from the deal will be paid in shares in three equal instalments on an annual basis - so if he leaves the company before 2002, he forfeits his right to receive any further shares.

SMG's chief executive, Andrew Flanagan, said that the company also has an option to renew Evans's contract for a further three years, covering all his television and radio work.

Mr Flanagan added he was confident that Evans, who walked out on his BBC contract to produce the Radio 1 Breakfast Show, would remain motivated to work for the new company.

"He is very much a feet-on-the-ground person with a very clear view about his life. This guy is already very wealthy and he still gets up every day at 4am to do his radio show," he said.

At 33, Evans has founded one of the country's leading media companies in just seven years.

He was a little known DJ on GLR 10 years ago before he joined the Big Breakfast in 1992 and became known as a talented producer and presenter.

The Channel 4 entertainment series Don't Forget Your Toothbrush consolidated his reputation, and the future of his production company Ginger Television.

However, TFI Friday, his Channel 4 show, has suffered dwindling ratings.

The show's contract finishes at the end of the year and although talks with Channel 4 are continuing, no decision has been made about its future.

Evans bought Virgin Radio for £85m two years ago from under the nose of rival bidder Capital Radio, taking just over 50% of the resulting Ginger Media Group, with venture capitalists Apax Partners and Sir Richard Branson each owning 20%.

They are reported to have prompted yesterday's sale by wishing to cash in their stakes in the company. Other bidders for Ginger are reported to have included the Guardian Media Group, the US media group Clear Channel, and the French radio group NRJ.

Evans insisted yesterday that the deal was "a merger, not a takeover" and said key Ginger executives will continue to run the group's divisions.

SMG will form a new national media division, run by Ginger chief executive David Campbell, to house Virgin Radio along with the group's cinema advertising sales company, Pearl & Dean, and its poster advertising business.

Ginger Television will sit alongside Scottish Television Enterprises which produces a number of ITV children's programmes and dramas including Taggart.

The combined TV production operation will be headed by Eileen Gallagher, managing director of Ginger Television.

SMG proposes to raise money to fund the deal through a £58m rights issue. Its shareholders are to vote on the deal on January 31, although its largest shareholder, television channel provider Flextech, has already given its approval.

But Granada Group which owns 18% of SMG is likely to vote against, having said last year it was opposed to the acquisition when it was first mooted.

The deal coincides with a period of frantic activity among ITV companies jostling to form a consolidated network. Granada, which has been long expected to acquire SMG's ITV franchise, recently declared an intention to bid for the ITV franchises owned by Carlton Communications and United News and Media, which are themselves in the throes of a proposed merger.

Industry sources suggest that SMG has preserved itself from the immediate threat of a takeover by Granada by acquiring Ginger. The group was founded in 1993 as Ginger Television after Chris Evans quit the Big Breakfast morning TV show. It now consists of three main operations:

Virgin Radio

Launched on AM in 1993 by Richard Branson as one of three national commercial radio stations; two years later FM broadcasts were added in London. Evans joined the station in 1997 as the breakfast show DJ after storming out of his Radio 1 Breakfast Show.

With backing from venture capitalists, he beat a rival bid from Capital Radio to buy the station from Branson later that year and merged it with Ginger Television to form the Ginger Media Group.

Listening figures rose, but have since fallen. Evans created the UK's first quiz show millionaire in December in an attempt to boost the station's audiences.

Virgin Radio is now part of a consortium bidding for two London digital radio licences.

Ginger Television

Also founded in 1993, after Evans quit the Big Breakfast on Channel 4.

Its first success was Don't Forget Your Toothbrush, the Channel 4 Saturday night entertainment show devised and hosted by Evans. The format was sold around the world, earning him millions.

TFI Friday followed in 1996, complete with a record three-year deal with C4. Ratings have fallen by 15% to 1.8m amid surveys declaring that teenagers think Evans is deeply uncool.

He used the company to produce his Radio 1 Breakfast Show, which ended when he quit to join Virgin.

Last year, a push into new productions in an attempt to make the company less dependent on Evans himself saw the launch of Red Alert, Lulu's Saturday night lottery show on BBC1, and The Priory, a celebrity chat and music show presented by Zoe Ball and Jamie Theakston on Channel 4.

Red Alert was critically-mauled, but has been recommissioned with an overhaul of the format.

A spin-off for television of the feature film Lock Stock and Two Smoking Barrels is in production for Channel 4.

Ginger Online

Launched in June 1998, the internet service includes output from Virgin Radio and a music, news and e-commerce site.

Ginger Media Group

www.virginradio.co.uk/

fields.headline: Scissors at dawn
fields.standfirst: It is the street synonymous with high-class tailoring for gentlemen of means. But now, thanks to an influx of newcomers threatening tradition, it has become a battleground.  Simon O'Connell reports on the row in Savile Row
fields.trailText: It is the street synonymous with high-class tailoring for gentlemen of means. But now, thanks to an influx of newcomers threatening tradition, it has become a battleground. Simon O'Connell reports on the row in Savile Row
fields.body:
Savile Row, for 200 years a mecca for well-dressed men the world over, is facing civil war. The old guard is taking a stand against the suave young upstarts who are invading their territory. At stake (depending on who you listen to) is either the entire future of high-class tailoring, or the effective modernisation of the industry.

Savile Row had its heyday in the 1920s and 30s, when the surrounding streets were occupied by hundreds of tailors employing thousands of people. This situation remained until the 70s, when ready-to-wear began to take over as a far cheaper alternative. The 80s were lean times; new talent dried up when traditional apprentice schemes were ended to cut costs and many tailors closed their doors.

In the 90s, a new slimline Savile Row, consisting of fewer than two dozen tailors, flourished again as a modish search for luxury encouraged newly-moneyed men to demand the same hand-crafting the upper classes had always enjoyed. No Wall Street trader was complete without a visit from a flying Savile Row tailor.

On to this thriving scene, several new businesses have arrived - Alexandre, 40 Savile Row, Paname - which advertise "bespoke" suiting at a third of the price of traditional tailors such as Dege & Skinner, Anderson & Sheppard, Maurice Sedwell or Kilgour French & Stanbury, but use very different methods.

Not everyone is happy to see these newcomers. Michael Skinner, managing director of Dege & Skinner, explains: "I'm delighted for them to be here, selling made-to-measure clothes, but 'bespoke' means the person who measures you cuts the pattern, cuts the suit, supervises the making in his own premises and is totally responsible for how it turns out. You can't achieve that in a factory."

The book Textile Terms and Definitions defines bespoke as "descriptive of a tailored garment made to an individual customer's specification". Anthony Hendley, brands director at Baird plc, the company behind newcomer Alexandre, says bespoke does not mean made on-site. "We want to take a fresh approach to bespoke garments - cleaner lines, a smoother finish. We're not aiming at the same price bracket. We're bringing fresh air to a staid and stuffy street."

Alexandre's suits are hand-cut and machine-sewn. So are those of the traditional tailors. The difference is Alexandre's are cut by factory workers in Goole, Humberside, whereas traditional tailors cut the cloth themselves and the sewing is done on site by skilled trouser or coat makers.

Around the corner at James & James on Old Burlington Street, a different system is in place. "The customer is measured by a tailor on site and his figures transmitted to a factory in France, where the cloth is cut by laser, machine-sewn, then sent back to the tailor for a final fitting."

Eric James, owner of James & James, is the only Savile Row tailor to make suits both traditionally and with the laser system. "The best comparison is between a top-of-the-range Ford Scorpio costing £30k and a Rolls-Royce costing £130k. Both are great cars. The Scorpio's fantastic - smooth, beautiful and fast - but if you're lucky enough to own a Rolls-Royce, you'll notice the difference and won't go back to a Scorpio.

"I made a bespoke suit and a laser suit for an American. The laser suit fitted so beautifully, it worried me a little. The bespoke suit fitted perfectly, too, and I suspect he was thinking: 'What's the difference?' Recently he came back to order more suits. He said: 'I'm going to order bespoke; the laser suit is fine, but bespoke is different.' And it is because we can do hand-work: smaller armholes, bigger sleeves for fullness in the shoulders. That can't be done in a factory."

To combat accusations of selling out, James has introduced a new class of suit. When tailors on Savile Row say "hand-made", what they mean is hand-cut, machine-sewn and hand-finished. James is introducing a super-bespoke suit in which every stitch is hand-sewn, as it was in the 19th century. It will cost £18-£20k.

The starting price for a traditional Savile Row bespoke suit is £2k, which sounds outrageous until you hear it takes 70-80 hours to make. "If you look at the rates charged by everyone from plumbers to window cleaners, you'll see why it's so expensive," says Hugh Holland, managing director of Kilgour French & Stanbury.

He takes a neutral view of the conflict on Savile Row. "Bespoke is not the word to be having an argument about. Bespoke means 'bespoken' in the context of a customer asking for a particular type of suit. It's an order, not a standard or style of garment." But, he adds: "People saying they are making a Savile Row-quality suit, but doing it in a factory, principally by machine, are trading on a reputation that's not theirs to trade on."

Alexandre's Anthony Hendley believes nostalgia for the old ways fails to take into account developments in clothing manufacture. "I have no desire to see a suit made the way I was taught 25 years ago. Trousers are crisper and cleaner now; jackets need to be sharper. If someone comes in and asks if we do hand-work, we send them to our next-door neighbour or to Kilgour. We give them business."

Given that a made-to-measure suit from Alexandre or a laser suit from James & James start at around £500 - roughly a quarter of the price of a traditional tailor's - it's little wonder the two are quarrelling. But the bigger problem for the industry is its lack of a large, solid client base: most men today have no knowledge of visiting a tailor and of the range of different services available. Men everywhere should be applauding the wider choice on offer. Though, as a general rule, "You get what you pay for" is probably still true.

webTitle: The shape of things to come

fields.headline: The shape of things to come
fields.standfirst: Time to get fit, guys: next season's styles are slimmer, skinnier, tighter, clingier
fields.trailText: Time to get fit, guys: next season's styles are slimmer, skinnier, tighter, clingier
fields.body:
Men have had it far too easy for far too long. The enduring popularity of urban chic - slouchy sweats, chunky knits and oversized combats with more pockets than you have possessions to fill them with - has enabled us all to get lazy, drink more, work out less and shove on any old thing in the name of style. But the brutal news from Milan is this: get fit and shape up for autumn, or forget being on the coming season's best-dressed list. Body-conscious style is here and if you don't have a taste for Diet Coke, you'd better acquire one because suits are slimmer, casualwear tighter, and there is a marked move towards skinnier styling all round.

Donatella Versace likes her blokes to show off their bodies. In one of her strongest menswear collections to date, she showed multi-zipped leather biker gear, Jacquard silk suits and super-tight metallic lace shirts with matching ties, as well as evening tuxedos that glittered with the polish of mirrored razor blades. Inspired by Fight Club, this was nose-bleed chic at its punchiest.

Like Versace, costume national hommes had a deliberately dangerous feel. In a show broadcast live on the Internet (a first in menswear), models ground their heels into a runway lit with a grid of laser beams, wearing crackled black PVC trenchcoats, sandblasted leather Vespa jackets and second-skin trousers which zipped halfway up the leg and were worn with bronze metallic or tailored jackets.

Even Milan's most sedate designers ditched their usual soft and non-confrontational characteristics to explore a different vision. Jil Sander, never one to expose the body, chose a much skinnier silhouette, announcing that the Sander man "has never been in such good shape". "Suits which come closer to the man, without being too close to him" were elegant and modern, in lightweight flannels of tonal foggy shades, the best of which featured peaked lapels and narrow shoulders. Even more daring for a designer who has made her name with luxuriant understatement were the electric shocks of violet and magenta she injected throughout the collection.

Giorgio Armani, king of the soft, wide-legged trouser, chose a suit shape that was sculpted to the body, featuring a shaped waistline and a rigid shoulder. D-squared took hipster proportions to new depths, cutting trousers low enough to show a bit of butt cleavage, which then clung to the hips and flared gently into a boot cut at the ankle. In a collection entitled Demolition Chic, denim with a sandpaper texture, top-stitched in gold and splattered with mud at the ankles, was worn with T-shirts that were ripped, then laced together with leather thongs.

Prada and Alessandro dell'Acqua both took a more sophisticated approach to the slimming-down process. At Prada, with a collection Miuccia called "conscious elegance", understated tailored separates in shades of espresso, Bordeaux, chino beige and washed navy were mismatched and just off-centre enough to look right. Overnight bags of canvas and ostrich leather, traditionally English shoes and conservative caban coats completed the look. Dell'Acqua used a caramel and butterscotch palette, highlighted with hot pinks, to rework traditional Fair Isle and argyle knits into retro jogging suits.

Calvin Klein also looked strong this season, using a palette of greenish blacks, inky blacks and blackish blues for tight-legged tuxedo pants with a slight boot cut and fitted shirts with pocket flaps and matching silk ties. Nicole Farhi, in her first Milan show, also opted for the straight and narrow, describing her collection simply as "real clothes". She chose to experiment with contrasting textures, teaming fluffy mohair diagonal-striped sweaters with tough leathers.

Jean Paul Gaultier is over gimmickry, for this season at least. Instead of his usual cocktail of avant- garde colour, he chose to say it all in sober tones of black, ivory and wet sand, accented only with metallic rose-coloured Lurex knits for evening. A sophisticated style for Gaultier and one that fell beautifully in line with the season's narrow-minded trend. The usually ebullient Dolce & Gabbana also went with the flow for well-tailored clothes. Only subtle mixtures of oversized polka dots and Jermyn Street stripes on shirts, and shaved furs or lux furnishing fabrics on jeans, added the balanced mixture of excitement needed to make this vintage Dolce.

If the trend for cling-to-fit is going to be taken seriously, other highlights to remember include optical-knit tank tops at Byblos, sprayed-on leather pants at Dirk Bikkembergs and seamed tracksuits at Issey Miyake. Vivienne Westwood produced some of the most covetable denim of the season, especially her boiler suit shot with bullet holes and washed out to look faded by time. Moschino added its usual high camp, with pinstriped suits spray-painted for added glitz.

Two new names to look out for are Daniel Margolin and Andrew Mackenzie. The latter, who is currently stocked by Harvey Nichols, pushed all the right buttons with his spin on football terrace chic, while California-born Margolin, now being handled by Eo Bocci, the powerhouse distributor who works with Olivier Theyskins and Ann Demeulemeester, looked to his father's wardrobe for inspiration and presented odd-fitting but cleverly proportioned separates. These are menswear's greatest white hopes for the future.

Two labels that presented flawless collections were Burberry Prorsum (new ways with the traditional check and a slimline look of rustic elegance) and Gucci (leaving those in search of ultimate luxury weak at the knees). For autumn, Tom Ford took a trip to St Moritz, with caramel-coloured biker leathers, hand-stitched shoes, mink ski jackets and cream and toffee Capucci-style scarf prints.

Gold jewellery, white velvet bow ties, tinted aviator glasses and shoulder-strap bags were the ultimate claim to ingenious accessory development. Sophisticated and racy (think walnut-interiored Aston Martins), this was Gucci's strongest show to date.

 Adrian Clark is fashion director of Attitude.

fields.headline: Russia: state of the nation
fields.trailText: Embroiled in a savage war in the Caucasus, equipped with a new parliament, and under the leadership of a new, young strongman in the Kremlin, Russia is in a condition of extreme flux.
fields.body:
Embroiled in a savage war in the Caucasus, equipped with a new parliament, and under the leadership of a new, young strongman in the Kremlin, Russia is in a condition of extreme flux.

The former superpower of 143 million people which takes up half the northern hemisphere, bordering countries as far apart as Norway, Turkey, and China entered the new millennium with a dramatic flourish.

Boris Yeltsin, the leader who was Russia's first ever democratically elected president, suddenly resigned in a New Year's Eve coup de theatre, and handed the reins of power to his protégé, the prime minister, Vladimir Putin, who hopes to seal his swift ascendancy in early presidential elections set for March 26.

It has been a century of tragedy for Russia - war, revolution, civil war, dictatorship, the second world war, then more dictatorship over a period of 75 years climaxing in the collapse of Soviet communism in 1989-91 and the implosion of the Soviet empire in eastern Europe.

Boris Yeltsin, through two terms or eight years in power, buried Soviet communism as a political force, but his destructive and combative talents far outweighed his creative and constructive abilities. He left a legacy of an economy in tatters, with GDP in the late 90s around half of what it was in the 80s, mass poverty, declining health, birth rates and life expectancy. Although Russia remains the world's second biggest nuclear power, its economy resembles more that of a developing country, dependent on mineral wealth and raw materials.

Yeltsin left behind an imperfect, corrupt and venal democracy with the prospects for stability uncertain.

Russia is hurting from 10 years of decline, resentful at its reduced international status since losing the Cold War. Rather like Weimar Germany chafing at the punitive terms of the peace imposed after the First World War, Russia is turning more nationalist, anti-western and isolationist.

The expansion of Nato into the former Soviet client states in eastern Europe, Nato's war with Yugoslavia over Kosovo, and the Gulf War have left Russia raging impotently on the sidelines, nursing its grievances through the post-communist 90s.

Putin, 47, is a veteran of the KGB and former intelligence chief with no democratic legitimacy. He has never contested an elected office in his life, but is hugely popular and expected to win the Kremlin seat in March.

He promises to rebuild Russia, restore its great power status, and is also expected to increase the powers of the state at the expense of individual liberties, rejecting western models in favour of drawing on Russian history and tradition, whether communist or Tsarist.

But his real political beliefs remain shrouded in mystery and some of his key supporters are also the strongest liberal, pro-western figures in Russian politics.

A new Duma or lower house was elected on December 19, the third free parliamentary election since communism collapsed, and Putin's allies did very well. The acting president can count on much stronger parliamentary support than Yeltsin ever enjoyed, meaning that he may be able to break the legislative gridlock that characterised the Yeltsin years.

Putin has risen to power by warmongering. After being made prime minister in August 1999, he launched the war in Chechnya a month later and then watched his ratings soar. The army top brass are grateful to him. Given his KGB past, he enjoys strong support in the security structures.

His leadership promises a much more dynamic and possibly more authoritarian period in Russia's feeble, infant democracy. But his hopes of waging a ''small, victorious war'' in the Caucasus to entrench his power and popularity could be frustrated by a long guerrilla campaign fought by determined and resourceful Chechen rebels who dealt Russia a humiliating defeat in 1994-6.

And even if he wins in Chechnya, it is not clear what he will then do with the restive republic which will need to be garrisoned by a Russian army of occupation for years.

Russia has experienced more upheaval and change in the past decade than most societies go through in several generations and ordinary Russians are punch-drunk and reeling while a tiny minority of corrupt businessmen and politicians have grown extremely rich on the post-communist pickings.

Putin appears to believe that Russia needs a period of consolidation, a slower pace of reform, a more managed and less chaotic transition from decaying communism to robust democracy.

But he is a political leader of scant experience. In a democratic culture with such shallow roots where the electorate is notoriously fickle and where politicians' popularity is so ephemeral, it is far from clear if the Putin phenomenon has legs.

fields.headline: Profile: Vladimir Putin
fields.standfirst: What do we know about the man destined to be Russia's next leader?
fields.trailText: What do we know about the man destined to be Russia's next leader?
fields.body:
Age: 47
Current position: Acting president of Russia

Born in St Petersburg in 1952, Mr Putin joined the KGB's foreign intelligence directorate after graduating from Leningrad state university with a law degree in 1975. He spent - officially, at least - most of his KGB career stationed in East Germany monitoring political attitudes there.

He returned to Leningrad in 1989, where he took up a position at the state university and developed a close relationship with Anatoly Shobchak, a key reformer who in 1991 became the city's mayor and appointed Mr Putin to various key administrative posts.

Having proved himself a competent manager in St Petersburg (Leningrad's original name, restored after the collapse of communism), he was brought to Moscow in 1996 to serve on Boris Yeltsin's presidential staff. Two years later, Mr Yeltsin appointed Mr Putin head of the FSB, the KGB's successor organisation, and last year he assumed control of the coordinating body of all of Russia's security and intelligence ministries before being named prime minister.

Mr Putin does not appear to have distinguished himself in his various posts. But he has his fans. Anatoly Chubais, a former deputy prime minister and market reformer and a friend of Mr Putin, says he had no trouble grasping economic complexities that left other Soviet-era apparatchiks befuddled.

In his first speech as acting president, Mr Putin insisted there would be no backsliding on any of the key political liberties gained in the past decade. "Freedom of speech, freedom of conscience, freedom of the press, the right to private property - these basic principles of a civilised society will be protected," he said.

Human rights activists are prepared to give Mr Putin the benefit of the doubt for now. "People learn and change," says Larisa Bogoraz, a dissident who served seven years in Siberia. "We all know democrats who turned out to be criminals. So there may be KGB officers with understanding of democratic values."

One of Mr Putin's first decisions as acting president was to guarantee Boris Yeltsin from immunity for alleged crimes in the past, when many in Russia would have branded the former president deeply corrupt. That guarantee more than outweighed the dismissal of Tatyana Dyachenko, one of Mr Yeltsin's daughters, as a Kremlin adviser.

Moreover, Mr Putin has retained many from the Yeltsin entourage, indicating that it will be as business as usual in domestic policy. The powerful Kremlin chief of staff Alexander Voloshin kept his job and Boris Berezovsky, the influential business magnate with extensive control over media outlets, is likely to remain an important figure in a Putin administration.

In his short tenure as prime minister, Mr Putin has attained enormous popularity by launching a war against Chechen rebels. As Russian troops swept through Chechnya unopposed, the public loved their new leader.

But his popularity could dive as quickly as the number of Russian casualties rises. As long as it was going well, the war masked public disaffection with the economy and muffled complaints about corruption. If the tide turns in the Chechnya war, that discontent could re-emerge and give Mr Putin's opponents an opening in the forthcoming election.

webTitle: Peers revolt may scupper jury bill

fields.headline: Peers revolt may scupper jury bill
fields.standfirst:
Jack Straw's speech to the IPPR
Trial by jury explained
New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: Rebel peers were heading for a major clash with Jack Straw about plans to scrap the right to jury trial for some defendants, despite the home secretary's claims that their wrecking tactics were "profoundly undemocratic".
fields.body:
Rebel peers were heading for a major clash with Jack Straw about plans to scrap the right to jury trial for some defendants, despite the home secretary's claims that their wrecking tactics were "profoundly undemocratic".

The new Labour peer and leading barrister, Baroness Kennedy, heads a cross-party coalition which yesterday tabled amendments which would effectively sink the legislation when it reaches its crucial committee stage in the House of Lords next Thursday.

Rebel peers stressed last night that since Labour went into the last election supporting the right to jury trial, there was no obligation on them to pass the measure.

The fact that the criminal justice (mode of trial) bill - which would remove the right to choose trial by jury from defendants accused of middle-ranking crimes such as burglary - started life in the Lords also means that the peers will not be voting against a measure already endorsed by MPs.

An added element of uncertainty is that this is the first big test for the reformed House of Lords after the removal of the hereditary peers before Christmas. Nobody is exactly sure how the arithmetic will work out.

"The arguments in favour of this change are overwhelming and it has to be a matter for the elected House of Commons," said Mr Straw. "We were elected to modernise the criminal justice system. This is an important part of our manifesto commitment and for the Lords to prevent the bill even being discussed by the Commons would be profoundly undemocratic.

"Time and again we have seen professional lawyers resist measures such as these but once the changes are through, the water clears and people recognise the benefits of those changes."

But Mr Straw went on to infuriate his critics when he dismissed the "liberal left" and most of the legal establishment as "woolly minded". Downing Street claimed that the government was about to embark on a battle with "the forces of conservatism in the legal profession". His attack provoked attacks from the Bar Council, representing Britain's barristers, and the opposition.

Both the Conservatives and the Liberal Democrats argued before Christmas that the bill removing the defendant's choice in about 18,000 cases a year was "unamendable" and therefore would have to be opposed as a whole.

Amendments tabled last night try to restore the status quo by inserting the words that "on application of the accused shall he be tried on indictment" into the appropriate places in the bill.

Mr Straw admitted yesterday he had changed his position on the issue but claimed "the more I have examined the evidence the more it becomes overwhelming and the more the case against simply dissolves."

He said perhaps the "ultimate irony given the views of many who oppose the change" was that one effect of the re form would be to reduce the prison population by increasing the number of people receiving lighter sentences in the magistrates rather than the crown court.

The Liberal Democrats later produced figures showing that it was these shorter sentences which would produce the lion's share of the £100m saving that Mr Straw claims the measure will make, rather than cutting "time-wasting" by defendants playing the system as he had previously alleged.

He said perhaps the "ultimate irony given the views of many who oppose the change" was that one effect of the re form would be to reduce the prison population by increasing the number of people receiving lighter sentences in the magistrates rather than the crown court. The Liberal Democrats later produced figures showing that it was these shorter sentences which would produce the lion's share of the £100m saving that Mr Straw claims the measure will make, rather than cutting "time-wasting" by defendants playing the system as he had previously alleged.

webTitle: Wallace  and Gromit take to cyberspace

fields.headline: Wallace  and Gromit take to cyberspace
fields.trailText: Fans of Wallace and Gromit will soon be able to relive edited highlights of their TV capers whenever they want on a new web site.
fields.body:
Fans of Wallace and Gromit will soon be able to relive edited highlights of their TV capers whenever they want on a new web site.

Aardman Animations, the Bristol-based company behind the Oscar-winning short films, today launched a new internet-based 'channel' to showcase classic clips of its work.

The free service, which kicked off this morning with episodes of BBC1's Morph, from 1981, and the ground-breaking Creature Comfort commercials from 1989, will run 24 hours a day, seven days a week.

Every fortnight, new content will be added, including excerpts from animator Nick Park's Wallace and Gromit trilogy, A Grand Day Out, The Wrong Trousers and A Close Shave.

The new service is being run via the award-winning Atom Films entertainment web site.

Liz Keynes, head of rights and licensing at Aardman, said: "The internet means audiences no longer have to rely on TV channels to see their favourite Aardman films.

"Wallace and Gromit are becoming known globally, but the World Wide Web is a great way to let audiences across the world see the diversity of Aardman's output - from Rex the Runt to less well-known characters like Adam and Pib and Pog."

In addition to being able to view classic Aardman highlights, those who access the new service can rate and review the content and read other fans' comments. The site will also contain production details on each film, information about Aardman, and the chance to join an online fan club.

 Aardman has just completed its first feature-length film, Chicken Run, for Stephen Spielberg's DreamWorks company, which will be released in cinemas in June.

webTitle: Man who led anti-Sartre revolt repents at length

fields.headline: Man who led anti-Sartre revolt repents at length
fields.standfirst: French writer Bernard-Henri Lévy reveals secret passion in new book
fields.trailText: Twenty years after his death, Jean-Paul Sartre has been raised to the status of "man of the century" by Bernard-Henri Lévy, the philosopher-showman who led the revolt against leftwing thinkers in the 1970s.
fields.body:
Twenty years after his death, Jean-Paul Sartre has been raised to the status of "man of the century" by Bernard-Henri Lévy, the philosopher-showman who led the revolt against leftwing thinkers in the 1970s.

His 650-page book, Le Siècle de Sartre, abounds with unsuspected enthusiasm for the guru of postwar existentialism, revealing a passion that Lévy, 51, admits to keeping secret for years.

"What is a great intellectual? The talent, or rather the ambition of Sartre?" he writes.

"His appetite. His insatiable curiosity. His incorruptible intellectual side. Philosophy of course, but also literature, journalism, reporting, theatre, songs, lectures, broadcasts and cinema."

Elsewhere he writes: "Sartre is the only [intellectual] of his generation with a unique energy which will never be found again in anyone else."

Although Lévy says that Sartre anticipated in a "vertiginous manner most of the theoretical inventions of Michel Foucault, Jacques Lacan and Gilles Deleuze", the admiration appears based largely on Sartre's ability to get things "outrageously wrong".

The book, in Lévy's words, is intended in part to explain how a "magnificent philosopher and master of freethinking" could become a sad communist fellow traveller and a friend of Maoists - one of the reasons why the young Lévy founded the upstart New Philosophers movement when still in his early twenties.

"Why was the man who invented all the anti-totalitarian inoculations unable to inoculate himself?" Lévy said in an interview with the leftwing Nouvel Observateur, which acts as a permanent shrine to all things Sartrean. "In the twilight of his life, Sartre decided to break everything up [by associating with the extreme left]. To the shock of his intellectual family, he dynamited Sartreism. He took a magnificent gamble on a new surge of youth."

Lévy explains for the first time why he originally shrugged off the masterthinker who was idolised by French youth before the war and well into the 60s.

"I belong to a generation which came of age at the beginning of the Sartrean desert," he said.

"At the end of the 60s it was unanimously accepted that Sartre's work was a humanist whim. In fact L'Etre et le néant, [Being and Nothingness] was the last real attempt at modern philosophy - an ultimate attempt to escape from Hegelianism."

Lévy's colourful activism in campaigns from the condemnation of totalitarian barbarism to a save-Bosnia crusade and beyond has brought him more media attention than his books, particularly since he married the American-born actress Arielle Dombasle. But his avowed determination to "come out" in his enthusiasm for Sartre's double career as thinker and novelist could revive a faltering cult.

"After 20 years, nothing much remains of Sartre other than cliches," Lévy said. "We must repair some immense injustices which see Sartre as the paragon of errors and the scapegoat for all sorts of 20th century madnesses. Hate has pursued him and the dirty jokes around the magnificent couple formed by Sartre and Simone de Beauvoir are pure infamy."

His praise for "this philosopher who so often got things wrong in a magisterial fashion" also extends to Sartre's novels, which have suffered much the same fall in popular interest as those of his contemporary and political adversary, André Malraux.

"La Nausée [Nausea], an absolute masterpiece, remains young and full of life," he said, predicting a revival for Sartre's novels to parallel a similar recent resurrection of Sartre's plays in Paris and Berlin.

fields.headline: Mirror Image by Danielle Steel
fields.standfirst:
(Corgi books, £5.99) digested in the style of the original in 400 words
Buy it from BOL
fields.trailText: Remember, sleepy reader, appearances can be deceptive. Identical twins can be completely different. Like a mirror-image. Just don't ask about the movie rights...
fields.body:
I am half the mirror as you will see. My name is Olivia and I am a beautiful, upper-crust twin. We are identical twins, Victoria and I. Not even our bewildered widower of a father can tell us apart. Even after 20 years. And in spite of our radically different personalities. And dress. And manner. And way of speaking. Some say he is blind or dumb or that it is a novelistic cliché anyway, but he really is dumbfounded by our sameness. Truly. If I keep on going, will you believe me? Seriously, I can say it again!

Daddy wanted his children to run his old steel mills for him but we're women and this is the early 20th century so all those petticoated, middle-class women's libbers haven't made any changes yet. Don't tell Victoria I said that - she's my other half, the racy, adventurous one. I am as timid and chaste as a virgin, she is as pure as the driven slush. I, one half of the mirror, she the other. M-i-r-r-o-r I-m-a-g-e. Do you see it now? Are you sure? I can spell it out if you wish, dear casual reader! She married the man I loved. Bitch. Daddy made her do it - she kept on having affairs with rich, handsome men. Which is fine in itself, but they were all married. Daddy said she'd scandalise the family name. So we tied her up and made her marry the most boring, backward, penny-pinching lawyer we could find. His wife had conveniently died on the Titanic. He didn't know what she was doing on it. Travelling to America by herself for God's sake! It's the stuff of trashy bestsellers, not the stuff of life. Anyway, Victoria could never quite suppress her rebellious urges - she attached herself to any passing project that demanded a leap of faith. She wanted to join that big war outside the window. It did look tremendous fun! So, tally-ho, off she went like a bullet. Of course, we couldn't tell papa or her husband so I took her place.

Our father dies (I watch him do so, fighting back the tears). We both fall pregnant - Victoria, the little demon, by another man. I give birth to twins (and yes, you guessed it, they're identical girls). But Victoria dies. What did you think this was - a bloody fairy-tale?

 And if you really are pressed: The digested read, digested Remember, sleepy reader, appearances can be deceptive. Identical twins can be completely different. Like a mirror-image. One wants to have babies by her twin sister's husband. Confused? You will be. Just don't ask about the movie rights...

webTitle: Research raises hopes of CJD cure

fields.headline: Research raises hopes of CJD cure
fields.trailText: Scientists have reported a discovery that could lead to the first effective treatment for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.
fields.body:
Scientists have reported a discovery that could lead to the first effective treatment for Creutzfeldt-Jakob disease.

The disease, which causes brain damage and is eventually fatal, has claimed an increasing number of victims in this country and is linked to the consumption of BSE-contaminated beef.

In experiments with mice, researchers identified a process that reverses the brain damage characteristic of CJD and related diseases such as BSE and scrapie in sheep, collectively known as transmittable spongiform encephalopathies.

These diseases occur when abnormal behaviour from nerve tissue proteins called prions destroy the brain by forming increased amounts of a protein structure called "beta-sheet". The research centres on a peptide - a protein component - that blocks beta-sheet formation.

Purified samples of abnormal prion protein taken from the brains of mice given scrapie, and people who had died from both sporadic and new variant CJD, were exposed to the peptide in a laboratory.

The international team of researchers also investigated whether the peptide altered the time it took for infected mice to show symptoms. They discovered that treatment with the peptide reversed the structure and properties of the dangerous prion to a form similar to the "safe" prion.

In the mouse studies, the peptide decreased infectivity by up to 95%, greatly delaying the onset of symptoms.

The research, led by Claudio Soto from New York University and Serono Pharmaceutical Research Institute in Switzerland, was reported in the Lancet medical journal.

Dr Soto said: "There is still a lot of work to be done before we can use these peptides in the actual treatment of the disease. However, this concept may represent a novel approach for the rational design of drugs that may prevent protein conformational changes implicated in a variety of diseases."

The same peptides have already been used to inhibit and reverse the formation of brain plaques in Alzheimer's disease.

webTitle: Bosnian Croats guilty of crimes against humanity

fields.headline: Bosnian Croats guilty of crimes against humanity
fields.standfirst: UN International Criminal Tribunal for the Former Yugoslavia
fields.trailText:
In a case hailed as a benchmark for future cases of ethnic
cleansing, a UN criminal tribunal today found five Bosnian
Croats guilty and acquitted one of crimes against humanity.
fields.body:
In a case hailed as a benchmark for future cases of ethnic cleansing, a UN criminal tribunal today found five Bosnian Croats guilty and acquitted one of crimes against humanity.

The UN tribunal for the former Yugoslavia handed down heavy sentences in connection to the massacre of Muslims in a central Bosnian village in April 1993. Presiding judge Antonio Cassese described how the rampage had resulted in the murder exclusively of Muslim inhabitants and the burning of 169 houses and two mosques. He said the "tragic episode" was aimed at expelling the Muslims from the village, just stopping short of the highest war crimes count of genocide.

"Indisputably, what happened on April 16, 1993, has gone down in history as comprising one of the most vicious illustrations of man's inhumanity to man," he said. "Today, the name of that small village must be added to the long list of previously unknown hamlets and towns that recall abhorrent misdeeds and make us shudder with horror and shame."

The judge sentenced the five - brothers Zoran and Mirjan Kupreskic, their cousin Vlatko Kupreskic, Drago Josipovic, and Vladimir Santic _ to jail terms ranging from six to 25 years for killing 116 Muslims, including 33 women and children. The defendants were all found guilty of persecution and some also of murder.

The five helped organise or took part in shelling and house-to-house attacks in the town of Ahmici-Santici as soldiers of the Croatia defence force (HVO) swept through the Lasva Valley from January to May 1993.

HVO soldiers, their faces painted black, burned houses, barns and livestock in the cold-blooded massacre. One witness in the case told how she stood on a balcony, her dead son below, as jeering Bosnian Croat soldiers told her to jump. The case against the six was one of the largest heard by the tribunal so far.

The sixth accused, Drago Papic, is to be released. The accused, the Kupreskic brothers in front, their co-defendants behind, were flanked by a coterie of lawyers and nine guards. Each accused, dressed in a suit, stood in turn as the rulings were delivered

The three trial judges heard testimony from 158 witnesses over 15 months, although little mention was made of the possible role of Croatian authorities. The full judgment, which comes just 10 days before Croatian presidential elections, ran to 340 pages.

Santic, commander of the notorious special purpose military police unit known as the Jokers, will face the longest sentence of 25 years. Judge Cassese said Santic had undoubtedly passed on the orders of his superiors and, by his presence, encouraged his subordinates.

"The Trial Chamber finds that the fact that you, Vladimir Santic, were in a position of command during the events in question lends an even greater magnitude to your responsibility," Judge Cassese said.

Prosecution spokesman Paul Risley said the trial had proved the first test of direct ethnic cleansing brought before the tribunal. "The verdict and the sentences set by the justices today," he said, "are a benchmark for future cases of ethnic cleansing that will be brought by the prosecutor."

fields.headline: What the US says
fields.trailText:
What Bill Gates says
"I'm returning to what I love most - focusing on technologies for the future. This was a personal decision, one I have discussed with Steve and our board of directors for some time. Although I've been able to spend more time on our technical strategy since naming Steve as president in July 1998, I felt that the opportunities for Microsoft were incredible, yet our structure wasn't optimal to really take advantage of them to the degree that we should. Steve's promotion will allow me to dedicate myself full-time to my passion -- building great software and strategizing on the future, and nurturing and collaborating with the core team helping Steve run the company."
The Microsoft press release

What Bill Gates says

Although I've been able to spend more time on our technical strategy since naming Steve as president in July 1998, I felt that the opportunities for Microsoft were incredible, yet our structure wasn't optimal to really take advantage of them to the degree that we should. Steve's promotion will allow me to dedicate myself full-time to my passion -- building great software and strategizing on the future, and nurturing and collaborating with the core team helping Steve run the company." The Microsoft press release

Why he stepped down
 Gates figured it was Ballmer's turn to pretend not to understand the Justice Department's questions.
 The cross-house commute from his bedroom to his home office had become too exhausting.
 Steve Case doesn't have to be CEO anymore and gets to be the visionary - why can't I?
Salon Magazine

Who is Steve Ballmer?
He's big, loud, funny and fearless. He's a hardball negotiator who never seems to give up or tire. And he's definitely not diplomatic. Soon after the Department of Justice filed its massive antitrust case against the company, Ballmer blurted out, "To heck with Janet Reno!" Though he later retracted the comment, the line became a symbol of Microsoft's attitude toward the government's attempts to rein it in. The Washington Post

The differences at the top
When Bill Gates says something outrageous or false, you get the distinct impression that he actually believes what he's saying. With Steve Ballmer, the new chief executive at Microsoft Corp., it's the opposite. The more off-the-wall the Ballmer remark, the more you can suspect he doesn't entirely buy it, either. That's just one of the differences between the two men, who are not peas in a pod despite their ultra-close working relationship and friendship for more than two decades. San Jose Mercury News

Ballmer never leaves doubt where he stands
During his years as the chief salesman for Microsoft Corp., Steve Ballmer's most important weapon has been his mouth. The problem is, sometimes he uses it to his own detriment. Like this past September when Ballmer was speaking before a gathering of business journalists in Seattle. Across town, Microsoft was announcing plans for an initial public offering of its online travel service to take advantage of the sky-high valuations of Internet stocks. At almost the same moment, Ballmer was helping drag them back to earth. "There's such an overvaluation of tech stocks that it's absurd,'' Ballmer told the Society of American Business Editors and Writers, responding to a question about business stories ignored by the news media. "I would put our company, and I would put most companies, in that category.'' Oops. San Jose Mercury News

Microsoft will not lose a step
That's the conclusion of about a dozen industry watchers - from VCs to CEOs to analysts - about Bill Gates's announcement on Thursday that he will step down as the company's chief executive officer. Some made light of the news. "I wonder if he's interested in being a CEO of another company - if he goes to a startup, I wouldn't mind investing in it," said Marc Andreessen, cofounder of Netscape and chairman and cofounder of stealth Internet startup Loudcloud. Other vocal Microsoft critics were notably silent: Oracle chairman and CEO Larry Ellison had "no comment." Red Herring

Weary Gates
Analysts conjectured that Gates may have grown weary of Microsoft's prolonged battle with the Justice Department, which accused the company of using its monopoly on operating systems to control the market for desktop software. Microsoft Windows runs nine of every ten PCs in the world. "The DOJ [Department of Justice] action took all the fun out of the job, and Gates wants to go out on a high point rather than a low point," said analyst Rob Enderle of Giga Information Group. The Washington Post The differences at the top When Bill Gates says something outrageous or false, you get the distinct impression that he actually believes what he's saying. With Steve Ballmer, the new chief executive at Microsoft Corp., it's the opposite. The more off-the-wall the Ballmer remark, the more you can suspect he doesn't entirely buy it, either. That's just one of the differences between the two men, who are not peas in a pod despite their ultra-close working relationship and friendship for more than two decades. San Jose Mercury News Ballmer never leaves doubt where he stands During his years as the chief salesman for Microsoft Corp., Steve Ballmer's most important weapon has been his mouth. The problem is, sometimes he uses it to his own detriment. Like this past September when Ballmer was speaking before a gathering of business journalists in Seattle. Across town, Microsoft was announcing plans for an initial public offering of its online travel service to take advantage of the sky-high valuations of Internet stocks. At almost the same moment, Ballmer was helping drag them back to earth. "There's such an overvaluation of tech stocks that it's absurd,'' Ballmer told the Society of American Business Editors and Writers, responding to a question about business stories ignored by the news media. "I would put our company, and I would put most companies, in that category.'' Oops. San Jose Mercury News Microsoft will not lose a step That's the conclusion of about a dozen industry watchers - from VCs to CEOs to analysts - about Bill Gates's announcement on Thursday that he will step down as the company's chief executive officer. Some made light of the news. "I wonder if he's interested in being a CEO of another company - if he goes to a startup, I wouldn't mind investing in it," said Marc Andreessen, cofounder of Netscape and chairman and cofounder of stealth Internet startup Loudcloud. Other vocal Microsoft critics were notably silent: Oracle chairman and CEO Larry Ellison had "no comment." Red Herring Weary Gates Analysts conjectured that Gates may have grown weary of Microsoft's prolonged battle with the Justice Department, which accused the company of using its monopoly on operating systems to control the market for desktop software. Microsoft Windows runs nine of every ten PCs in the world. "The DOJ [Department of Justice] action took all the fun out of the job, and Gates wants to go out on a high point rather than a low point," said analyst Rob Enderle of Giga Information Group. webTitle: What is the secret of your success, Comrade Hague?

fields.headline: What is the secret of your success, Comrade Hague?
fields.standfirst:
Tories in opposition: special report
Life in parliament: special report
fields.trailText: I popped down to No 4 Millbank, the building that is the real centre of our national debate now few people pay attention to the House of Commons.
fields.body:
I popped down to No 4 Millbank, the building that is the real centre of our national debate now few people pay attention to the House of Commons.

It's where the BBC, ITN, Sky and local broadcasting stations have their Westminster offices. Even when the chamber is deserted you can still find a clutch of senior politicians there, all desperate to be offered an appearance on Good Morning, Oswestry!

The draw yesterday was Ann Widdecombe, who has been presenting the Powerhouse political programme on ITN all week. She was to meet her own leader, William Hague, in what was billed as "an exclusive interview - his first of the year".

I am full of admiration for Ann Widdecombe. Working in a political world that prefers appearance to reality, image to substance, she sticks by her convictions. I don't like many of her convictions, but that is not the point.

This is a woman who refused to change her underwear as instructed by Tory central office. What you see is what you get. If she had a spin doctor, he would have been long ago struck off by the BMA.

However, when it comes to gritty, no-holds-barred, in-your-face interviews, she will not have had Jeremy Paxman too worried.

Indeed, as I felt obliged to tell her towards the end of the programme, I was reminded of those interviews conducted by the late Robert Maxwell with various east European apparatchiks.

"Tell me, President Ceausescu, what is the secret of your great popularity?" he would probe. Or: "Just why are the people of Albania so content, President Hoxha?"

Of course, Mr Hague is no blood-soaked tyrant. But he can't have been any more fearful than they were. Soon afterwards, the Labour party jubilantly published a transcript of Miss Widdecombe's less than pitiless questions.

"Thank you for joining us," she began. "I'm very pleased to be here," he shot back.

"Last year we had quite a good year in terms of election results," she insisted. "Yet we've still got our critics, particularly over keeping the pound. Does that matter?"

Mr Hague felt that, on balance, it didn't. "We are sticking up for the British people. You go round sticking up for the British people yourself," he confessed.

"You've been setting out your vision of the Conservative party, I have to say, a vision that I think will encourage people," she rapped.

We leaned forward to see if the sweat was pouring from his face as he chased after these blasts to the boundary. He must have felt like Andre Agassi facing Pete Sampras with the score two sets all.

"Yesterday Tony Blair described Blairism as winning elections. What's Hagueism?"

Phew. Luckily the young leader had an answer ready for that toughie. "I want to win elections in order to govern. He wants to govern in order to win elections."

Like Monty Python's Cardinal Fang from the Spanish Inquisition ("Bring on the comfy chair!") she was pitiless. "One of our traditional areas has been law and order, but we see Jack Straw making quite a sizeable mess of that, don't we?"

As if stretched on the rack, he choked out the words: "Our response to that would be put in a much better home secretary, which is why I hope you will do that, unless you're going to go into full-time TV presentation, which you also do very well."

I don't want to mock too much, and Miss Widdecombe did admit afterwards that she had been pretty fearful about the interview, knowing how it might look. But of course most politicians would love to be grilled like that every time. Thirty years ago, they always were.

Next week, Alastair Campbell's merciless quizzing of Tony Blair. Followed by David Dimbleby asking his brother: "Tell me, please, what is the secret of your dazzling success, Jonathan?"

webTitle: Indonesia arms ban to be lifted

fields.headline: Indonesia arms ban to be lifted
fields.standfirst:
Human rights campaigners angry at decision say militia groups are still terrorising refugees
Indonesia and East Timor: special report
fields.trailText: Britain and its EU partners are to resume arms sales to Indonesia, the government announced yesterday, in a move which enraged human rights groups and anti-arms trade campaigners.
fields.body:
Britain and its EU partners are to resume arms sales to Indonesia, the government announced yesterday, in a move which enraged human rights groups and anti-arms trade campaigners.

John Battle, the foreign office minister, made it clear that the EU arms embargo, imposed four months ago in response to the atrocities in East Timor, will be allowed to lapse on January 17.

"It would require absolute unanimity of every single country in the EU to actually extend it further," he said. "East Timor has been positively sorted and there is not, I don't think, the will to extend the embargo." Mr Battle, who is to visit Indonesia and east Timor next week, said there had been a new election and there was now a civilian defence minister, a minister for human rights and their claim to East Timor had been relinquished.

"If you look back a year ago the situation has been transformed politically," he said. "What we believe is that we need now to be underpinning rather than undermining Indonesia at this important time, helping build Indonesia's young democracy."

However, his remarks with the clear implication that Britain would resume its lucrative arms trade with Indonesia, was sharply attacked by human rights groups who pointed out that Indonesian forces had failed to disarm militia groups which were still terrorising up to 170,000 East Timorese refugees trapped in West Timor. They also pointed out that British-made Saladin armoured cars were being used in attacks in Ambon, provincial capital of the Maluku islands, where inter-communal violence between Christians and Muslims have led to over 1,000 deaths over the past year.

Tapol, the Indonesian human rights campaign, said yesterday that on Boxing Day after a Christian church was brunt down, people were reported to be dancing on top of the British armoured cars. "It is a very bad development," Carmen Budiardjo, Tapol's director, said last night reacting to Mr Battle's comments.

Indonesian forces were stull refusing to colloborate with UN investigations into atrocities in East Timor. Dave Holland, of Saferworld, an independent research group, described Mr Battle's remarks as "inappropriate". It was premature to lift the embargo, he said.

A secret assessment by Australian defence intelligence was reported last month as stating that extending the embargo would help to prevent the Indonesian army oversee internal repression.

Lifting the embargo could open the way to the supply of seven remaining British Aerospace Hawk aircarft to Indonesia. Of the 16 Hawks approved by the previous Conservative administration for sale to Indonesia, nine were supplied last year.

Britain supplied over £70m worth of arms to Indonesia in 1988, according to the latest official figures. They included 38 armoured combat vehicles despite government guidelines stating that arms would not be exported if they were likely to be used in internal repression.

Foreign office sources said any applicants for weapon sales would still have to go through strict licensing controls and Indonesia would still be closely watched to see if there were any future human rights abuses. They said Indonesia would be "on notice" but it was important not to undermine the new government led by president Abdurrhaman Wahid.

Mr Battle plans to see the refugee situation at first hand and also hold talks with groups helping to build the shattered region. "I am told that there is not a brick standing upon a brick, the place was absolutely flattened," he said yesterday.

In Indonesia, he said, there had been a new election and there was now a civilian defence minister, a minister for human rights and their claim to East Timor had been relinquished.

webTitle: Millennium wheel - all capsules need new clutches

fields.headline: Millennium wheel - all capsules need new clutches
fields.standfirst:
Official London Eye site
The London Eye webcam
fields.trailText: Alterations are having to be made to all 32 passenger-carrying capsules on the delay-hit millennium wheel, it was disclosed today.
fields.body:
Alterations are having to be made to all 32 passenger-carrying capsules on the delay-hit millennium wheel, it was disclosed today.

But the £35m wheel - officially known as the British Airways London Eye - is still expected to be open to the paying public on the new scheduled date of February 1.

Problems with a German-built clutch on one of the capsules prevented the 450ft-high River Thames attraction from starting as planned on new year's eve. BA said today that tests had shown that clutches on all the capsules needed to be replaced - a job that should be completed next week.

"There is no problem with the design of the clutch. This has been a manufacturing fault," said a BA spokeswoman. "We are hoping to operate preview rides this month, ahead of the February 1 opening date."

BA had planned to take competition-winning guests on a ride on new year's eve after the official opening of the wheel by prime minister Tony Blair.

But the clutch problem led the Health and Safety Executive to rule against the start of operations. Instead, guests were given a champagne dinner and free BA flights. They will also be given a free ride on the wheel when it opens.

webTitle: Virus warning: forward to everyone you know

fields.headline: Virus warning: forward to everyone you know
fields.trailText: There is a new virus going around, called "work". If you receive any sort of "work" at all, whether via email, internet or simply handed to you by a colleague...DO NOT OPEN IT.
fields.body:
There is a new virus going around, called "work". If you receive any sort of "work" at all, whether via email, internet or simply handed to you by a colleague...DO NOT OPEN IT.

Work has been circulating around our building for months and those who have been tempted to open "work" or even look at "work" have found that their social life is deleted and their brain ceases to function properly.

If you do encounter "work" via email or are faced with any "work" at all, then to purge the virus, send an email to your boss with the words "Sorry...I'm off to the pub". The "work" should automatically be deleted from your brain.

If you receive "work" in paper-document form, simply lift the document and drag the "work" to your garbage can. Put on your coat and skip to the nearest bar with two friends and order three pints of beer. After repeating this action 14 times, you will find that "work" will no longer be of any relevance to you.

Send this message to everyone in your address book. If you do not have anyone in your address book, then I'm afraid the "work" virus has already corrupted your life.
