webTitle: Moore signs up with Sixth Sense director

fields.headline: Moore signs up with Sixth Sense director
fields.standfirst: Also today, Edward Norton expresses interest in Howard Hughes biopic | Laziness rules my life, says Allen | Oscar best visual effects nominations announced | Parker steers clear from Commitments sequel | In brief | and the latest casting news
fields.trailText: Also today, Edward Norton expresses interest in Howard Hughes biopic | Laziness rules my life, says Allen | Oscar best visual effects nominations announced | Parker steers clear from Commitments sequel | In brief | and the latest casting news
fields.body:
Julianne Moore is to star in Unbreakable, M Night Shyamalan's follow-up to The Sixth Sense. Shooting is scheduled to start in April in Philadelphia; Moore will be playing opposite Shyamalan regular Bruce Willis, as well as Samuel L Jackson.

The writer-director describes Unbreakable as "an old-style suspense movie in which suspense unravels and bizarre things come into play.'' Willis plays the sole survivor of a large accident, with Jackson's character proposing an explanation of why he survived. Moore, meanwhile, will play Willis' wife, a physical therapist.

"Julianne is on a very short list of naturalistic actresses working in the business,'' Shyamalan told Daily Variety. "She is able to emote and really connect with audiences, and will be a great match with Bruce. Julianne adds a lot of class to the project.''

Norton interest in Hughes biopic

A new actor and director team has emerged as another contender for the great Howard Hughes film-off. Mr Showbiz reports that rising star Edward Norton, last seen in The Fight Club, is looking at a project to play the movie-mogul billionaire, coached by two-time Oscar winner Milos Forman.

They're up against heavyweight contenders Leonardo DiCaprio and Michael Mann, whose project has long been set up at Disney, not to mention that Warren Beatty has also expressed an interest in producing a biopic of the late, eccentric Hughes. A version with Johnny Depp as the one-time head of RKO has apparently been sidelined.

Scott Alexander and Larry Karaszewski, who scripted the biopics Man on the Moon and The People vs Larry Flynt for Forman, and are currently working on one about the Marx Brothers, confirm they've been approached about the Hughes project.

Laziness rules my life, says Allen

In an interview with online newspaper the Nando Times, Woody Allen shatters his painstaking auteur image.

"If the choice was between getting another angle in a shot or going home and watching the Knicks on television, I'd go home and not do the shot," he says.

"You'll notice in my films so often in the last 20 years, I do everything in one shot. People say it's a 'style'. But it's not a style. It's laziness. If I'm doing a conversation, I'd rehearse it with the cameraman and shoot it at 4 o'clock and it would be over."

If you're blessed with a good script and cast, reckons Allen, an assistant director or competent cameraman could make the film. "I want to eat leisurely at lunch. I want to come home at 6 o'clock at night and not at 10 o'clock. I was not so dedicated," he says.

Read the full interview here

Oscar nominations for nominations

The stage was set yesterday for a turbo-charged race for the best visual effects Oscar as the Motion Picture Academy shortlisted the seven films that will compete for the three nomination slots.

The films, selected by the executive branch of the visual effects committee, are The Matrix, The Mummy, Star Wars: Episode I, Sleepy Hollow, Stuart Little, Wild Wild West and The World Is Not Enough.

Parker not ready to recommit

While fending off criticism about his latest film, Angela's Ashes, Alan Parker has said he will not be directing the forthcoming sequel to his first Irish literary adaptation, The Commitments.

Although a screenplay is in development, the outspoken director has said neither he nor the author Roddy Doyle were involved in the project and that a follow-up would be like "putting a wart on a pretty face".

In brief

 Kenneth Branagh is to be rewarded for his services to Shakespeare. The actor, who has adapted five Shakespeare plays for the cinema - including the forthcoming 30s musical version of Love's Labour's Lost - will be presented with the prestigious Gielgud Award on Saturday.

 Catherine Zeta-Jones seems to be constantly changing her mind about where she wants to wed Michael Douglas, according to the star's younger brother. In an interview for this week's Now magazine, Douglas Jr says: "Catherine's changed her mind about every 30 minutes since Michael proposed." Apparently, the 30-year-old Welsh rose has veered between Majorca, California and a tiny chapel near her South Wales home as her choice of ideal location. The movie world holds its breath

 The Lord of the Rings movie official site, Theonering.net, carries some new pictures from the New Zealand set. Hardcore fans only can check out off-duty Black Riders and on-duty Liv Tyler.

 The much anticipated pairing of Madonna and Rupert Everett playing ill-matched parents in The Next Best Thing is due out in the US in March. The trailer has just gone online; view it here.

Casting couch

 According to a Sony insider who has spilt the beans to SpidermanHype.com, Jason Schwartzman (Rushmore), Wes Bentley (American Beauty) and Nicholas Brendon (from Buffy: The Vampire Slayer) are all in the running to become the new Spiderman.

 Billy Bob Thornton has dropped out of Columbia Pictures' The Shipping News. The actor was expected to star in and direct the adaptation, but it seems he will instead helm Cinderella Man, the Depression-era true story of boxer Jim Braddock, who became a national hero.

Lord Winston, the fertility pioneer and Labour supporter, is disillusioned with the government's stewardship of a deteriorating NHS, believing the public has been deceived and medical care is "deeply unsatisfactory" for many people.

In a devastating interview in this week's New Statesman magazine, the peer, who takes the Labour whip in the Lords, tells of his professional frustration and his personal experience of the failings of the NHS that his party promised to reform.

His 87-year-old mother, a diabetic, was admitted to hospital a few weeks ago. "She waited 13 hours in casualty before getting a bed in a mixed-sex ward - a place we said we would abolish. None of her drugs were given on time, she missed meals and she was found lying on the floor when the morning staff came on," he said. "She caught an infection and now has a leg ulcer."

He acknowledges that his mother's predicament is not unusual. "It is normal. The terrifying thing is that we accept it," he said.

Lord Winston is one of Britain's best-known doctors and has regularly been outspoken in the past in his areas of expertise - in vitro fertilisation, over which he presides at his clinic in Hammersmith hospital, west London, and genetic screening of embryos for diseases such as cystic fibrosis.

But he has long been close to 10 Downing Street - in the interview he reveals Cherie Blair will have her fourth child by a caesarean delivery - and has never before expressed such profound disillusion with the Labour party.

In his own field, reproductive medicine, he admits to "inevitable disappointment" that Labour had failed to translate encouraging noises in opposition into more funding for treating the childless.

"The truth is that our services are much the worst in Europe. There are fewer IVF treatment cycles under this government than there were under the Tories.

"That is a pretty uncomfortable feeling for someone who takes the Labour whip in the Lords, who has tried to run an NHS service for 20 years. One could not be anything but unhappy about that," he says.

Labour's health reforms, he believes, have eroded specialist care, failed to eradicate the internal market put in place by the Tories and offered a cash provision that is "not as good as Poland's".

"We still have an internal market, but instead of commissioning by local health authorities, we have primary care groups. I think we've been quite deceitful about it.

"We haven't told the truth, and I'm afraid there will come a time when it will be impossible to disguise the inequality of the health service from the general population.

"We gave categorical promises that we would abolish the internal market. We have not done that. Our reorganisation of the health service was very bad. We have made medical care deeply unsatisfactory for a lot of people.

"We've always had this right but monolithic view that there should be equality throughout the nation at the point of delivery. All very good stuff, but it isn't working."

He believes that changes to the way the NHS is funded are necessary - either through more taxes or through an insurance system.

"Do we want a health service that is steadily going to deteriorate and be more and more rationed and will be inferior on vital areas such as heart disease and cancer compared to our less well-off neighbours? That is where we are going at the moment.

"If we don't want that, then we pay more tax or have an insurance system. I see no alternative. There is a lot wrong with the health service and no one is prepared to say so."

He adds: "I shouldn't really be saying these things to you now."

Asked if he considers healthcare worse than it was under the Tories, he replies: "It's just gradually deteriorating because we blame everything on the previous government."

But he does not blame Tony Blair. The prime minister does not know the scale of the problems, he suggests.

"I don't think he's been informed about what's happening," says Lord Winston. "I think there is a conspiracy of silence. I don't believe he would allow this. I think he is a good man. I don't think he realises how frustrated we are."

fields.headline: The NHS
fields.standfirst: Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: When was it set up?
fields.body:
When was it set up?

In 1948 Labour's Aneurin Bevan established the National Health Service to provide free, state-run, health care for all, a crucial part of the welfare state.

Why all the talk of crisis?

Every winter, bed shortages in the NHS provoke a spate of stories about a worsening 'crisis'. This year is no exception. On Sunday, it was reported that there were fewer than 30 emergency hospital beds free across the entire country. Lurid accounts of chaotic emergency wards and crammed morgues abound.

Why are hospitals short of beds?

Hospitals now operate at close to full capacity. A decade ago, around 75% of beds in emergency wards were regularly occupied. Today, more than 95% are.

The shortage of emergency beds can be traced to a lack of money and related 'efficiency savings'. London has lost 40% of its acute beds since 1982, a figure that is reflected nationally.

What are the reasons?

There are broadly three theories. First, the government blames the bed shortages and cancelled operations on the current outbreak of flu, which they say has reached epidemic proportions, a claim refuted by the Birmingham research unit which collates flu figures.

Second, the structure of the NHS is said to be responsible: either too hierarchical and rigid, or hampered by an expensive and inefficient internal market, according to different critics.

Third, "the problem is money," as one consultant recently wrote. It is echoed by many doctors in the NHS and by Stephen Thornton, chief executive of the NHS Confederation, who has called for more funding to stop the same problems recurring next year.

Is the NHS under-funded?

The NHS is deep in debt. Mr Thornton estimates that the NHS's deficit will reach £300-400m by the end of the financial year. A national audit office report last May reported an underlying deficit of £717m, putting the total NHS debt at nearly £1bn.

The government stuck to the Tory spending plans it inherited for the first two years of this parliament, but its spending review last summer gave the NHS an extra £21bn over three years. At an average 4.7% above inflation, it is the most generous increase for six years, but this extra spending hasn't filtered through to the NHS yet.

Critics argue that it won't solve the current crisis, pointing out that Britain spends 1% less of its GDP on health than the international average, equivalent to some £9 billion a year.

Are the Tories to blame?

The 1991 NHS reforms saw the introduction of the 'internal market' to the NHS. The Conservative government made healthcare providers such as hospitals compete for business from doctors and regional health authorities. Doctors could become 'fundholders', 'buying' the most cost-efficient service for their patients. Opponents of the scheme have criticised it for causing inequality in health care, as patients treated by profitable, fund-holding doctors could get better services "bought" for them than patients of poor practices or non-fundholding doctors.

What is Labour doing now?

Labour promised in its manifesto to "raise spending on the NHS in real terms every year" and abolish the internal market.

It has also continued to use the Conservatives' rhetoric of creating more consumer choice, bringing NHS care closer to the customer. The NHS Direct telephone and internet service aims to provide people with basic diagnosis and health advice without them visiting a doctor or hospital.

As part of this vision, the government's 1999 health act will introduce primary care trusts across England this spring.

What are primary care trusts?

Primary care trusts will be autonomous, statutory bodies run by GPs, nurses and other health professionals, handling annual budgets of at least £60m.

They will offer services such as high street health centres and more convenient day surgery, providing more flexible healthcare that also reduces the strain on hospitals.

What do the critics say?

Many doctors argue that primary care trusts may treat local needs with more sensitivity, but will be powerless to improve the health service because they won't have the funds.

They say the public is more concerned with waiting 18 months for an operation than being unable to get telephone advice or see a doctor in the evening. And Labour has notably back-tracked from its manifesto commitment to reduce hospital waiting lists by 100,000.

What alternatives are there?

Alan Milburn has suggested the previously unmentionable idea of hypothecated taxes - taxes which directly go to the NHS. It could be a way to get the public to accept higher taxation on, for example, tobacco and alcohol.

Alternatively, Michael Portillo has suggested that NHS under-funding will remain as long as it is dependent on taxation. In the Netherlands over 80% of total expenditure comes from health insurance. Only about 10% comes from taxes. In the UK 85% of health spending comes from public expenditure. However, funding the NHS through a new health insurance might simply be a tax by other means.

Will the NHS ever be out of "crisis"?

There are several fundamental problems. Treatments and drugs are improving all the time and becoming more expensive. More people are living longer. And expectations of good health and care are rising all the time.

The NHS has done well to increase its supply. Between 1976 and 1998, the number of prescriptions dispensed rose from 309 million to 505 million, while the number of patients per doctor has fell from 2,400 to 1,900.

Sooner or later, people may have to accept that a state-of-the-art NHS requires noticeable increases in taxation of one sort or another. The risk remains that the affluent will simply choose private healthcare instead of the NHS and then object to having to fund a poor service for poor people.

webTitle: Gates to face bumpy road ahead

fields.headline: Gates to face bumpy road ahead
fields.standfirst: Mark Tran examines the options for Microsoft and its founder
fields.trailText: Microsoft chairman Bill Gates is the computer age's version of John D Rockefeller, history's first billionaire, whose Standard Oil company once controlled 90% of the US oil industry.
fields.body:
Microsoft chairman Bill Gates is the computer age's version of John D Rockefeller, history's first billionaire, whose Standard Oil company once controlled 90% of the US oil industry.

Rockefeller's empire was broken up after a marathon antitrust battle and a similar fate appears to be in store for Microsoft, the first company to be worth $500bn thanks to its dominance of operating systems.

In yielding the position of chief executive to his close friend, the rumbustious Steve Ballmer, Mr Gates will remain chairman of the company he co-founded with Paul Allen 25 years ago. He says he will focus on technology - his first love - as the company's top software architect.

Warren Buffett, one of the world's most successful investors and a close friend, attributes Mr Gates's decision to a desire to get away from the daily grind. "I've seen this coming but I wasn't sure when it would happen," Mr Buffett told the Washington Post. Each year the two men get together for a "think week" to reflect. Mr Buffett believes this is when Mr Gates appears most at peace. "I think Bill was ready to turn think weeks into think years," Mr Buffett said.

But still only 44, it is hard to think of Mr Gates withdrawing completely from an industry he helped transform. A more likely explanation is that Mr Gates is preparing himself for the next phase in Microsoft's existence: its break-up. What seemed unthinkable when the government started its landmark antitrust case against the software giant is being increasingly mooted at the Justice Department.

Mr Gates brought this upon himself, mounting an unconvincing defence that his company was not a monopoly. He came across as arrogant, evasive and less than truthful. The US government has two options, breaking Microsoft into three, corresponding to the parts already used for internal accounting, or dividing the company into an operating systems company and a software company.

In stepping down and appointing himself as chief software architect, Mr Gates has positioned himself to head a company focused exclusively on the Windows operating system, leaving Mr Ballmer to lead the software side of Microsoft. Although he may shed some tears at the break-up of the company he created, Mr Gates is well aware of the contrasting fortunes of IBM and AT&T, two giants that tangled with the antitrust authorities.

IBM won the battle but lost the war. The computer giant saw off the government in a decade-long battle, but was a spent force as a result and lost billions of dollars in the 1980s. AT&T, the telecommunications monopoly was broken up into regional phone companies, which are now key players, along with the original AT&T.

Mr Gates does not want to travel down the road taken by IBM and as the head of a smaller Microsoft entity, the former Harvard University dropout could rediscover the thrill of leading a nimbler company at the technological cutting edge. Strong as he is as a business, Mr Gates remains a geek at heart and he would rather try to discover new technological toys.

The ruthless Rockefeller never called Standard Oil a monopoly, referring to it as the result of "financial cooperation". Likewise, Mr Gates insisted Microsoft was not a monopoly although it controlled 90% of the world's PC operating systems. But the US government was right to describe Microsoft as a monopoly. Mr Gates, the richest man in the world with a fortune of about $90bn, should thank those pesky government lawyers for injecting a lumbering giant with new vigour.

fields.headline: Winston's finest hour
fields.standfirst:
Derek Brown on the fertility expert made Labour peer who has slated the government for its failure to reform the NHS
Plus: The man from the Pru
fields.trailText: Lord Winston, the Labour life peer and fertility treatment specialist, has launched a devastating attack on the government's stewardship of the National Health Service. Writing in today's New Statesman, he accuses his own party of failing to dismantle the Tories' dismal internal market reforms and starving the service of funds.
fields.body:
Lord Winston, the Labour life peer and fertility treatment specialist, has launched a devastating attack on the government's stewardship of the National Health Service. Writing in today's New Statesman, he accuses his own party of failing to dismantle the Tories' dismal internal market reforms and starving the service of funds.

"We haven't told the truth, and I'm afraid there will come a time when it will be impossible to disguise the inequality of the health service from the general population," he says.

Winston's excoriating attack is all the more embarrassing for the government as he is close to Tony Blair, who gave him his peerage. Damning the prime minister with faint praise, he says that his friend is not responsible for the downward slide of the NHS.

"I don't think he's been informed about what's happening," he says. "I think there is a conspiracy of silence. I don't believe he would allow this. I think he is a good man. I don't think he realises how frustrated we are."

Health secretary Alan Milburn was wheeled out this morning to reply to Lord Winston's criticism. And a pretty feeble reply it was. "Of course there are inequalities and we are busy addressing those," he told the BBC Today programme.

"Nobody pretends we can turn round the National Health Service overnight; we have never actually made that claim. What we have consistently said is that to turn round the National Health Service and to give the country the NHS that is fit for the 21st century will take 10 years."

Milburn is a skilful droner of the party line. He trots out dreary numbers to show how much more this government is spending compared with the last, as if that proves or promises anything. He fails, though, to address the nub of Winston's argument, which is that the whole issue of NHS funding needs to be reassessed, on the basis of need rather than affordability.

Essentially, Winston is urging that the service be underpinned by higher taxation or by an insurance system. Instead of getting whatever the treasury deems appropriate year by year, it would then be able to plan ahead for likely demand, rather than its perpetual make-do-and-mend approach.

The debate over the mechanics of funding is vital, but dry. Much more immediately telling is Winston's appallingly succinct account of what recently happened to his 87-year-old mother, a diabetic, when she was admitted to hospital. "She waited 13 hours in casualty before getting a bed in a mixed sex ward - a place we said we would abolish. None of her drugs were given on time, she missed meals, and she was found lying on the floor when the morning staff came on."

Winston notes, laconically, that such tales are not unusual. "It is normal. The terrifying thing is that we accept it," he says. He is quite right. Most of us cherish the idea that our health service is free and civilised, when it is neither. We rightly honour the heroic service of doctors and nurses, but very few of us can claim to have had truly excellent treatment.

All of us have heard tales of or experienced unavailable ambulances, horrendous waiting lists and cancelled operations, peremptory treatment by harassed staff, and crowded, even dirty conditions. We know in our guts - sometimes literally - that the edifice is crumbling, and that no amount of clever number-crunching will patch it up.

The New Statesman

The man from the Pru

Sir Peter Davies, writes Julia Finch, chief executive of insurance giant Prudential, has been drafted in to replace Dino Adriano as boss of the ailing Sainsburys supermarket chain. He will be paid £750,000 a year, but stands to bank up to £8m from cheap share options if he boosts the groups standing in the competitive UK grocery market and in the process increases its share price.

Sir Peter, who is a marketing man rather than an insurance expert, worked for Sainsbury's for 10 years between 1976 and 1986 - the period of the chain's high-street supremacy - and was the groups first ever marketing director. He quit when the top job went to a member of the Sainsbury family and took charge of the giant Reed publishing empire, which then used to publish a stable of top consumer magazines including Woman and Womans Own.

He joined the Pru five years ago after a boardroom bust-up at Reed, walking away from the publisher with a near record pay-off at the time of £2.8m. At the Pru he has masterminded a revival of its core insurance business and the launch of the market-leading Egg internet bank. Opera and ballet fan Sir Peter - who starred in his own Man from the Pru TV adverts - is reckoned by City analysts to be a good bet for the supermarkets group.

Sir Peter, who is a marketing man rather than an insurance expert, worked for Sainsbury's for 10 years between 1976 and 1986 - the period of the chain's high-street supremacy - and was the groups first ever marketing director. He quit when the top job went to a member of the Sainsbury family and took charge of the giant Reed publishing empire, which then used to publish a stable of top consumer magazines including Woman and Womans Own. He joined the Pru five years ago after a boardroom bust-up at Reed, walking away from the publisher with a near record pay-off at the time of £2.8m. At the Pru he has masterminded a revival of its core insurance business and the launch of the market-leading Egg internet bank. Opera and ballet fan Sir Peter - who starred in his own Man from the Pru TV adverts - is reckoned by City analysts to be a good bet for the supermarkets group. Useful link J Sainsbury plc

webTitle: Wisden Australia makes its second appearance

fields.headline: Wisden Australia makes its second appearance
fields.trailText: Wisden Australia was first published in 1998, to widespread acclaim. The second edition was recently launched in Australia, and is now available in the UK.
fields.body:
Wisden Australia was first published in 1998, to widespread acclaim. The second edition was recently launched in Australia, and is now available in the UK.

The 1999 edition focuses on all aspects of Australian cricket, both at home and on tour, including their successes in the recent Ashes series and the World Cup.

Published in the traditional Wisden format, the lead articles include tributes to Mark Taylor on his retirement, and the green and gold colours on their centenary.

The book also features comprehensive profiles of all current Australian first-class cricketers, plus match reports and scorecards from the 1998-99 Sheffield Shield.

fields.headline: The guzzler
fields.trailText: by Matthew Fort
fields.body:
Quick bites.... where to eat out in under 15 minutes

Caffe Umbria
108 Heath Street, NW3. Tel: 0171-431 4969

A fine bit of Med sunshine food in gastro-benighted Hampstead. Long and thin, like a good many of the customers. Blond on blond wood, like ditto. Sound pedigree (from same stable as the long-serving Vasco & Piero's Pavilion, originally above Academy Cinema in Oxford Street - ah, those were the days - now in Poland Street). Eat light: olives, slices of salami, bread, grilled cuttlefish, rocket and tomato salad for under the statutory £15 a head. Or eat hearty: pasta, meat and fish plus terrif wines for just over, then go and walk it off on the heath. The place is ever so child-friendly, but it does have odd opening times - most evenings and most of the weekend - so ring and check first.

Cheapskate... where to eat out for under £15

Lunch
Exmouth Market, EC1 Tel: 0171-278 2420

On those rare days when Guardian drones are able to drag themselves away from our beloved canteen, they could do a heck of a lot worse that totter out to Lunch which is just up the road. Take out a disposable version of the bento box complete with soup, sarnies, stuffed bagels, flat breads rolled round various animal and/or vegetable fillings and very much above average salads. There's also a variety of mezze or falafel, hummous and couscous. You can stay in and eat the same from a non-disposable bento box equivalent. A mite post-modernist, perhaps, but small, perfectly formed, friendly, functional and, well, rather funky. The price is right, too, ie reasonable to cheap.

On the menu: sorghum

What is it? It's a cereal

Sort of like Puffed Wheat, you mean? Not exactly. More like the next hot pulse. A close relative of millet, sorghum is used as food for humans in Africa and India, and food for animals elswhere. But it's packed with high fibre and loads of other goodies.

Does it taste fab? It hardly tastes at all, but it does have a nice soft, nutty texture.

What do I do with it? Cook it like rice. Or ferment it to make beer. Or stew it to a syrup, but that's a hard pounding.

Cyberfood
www.dominos.co.uk

Admittedly, phoning for a pizza was never too tricky, but Domino's has gone online, offering deliveries from all of its 190 stores.

Pros: Expected delivery times flash up before you order. There is nutritional info and a picture for most of the grub, and all Domino's food is proudly announced to be GM-free. Arrived piping hot.

Cons: Lack of human confirmation of your order can make for an uncertain wait - after the promised 40 minutes had passed, we resorted to phoning the store, which made the whole venture rather pointless.

fields.headline: Pretend you know all about...
fields.standfirst: Poste
fields.trailText: Poste
fields.body:
While shoe fetishism is almost ubiquitous among the female of the species, Richard Wharton, buying director of Office, admits: "The average lad doesn't give a s*** about shoes." Not that this has stopped him opening Poste, a shop that promises to breathe new life into men's footwear. Poste, Wharton says, is "nowhere near the mainstream. But there are discerning men out there. I know guys with a hundred pairs of sneakers and they are not being catered for."

Despite the high-fashion clientele, Wharton insists Poste will be a comfortable place to be, to sit and read the paper: "A bit like Steptoe and Son's yard."

Around 80% of Poste's stock will be classic, smart shoes by Donna Karan and Paul Smith; casual styles by Camper, Clarks, Snipe, Birkenstock; hard-to-find Japanese and Italian labels; and "quirky touches like Moroccan slippers". The other 20% will be trainers, for which the buying policy will be "very, very selective". Alongside selected new styles, such as the three-colour Nike Air Rift, will be rare and vintage trainers: "Like Nike Huraches from 10 years ago. If we get six pairs of something, six people who know what they're about will buy them and be really happy. Though obviously we're not going to make much money from selling six pairs of shoes."

 Poste will open at 10 South Molton St, London W1 on January 24.

fields.headline: Most everywhere
fields.standfirst: Men in scarves
fields.trailText: Men in scarves
fields.body: It's a delicate area, this. It's not that all men look stupid in scarves. Football scarves, for instance have immunity from fashion cattiness. The tucked-under-the-lapel-of the-overcoat look, as sported by Ken Livingstone and my dad, I've no problem with. Wrapping the whole scarf round your neck with the ends tucked in, as threatening looking 15-year-olds do, I can see is a practical compromise if you're too hard to wear a coat but still live with your mum. The key is to avoid unnecessary flapping: you might imagine flinging one end over your shoulder in a carefree fashion makes you look dashing in a 40s fighter pilot kind of way, but in reality you look like a Brideshead Revisited throwback who's lost his punt. Take it off or tuck it in, OK?

webTitle: Bill Gates steps down as Microsoft chief executive

fields.headline: Bill Gates steps down as Microsoft chief executive
fields.standfirst: What the US makes of the move
fields.trailText: Microsoft founder Bill Gates is to step down as chief executive of the software giant, promoting Microsoft president and close friend Steve Ballmer to the post.
fields.body:
Microsoft founder Bill Gates is to step down as chief executive of the software giant, promoting Microsoft president and close friend Steve Ballmer to the post.

Mr Gates, who will remain chairman and take a new title of chief software architect, said he was giving up the CEO title so he could return "to what I love most, focusing on technologies for the future."

Microsoft has made Mr Gates the wealthiest private individual in the world, with a fortune estimated at over $80bn.

Yesterday's announcement does not necessarily mean he is giving up any power in the company he co-founded in 1975 with Paul Allen.

Mr Gates said he planned to dedicate his time to fashioning and promoting the "next generation" of Microsoft's flagship product, the Windows 2000 operating system.

He said he particularly wants to develop software services that will be hosted on the internet and made part of future versions of Windows.

Microsoft is working to make its popular software, especially its Office suite of business programs, available over the internet, in addition to the traditional way of loading it onto individual personal computers.

"Steve's promotion will allow me to dedicate myself full time to my passion - building great software and strategizing on the future and nurturing and collaborating with the core team helping Steve run the company," Mr Gates said.

Mr Ballmer will retain his title of president. He also will be given a seat on Microsoft's board of directors.

"I'm certainly honoured and very, very excited about the opportunity," Mr Ballmer said.

Mr Ballmer, like Mr Gates, has already staked out a position against breaking up the company, a possible remedy which may be sought by the federal government and 19 states that are suing Microsoft over alleged antitrust violations.

"I think it would be absolutely reckless and irresponsible for anyone to try to break up this company," Mr Ballmer said. "I think it would be unprecedented and I think it would be the single greatest disservice that anybody could do to consumers in this country... I just think it would be reckless beyond belief."

Mr Ballmer, 43, was appointed president of Microsoft in July 1998, giving him direct responsibility for improving the performance of all of the company's divisions, as well as customer satisfaction.

He grew up in Detroit, where his father, a Swiss immigrant, worked for Ford Motors. At Harvard, he lived just down the hall from Mr Gates and the two became friends.

After Mr Gates hired Mr Ballmer, the two reportedly had some rocky times. In the spring of 1985, as Microsoft's deadline to produce Windows slipped behind, Mr Gates reportedly threatened to fire Mr Ballmer if Windows wasn't on the shelves by the end of the year, though few people believe he was serious. Windows was ready by November.

Along with Mr Ballmer's promotion, Mr Gates announced that Microsoft would develop the "next generation windows services", which will power new products and services over the internet.

Microsoft wants to use the internet to transmit data to any device, including computers, cell phones, handheld computers and home electronics.

The new internet-based Windows services will be developed over the next two or three years, with developers getting the first detailed view of Microsoft's strategy this spring, Gates said.

webTitle: Failing pupils should be held back a year, suggests Woodhead

fields.headline: Failing pupils should be held back a year, suggests Woodhead
fields.trailText: Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, yesterday urged the government to consider adopting a European approach to making children retake a year in school if they failed to show enough progress and could not keep up with their classmates.
fields.body:
Chris Woodhead, the chief inspector of schools, yesterday urged the government to consider adopting a European approach to making children retake a year in school if they failed to show enough progress and could not keep up with their classmates.

In a pamphlet on international standards in education, he said British schools should pay more attention to differences that made other countries more successful at teaching children to read, write and count.

The range of abilities of children in classes in Germany, France and the Netherlands was much narrower, allowing for more effective teaching. "Students in these countries can be kept down a grade until they have acquired the level of achievement in all subjects to move on to the next level. Teachers use textbooks and do not waste time and energy producing worksheets," he said in a pamphlet published by the rightwing think tank Politeia.

An Ofsted spokesman said Mr Woodhead did not endorse the conclusions of the pamphlet's other authors, including a recommendation for delaying the age at which young children, particularly boys, start formal schooling. But the chief inspector did see merit in narrowing the ability range of teaching groups.

"This is common practice in France and other European countries, holding children back if they are not ready to go on to the next stage. While he is not advocating this as a road we should necessarily move down, he does think we should learn more about the way it operates in other countries. We should look at the positive aspects as well as the negative ones, and then decide whether there is anything we could learn from it and whether it could be applicable here. We should consider it, looking at the pros and cons.

"Maybe we ought to have greater flexibility not just for less able children, but also for the brighter ones, allowing them to move through school more quickly. Maybe we should look at that as well."

Mr Woodhead's contribution to the pamphlet suggests that Asian pupils' superior performance at maths may be linked to more days at school, more homework and more specialist teachers in primary schools.

In Taiwan, Korea and Japan, all children were expected to master the basics of literacy and numeracy. "This contrasts starkly with the belief within the English education system that perhaps 20% of children have special educational needs that prevent them making normal progress.

"It is also significant that Pacific Rim countries focus on a small number of academic goals," he said.

Mr Woodhead warned of competing pressures on classroom time. "As we ask ourselves what further skills we need for the 21st century, more simply gets added. Citizenship ... will soon be a statutory new subject for secondary schools."

Academics might be right to argue that concentration on arithmetic should not be at the expense of other areas of maths where English children did well. "But we have to have some priorities and we would do well to bear in mind the factors that make other countries in these studies so successful."

fields.headline: Partners push Lastminute.com value to £700m
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Lastminute.com, the high-profile online merchant for travel, gifts and entertainment, has brought in seven new strategic investors in what is likely to be its last round of fundraising prior to a flotation which could value the 15-month-old company at up to £700m.
fields.body:
Lastminute.com, the high-profile online merchant for travel, gifts and entertainment, has brought in seven new strategic investors in what is likely to be its last round of fundraising prior to a flotation which could value the 15-month-old company at up to £700m.

BAA, the airports operator, led the round, committing $13.25m of the total $31m raised for a stake of around 5% in Lastminute. The fundraising values the company at £160m.

In the autumn market speculation suggested Lastminute would float with a valuation of around £400m but the recent rally by net stocks including QXL.com and Freeserve has led many in the City to suggest that the company might be worth nearer £700m.

The other new investors were Bass Hotels & Resorts, Sony Music Entertainment, Mitsubishi Corporation Finance, Vivendi's Viventures, Starwood Hotels and priceline.com, the US internet company.

The funds will be invested in pan-European marketing campaigns and strengthening technical and operational infrastructure, Lastminute said.

Analysts believe the backing from US-based Starwood and particularly priceline.com, which offers bargain travel, will speed up Lastminute's plans to expand across the Atlantic.

Brent Hoberman, Lastminute.com's 31-year-old managing director, said: "This is another important step in realising our strategy to become the global last-minute marketplace.

"We look forward to adding these great companies to the group of high quality companies and the high quality investors that have already invested in Lastminute.com and working actively with each partner to create new and exciting offerings for our customers in our target markets." BAA said it will give Last minute "high visibility marketing opportunities" at its seven British airports and add its content to its own website as part of its investment. Brian Collie, BAA's group retail director, will join the Lastminute board as a non-executive director.

Mike Hodgkinson, chief ex ecutive of BAA, said: "Lastminute.com is an important strategic partner in growing our e-commerce activities."

Other shareholders in Lastminute include Intel, Deutsche Telekom, France Telecom, impresario Harvey Goldsmith, and Global Retail Partners, a venture capitalist backed by Microsoft founder Paul Allen.

Morgan Stanley Dean Witter advised Lastminute on the fundraising and is likely to lead the flotation, possibly in conjunction with Warburg Dillon Read.

Lastminute, which aims to encourage cash-rich but time-poor consumers to make spontaneous purchases, now has 650,000 registered users.

It has not published any revenue figures, but Mr Hoberman claimed that Lastminute had experienced a "fantastically busy" period from people making their new-year celebration plans.

It recently expanded beyond its London headquarters, opening offices in Paris, Munich and Stockholm.

Mr Hoberman and 26-year-old Oxford graduate Martha Lane-Fox co-founded Lastminute in 1998, after working together at media strategy consultants Spectrum. Their early success and self-promotion has made them pin-ups for the growing band of UK internet entrepreneurs.

fields.headline: E-xentric turnround for pizza magnate
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Hugh Osmond, the pizza entrepreneur and pub owner, has turned his hand to the internet with startling effect, seeing the value of the shares in his internet shell-company jump almost 20-fold before it has even made its first investment.
fields.body:
Hugh Osmond, the pizza entrepreneur and pub owner, has turned his hand to the internet with startling effect, seeing the value of the shares in his internet shell-company jump almost 20-fold before it has even made its first investment.

Shares in Blakes Clothing, formerly a Basildon-registered menswear retailer, yesterday returned from suspension as a net investment vehicle and climbed from 7p to 146p.

The business, which is to be renamed e-xentric and plans to seek out e-commerce and telecoms opportunities, has raised £1.6m by issuing 70m new shares at 2p each.

At one stage, the stock was trading at 225p, meaning that investors in the placing were sitting on a 100-fold profit. Despite having no other trading subsidiaries the company ended the day valued at around £70m.

Mr Osmond owns around 11%, with his Pizza Express co-founder Luke Johnson owning around 12%. It is unclear whether Blakes has any investments already lined up.

However, the early euphoria surrounding the tightly held stock could be dampened slightly by a £500,000 claim from Sizecheck Limited, a north-east based clothing chain which bought Blakes' clothing business Casanova Fashion for £1.8m cash last August.

David Charlton, the owner of Sizecheck, which now trades as Officers Club, said that his claim related to a dispute over the net asset value of Casanova.

Blakes acknowledged the existence of the claim but a spokeswoman insisted that the company's maximum potential liability would be no greater than £250,000.

Charles Nasser, founder of internet company ClaraNet, has been appointed to the Blakes board to seek out net investment opportunities.

Edward Spencer-Churchill, the 25-year-old son of the Duke of Marlborough, and an adviser to Mr Osmond, will also become a director.

Mr Spencer-Churchill, a 5% shareholder in Blakes, has previously been an adviser to Mr Osmond's Punch Group of pubs and e-capital investments, another net investment company.

webTitle: Tests at 14 show lack of progress

fields.headline: Tests at 14 show lack of progress
fields.trailText: The performance of 14-year- olds in last year's national tests showed "a disappointing lack of improvement" across all subjects according to the official analyis published today, despite the significant progress made by 11-year-olds, notably in reading.
fields.body:
The performance of 14-year- olds in last year's national tests showed "a disappointing lack of improvement" across all subjects according to the official analyis published today, despite the significant progress made by 11-year-olds, notably in reading.

The government said the news confirmed the need for the wide-ranging strategy to raise standards in secondary schools, which will include a new series of tests, announced earlier this month by the education secretary, David Blunkett.

The analysis of the results of last spring's national curriculum tests published today by the government's qualifications and curriculum authority shows that among 11-year-olds (key stage 2) boys' reading improved significantly, but still lags behind that of girls. Overall, pupils' writing was less good than their reading, even though there was better use of capital letters and full stops.

Within the same age group, pupils' achievement in mental arithmetic continued to improve, although they found calculating decimals difficult.

The results of the national tests for seven-, 11- and 14-year-olds are monitored by the government, and are critical because they determine whether tough national learning targets for the year 2002 are reached.

Mr Blunkett has said he will resign if the targets are not met and his department has provided extra funding to allow schools to hold special "booster" or revision classes to prepare for the tests. Ministers are particularly concerned about pupils' standards slipping when they move from primary to secondary school in what they have dubbed "the lost year".

Earlier this month Mr Blunkett announced a package of measures designed to address the problem, which include national tests for 12-year olds in English and maths, and individual learning plans for all secondary school pupils.

The 1999 results, published today, show that among 14-year-olds, girls achieved better results in English than boys, reflecting the pattern of weaker performance by boys seen at key stage 2 (11-year-olds) and GCSE.

Overall in English, there was a slight drop in the proportion of pupils achieving the top marks of level 5 or above. And in science, the results were slightly lower than the 1998 results.

Spelling was found to have improved among seven-year-olds, where there were also improvements in maths.

Nick Tate, chief executive of the QCA, said: "The analysis of last year's tests clearly shows that the government's literacy and numeracy strategies are leading to an improvement in the performance of pupils in primary schools.

"But it also highlights the need to build on this improvement in the early years of secondary education. QCA will be working closely with the department for education and employment to raise standards in secondary schools, in particular by developing new optional tests to allow pupils' progress to be tracked more effectively."

fields.headline: Professional foul
fields.standfirst: Football players and supporters complain loudly about the quality of refereeing. But plans for full-time, properly paid refs have foundered
fields.trailText: Never before has the man in the middle of the football pitch been at the centre of so much controversy and criticism. Read the sports pages and the chances are that the match reports will focus as much on the referee's performance as that of the men kicking the ball.
fields.body:
Never before has the man in the middle of the football pitch been at the centre of so much controversy and criticism. Read the sports pages and the chances are that the match reports will focus as much on the referee's performance as that of the men kicking the ball.

Last weekend for example, referees dominated the headlines in coverage of two vital FA Cup matches. The officials who presided over the bungled end of the game between Tranmere and Sunderland face an FA commission of inquiry. Refs are regularly criticised by managers, football pundits and irate fans. They certainly have been active - no complaints on the productivity score. This season alone there have been 843 bookings in the Premier League with 49 players sent off, compared to 795 bookings and 38 red cards for the same period last season.

Managers are wont to blame over-zealousness, claiming refereeing standards have dropped; as a result, they say, the physical nature of the game is being killed. Officials respond that saturation television coverage, greater player indiscipline and the pressures of the modern multimillion pound game are making their job harder: managers, players and fans want scapegoats. If professional football has never had it so good, with increasing gates, widened popularity and spiralling wages, refs have never had it so bad.

"Standards have not deteriorated," says Philip Don, the Premier League's referees officer. "It is television. At some matches there are more than 20 cameras. Every decision is analysed. Referees are under greater scrutiny than ever."

There are 21 referees on the Premier League's list. None is full-time. Most have day jobs and have to take time off to referee matches involving multimillion pound players. Similarly, on the Continent there are no full-time referees, but those in Italy, who are among the highest paid in Europe, are given three days to prepare for a game.

In England, each ref is officially judged on his handling of a game. An independent assessor attends each Premier League game, awarding marks out of 10 on the ref's performance; managers also mark referees. These marks are then sent to Philip Don who, on the basis of the assessors' reports, draws up a league table of performance. It is not made public. Some managers would like to see an automatic scheme for demoting and promoting refs. The bottom three in the table would be removed from the Premier League list while the top three in the First Division get promoted. Last season, the Premier League did indeed promote five from the First Division and removed two (on age grounds) - at its own discretion rather than on the basis of a system.

John Barnwell, of the League Managers Association, says: "Our profession is transparent. We have league tables and we are accountable. Everyone can see how we are doing. Referees are not accountable but their decisions can be crucial to the outcome of a game."

Why not professionalise? Last year, Don suggested to the Premier League that nine referees should become full-timers, drawing a salary of between £50,000 to £60,000 on the basis of two to three-year contracts. This would give them more time to prepare for matches, increase levels of fitness, allow them to examine decisions and establish closer connections with the game.

Premier League chairmen rejected the idea (which had the backing of football managers): it cost too much. Yet John Barnwell insists that there is no doubt "full-time referees would improve standards. If someone does something on a full-time basis then they are likely to do it better than a part-timer. Of course there is no guarantee, but it does increase the chances."

In cricket, former players do become umpires. Some within football claim that former players are likely to make better referees, given their "internal" understanding of the game. But there is a time problem with this suggestion. On average, it takes 10 years for a referee to make it to the Premier League, with most starting off with Sunday league matches. So even if the Premier League decided to fast-track former professional players, it would still take them six years to make it to the top. Don adds a rider: "You also have to ask whether former professionals have the temperament to be a referee; how many of them would be prepared to start at the lowest level?"

The football insiders' view is often that referees conduct games in order to satisfy the independent assessor attending the match. They are motivated by the prestige and money of working in the Premier League. Philip Barnwell observes that there is indeed more money at the top. "Many referees do not want to lose their place on the list. They are more concerned about satisfying the assessor and getting the money."

This is unfair, given that Premier League referees are the poorest paid in Europe. The table on the left shows relative rewards from refereeing. England's £600 per match hardly compares with the rewards offered in Italy and Germany.

Tension between those who manage and those who play the game is endemic. Footballers, managers and fans have tended to line up on the opposite side to refs since the rules of the game were first drawn up. That is unlikely to change. Yet the same technology that is making the job of the referee harder could one day make his life easier. (The pronoun looks likely to remain male for an even longer time.)

Next season, technical systems are likely to be introduced at Premiership grounds to help decide whether the ball has clearly crossed the goal line. Camera coverage might also come to the assistance of referees. This has happened in cricket where a third umpire helps give decisions based on video evidence.

Philip Don makes the obvious rejoinder. Technology cannot substitute for referees' discretion: "While you have the human element within the law and the word of the referee counts, then people will just have to accept it."

fields.headline: Cherie plots star chamber
fields.trailText: Cherie Booth, QC is involved in setting up a new star-studded set of chambers with leading radical barristers who have built up a reputation for taking on high profile cases that challenge the government.
fields.body:
Cherie Booth, QC is involved in setting up a new star-studded set of chambers with leading radical barristers who have built up a reputation for taking on high profile cases that challenge the government.

Some of the most sought-after barristers at top civil liberties chambers are set to join the prime minister's wife in the new venture.

They include Tim Owen, who has acted for Winston Silcott and the killers of the Liverpool toddler James Bulger, and Ben Emmerson, one of the most prolific opponents of the government at the European court of human rights, in Strasbourg.

Both are in the Doughty Street chambers of the prominent QC Geoffrey Robertson.

Two other barristers had also been thinking of leaving the chambers, but have decided to stay.

Baroness Kennedy of the Shaws - the QC Helena Kennedy - is a leading Doughty Street light and a friend of Ms Booth, but she is not planning to leave.

The move has caused dismay in the small number of chambers which have cornered the market in civil liberties work.

A source close to Doughty Street said: "This has been causing turmoil for about a month."

The source said there had been anxiety about the defections, but this had lessened now that the other two barristers had chosen to stay.

Another of Ms Booth's new colleagues will be Nick Blake QC, who has inflicted a series of defeats on the home office in immigration cases.

He will leave another well-known set of radical chambers, 2 Garden Court, which is expected to lose a second QC as well.

The venture has been hatched amid great secrecy, and none of the lawyers involved would speak about it yesterday.

Jon McLeod, of the public relations firm Shandwick, said: "We can confirm that proposals for a new organisation are under consideration, and that we hope to make an announcement of major interest to the legal sector in the near future."

The new chambers will concentrate on human rights law, expected to be a boom area once the human rights act comes into force next October.

Ms Booth is unlikely to find herself personally in conflict with the government very often. She specialises in employment law and public law, but most of her public law cases are for or against councils.

Because barristers are independent practitioners who share premises and facilities, rather than partners, her colleagues' challenges to the government are unlikely to embarrass her either.

fields.headline: Irving fears arrest over speech
fields.standfirst: Special report: the David Irving libel trial
fields.trailText: The alleged Nazi apologist David Irving yesterday revealed that Germany had issued a warrant for his extradition on charges of racial incitement.
fields.byline: Vikram Dodd and  John Hooper  in Berlin
fields.body:
The alleged Nazi apologist David Irving yesterday revealed that Germany had issued a warrant for his extradition on charges of racial incitement.

Mr Irving told the high court in London, where he is suing for libel over claims he is a Holocaust denier, that he feared arrest by police executing the warrant.

He told the judge, Mr Justice Gray, that he was informing him about the warrant in case "this end of the bench should suddenly be empty".

Mr Irving has been indicted since 1996 by German magistrates for allegedly breaking laws protecting the memory of the Holocaust.

The charge relates to a speech the author made to a meeting organised by the far right German National Party in September 1990 in which he said: "The gas chambers at Auschwitz which they show to the tourists are a fake."

He was indicted over the speech six years later. A hearing was fixed for the following year, but Mr Irving did not attend. An extradition plea was sent to Britain last August.

Mr Irving was fined £15,000 in 1992 in Germany for making the same claim.

He said he feared being arrested at any time: "I have warned my family that I might not return one of these days."

Mr Irving is banned from entering Germany. He said he did not attend the trial because his safe passage in and out of the country was not promised. Scotland Yard and the home office refused to discuss the matter.

Meanwhile, back in court, Mr Irving denied accusations that he had manipulated documents to bury evidence that Adolf Hitler had ordered the mass murder of Jews.

He is suing over the book Denying the Holocaust, which said he distorted documents to support his controversial views on the Holocaust.

The book's author Deborah Lipstadt and her publishers Penguin books, deny libel.

In his second day in the witness box, Mr Irving was tackled over his belief that Hitler did not order the annihilation of European Jewry.

In his book Hitler's War he used files detailing communications between German army chiefs to claim that the Nazi leader had intervened to stop the murder of Jews.

But Richard Rampton QC, representing Prof Lipstadt and Penguin, accused Mr Irving of deliberate mistranslation.

One document refers to an order not to liquidate a trainload of 1,000 Jews in 1941.

But Mr Irving had claimed it was an order from Hitler to halt all such killings.

Mr Rampton said: "You inflated it from one trainload of Jews and you inserted an order from Hitler for which there was no evidence."

Irving denied a deliberate error and later under questioning said: "Why should I lie?"

Mr Rampton replied: "Because you are trying to exonerate, exculpate Adolf Hitler."

In a dramatic intervention, Mr Justice Gray accused Mr Irving of "totally perverting" the sense of a key document in an article he had written.

Again Mr Rampton had alleged the effect was to ignore evidence implicating Hitler to the mass murder of Jews.

Mr Irving, who is representing himself, looked tired after a second day of cross-examination which at times dwelled on German linguistics.

The case continues on Monday, in a bigger courtroom to accommodate the number of journalists and members of the public who want to attend.

webTitle: Flu figures undermine claims of epidemic

fields.headline: Flu figures undermine claims of epidemic
fields.standfirst:
Flu epidemic: special report
More about the NHS
fields.trailText: The flu figures yesterday edged just over the norm for the time of year, but the official statistics got nowhere near the epidemic levels that the health secretary, Alan Milburn, has claimed are to blame for cancelled operations and hospital bed shortages.
fields.body:
The flu figures yesterday edged just over the norm for the time of year, but the official statistics got nowhere near the epidemic levels that the health secretary, Alan Milburn, has claimed are to blame for cancelled operations and hospital bed shortages.

The latest figures collected by the Birmingham research unit of the Royal College of General Practitioners rose to 203 per 100,000 of the population from last week's level of 144. The nationwide averages are extrapolated from figures submitted from 70 GP practices in England and Wales.

The unit's director, Douglas Fleming, called the new level "not particularly exceptional". The public health laboratory service considers a rate of between 50 and 200 per 100,000 is usual when a flu virus is circulating. Levels above 400 are considered an epidemic.

Dr Fleming acknowledged that the elderly had been particularly badly hit by the Sydney strain of flu that has affected the country this winter, but suggested that the acute bronchitis many had gone down with was caused by other viruses as well as flu.

"The high incidence in the elderly, coupled with particularly high rates of acute bronchitis in this age group (the highest for those over 65 for 15 years), is the reason that hospitals are pressured by this particular outbreak. Acute bronchitis in the elderly is caused by several viruses including influenza," he said.

In a normal year, doctors expect to see 600 to 800 elderly people per 100,000 over the age of 65, with acute bronchitis. In the last week, they were dealing with 943 per 100,000.

The flu outbreak is worst in the north, where the official figures record 259 per 100,000 as visiting their GP with flu-like symptoms. In the central region, the numbers drop to 198 and in the south to 174 per 100,000.

A spokesman for the public health laboratory service said: "The virus is always unpredictable but we now think we are seeing the peak and the numbers will begin to tail off in the next few weeks."

Thousands of people have had their operations cancelled this week as beds were commandeered for those with complications resulting from flu. Ministers have insisted that the NHS difficulties have been caused by an exceptionally severe outbreak of flu, which the chief medical officer, Liam Donaldson, termed an epidemic. They argued that many people would not be recorded in the official statistics because they had contacted NHS Direct, the telephone help service, rather than visiting their GP.

Most flu casualties are the frail and elderly, who are recommended by the department of health to have a flu vaccination in October or November. But take-up of the flu jab has not been high. "We would like to be able to have better take-up of the vaccination programme in the coming year. We are going to have to look at how we can improve take-up," said a spokesman for the prime minister.

Mr Nicholson said: "My wife had the baby five weeks before Christmas, then the flu, so when she started feeling ill again we just thought it had come back.

"She had the usual high temperature and there was no sign of her fighting for breath. We had no idea it might be pneumonia. She did not have the strength to fight."

fields.headline: Diary
fields.trailText: • Take note, Frank Dobson. The bearded one's snowy whiskers have already been exposed as an electoral catastrophe in the making, yet Downing Street's great white hope for London's mayor refuses to shave them off. But now he has no excuse after armed robber Charles Bronson has set such a good example. Bronson, who has enjoyed Her Majesty's hospitality for 26 years, is a sensitive chap. As Diary aficionados may recall, he was deeply hurt a few years back when a prison officer unkindly remarked that he couldn't be trusted with a razor while shaving. Bronson promptly vowed that he would not tackle his stubble until the year 2000. Now he has kept to his word, shaved off his impressively long, bushy beard and 8in-wide handlebar moustache and dispatched them to his girlfriend, Joyce Connor - an inmate at HMP Foston Hall whom he has never met - by way of a "millennium gift". And who says romance is dead?

Now he has kept to his word, shaved off his impressively long, bushy beard and 8in-wide handlebar moustache and dispatched them to his girlfriend, Joyce Connor - an inmate at HMP Foston Hall whom he has never met - by way of a "millennium gift". And who says romance is dead?

 Glum faces at Chepstow Community Hospital the other day, when bosses of the first privately financed NHS hospital announced that the grand opening had to be delayed because doors are not wide enough to allow patients' beds through. The Glan Hafren NHS Trust deputy chief executive is of a sunny disposition, though, and describes the blunder as "a minor design fault".

 During these long winter months, it's important to remember those less fortunate than ourselves. Take the Tories, for instance. Despite the best efforts of Michael Ashcroft, party coffers remain in the red, with a whopping great £1.9m still to pay off. The Diary, with its usual flair for fundraising wheezes, helpfully suggests a talent show featuring frontbench Tories, along the lines of Matthew Kelly's hit ITV show Stars in Their Eyes. Our first contestant looks set to be Nigel Evans, the grandly titled party vice-chairman and Ribble Valley MP, who tonight, Matthew, is going to be... William Hague. The talented Welsh spokesman has been honing his impression for some months now, but his party leader has yet to see it. "I don't think William would see the funny side," Nigel admits. It can't be that bad, surely? "It's a Welshman impersonating a Yorkshireman, so what do you think? I'm pretty poor, actually." Tory Stars in Their Eyes, however, has been rudely snubbed by the stiffs at Smith Square. "This is a very silly idea," an ungrateful type at Central Office sneers. "The Tory frontbench already show off their talents daily in the Houses of Parliament." Humph.

 My overworked and underpaid confrères at the Independent on Sunday whisper news of a forthcoming sweepstake on the future of Janet Street-Porter as that esteemed organ's editor. Hacks can pay a £1 stake to guess Ms Janet's leaving date and likely replacement (favourites so far: May and Bruce Forsyth). All the editorial staff plan to take part and the winner gets to keep the entire £4 jackpot.

 Tony Robinson - aka Blackadder's sidekick Baldrick - has a cunning new plan to forward his political aspirations. Not content with being wheeled out at the end of Labour party conferences as Tony Blair's personal court jester and being tipped as a future mayor of Bristol, Robinson's heart is now set on winning the NEC seat soon to be vacated by fellow thespian and Euro MP Michael Cashman, Labour insiders tell me. Robinson was unavailable for comment as, I learn, he is busy brushing up on the party constitution during a well-earned break in Mauritius.

 And finally, with just five months to go until the birth of the nation's First Baby, bookmakers City Index are offering an impressive array of odds on the name of the PM's fourth child. Anthony is the 16-1 favourite, with Cherie at 25-1, while Frank comes in at 50-1 and Ken gets 100-1. Worryingly for the Jackson camp, Glenda does not even merit a mention, while Elvis (at 500-1) and Lionel (1,000-1), do.

webTitle: Cancer sufferer doomed by flu delay

fields.headline: Cancer sufferer doomed by flu delay
fields.standfirst:
Flu epidemic: special report
More about the NHS
fields.trailText: A cancer patient whose operation was cancelled four times in succession because of bed shortages resulting from the flu epidemic has been told that her cancer is now inoperable.
fields.body:
A cancer patient whose operation was cancelled four times in succession because of bed shortages resulting from the flu epidemic has been told that her cancer is now inoperable.

Mavis Skeet, 74, will now be sent home from Leeds general infirmary. Doctors say there is nothing more they can do because the tumour in her oesophagus has grown too large and pierced her windpipe in two places.

She should have undergone an operation to remove it five weeks ago. But her first date for surgery was cancelled because her anaesthetist was down with flu. Three further operations were stopped because of a shortage of intensive care beds at the hospital caused by the large numbers of elderly people succumbing to flu and needing urgent treatment for serious complications.

According to Mrs Skeet's daughter Jane, 32, who lives in Wakefield, the cancer that was small enough to remove in surgery five weeks ago has now spread too far to make that possible.

"My mum is devastated and very angry," she said. "I know that if she had had the operation five weeks ago the cancer would not have spread to her windpipe. The doctors have said as much to me.

"I'm so angry. The government say they are dealing with the situation, but they are obviously not. I don't think it's just because of the flu crisis either.

"I think they are just using it as an excuse because there are simply not enough intensive care beds. The flu crisis has just tipped it over the edge."

A course of radiotherapy has already failed. Miss Skeet says the doctors have told her mother she cannot have further treatment. But she will not be discharged from the hospital until doctors have found a way to enable her to eat normally - she is at present fed intravenously. "It's a disgrace," added Miss Skeet. "There must be so many people out there that are in a similar situation or in an even worse position than my mother."

Her mother has received an apology from Leeds general infirmary for the delay.

A spokesman said yesterday: "The treatment of Mrs Skeet's complex clinical problems continues. Discussions between clinical staff and the patient and her family are still taking place about the most appropriate course of treatment following recent diagnostic tests."

Liam Fox, the Tory health spokesman, said the case illustrated the government's incompetence. "How can it be that, at the beginning of the 21st century, in the world's fifth largest economy, an entirely predictable, cyclical flu outbreak can bring the health service to its knees?"

And while the flu mainly affects the elderly, it has also taken its toll on the young.

webTitle: Deaths in custody fall after reforms

fields.headline: Deaths in custody fall after reforms
fields.standfirst:
Deaths in custody: special report
Home office: Deaths in custody 1998/99
Home office: Deaths in custody by ethnic origin 1998/99
fields.trailText: The number of deaths in police custody has fallen since the publication last year of a report which condemned the restraining techniques used by some officers.
fields.body:
The number of deaths in police custody has fallen since the publication last year of a report which condemned the restraining techniques used by some officers.

The police complaints authority will reveal today that 35 people died in police care between April and December last year, compared with 47 in the same period in 1998.

The fall comes after four successive annual increases in the number of deaths, culminating in a record 65 for the period April 1998 to April 1999.

The PCA, an independent watchdog, said yesterday that the drop was due to the reforms implemented by forces in England and Wales, but warned that more work had to be done.

"The aim must be to eliminate all avoidable deaths in police care," said Molly Meacher, acting chairwoman of the PCA.

The authority's latest study, One Year On, Deaths in Police Custody, describes how 11 forces have installed closed-circuit TV cameras in cells for the first time and that 14 more are considering the move.

Most forces have started to provide training for custody officers, including basic first aid and techniques for rousing drunks.

Kent has nurses working in its police cells and 30 forces have started questioning prisoners to try to establish if they are mentally ill or have a history of self-harm.

Merseyside, West Mercia and Sussex police were particularly commended in the report. Merseyside is spending £9m on six centralised custody cells and has introduced a custody training course for sergeants and civilians.

The PCA points out that most deaths in police custody do not occur in police stations. Rules governing the classification of deaths mean that someone dying from natural causes when in police care, such as a man suffering a heart attack after being caught drink-driving, is recorded in the figures. Suicides are also included.

There are nine recommendations in the report, including a demand that all forces consider installing CCTV and using psychiatric nurses in cell suites.

Last July the authority's annual report demanded rapid reform after a rise in the number of deaths. There was concern over the use of CS spray, which temporarily disables suspects. Prisoners complained that officers were using it unnecessarily.

The PCA also demanded that forces review the use of neck holds and have more awareness of the danger of restraining people face down on the ground with their arms handcuffed behind their backs.

A more detailed report on the progress forces have made, and the number of complaints tackled, will be published this summer.

webTitle: Kennedy warns Labour on vote reform pledge

fields.headline: Kennedy warns Labour on vote reform pledge
fields.standfirst: Proportional representation: special report
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, yesterday threatened to pull out of the joint Lib Lab cabinet committee if Tony Blair abandons his commitment to hold a referendum on electoral reform.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy, the Liberal Democrat leader, yesterday threatened to pull out of the joint Lib Lab cabinet committee if Tony Blair abandons his commitment to hold a referendum on electoral reform.

In an attempt to step up pressure on the prime minister, Mr Kennedy warned that "all bets would be off" over Lib Lab links if Labour failed to fulfill its manifesto pledge.

"What I have made quite clear, in a completely non-antagonistic way, is that if Labour reach a conclusion which is diametrically different from the one they reached as a result of discussions before the last election, then obviously all bets would be off," Mr Kennedy said on Radio 4's The World at One.

"Obviously if you reach the end of the road in terms of a relationship which is trying to roll forward constitutional reform, you reach the end of the road."

His remarks came after Mr Blair sounded a distinctly cool note about a referendum on electoral reform in the Commons on Wednesday. Asked by William Hague when he would hold a referendum, he would only say: "Our commitment still stands and the debate goes on."

Labour has lived up to its commitment to set up a commission on electoral reform, which reported in 1998.

However, Mr Blair has failed to fulfill his pledge to hold a referendum in this parliament because he says the commission's proposals could not be introduced until after the next election.

Lib Dems, who have accepted that a referendum cannot take place this side of a general election, fear that Mr Blair is going cool on the idea and may abandon his commitment altogether in Labour's next manifesto.

Their fears were raised by a recent Labour party consultation which found that party members were overwhelmingly opposed to electoral reform.

Mr Kennedy, who is still holding out hope that Mr Blair will keep his word, said that he was willing to wait a little longer for a referendum because he believes that supporters of electoral reform would lose a vote at the moment.

"I would rather that we go that bit longer and we win, than we were to have a referendum next week and we lose," he said. "That would set back the whole cause for a generation."

Mr Kennedy's threat to abandon the Lib Dems' links with Labour have been criticised by Paddy Ashdown's closest ally at Westminster.

Menzies Campbell, the party's foreign affairs spokesman, told the Guardian that Mr Kennedy should continue with the Lib-Lab cabinet committee regardless of what the prime minister does over PR.

His remarks, which set Mr Campbell at odds with Mr Kennedy, lifted the lid on a simmering row among senior Liberal Democrats over the performance of the party's new leader.
