webTitle: Bogged down in Chechnya, Russia returns to cold war rhetoric and the nuclear option

fields.headline: Bogged down in Chechnya, Russia returns to cold war rhetoric and the nuclear option
fields.standfirst:
Decline and fall: Hard times for Russian soldiers near Grozny and the glory days of the Soviet empire

Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Wading through a field of mud and ice north of the Chechen capital, Grozny, a few weeks ago, scratching together fragments of wood to build a fire against the freezing cold , Andrei put a brave face on the wretched lot of the Russian conscript.
fields.body:
Wading through a field of mud and ice north of the Chechen capital, Grozny, a few weeks ago, scratching together fragments of wood to build a fire against the freezing cold , Andrei put a brave face on the wretched lot of the Russian conscript.

"Everything's normal... We're getting 810 roubles [£20] extra a day for being here," shrugged the 30-year-old from Rostov, a soldier in the 100,000-strong Russian army struggling to tame Chechnya.

But Igor, a young officer, was less timid about speaking his mind. "Just look at these guys, look at their kit, look at their uniforms, look where they're sleeping. I bet your armies in the west don't have to put up with this. How much does a soldier or a policeman earn in Britain?" he asked.

It is one of the first questions a Russian soldier asks an outsider in Chechnya. No wonder, given the decay and demoralisation of the once mighty Red Army. Andrei has not seen any of his Chechnya bonuses yet, and with the military's unpaid wages bill running into billions of roubles, it is doubtful whether he ever will.

After speaking to Andrei and Igor, I boarded a creaking Russian armoured personnel carrier which broke down half a dozen times. It seemed an appropriate metaphor for the mishap-prone Russian campaign in the Caucasus. "The Russians are stalled," said Pavel Felgenhauer, a Moscow military analyst. "They're losing the war. The Russian troops are not good enough. The commanders are making stupid tactical mistakes."

But Chechnya is only the most dramatic symptom of the degradation of the Russian military machine. The inability to engage in proper structural reform in the post-communist decade means that Russia is more than ever dependent on its vast nuclear arsenal.

Nuclear options
Vladimir Putin, the prime minister of Russia and now its acting president, publishes his new national security strategy today, after finalising its details on Monday. He declares that the combat readiness of the conventional forces is "critically low", while broadening the criteria for when Russia would be prepared to use nuclear weapons.

The vast nuclear arsenal stretches to 750 intercontinental ballistic missiles equipped with 3,500 nuclear warheads, 13 submarines that can boast 232 sea-launched nuclear missiles, 50 Tu-95 "Bear" bomber aircraft, and, under an aircraft-for-debt deal with Ukraine, 12 Tu-160 "Blackjack" bombers.

The end of the Soviet Union ushered in one long spell of humiliation for the Russian military. After the withdrawal from Afghanistan in 1989, there followed the dissolution of the Warsaw Pact in 1990 and the first bungled war against the Chechens in 1994-96. It was made all the more miserable by watching Nato move into eastern Europe and, most of all, wage war against Slobodan Milosevic's Serbia against Russian protests.

The Soviet Union could once field a force of 5m, now Russia can barely maintain its largely conscript army of 1.2m. Its military is currently being humiliated for the second time in five years in Chechnya, which had a pre-war population of 860,000.

"Our country Russia was a great, powerful, strong state and it is clear that this is not possible if we do not have strong armed forces, powerful armed forces," Mr Putin proclaimed on Tuesday, setting himself up as the man who will stop the rot.

It is not clear how he will manage to do this. He has promised to raise defence spending by 57% and announced an extra £60m for the war in Chechnya on top of an annual defence budget of £3bn.

But he seems aware that broader social and economic troubles lie behind the decline of the military. Suicide and bullying are rife in the army, with human rights organisations reporting 1,000 suicides a year and some 4,000 murders. Amnesty International has likened army life in Russia to penal servitude, describing the military as a "gulag-style institution".

Training, maintenance, and combat readiness are grossly inadequate. Air force pilots last year enjoyed 21-24 hours of test flights, a fraction of the Nato norm.

Demoralised
Russia's progress towards creating a professional, well-equipped military capable of prosecuting a short, sharp campaign is non-existent, despite Boris Yeltsin's declaration several years ago that by 2000 such a force would be created.

Gen Kvash nin commanded and lost the last Chechen war but sees the current exercise as an opportunity to grab more resources.

Marshal Sergeyev this week threw his support behind a plan for a new, integrated command of the elite nuclear forces - the strategic rocket forces, the nuclear submarine fleet, and strategic air command. He claims that this would ensure that "Russia will remain a nuclear power without losing its conventional forces". fields.headline: Russia raises nuclear threat
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Russia has revised its defence doctrine to make it easier to press the nuclear button in an international crisis, while unequivocally declaring the west a hostile power that must be resisted.
fields.body:
Russia has revised its defence doctrine to make it easier to press the nuclear button in an international crisis, while unequivocally declaring the west a hostile power that must be resisted.

A new national security strategy decreed by the acting president, Vladimir Putin, on Monday and to be published today marks a radical shift in Russia's view of the world. It ushers in a policy of "expanded nuclear containment" while pledging to resist western attempts to dominate the globe.

The strategic shift lowers the threshold at which Russia may resort to nuclear weapons and is the first foreign policy move that Mr Putin has taken since replacing Boris Yeltsin in the Kremlin on New Year's Eve.

Mr Yeltsin's strategy, decreed in December 1997, declared that nuclear weapons could only be used "in the case of a threat to the very existence of the Russian Federation as a sovereign state".

The new document states that the use of nuclear weapons is necessary "to repel armed aggression if all other means of resolving a crisis situation have been exhausted or turn out to be ineffective".

The new strategy substantially eases the constraints on resort to the nuclear option. This has been partly triggered by the fact that Russia still commands a large nuclear arsenal, but its conventional forces lack combat readiness.

"These are very substantial changes," said a military affairs expert, Sergei Sorkut. "The emphasis on nuclear weapons has changed. They can now be used in crisis situations."

The Putin strategy takes a much more confrontational position towards the west, a policy overhaul sparked by Nato's expansion into former Warsaw Pact countries and by the US-led war against the former Yugoslavia last year.

Whereas the 1997 strategy spoke of "partnership" with the west and decreed that there was no threat of military aggression to Russia, the new paper says that two "mutually exclusive tendencies" are now locked in combat on the globe.

It says that the "multi-polar world" promoted by Mr Yelt sin, who sought to enlist India and China as allies, is in conflict with "the west led by the US" which aims to use its military might to dominate world affairs.

It is not clear what the new strategy may mean for Nato's Partnership for Peace pact, agreed to appease Russia during negotiations to admit Poland, Hungary, and the Czech Republic to the alliance. Moscow froze its participation last year in protest at the Nato war in Kosovo although more than 3,000 Russian troops are serving in the Nato-led peacekeeping force.

Russian commentary on the leaked 21-page document said it made it clear that "the term 'partnership' has been consigned to the past".

The radical departure in nuclear doctrine, said Moscow analysts, represented an "entirely logical development" enshrining a new policy of "expanded nuclear containment".

"Russia will not only use nuclear weapons in response to a nuclear attack, but in response to a conventional attack when there is no other way out."

The hostile tone appears to seal a drawn-out process of disenchantment with the west.

A new Russian military doctrine, dovetailing with the Putin national security strategy, is expected to be endorsed by the acting president in February, said Sergei Ivanov, a close Putin ally and secretary of the Kremlin's influential security council.

A draft of the military doc trine, published last October, also attacked the US and Nato but attracted much adverse comment in Moscow and many thought it would be toned down.

Monday's decree by Mr Putin confirms that this will not happen, although Mr Ivanov said changes to the military doctrine would still be "necessary".

On a more conciliatory note, however, Igor Sergeyev, the defence minister, said he was confident that the new parliament in Moscow, due to convene this month, would soon ratify the Start-2 arms control treaty with the US.

Mr Putin is known to support ratification and he wants parliament to act before Russia's presidential election on March 26, a contest that he is widely expected to win.

The timing of the adoption of the security strategy this week and the military doctrine next month also represents electioneering by Mr Putin, whose central message to voters is that he will restore Russia to its great-power status.

The new strategy also places greater emphasis on the threats to Russia from separatism, terrorism and organised crime, and, in an indirect reference to the war in Chechnya, delivers a more forthright assertion of when Russia may deploy armed forces domestically "in strict accordance with the constitution".

fields.headline: Primakov opts for Duma post
fields.standfirst: Russia: special report
fields.trailText: Acting President Vladimir Putin saw his chances of winning the presidential election boosted further yesterday when his rival Yevgeny Primakov hinted that he would not run.
fields.body:
Acting President Vladimir Putin saw his chances of winning the presidential election boosted further yesterday when his rival Yevgeny Primakov hinted that he would not run.

On the day that Mr Putin officially confirmed he would stand for the presidency, Mr Primakov indicated to fellow politicians that he would instead run for parliamentary speaker in the state Duma. If confirmed, the move is a strong indication that he has put his presidential ambitions behind him.

webTitle: C&W buys into Europe in bulk

fields.headline: C&W buys into Europe in bulk
fields.standfirst:
High-speed links for 200 cities in move on business ISP market
E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Cable & Wireless stepped up its assault on the market for data services supplied to business yesterday by confirming that it had bought eight European internet service providers.
fields.body:
Cable & Wireless stepped up its assault on the market for data services supplied to business yesterday by confirming that it had bought eight European internet service providers.

The deals, aimed at cementing the telecoms group's position as a provider of internet protocol services to business, bring C&W's investment in business ISPs to £300m.

Announcement of the acquisitions coincided with confirmation from C&W that it plans to spend another £300m building on its European IP network. The investment is in addition to the company's plan to spend £600m on its IP network in the region.

The eight ISPs bought by C&W are Xpoint in Austria, online internet in Belgium, ISDnet in France, Unidata and DSLogic-DSNet in Italy, grupo Intercom in Spain, and agri.ch and Petrel Communications in Switzerland.

C&W bought three business ISPs last year - INS in Britain, pi.se in Sweden, and ECRC in Germany.

The eight ISPs bought yesterday have annualised revenues of $130m in total. With the ISPs come business clients including BMW, Volvo, Oracle, Sony Europe, Siemens, Lufthansa and Honda.

The network investment means that C&W will have a high-speed network connecting 200 cities across the continent, up from 40 originally planned.

By this April, 18 cities will be connected, with the full 200 linked up by 2002.

The moves are part of the strategy of Graham Wallace, the C&W chief executive, of concentrating on the business market in preference to the fashionable and competitive world of mobile phones, consumer television and telephony.

C&W is planning to exploit the surge in demand for IP services which will follow as the boom in e-commerce begins. The company is concentrating its investment on Europe, the US and Japan which account between them for 85% of the business IP market.

Promising that the pace of the deal-making would not slacken over the year ahead, Mr Wallace said the latest deals would be funded from C&W's internal resources which are being boosted by the company's programme of selling peripheral operations and holdings.

City sources suggested that C&W's gearing was about 7% in October, and would rise to about 30% by the financial year-end.

Analysts said that the deals seemed fairly priced. Investors welcomed the deal and C&W shares closed at £10.98, 57p up on the day.

Mr Wallace indicated that C&W was unlikely to turn to joint ventures to speed up its progress in this area.

webTitle: Kingfisher to float fifth of LibertySurf

fields.headline: Kingfisher to float fifth of LibertySurf
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Kingfisher yesterday announced plans to float LibertySurf, the free internet service provider in which the Woolworth's and B&Q retail group has a 45% stake.
fields.body:
Kingfisher yesterday announced plans to float LibertySurf, the free internet service provider in which the Woolworth's and B&Q retail group has a 45% stake.

Market estimates put a value of about £1bn on LibertySurf, which has now appointed Deutsche Bank to look at a flotation on the Paris bourse to generate fresh funds for expansion. Kingfisher, which has a range of business operations in France including the Darty electrical retail chain, owns LibertySurf in partnership with Europ@web, a private company controlled by Bernard Arnault, the chairman of French luxury goods group LVMH. The remaining 15% of the shares are owned by the management.

The euphoria that boosted Kingfisher shares immediately after the announcement wore off during the day. They closed down 15p at 547p, still suffering from the malaise generated by worries about declining margins.

According to Pierre Besnainou, the chairman of LibertySurf, only 20% of the company will be floated initially. However, he gave no indication of when the company might make its debut on the bourse.

In the eight months since LibertySurf was launched, the operation has gained 610,000 subscribers with 120m minutes of telephone communications.

The company said: "LibertySurf plans to continue the acquisition programme it began in 1999 and, like many of its competitors, is considering tapping the capital markets in order to accelerate its international growth."

That expansion continued yesterday when the company paid $5m to acquire a 10% stake in X-Stream, Britain's third-biggest free internet service provider with some 500,000 subscribers.

The Kingfisher group has also been extending its involvement in e-commerce with the launch of internet selling sites for retail brands such as Woolworth and B&Q.

The group recently acquired a mail order and e-commerce hardware operation, Screwfix Direct.

webTitle: Virgin pleads for email patience after security breach

fields.headline: Virgin pleads for email patience after security breach
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: Virgin.net has pleaded with its customers to "bear with us" as it struggles to overcome a potential security breach, which has left more than 150,000 customers without access to email accounts.
fields.body:
Virgin.net has pleaded with its customers to "bear with us" as it struggles to overcome a potential security breach, which has left more than 150,000 customers without access to email accounts.

Frustrated Virgin.net customers have been forced to change their email passwords after last weekend's incident, which Virgin says is being investigated by police.

One businessman from Yorkshire said he planned to cancel his subscription with Virgin after four days of trying and failing to contact the company's customer support line to reactivate his email account.

"We've been on the phone to Virgin constantly and cannot even get through at five in the morning," said Robert Minton-Taylor, who runs the Minton-Taylor public relations consultancy in Skipton, Yorkshire.

"I appreciate all companies have the occasional problem but our firm relies on Virgin.net for 80% of our business communication needs.

"We will be switching to another provider."

A spokesman for Virgin.net said that capacity at its customer support call centres had been increased and 166,000 of its subscribers had been sent letters in the post explaining how they could get their email accounts up in working order again.

"We apologise to our customers and ask them to be patient," the spokesman said.

"We are throwing every resource we can at solving the problem and working through the night to get it fixed. It is a mammoth effort.

"Customer security is of paramount importance to us and we want to ensure everything is done properly."

Virgin.net, which has 620,000 users, said last night that 40% of affected users had been given working passwords and the rest would be able to send emails by the start of next week.

fields.headline: Stereotypes live on in cyberspace
fields.standfirst: E-finance: special report
fields.trailText: They are at the cutting edge of the new economy, but young hi-tech firms in Britain and Germany behave much like their forebears, according to new research published today.
fields.body:
They are at the cutting edge of the new economy, but young hi-tech firms in Britain and Germany behave much like their forebears, according to new research published today.

Confirming national stereotypes, the research found that British new-technology based firms are much more buccaneering than their risk-averse German counterparts. They are more international in their outlook, selling into a wider range of foreign markets, and also have the edge when it comes to marketing.

German hi-tech firms tend to be more parochial, concentrating on the home market and Europe. They are often closely integrated to the supply chains of big international German businesses and more likely to sell customised products.

British firms are promiscuous, preferring to make "off the peg" products which they sell to a broader range of customers with whom they have a casual relationship.

The research, by academics from the London Business School and Germany's Centre for European Economic Research, found that the relative weaknesses of British hi-tech firms are familiar to students of British industry - poor skill levels and insufficient investment in research and development.

The German firms are predictably strong in both departments, with a broader base of skills compensating for a less flexible labour market. Oliver Burgel, one of the study's authors, said: "UK firms depend more on marketing. Their sales patter is good. If the product doesn't work, they blame the technology. But exchange rate risk is more important for them because they make less bespoke products."

 The Rapid Internationalisation of High-Tech Young Firms in Germany and the United Kingdom. Oliver Burgel and Gordon Murray, LBS, and Andreas Fier and Georg Licht, CEER.

fields.headline: Whistling in the dark
fields.standfirst:
Personal experience tells me Lord Neill's anti-sleaze proposals will turn out to be worse than useless

The Aitken affair: special report
The fall of Archer: special report
Hamilton, Al Fayed libel trial
fields.trailText: Personal experience tells me Lord Neill's anti-sleaze proposals will turn out to be worse than useless.
fields.body:
Whistleblowers may duly choke on their peas. The Committee on Standards in Public Life didn't come into being five years ago because of some long-running Whitehall quest after probity and truth. It was set up in a rush by a prime minister in a jam who couldn't cope with the clouds of murk engulfing his government. Its essential progenitors were Jonathan Aitken, Tim Smith and Neil Hamilton; and it is their parliamentary shades, bizarrely enough, who emerge smirking from Lord Neill's latest review of his rules and regulations.

Nothing Lord Neill's committee now proposes would have uncovered Jonathan Aitken's lies long before his own follies laid them bare. Nothing, either, makes it remotely likelier that corrupt MPs offering services for cash will find themselves dragged into some spotlight of infamy. On the contrary, future whistleblowers may look at the hurdles solemnly erected, shrug and walk away. Who wants so much damned hassle for so little reward?

Be clear. We only knew about Mr Aitken and Mr Hamilton in the first place because informants put themselves at risk and because journalists ploughed along - often fruitlessly - over months and years of investigation. Without that conjunction, there would have been no Nolan (or Neill) apparatus.

Without it, too, we'd have pottered on oblivious of the underground streams of sleaze below Westminster's pavements. We'd have told ourselves complacently that public corruption only happened somewhere distant, somewhere over there - in Berlin or Cairo or Washington DC. The danger of this review is that everything will go quiet again - feeble evidence that all is well.

Jonathan Aitken's lies about his stay at the Ritz in Paris - the lies that led to other lies - were evident to anyone with a will to inquire as long ago as January 1994. They were evident to me, editing the Guardian. I took them to the supposed guardian of ministerial standards, the then cabinet secretary, Sir Robin Butler. A very busy man. He didn't even read the paperwork; he didn't quiz Mr Aitken. He gave the minister a clean bill of health and allowed Jonathan himself to draft the push-off letter to me.

Not very satisfactory? I took the case to John Major himself. These were, after all, his own rules of conduct, lately published. Push off, he said in turn, Sir Robin has found nothing wrong. The natural circle of evasion closed shut. Of course Mr Major didn't want to be prodded into action by some outside journo asking awkward questions. Of course he didn't want to lose a key political ally. In 1994, as I bitterly discovered, you couldn't blow whistles in the land of the wilfully deaf - and this, crazily, is the situation Neill leaves in place.

Tony Blair's rules of conduct are tighter and longer than ever. But the judge and jury in any case of alleged transgression remain T Blair and his cabinet amanuensis, Sir Richard Wilson. No independent eyes, no ethical commissioners. Downing Street doesn't want outsiders peering behind closed doors (and Lord Neill tactfully defers to that view). The system that "dealt" with Peter Mandelson rules OK. I thought that system was pretty unfair to Mr Mandelson, as it happened, and unfairly difficult for Mr Blair, too: but that's not the immediate point. The point for prospective whistleblowers is: don't complain in the first place. Who needs the toil and the grief?

And that, more grimly yet, is also the Neill verdict on Mr Smith and Mr Hamilton. First, make bribery of an MP a criminal offence. Fair enough on the surface - but ask yourself thereafter how we're ever to know what bundles of £50 notes pass behind closed doors if the giver and receiver may both end up in prison? A very private corruption reinforced. Mohamed Al Fayed continues to take predictable stick from predictable adversaries, but it was he who blew the whistle in the end, knowing that he'd heap more trouble on his own head and in the teeth of opposition from his own advisers. Would he do that again if the law were changed? Surely not; surely the advisers would have the last word; and surely we'd be left darkling.

Lord Neill and Jack Straw, moreover, have chosen not merely to shoot the messenger but to truss him up in a legal quagmire. Say you, Joe or Josephine Public, smell something rotten around the Commons. You go to the parliamentary commissioner who looks at it and passes it up to the privileges committee which, after due thought, summons its new tribunal (with an independent legal eagle in the chair). The accused MP has legal aid there; we pay for his silk. And if he doesn't like that verdict, there's a second appeal tribunal and retired judge in waiting.

Who knows where this four-headed monster fits with the libel courts? Who can tell of the strain - in cash, time and emotion - which falls on those who smell something wrong in the beginning and are stuck with following it through? I've been there, done that. I wish in my heart that I could look at Neill's lugubrious prescriptions and believe that I'd do it all over again.

webTitle: The idealist generation finds its 90s self: going for easy millions

fields.headline: The idealist generation finds its 90s self: going for easy millions
fields.standfirst: Special report: Time Warner/AOL merger
fields.trailText: I woke up feeling intensely guilty. When I was young, I used to go into a dark box at church and confess all kinds of guilt: about talking back to my parents, about unkindnesses, about impure thoughts. But now I feel guilty about just one thing: not being a millionaire. On the glowing boxes of my adulthood, the TV and computer, people are constantly getting rich quick.
fields.body:
I woke up feeling intensely guilty. When I was young, I used to go into a dark box at church and confess all kinds of guilt: about talking back to my parents, about unkindnesses, about impure thoughts. But now I feel guilty about just one thing: not being a millionaire. On the glowing boxes of my adulthood, the TV and computer, people are constantly getting rich quick.

When Time Warner merged with AOL this week, some predicted the end of print, and my life passed before my eyes. But I was far more disturbed that I had lost yet another opportunity to cash in, or to cash out.

I worked at Time in the early 80s. The magazine was not on the cutting edge of technology then. When Time named the computer as its 1982 "Man of the Year" we were still pounding out our stories on typewriters. I didn't hold on to my Time stock. And on Monday many of my old colleagues became multimillionaires. If there's a way to lose money, I'll find it.

I called a Washington psychoanalyst named Justin Frank. I told him I didn't want to feel deeply inadequate just because I didn't know how to day-trade.

He confessed his own feelings of inadequacy. "As a psychoanalyst, I subjectively feel like a dinosaur because I am exploring things in depth, and in the meantime everyone around me has got rich.

"We are moving into an era of decisiveness as opposed to an era of thoughtfulness. People feel guilty if they have a subconscious identification with Hamlet."

To trade or not to trade. I never cared about money before. It was not what Country Joe and the Fish taught me to value.

Once upon a time, money was an occasion for guilt. The robber barons who had exploited the poor would cleanse their lucre by buying great art or pouring it into charity; the Guilted Age. But now the only remorse that people feel about money is, why haven't they made more? "Once, new money tried to disguise itself as old money," says Michael Lewis, who wrote "The New New Thing," about a Silicon Valley billionaire.

"It gave some of itself away. It dressed itself up in airs and pretensions. Now old money cringes in the face of new money. Now even new money gets stale fast, and has a sell-by date."

We are obsessed about making money with our money. Making an honest living does not seem like a particularly sensible thing to do any more when you can simply hold on to a stock that rises to the stratosphere. "I have never seen so many disgruntled people at the peak of a bull market," says James Stewart, the author of "Den of Thieves" about the Wall Street scandals of the 80s and now an editor at Smart Money.

"People look at their portfolios going up 40% last year and they are whining and complaining to me that they didn't own Qualcomm. They don't even know what Qualcomm makes. If they had Qualcomm, they whine they wish they had more of it.

"Everybody brags about their gains. Nobody talks about their losses. As a subject for boasting, portfolios have supplanted sports and sex."

Jim Cramer agrees. He is the money manager who founded TheStreet.com: "People used to be mortified to talk about how much money they made. Now they get in my face and say, 'I caught 79 points on Oracle, what did you catch?' "

In the old days, you had to be intrepid or the owner of a Master's in business administration to get in on a gold rush.

Now your personal trainer knows as much about one-day price movements as Warren Buffett.

"It's not like a land grab, where you had to go out west, brave native Americans and horrible rains and run into the Donner party," Mr Cramer says.

"You don't have to brave anything at all. You just have to have a predilection not to sell."

So the generation that prided itself on its idealism has finally found its true signature. And the question that the children will ask is: "What did you do in the bull market, Daddy?" - New York Times

webTitle: Outcry as Russia's new rules trap children in war zone

fields.headline: Outcry as Russia's new rules trap children in war zone
fields.standfirst: Crisis in Chechnya: special report
fields.trailText: Russia came under strong international pressure yesterday to revoke a new diktat defining as rebels all Chechen males between the ages of 10 and 60, as the tougher security regulations provoked chaos and misery for civilians trying to flee heavy fighting in the region.
fields.body:
Russia came under strong international pressure yesterday to revoke a new diktat defining as rebels all Chechen males between the ages of 10 and 60, as the tougher security regulations provoked chaos and misery for civilians trying to flee heavy fighting in the region.

Some children were trapped inside the war zone as a result of the rules which came into force on Wednesday and now automatically classify them as fighters. The crackdown follows a number of reversals for the Russian military offensive in recent days.

Médecins Sans Frontières, the international humanitarian group which won the 1999 Nobel Peace Prize, yesterday accused Russia of committing war crimes in Chechnya, and the US state department told Moscow it had an obligation to respect the rights of civilians trying to escape the war zone.

Médecins Sans Frontières made its accusation in an open letter to Washington urging President Clinton to press for an end to the war launched in late September by Moscow, which said its aim was to quash Islamic militants it blames for hundreds of kidnappings, incursions into Russian areas and a series of apartment bombings inside Russia.

The president of the republic of Ingushetia - which borders Chechnya and has taken in wave after wave of refugees - also condemned Russia's new crackdown on civilians. It was crueller, he maintained, than anything done to the Chechens under Joseph Stalin's rule, when the entire nation was deported to Asia during the second world war.

There was growing fear that the suffering could worsen dramatically if new "filtration camps" are set up to sift Chechen fighters from civilians detained under the new regulations; during Russia's previous war against Chechnya in 1994-96, such camps became notorious for their brutality.

Russia has launched a fierce new assault on Chechnya to try to reverse successes by the rebels there earlier this week, and large numbers of civilians were yesterday trying to escape the intensified fighting.

But refugees on the Chechen border with Ingushetia told of families torn apart by the Kremlin's new rules: Russian soldiers were refusing to let young boys flee the bombing with their relatives, refugees said in accounts from the scene.

Datu Isigova, a refugee from the Chechen capital, Grozny, said she had been forced to abandon her 11-year-old son Arbi and her husband Suleman as she fled to Ingushetia. Other women had decided to stay in combat areas rather than leave their sons.

Some men were unable to get back into Chechnya. Kairish, a hairdresser, was trying to return to his eight children living alone in a train carriage a few miles in from the border, after what he thought would be a short trip to Ingushetia to buy food and shoes.

"I don't know what to do. My wife is dead and my kids have been left by themselves for two days," he told Reuters, holding a bag of bread. "I am 55, and the guards told me I'm not allowed to cross because I'm not 60."

President Ruslan Aushev of Ingushetia condemned Russia's measure in the bitterest terms, describing it as "illegal and discriminatory".

It would succeed only in alienating any Chechen who still felt residual sympathy for the Russians, he warned, and would prompt young men to join the rebels' cause.

The problems experienced by refugees as a result of the measure were being monitored by human rights activists in Ingushetia. "Chechen males are now effectively trapped in a dangerous war. It is fundamentally unacceptable to deny civilian males - including children as young as 10 - the right to flee from from heavy fighting," said a spokesman for the New York-based group Human Rights Watch.

In its open letter, published in the New York Times, Médecins Sans Frontières said that almost four months of indiscriminate Russian bombing of Grozny and other parts of Chechnya "constitute war crimes".

During the conflict in the Serbian province of Kosovo earlier this year, the letter said to the White House, "your administration mounted an all-out public relations campaign aimed at rallying support for the humanitarian concerns of the besieged citizens of Kosovo. Where is the similar high-level, public discussion of the plight of civilians in Chechnya? Do they suffer less than the people of Kosovo?"

fields.headline: Selling arms to dictators
fields.trailText: Only 18 months ago the EU code of conduct on arms exports was adopted. It was presented at the time as a flagship of the British presidency of the EU. Now Britain is contemplating resuming arms sales to the Pakistani military dictatorship (Report, January 12), which less than three months ago ousted a democratically elected government. Pakistan has a dreadful human rights record and has recently been involved in military skirmishing with India over Kashmir. It has huge debts, pressing development needs and a bloated military expenditure. Many will question why Pakistan was not included in the list of countries for which public money will no longer be available to subsidise arms exports.
fields.body:
Only 18 months ago the EU code of conduct on arms exports was adopted. It was presented at the time as a flagship of the British presidency of the EU. Now Britain is contemplating resuming arms sales to the Pakistani military dictatorship (Report, January 12), which less than three months ago ousted a democratically elected government. Pakistan has a dreadful human rights record and has recently been involved in military skirmishing with India over Kashmir. It has huge debts, pressing development needs and a bloated military expenditure. Many will question why Pakistan was not included in the list of countries for which public money will no longer be available to subsidise arms exports.

Arms exports to Pakistan could breach as many as five of the eight criteria of the EU code. One hopes our European partners would not supply arms to Pakistan if Britain does not. The EU code is designed to discourage undercutting. If the 80 pending licence applications are refused by the UK, then under the terms of the code any EU country considering supplying these armaments will have to consult with Britain. The decision over arms sales is a litmus test for the seriousness of claims for a responsible UK arms exports policy and for the EU code.
Paul Eavis
Saferworld

 Peter Hain is right to argue that "the military cannot solve Pakistan's long-term problems" (Arming the general, January 12), but he is wrong to hold out any hope that General Musharraf can be "a military ruler of a new type" with whom Britain can engage "constructively". The upcoming visit to Pakistan of the UK's chief of defence staff, Charles Guthrie, sends out all the wrong signals and undermines the foreign office's initial robust condemnation of the coup. In the past, such de facto recognition by foreign governments has served only to entrench the military's long-term grip on political and civil society. And it is this grip that remains at the root of so many of the ills that beset Pakistan today.

In 1971 democracy was restored only because the military was discredited in the wake of the defeat by India. In 1988 democracy was restored only after the death of General Zia-ul Haq in a mysterious air crash. In both instances, democracy was hamstrung by continuing military influence over civilian politicians.
Dr Arif Azad
London

 Your report on the conflict between the foreign office and the DTI and MoD over the export of weapons to Pakistan highlights one of the most important barriers to a more human-rights-centred foreign policy.

Amnesty International has long argued that Labour's manifesto promise on this can only be met through a commitment to end the export of arms to countries where they may be used in human rights violations. Given that a decision on whether to lift the EU arms embargo on Indonesia is imminent, this lack of joined up thinking could not be more worrying.
Mary Robinson
Amnesty International UK

 If British armaments are as bad as you say they are (Culture of failure, January 12), why are you objecting to their being sold to Pakistan (Leader, January 12)?
Don Jowett
Blockley, Glos

 I was disappointed to see your leader (December 29) equating Pakistan with India for not making efforts to build bridges on Kashmir. Every Pakistan government has emphasised the importance of dialogue on Kashmir.
Samina Parvez
Pakistan High Commission
fields.bodyText: Only 18 months ago the EU code of conduct on arms exports was adopted. It was presented at the time as a flagship of the British presidency of the EU. Now Britain is contemplating resuming arms sales to the Pakistani military dictatorship (Report, January 12), which less than three months ago ousted a democratically elected government. Pakistan has a dreadful human rights record and has recently been involved in military skirmishing with India over Kashmir. It has huge debts, pressing development needs and a bloated military expenditure. Many will question why Pakistan was not included in the list of countries for which public money will no longer be available to subsidise arms exports. Arms exports to Pakistan could breach as many as five of the eight criteria of the EU code. One hopes our European partners would not supply arms to Pakistan if Britain does not. The EU code is designed to discourage undercutting. If the 80 pending licence applications are refused by the UK, then under the terms of the code any EU country considering supplying these armaments will have to consult with Britain. The decision over arms sales is a litmus test for the seriousness of claims for a responsible UK arms exports policy and for the EU code. Paul Eavis Saferworld  Peter Hain is right to argue that "the military cannot solve Pakistan's long-term problems" (Arming the general, January 12), but he is wrong to hold out any hope that General Musharraf can be "a military ruler of a new type" with whom Britain can engage "constructively". The upcoming visit to Pakistan of the UK's chief of defence staff, Charles Guthrie, sends out all the wrong signals and undermines the foreign office's initial robust condemnation of the coup. In the past, such de facto recognition by foreign governments has served only to entrench the military's long-term grip on political and civil society. And it is this grip that remains at the root of so many of the ills that beset Pakistan today. In 1971 democracy was restored only because the military was discredited in the wake of the defeat by India. In 1988 democracy was restored only after the death of General Zia-ul Haq in a mysterious air crash. In both instances, democracy was hamstrung by continuing military influence over civilian politicians. Dr Arif Azad London  Your report on the conflict between the foreign office and the DTI and MoD over the export of weapons to Pakistan highlights one of the most important barriers to a more human-rights-centred foreign policy. Amnesty International has long argued that Labour's manifesto promise on this can only be met through a commitment to end the export of arms to countries where they may be used in human rights violations. Given that a decision on whether to lift the EU arms embargo on Indonesia is imminent, this lack of joined up thinking could not be more worrying. Mary Robinson Amnesty International UK  If British armaments are as bad as you say they are (Culture of failure, January 12), why are you objecting to their being sold to Pakistan (Leader, January 12)? Don Jowett Blockley, Glos  I was disappointed to see your leader (December 29) equating Pakistan with India for not making efforts to build bridges on Kashmir. Every Pakistan government has emphasised the importance of dialogue on Kashmir. Samina Parvez Pakistan High Commission

fields.headline: The price on Ken's head
fields.trailText: Readers of your diary (January 12) may imagine this centre has produced Frank Dobson's estimates of the impact of a Livingstone mayoralty. We haven't. All we have done is made a calculation (for concerned clients in the City) about the impact of a theoretical increase in corporation tax in London by 10p. This idea (which we estimate would be damaging to the London economy if implemented) has been floated by Mr Livingstone, although clearly he would not have the power to impose such a tax as mayor. I believe Mr Dobson's campaign has circulated this calculation. But we have not prepared any other of the estimates of "the cost of Ken".

fields.headline: Doctoring: the evidence
fields.trailText: I recently completed research on men aged 50 and over, held in three local prisons. The physical and mental condition of a number of these men was very poor (Pinochet failed senility test, January 13). Is the home secretary "minded" to inquire into the situation of these men, who were not held in the luxurious conditions enjoyed by Pinochet, but who had to take their chances in overcrowded and often brutalising conditions?
fields.body:

Is the home secretary "minded" to inquire into the situation of these men, who were not held in the luxurious conditions enjoyed by Pinochet, but who had to take their chances in overcrowded and often brutalising conditions?

There will be no inquiry as these men have little influence and power. Jack Straw and the government are making it clear that the powerful will rarely if ever be brought to account for their actions. The recent cases involving Kalejs and Rosemary Nelson illustrate this point. These recent events are a shocking indictment of a party that is supposedly interested in human rights and social justice.
Prof Joe Slim
 Liverpool John Moores University

 Strange that Pinochet required a team of five eminent physicians to assess him. His victims only needed one army doctor to check if their bodies would tolerate further electric shock torture.
Nelsa Silva
London

 As the doctors have had as much say as the judges, shouldn't they be subject to the same public scrutiny of their backgrounds, connections etc as the law lords, and their detailed reasons be published?
Peter Croft
London
peter_croft@textandvideo.co.uk

 Many torture victims and bereaved have an interest in the contents of the report. They should have the chance to question the findings.
Mark Hellen
London

 A crucial part of his assessment must have hinged on responses to questions from his assessors. How much fairer for Pinochet to have his mental assessment in Spain, with Spanish speaking doctors.
Dr Charles Price
Sheffield

 Had he been claiming benefit rather than resisting extradition, Pinochet would have been visited by an appeals service doctor with a preconceived agenda, a bullying and insensitive manner, a lack of respect for the age and state of health of the applicant and a determination to cheat claimants out of their rights... the general would have been quite impressed!
C Connolly
Chesterfield, Derbyshire
consperanza@yahoo.co.uk

 Is it not a little odd that it has only just been realised that Pinochet is demented?
MW Riddall
Folkestone, Kent

fields.headline: Holidays in the sun
fields.trailText: I'm puzzled as to how shuffling school holidays will help parents look after their children better (Inquiry into five-term school year, January 12). Surely, they will still have to organise care for the same length of time? The main difference would seem to be that under the new proposals there would be longer holiday periods during the darker and colder times of the year when it is harder to occupy children.

simon@smidgley.co.uk

Burntwood, Walsall

webTitle: No consensus on questions of religious faith

fields.headline: No consensus on questions of religious faith
fields.trailText: Two errors marred your coverage of the new census questions to be posed next year (Census to ask people about religious beliefs, January 11). Firstly, the Irish have long been acknowledged as the largest ethnic minority in Britain, measured historically in terms of place of birth. The "Irish question" next year will enable a more accurate assessment of the size of this largely invisible (ie pale-skinned and English-speaking) ethnic minority by permitting second- and third-generation Irish, born in Britain, to define themselves as Irish if they so wish.
fields.body:
Two errors marred your coverage of the new census questions to be posed next year (Census to ask people about religious beliefs, January 11). Firstly, the Irish have long been acknowledged as the largest ethnic minority in Britain, measured historically in terms of place of birth. The "Irish question" next year will enable a more accurate assessment of the size of this largely invisible (ie pale-skinned and English-speaking) ethnic minority by permitting second- and third-generation Irish, born in Britain, to define themselves as Irish if they so wish.

More objectionable was the reference to Muslims as an "ethnic" minority. We are not an ethnic group. Islam is a universalist religion which is open to individuals of all ethnic groups the world over. We may well be the largest non-Christian religious minority in this country, but that does not make us an ethnic group any more than, say, Methodists or tennis players or Liberal Democrats. It offends Islam to imply that it confines its message to a particular ethnic category.

The Guardian ought to be above the practices, however widespread in lesser organs, of taking "ethnic" to mean "brown-skinned", assuming that white (or English) people are somehow devoid of ethnicity, and using Islam as a racial category.
Michael Mullan
Bradford, W Yorks

 When I lived in England there was no question in the census form as to what languages I spoke. Now that I live in Wales the census asks me if I speak Welsh. The forthcoming census form for the UK will ask me, if I am Irish, to what ethnic group I belong, and what is my religious persuasion. My cultural identity, Welsh, is tied in with the Welsh language I speak. Surely it must be more relevant to know what languages are spoken in this multiracial, multicultural island; not only here in Wales, but in England too. I would like to know how many Urdu, Irish Gaelic and Welsh speakers there are living in England, Scotland, Northern Ireland, and Wales.
Dafydd Wyn Roberts
Cardiff

 Can someone explain why it is that yet again secular Jews, who are recognised as an "ethnic minority" by the race relations act, are exempted from identifying themselves in the census? Has there been pressure from a Jewish lobby conscious of how government statistics can be manipulated?
Ibrahim Thompson
Ferryhill, Co Durham

 No one should have to disclose their faith (or lack of it) mandatorily, least of all to the head of their household or the state. Neither will the statistics be accurate: those of believers will be substantially exaggerated, because people will tend to register their "faith" at birth. The inflated figures are likely be used to secure further unwarranted religious privileges. Neither will non-believers be accurately counted. Such terms as agnostic are too subtle to be registered in tick boxes.
K Porteous Wood
National Secular Society

fields.trailText: Commanding all around it, the palace stands in the most expensive quarter of London, just a stone's throw from the park. It is one of the nation's most famous landmarks. People from all over the globe come to see it and carry home photographs bearing its image. Eleven thousand light bulbs decorate it each night; 12,000 people phone it each day. But now this palace has fallen out with another palace. One of its most esteemed callers has said he will call there no more. The house of Windsor has struck the sort of blow at the house of Fayed which in an earlier spat between the houses of York and Lancaster landed this country in civil war.
fields.body:
Commanding all around it, the palace stands in the most expensive quarter of London, just a stone's throw from the park. It is one of the nation's most famous landmarks. People from all over the globe come to see it and carry home photographs bearing its image. Eleven thousand light bulbs decorate it each night; 12,000 people phone it each day. But now this palace has fallen out with another palace. One of its most esteemed callers has said he will call there no more. The house of Windsor has struck the sort of blow at the house of Fayed which in an earlier spat between the houses of York and Lancaster landed this country in civil war.

The Duke of Edinburgh, whose warrant is being withdrawn from Harrod's, is one of those sensitive people who tend to get upset when accused of conspiring with MI5 to murder their daughters-in-law. He is taking his custom elsewhere. His crest will have to be taken off Mohamed Fayed's building, off his stationery and off his famous olive green shopping bags. The duke's wife and son are expected to follow his lead, though his mother-in-law has apparently undertaken to buy her goods in Knightsbridge "in perpetuity". The power of human sycophancy being what it is, some store analysts believe that other shoppers may cease to patronise Harrod's when they no longer have the chance to bump into a royal in some corner of soft furnishings. Yet spokesmen for Mr Fayed suggest he is taking the blow serenely - indeed with good grace. "The Duke of Edinburgh," he kindly conceded yesterday, "is entitled to shop where he likes."

And why not? In the balance between the palaces, not all the advantages are on the royal side. The people at the top of the Mall may be heads of state, commanders-in-chief and so on. But when did they ever get Raquel Welch to open anything for them? And how many teams have they got in the Nationwide Football League?

fields.headline: Moving pictures
fields.standfirst: Tate extends partnership scheme
fields.trailText: The Tate Gallery, which already has regional outposts in Liverpool and St Ives, yesterday launched a project to distribute some of its greatest art works to galleries around England.
fields.body:
The Tate Gallery, which already has regional outposts in Liverpool and St Ives, yesterday launched a project to distribute some of its greatest art works to galleries around England.

Five galleries, including the £16m tower due to open in Walsall, West Midlands, next month, will receive pictures by artists such as Picasso, Chagall and Matisse from April under a scheme backed by a £337,500 grant from the heritage lottery fund.

More than 175 works will be seen by an estimated 350,000 visitors at 15 separate displays at galleries in Kendal, Norwich, Sheffield and Stoke-on-Trent as well as Walsall. The dispersal will be supported by training and development opportunities through seminars, secondments and curators' forums.

The project seeks to build on the Tate's increasing involvement with regional art venues which over eight years has included partnerships with Norwich's Castle Museum and the East Anglia Art Foundation. It has also been encouraged by the successful staging of Tate Liverpool's urban exhibition at Nottingham's Castle Museum, and the loan of Rodin's sculpture The Kiss to Lewes in East Sussex.

Sandy Nairne, director of national programmes at the Tate Gallery, said: "The Tate is looking forward to working closely with the five partner galleries, and seeing works from the Tate collection enjoyed by more visitors around the country."

Arts and heritage minister Alan Howarth said: "I welcome the sharing of expertise that this programme makes possible. Widening access to the great national institutions is of tremendous importance."

Peter Jenkinson, director of the Walsall gallery, said: "Regional galleries are no longer willing to accept the crumbs from the national cultural table. There has to be a more equal partnership, with expertise flowing in both directions."

webTitle: High commission worker's racism case rejected

fields.headline: High commission worker's racism case rejected
fields.trailText: An industrial tribunal ruled yesterday against a woman who alleged racial discrimination against a British high commission in the Caribbean.
fields.body:
An industrial tribunal ruled yesterday against a woman who alleged racial discrimination against a British high commission in the Caribbean.

In a landmark judgment, the London South tribunal said the case did not come under its jurisdiction and that, for legal purposes, British embassies and high commissions should not be considered as being on British soil.

The law firm acting on behalf of Pamela Baptiste, 43, who claimed she had been dismissed as a consular assistant at the British high commission in St Lucia on racial grounds, said it is to appeal.

The tribunal said the question to be determined in relation to both the unfair dismissal and the racial discrimination charges was whether "that place of work is properly to be regarded as having been in Great Britain".

It noted the foreign office argument that international law created a system of privileges and immunities for foreign missions but that this did not "make the soil of a UK embassy 'forever English'."

The tribunal concurred that "although diplomatic premises are inviolable by the agents of the receiving state, they nevertheless form part of the territory of that state". It concluded Mrs Baptiste had worked entirely outside Britain and so it did not have jurisdiction to consider her claim.

Mrs Baptiste worked at the commission from 1991 to 1998. She had brought the case in St Lucia but said the foreign office had raised the issue of diplomatic immunity.

A foreign office spokeswoman said: "We would welcome the opportunity to defend the reputation of the high commission and the professional integrity of Peter Hughes [high commissioner] in court in St Lucia."

She admitted the foreign office had raised immunity in St Lucia but that "we would not use that as a means to prevent the case being brought to court". Mrs Baptiste's case had run into trouble in St Lucia because she had taken action against the high commission rather than the foreign office.

The tribunal said the question to be determined in relation to both the unfair dismissal and the racial discrimination charges was whether "that place of work is properly to be regarded as having been in Great Britain". It noted the foreign office argument that international law created a system of privileges and immunities for foreign missions but that this did not "make the soil of a UK embassy 'forever English'." The tribunal concurred that "although diplomatic premises are inviolable by the agents of the receiving state, they nevertheless form part of the territory of that state". It concluded Mrs Baptiste had worked entirely outside Britain and so it did not have jurisdiction to consider her claim. Mrs Baptiste worked at the commission from 1991 to 1998. She had brought the case in St Lucia but said the foreign office had raised the issue of diplomatic immunity. A foreign office spokeswoman said: "We would welcome the opportunity to defend the reputation of the high commission and the professional integrity of Peter Hughes [high commissioner] in court in St Lucia." She admitted the foreign office had raised immunity in St Lucia but that "we would not use that as a means to prevent the case being brought to court". Mrs Baptiste's case had run into trouble in St Lucia because she had taken action against the high commission rather than the foreign office.

webTitle: Village in zany league of its own

fields.headline: Village in zany league of its own
fields.standfirst: Last of the winter whines have yet to be heard as BBC comedy series holds up a distorting mirror
fields.trailText: Residents of a Hovis-advert town in the Pennine foothills will be glued to their television screens tonight to see how the sleepy reality of their community has been transformed into a macabre stranger-hating village from hell.
fields.body:
Residents of a Hovis-advert town in the Pennine foothills will be glued to their television screens tonight to see how the sleepy reality of their community has been transformed into a macabre stranger-hating village from hell.

Some may fear the worst after seeing the first series of BBC2's League of Gentlemen, which won a Golden Rose of Montreux award but baffled some locals who did not know what to make of a comedy show featuring a cannibalistic butcher and a pen-fixated employment officer.

Others are hoping that the fortunes of Hadfield in north Derbyshire could be transformed by media fame and the kind of riches that Last of the Summer Wine brought to Holmfirth, a dozen miles away.

The filming of the second series was not without tensions. Residents complained of disruption as the 60-strong BBC crew took over Hadfield's Sta tion Road and turned it into the main street of the fictional Royston Vasey.

The film crew in turn complained of grouchy residents and lads who burst on to the set uninvited. "When the road was closed we received no warning whatsoever," said Debbie Howarth of Howarth's newsagents and video club at the top of Station Road. "They were under the impression that everything was Station Road, but we're on Railway Road, so we didn't receive any notification."

Owners of businesses in Station Road were equally disgruntled and tempers frayed to such an extent that the Glossop Chronicle ran a story headlined Plague of Gentlemen. A community meeting was called to discuss what was needed to be done if the producers decided to come back for a third series.

But by the time the meeting had taken place, the film crew had left, and more importantly the shop owners had received their compensation cheques for loss of profit. The complaining eased off and the Glossop Advertiser was happy to announce: "Hadfield traders want the BBC back to film another series of The League of Gentlemen". Any dissenting voices remained unheard.

Barbara Hollingworth, owner of the village haberdashery, explained why there had been such friction during the filming. "We have folk round here who have been walking down the left side of the road and coming up the right side of the road for the last 30 years.

"One day they are asked to do something different and they go barmy. They said it was an inconvenience, but if you can't read and you can't think, it's bloody inconvenient, isn't it?"

Sylvia Hutton, the local florist, said: "One or two people made a lot of noise. But I think it is the most exciting thing that has happened in Hadfield for the past 30 years."

The BBC's problems were caused by thefts from the set and by bored teenagers who entertained themselves during the dark November evenings by shouting and jeering during filming and causing delays.

Tony Uttley, owner of Country Sport, which specialises in selling handmade saddles, sympathises with the producers' problems. He no longer admits children into his shop. "They come in here at lunchtime to do one thing - steal." However, Mr Uttley is not a fan of League of Gentlemen. "The series portrays Hadfield as if it was populated by every screwball under the sun. If you have a screwball comedy, you're going to have screwballs watching it, and then it will be only screwballs coming to visit the town."

Other locals guardedly described the show as interesting, offbeat, and "like Monty Python". Few actually described it as funny.

But Ms Hollingworth knows why they cannot see the joke. "Half of them don't watch it because they can see their bloody selves," she said. "To be honest, I could see myself, but at one point we couldn't tell the cast from the bloody locals.

"We've more crackpots that walk through that door than you could ever put on film. They need only sit in the back of this shop and they'd never need to write a script again."

webTitle: Scientists develop way to block CJD

fields.headline: Scientists develop way to block CJD
fields.standfirst: What's wrong with our food? - special report
fields.trailText: Scientists in New York believe they may have found a way to block the development of variant Creutzfeld-Jakob disease, the human form of BSE, which has until now invariably been fatal.
fields.body:
Scientists in New York believe they may have found a way to block the development of variant Creutzfeld-Jakob disease, the human form of BSE, which has until now invariably been fatal.

Turning their research into a medicine that could save lives was still uncertain and a long way off, said Claudio Soto and an international team of scientists, who published an early report of their work in this week's issue of the Lancet.

But doctors and patients will be excited by the potential of their research which offers the first hope, albeit a long way off, for those with variant CJD.

The researchers said their findings might be of use in blocking the development of all the spongiform encephalopathies, from BSE to variant CJD to scrapie in sheep. Their work centred on preventing the changes in the prion protein that lead to spongiform encephalopathies developing.

They found that the treatment reversed the changes in the prion protein. The infectivity of mice was decreased by 90% to 95%.

A report in the British Medical Journal published this week found that the sudden rise in cases of CJD at the end of 1998 was real and not caused by any errors in the collection of earlier statistics.

Azeem Majeed and colleagues from the office for national statistics, the national CJD surveillance unit in Edinburgh and the London Schol of Hygiene and Tropical Medicine were asked to investigate whether the rise in variant CJD patient numbers could have been effectively a statistical error.

They looked at reports of cases of the ordinary form of CJD from 1979 to 1996 to see whether any variant cases - thought to be caused by BSE transmission - had been missed. They concluded that none had.

"Hence any rapid increase in the number of cases of variant Creutzfeld-Jakob disease in this age group is likely to be real," they said.

webTitle: Judge shields boys from adult court

fields.headline: Judge shields boys from adult court
fields.trailText: A judge refused yesterday to allow two 12-year-old boys to face a jury trial in the crown court, citing the findings of the European court of human rights last month that the 11-year-old killers of James Bulger did not receive a fair trial when they were tried at Preston crown court in 1993.
fields.body:
A judge refused yesterday to allow two 12-year-old boys to face a jury trial in the crown court, citing the findings of the European court of human rights last month that the 11-year-old killers of James Bulger did not receive a fair trial when they were tried at Preston crown court in 1993.

The ruling is thought to be the first of its kind, but more such cases are likely in the future. Judge George Bathurst-Norman said he did not intend to set a precedent banning children from being tried in the crown court. But following the ruling by the Strasbourg judges, he had to look at the individual circumstances.

The youngsters, who are accused of indecently assaulting a 13-year-old girl, will now have to be dealt with by a youth court, where powers of punishment are much less.

Yesterday's hearing at Southwark crown court was told that the 12-year-olds had indecently assaulted their victim in July last year. Their case had been transferred from the youth court for a crown court trial, listed to start next Monday.

But a problem had arisen because the IQ of one of the youths, neither of whom can be named for legal reasons, was so low he stood to be "intimidated" in a crown court. The forensic clinical psychologist who examined him spoke of his "learning difficulties and consequent vulnerability".

Judge Bathurst-Norman said the psychologist's view left him no option but to consider the matter against the findings of the European court over the Bulger trial.

It stated that children faced with criminal proceedings should have their "age, level of maturity and intellectual and emotional capacities taken into account".

The judge added that because the "interests of justice" required the boys to be tried together he had decided to quash the indictment against both of them. This meant their case would return to the youth court.

webTitle: Bad weather delays lost trawler inquiry

fields.headline: Bad weather delays lost trawler inquiry
fields.trailText: As severe weather yesterday delayed the launch of the investigation into why the Solway Harvester sank with her seven crew in the Irish sea, it emerged that it was highly unlikely that the boat would ever be raised.
fields.body:
As severe weather yesterday delayed the launch of the investigation into why the Solway Harvester sank with her seven crew in the Irish sea, it emerged that it was highly unlikely that the boat would ever be raised.

The remains of the scallop dredger have been pinpointed to a spot on the seabed 11 miles off the coast of the Isle of Man, which falls under Manx jurisdiction. Authorities from the island yesterday met with the marine accident investigation branch to lay a framework for their inquiry.

A spokesman for the investigators said they planned, initially, to use underwater surveillance equipment to examine the wreckage of the 70ft Solway Harvester. Divers may be used at a later stage.

"The first thing to do is to get a remote operating vehicle down to examine the wreckage. After that we may use divers but it not usual to raise wreckage, generally there is no need," said the spokesman.

The authorities, whose task is to establish why the modern vessel sank in storm conditions it had faced many times previously, hope to have a ROV examine the wreckage within the next few days, weather permitting.

The last communication from the vessel was at 5.40pm on Tuesday. Since then its crew have been missing, presumed dead.

They are: Craig Mills, 29, his brother Robin Mills, 33, their cousin David Mills, 18, John Murphy, 22, David Lyons, 17, Wesley Jolly, 17, and Martin Milligan, 26.

All the men came from three fishing villages in the south west of Scotland, known collectively as the Machars of Whithorn. Yesterday the villagers were struggling to come to terms with their loss.

A fisherman who would have been on the boat if he had not been ill was said to be finding the deaths particularly hard to bear.

Charlie Boyce did not go fishing with his friends because he had just returned from an American holiday and was suffering from jet lag and flu.

A friend, who asked not to be named, said Mr Boyce was devastated by what had happened to his friends. "He's really, really upset and he can't speak about it, but I know he's been wondering if the incident would have happened if he'd been on board and I think it's probably been preying on his mind," he said.

The wider fishing community was also trying to work out how the tragedy could have happened. John Hermse, secretary of the Scallop Association, said the area in which the boat sank was not especially dangerous, and would have been a regular spot for the crew.

Mr Hermse said he believed the sinking was caused by something that happened suddenly. "I don't think you will find that there is much to do with a safety aspect. You will find that the vessel concerned was fully conscious of all safety," he added.

Ian Duncan, of the Scottish Fishermen's Association, said fishing was an inherently dangerous profession. "An accident such as this makes us all aware that, whatever precautions we take, we are dealing with nature - and nature can surprise us."

webTitle: Killings put 'Gunchester' back on crime map

fields.headline: Killings put 'Gunchester' back on crime map
fields.standfirst:
Police warn that weapons have become a fashion accessory as 17-year-old becomes latest victim of Manchester's gangland rivalry
London's gun violence: special report
fields.trailText: Police warned yesterday that guns had become "almost a fashion accessory" among young drugs criminals on the streets of Manchester, where the eighth fatal shooting in seven months saw a teenager bleed to death on a roadside verge.
fields.body:
Police warned yesterday that guns had become "almost a fashion accessory" among young drugs criminals on the streets of Manchester, where the eighth fatal shooting in seven months saw a teenager bleed to death on a roadside verge.

Armed patrols have been stepped up in a wide area south of the newly regenerated city centre where gang disputes are believed to have entered a new and vicious stage of individual revenge attacks.

Greater Manchester police admitted that they were "very worried" about the resurgence of shootings in a city where sensitive policing after the murder of a 14-year-old bystander in 1993 saw the "Gunchester" tag disappear from the formerly troubled area of Moss Side.

The new wave of killings has spread south from Moss Side into the neighbouring areas of Whalley Range and Longsight, with separate incidents involving rival gangs in Cheetham Hill on the Manchester-Salford border.

The latest victim was 17-year-old Gabriel Egharevba, who was out cycling with a friend at 10pm on Wednesday when he was blasted from his bike by a gunman firing two bursts from a motorbike.

The shooting echoed round Coverdale Crescent in Longsight, bringing out neighbours including a 28-year-old man who ran to help the dying youth.

"His mate ran back and kept shaking his friend," he said. "When we arrived we could see he had been shot in the left temple. He wasn't breathing and there was blood everywhere."

Neighbours tried unsuccessfully to flag down traffic on Hyde Road before paramedics and police arrived, but the youth was declared dead at the scene.

The killing came shortly before a pre-arranged police appeal for information about the gangland "execution" of a father of three who was shot three times in the back of the head with a Browning auto matic on January 5 in an alley in Whalley Range.

The charred body of Roger Ormsby, 34, was recovered from his gutted red BMW 320 which burst into flames after the corpse's foot jammed its accelerator and overheated the engine.

Detective Superintendent Keith Jardine said that a frightening minority of local youths had turned to guns to get to the top of the local criminal pecking order. "We have a relatively small group of youngish people who are into a culture where firearms have a great deal of importance and who have the nerve at the moment to go and use these firearms.

It's a culture where the gun appears to play a large part. It is a respect thing. The gun is sometimes seen as an accessory - almost a fashion accessory - and is sometimes used to demand respect from their peer group."

Claims of gun law in Moss Side were attacked this week by Phil Sumner, parish priest of St Wilfrid's, Moss Side, since 1976, who told the Manchester Evening News: "Many people who have been in this area for years have never seen a gun and know only what they read in the papers about the trouble.

"A spate of shootings can often begin from an ordinary argument between two guys about a girlfriend, and because some of these men are involved in the drug economy they have the weapons to protect themselves. Once someone is shot the tit-for-tat thing can happen."

The parish has targeted social deprivation in an area where pockets of unemployment among young black men top 80%. Self-confidence building measures include a module in African studies at St Thomas Aquinas school, where Father Sumner chairs the governors.

He said: "There is fortitude and joie de vivre here - the ability to celebrate life in spite of many problems."

Posters appealing for information about the two latest killings were distributed yesterday in Whalley Range and Longsight and police are trying to build up a picture of gangland suspects. Mr Jardine said that evidence had not been found to link any of the eight killings directly to one another, beyond the spread of the youth gun culture.

Motives for both murders remain unclear, with the teenager not regarded by police as a known gang member. He was on his way to his mother's when the gunman drew alongside, firing four or five shots and then a second burst.

Mr Ormsby was described as "free of any record of serious trouble with the law," with only minor convictions from his youth. Mr Jardine said that he was a "private man", with a long-standing partner, three children, and a share in a garage business and a small property company.

The killings followed the shooting of Simon Brown, 27-year-old father of one, in front of relatives and friends at a Boxing Day party in Cheetham Hill.

Shootings in the area totalled 41 last year, but the previous spate of fatalities came within 10 days last summer, when Martin Bennett, 25, Dorrie McKie, 20, and Antony Cook, 25, were all shot dead. The year's shootings included the raking of a pub and a family house in Longsight with semi-automatic fire.

January 12, 2000 Gabriel Egharevba, 17, shot from his bike in Longsight

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Hindley back in hospital
fields.body:
Hindley back in hospital

Moors murderer Myra Hindley was last night admitted to hospital for more tests over a potentially fatal brain condition.

Hindley, 57, was driven from Highpoint prison near Bury St Edmunds, Suffolk, where she is serving a life sentence, to Addenbrooke's hospital in Cambridge. It is the third time she has been admitted to hospital since collapsing in her cell after Christmas.

Docklands rail strike

Passenger service staff on the Docklands Light Railway, in east London are to stage a one-day strike over pay. They will walkout on January 24 in protest at a 3% pay offer.

The Rail Maritime and Transport union said it expects services to be seriously disrupted.

Hibs fan dies on Caribbean tour

A Hibs fan has died while jet-skiing in Tobago during a trip to support the Scottish Premier League football team on their Caribbean tour, the foreign office confirmed yesterday.

Alexander Urquhart, believed to be 47 and from Bankfoot, Perthshire, was with fellow fans near the Turtle Beach Hotel where they were staying when the accident happened.

A foreign office spokeswoman said a post mortem would be carried out.

Rescuers find body

Rescuers searching for a 43-year-old climber who slipped and fell on Ben Nevis have found a body, the Northern constabulary said yesterday.

Police said the body had not yet been identified as that of the missing climber from the north of England, but the search had been called off.

Samaritans deluged

The Samaritans yesterday disclosed that it was deluged by lonely and depressed callers during Christmas and New Year.

Some 246,000 callers rang the helpline over the period starting December 25 and ending January 7, 18% more calls than last year.

The charity said high expectations and "millennium hype" could have contributed to a sense of anti-climax and depression.
