webTitle: Oxford rowers in hot water in Spain

fields.headline: Oxford rowers in hot water in Spain
fields.trailText: All 24 rowers from the Oxford university lightweight rowing club held over an alleged rampage through the Spanish town of Amposta have been released without charge, the foreign office said last night.
fields.byline: Stuart Millar  and Adela Gooch  in Madrid
fields.body:
All 24 rowers from the Oxford university lightweight rowing club held over an alleged rampage through the Spanish town of Amposta have been released without charge, the foreign office said last night.

They each weigh under 11-and-a-half stone, but for a bunch of lightweights, the team made an impact on one small Spanish town, 100 miles south of Barcelona.

It took three different police corps to round up the students early yesterday morning. But not before some of them had allegedly caused £500 of damage to a pizza restaurant, upturned litter bins, and attacked parked cars.

As embarrassed university officials moved quickly to distance its more famous boat club "blues" from the errant crew, the students, aged 19-27, spent the night in custody waiting to hear whether they would face charges for public order offences and damage.

One was alleged to have had in his pocket the rear view mirror from a car after its windows were smashed. At least one other car was badly damaged, according to local reports.

The group of rowers, made up mainly of Britons, was celebrating the last night of its winter training camp on the delta of the River Ebro when the trouble flared.

Fernando Jiminez, a Guardia Civil spokesman, said: "They had been eating and drinking in the restaurant when things got out of hand. They left the restaurant and damage was caused to cars and street furniture, including street lamps."

The group had hoped to fly home yesterday but were held up giving statements to an examining magistrate. They were booked on a 9pm flight from Barcelona to London.

David Broomfield, from the British consulate in Barcelona, who had been charged with negotiating their release, said: "It's a case of youthful exuberance that went too far. We think just a few got out of hand but the whole group was rounded up."

A university spokesman said complaints about student behaviour would be treated seriously and internal disciplinary proceedings would be considered in the light of court findings.

The university emphasised that the lightweight rowing club was distinct from Oxford's boat club, which trains the heavyweight members who compete against Cambridge in the boat race.

Although they race against Cambridge at Henley each March, members of the lightweight club have neither an official boat house nor blues status.

fields.headline: Court threat over Pinochet ruling
fields.standfirst: www.newsunlimited.co.uk/pinochet
fields.trailText: Human rights groups last night launched a strongly worded challenge to Jack Straw's announcement that he is to allow the former dictator Augusto Pinochet to return to Chile on medical grounds, claiming the decision flouted natural justice.
fields.body:
Human rights groups last night launched a strongly worded challenge to Jack Straw's announcement that he is to allow the former dictator Augusto Pinochet to return to Chile on medical grounds, claiming the decision flouted natural justice.

Amnesty International, the Redress Trust and the Medical Foundation for the Care of Victims of Torture warned they were examining grounds for a possible legal challenge ahead of the seven day deadline for lodging objections.

Any challenge would almost certainly be based on the decision not to publish the medical reports which the home secretary relied upon in making his assessment that the former dictator is not fit to stand trial.

"Spain and the other states requesting extradition have not been able to have access to the medical report to challenge it, or to obtain independent medical opinion," the human rights groups said.

"The procedure Jack Straw has followed in deciding on General Pinochet's extradition is totally irregular and flouts natural justice."

A home office spokeswoman said Mr Straw would only release the report with the agreement of Gen Pinochet, who has called for his medical confidentiality to be respected. The spokeswoman rejected claims by pro-Pinochet supporters that Mr Straw had called for the report to remain secret, saying the former dictator had blocked the home office from releasing the report to Madrid.

In Spain, prosecution lawyers in the case said Mr Straw was contravening the 1984 convention against torture by not allowing them to study the medical reports. However, legal sources conceded there was nothing they could do to challenge Mr Straw's decision.

Spanish lawyers Joan Garces and Manuel Murillo, who worked with Judge Baltazar Garzon to prepare the case for extraditing Gen Pinochet for human rights abuses, said the withholding of the reports and the failure to keep Spain notified violated the convention.

They claimed the medical checks should not have been carried out without doctors representing the Spanish case or the victims of torture.

The Spanish government has intimated it has no desire to block Mr Straw's decision, but reports from Spain suggested Judge Garzon was determined not to let the extradition move collapse without a fight.

Interested parties have until 5pm on Tuesday to submit objections. The home office indicated that Mr Straw may not reach his final decision for another week, depending on the number and length of the representations.

Mr Straw's officials will inform human rights groups of the timing of his announcement to allow them to make plans to mount a legal challenge. This will avoid a dash to the high court to keep the general in the country if the home secretary ratifies his decision to send him back to Chile.

Once Mr Straw makes his announcement he will have to refer the Pinochet case to the director of public prosecutions. Under the UN torture convention the home secretary has to inform the DPP who will decide whether Gen Pinochet should be prosecuted in the UK, although prosecution in British courts is thought unlikely.

Disgruntled Labour MPs yesterday stepped up their campaign against the decision to send Gen Pinochet home. MPs from across the party signed two Commons early day motions protesting at the decision. Stephen Twigg, the ultra Blairite MP for Enfield Southgate, joined forces with the leftwing Jeremy Corbyn to declare "profound regret" at the prospect of the former dictator returning to Chile.

"If Senator Pinochet were to return to Chile he is unlikely ever to stand trial for the crimes against humanity committed under his regime," said the 16 Labour MPs who signed the motion. A second motion, signed by Mr Corbyn and Tony Benn, called for the release of the medical report "in the interests of justice".

webTitle: All house prices to be published

fields.headline: All house prices to be published
fields.trailText: In a move that will delight freedom of information campaigners and nosy neighbours, previous prices for homes in England and Wales are to be disclosed on official Land Registry documents, the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, announced last night.
fields.body:
In a move that will delight freedom of information campaigners and nosy neighbours, previous prices for homes in England and Wales are to be disclosed on official Land Registry documents, the lord chancellor, Lord Irvine, announced last night.

The rule change, which will come into effect on April 1 and apply to all sales registered after then, means that someone buying a house will be able to find out what the previous owner paid for it. It also means that a homeowner will be able to learn what his or her neighbour paid for their property.

The change restores the position to what it was several decades ago, bringing England and Wales into line with Scotland and most of Europe, where the price paid for a property is a matter of public record.

"After extensive consultation I have decided to restore 'price paid' to the Land Register," Lord Irvine said. "This is consistent with the government's policy to improve the house-buying process by making important information more readily available, particularly at an early stage of the process."

He added that property values were of great interest to people and there was no good reason why they should not be made available.

The change forms part of an ongoing process of improving public access to the Land Registry.

Up until a few years ago, only the buyer of a home could consult any records. Now, for a fee of £4 upwards, anyone is able to obtain records held by the registry against a property.

It also comes hard on the heels of a shake-up of house-buying which aims to slash the time it takes to purchase a property from months to weeks.

Under a new system likely to come into force in 2001, all homeowners in England and Wales will be required by law to put together a "seller's information pack" before their property can be put up for sale.

The labelling of the sales price will not mean that reams of data will be available on properties. "On a subsequent change of ownership, the original price paid will be removed from the register," Lord Irvine said.

Nevertheless, the new price information could prove an eye-opener for someone looking to buy a house in one of Britain's property hotspots who is curious to find out what the previous owner paid.

During recent months some parts of the country have seen record price growth. A survey this week showed that the London boroughs of Hackney, Merton and Wandsworth, and the town of Brighton, have seen property values leap 36%-37% in just 12 months.

fields.headline: Harrods loses duke's royal warrant
fields.trailText: Harrods is to be stripped of the 44-year-old royal warrant granted by the Duke of Edinburgh - a month after he was accused by the store's owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, of masterminding a secret service plot to murder his son and Diana, Princess of Wales.
fields.body:
Harrods is to be stripped of the 44-year-old royal warrant granted by the Duke of Edinburgh - a month after he was accused by the store's owner, Mohamed Al Fayed, of masterminding a secret service plot to murder his son and Diana, Princess of Wales.

Buckingham Palace announced that the prestigious London store would lose the endorsement when it expires at the end of this year. The official explanation was a "significant decline in the trading relationship", but it was clear that Mr Fayed had not done himself any favours by accusing the duke of murder during the libel action brought by the former MP Neil Hamilton.

The palace refused to discuss the matter. "It is for other people to make that connection," a spokesman said.

While Mr Fayed's foes were jubilant - Christine Hamilton pronounced herself "delighted" - the official Harrods line was sanguine. Britain's first family might have taken its accounts elsewhere, but foreign royalty still treads the green carpets of the palace of Knightsbridge. "The Duke of Edinburgh is perfectly entitled to shop wherever he likes. It's his choice," said the store's chief spokesman, Laurie Mayer.

Harrods first received a royal warrant in 1913, from Queen Mary. The duke's warrant was awarded in 1956 for Harrods' services as an "outfitter"; now the "man's shop" at Harrods seems to have dropped out of fashion. Prince Philip no longer avails himself of the personal tailoring provided at the store by the suitmaker Gieves & Hawkes, nor the "classic shirts" of Turnbull & Asser.

Harrods must now remove the three replicas of the duke's crest that adorn its Knightsbridge building, reprint its stationery and alter its carrier bags by the end of the year - or face criminal action accord ing to an 1887 law that made it an offence to claim false possession of a royal warrant.

The store attempted to play down the significance of the decision, saying it would not affect profitability. Mr Mayer said: "Levels of trading with Harrods by the duke have declined significantly over the past three years and we don't read any more into it than that." The decline in the duke's patronage "predates the Paris tragedy and all the rest of it", he said in an oblique reference to the libel battle, which Mr Fayed won.

Mr Mayer added: "We were trading for 60 or 70 years before we ever had a royal warrant and doing it very successfully. Royals from all over the world still come here anyway."

Royal warrants are granted for five years before being renewed. There are about 800 warrant holders, with 1,100 endorsements between them.

Harrods is one of a select band of firms to boast the maximum four royal warrants: alongside the duke, only the Queen, the Prince of Wales and the Queen Mother hold the power to endorse retailers with their crests. Those awarded by the Queen ("suppliers of china, glass and fancy goods") and Prince Charles ("outfitters and saddlers") are due for review at the end of this year, and the store conceded yesterday that it would probably be relieved of those too. The Queen Mother has no plans to review her warrant ("suppliers of provisions and household goods").

Among current warrant holders are W Forbes, of Braemar, Aberdeenshire, which holds the royal seal of approval for taxidermy; Clark and Butcher, of Ely, Cambridgeshire, which holds a warrant for dog food; and the Glasgow firm RG Hardie & Co, which supplies bagpipes to Balmoral. Warrant holders in the 18th and 19th centuries included a pinmaker, ratcatcher and mole-taker.

webTitle: Tyson can enter UK, Straw rules

fields.headline: Tyson can enter UK, Straw rules
fields.trailText: Mike Tyson is to be allowed to enter Britain, despite his conviction for rape, after an intervention by the home secretary last night.
fields.body:
Mike Tyson is to be allowed to enter Britain, despite his conviction for rape, after an intervention by the home secretary last night.

After two days of insisting that the boxer's case could only be considered by the immigration service and was not a matter for the government, Jack Straw said it would be "invidious" to leave the decision to an immigration officer and that he was using his discretionary powers to allow Tyson into the country.

The ruling means Tyson will arrive in Britain on Sunday for a fight against Julius Francis in Manchester on January 29, his first outside America.

Mr Straw said he had been swayed by the potential economic damage involved in cancelling the sell-out fight and the fact that thousands of members of the public who had bought tickets would have been disappointed.

The future of the bout had been in doubt because of immigration rules which state that entry into Britain should be refused to anyone who has committed a crime that would carry a 12-month jail term or more in Britain. Entry could only be justified on compassionate grounds.

Tyson was sentenced to six years in 1992 for rape and last year was jailed for 12 months after attacking two motorists.

Initially the government insisted that the compassionate grounds would be considered by an immigration official when the American boxer arrived at Heathrow.

Mr Straw said: "In the special circumstances of this case, it would be invidious for an individual immigration officer to weigh the competing considerations involved.

"I have looked very carefully at the representations that have been submitted to the immigration service by [the fight's promoter] Frank Warren and I consider there are exceptional circumstances that justify my decision."

Mr Warren had submitted a 67-page document to the home office outlining the reasons why Tyson should be admitted to Britain.

He said last night: "I'm pleased that he has now gained entry. I have been proved right and have always acted correctly. I said at the start of this affair that this has been about people trying to get political gain from it."

Mr Straw said he was not satisfied that the rule preventing people with convictions from entering Britain, which has been in place since the early 1970s, had been consistently upheld. He conceded that people entering the country were not routinely asked about their convictions and ordered a review of the rule to be carried out.

Tyson's representatives claimed that he was being unfairly treated because a number of other boxers and sports stars with criminal convictions had been admitted to Britain in the past.

Ann Widdecombe, shadow home secretary, said: "This whole debacle has been bungled and mismanaged from beginning to end by Jack Straw."

Francis, Tyson's opponent, who has also spent time in prison, said: "People make mistakes, people change. I don't think that Mike Tyson should be punished every time he steps a foot sideways, frontways or backwards."

The British boxer will earn £350,000 for the fight. His opponent will receive £5m.

fields.headline: National round-up
fields.trailText:
Baby dies after being left in bath
A nine-month-old boy drowned after he was left playing in the bath with his two-year-old sister, an inquest heard yesterday.
fields.body:
Baby dies after being left in bath
A nine-month-old boy drowned after he was left playing in the bath with his two-year-old sister, an inquest heard yesterday.

Anthony Pinkerton died minutes after his mother had left him "splashing about, sitting up and laughing".

The inquest in Windsor, Berkshire, heard that the baby and his sister Charlotte were left for about five minutes while their mother Vanessa made breakfast and went about her daily chores.

Ms Pinkerton said the accident at her flat in Slough, Berkshire, last September happened as she chatted with her partner, Adam Leszek, about the birth of her cousin's new baby.

She said: "It is not very often that I put them both in on their own. I would normally get in with them and we would all play with the toys."

Anthony had been bathed using the adult bath for two months, she added, and could sit up on his own and pull himself up.

While the children were in the bath, she made cheese on toast and tea for herself and Mr Leszek and did some vacuuming before chatting in the bedroom with him.

After about five minutes she checked on the children and screamed when she saw Anthony "floating on his back face up".

She added: "Adam came running in and started to give him mouth to mouth resuscitation. Charlotte was standing up in the bath and screaming."

Neighbours called an ambulance which, according to Ms Pinkerton, "took 20 minutes" to arrive.

"The paramedics just walked up the stairs as if they did not have a care in the world," she told the inquest.

Anthony was pronounced dead on arrival at Wexham Park hospital, in Slough.

Peter Jerreat, a pathologist, said Anthony had drowned. He added that it was unlikely that the earlier arrival of the ambulance would have saved his life.

Recording a verdict of accidental death, Mr Bedford said: "It is an absolute tragedy that a child this age should lose its life."

Folic acid could cut spina bifida
Folic acid, which can prevent babies being born with spina bifida, may be added to all flour following a report published yesterday.

Yvette Cooper, minister for public health, yesterday said the government would put the proposal, in a report from the committee on medical aspects of food and nutrition policy, out to consultation.

In the report, scientists said mothers who ate foods made from flour which was fortified with folic acid before and during pregnancy could reduce the risk of neural tube defects in their babies. Spina bifida is a form of neural tube defect.

They said adding 240 micrograms of folic acid per 100g of flour would prevent 41% of cases of neural tube defects "without resulting in unacceptably high intakes in any group of the population".

Women planning a pregnancy would still be advised to take folic acid supplements.
Sarah Boseley

Insect study may save Africa crops
Scientists have been granted £34,000 to study why birds do not eat a type of African caterpillar, in the hope that their work can save crops.

Researchers at Stirling university will study the armyworm caterpillar, from east Africa, which is capable of destroying entire crops.

They will try to find whether the caterpillar's diet, which contains traces of cyanide from star grass, makes it immune to birds.

The project will also try to discover if birds avoid caterpillars of certain colours - armyworms turn from green to black when in groups.

Biologist Ken Wilson said: "The reason why they turn black has been a mystery for decades."

He added that by finding out more about the insects it might be possible to find methods to control them.

Life jail for revenge killing pair
The brother and husband of a woman who had an affair with her uncle were yesterday jailed for life for his murder.

Shazad Hussain, 25, and Imran Farid, 23, of Wakefield, West Yorkshire, killed Amjad Farooq, 38, because he had "disgraced the family".

Luton crown court heard that the killing was in revenge for Mr Farooq's secret five-year affair with Shazad's sister, Nyla Hussain, 24.

The trial jury was discharged after failing to reach verdicts on Nyla and her father Khadim, 49, who were both charged with murder.

Mr Farooq's body was found in a field at Silsoe, near Luton, in August 1998.

The court heard that Shazad and Imran Farid killed him after learning about the affair from Nyla.

Nine members of the Hussain family stood trial over the killing. Three were acquitted and two were released during the trial due to lack of evidence. Nyla and Khadim Hussain were released on bail after the hearing.

Khadim's nephew, Zahoor Rashid, 26, from Luton, who is wanted in connection with the killing, is believed to have fled to Pakistan the day after the murder.

Stalkers 'not crazed strangers'
The most dangerous stalkers are jilted lovers, not psychotic strangers, new research discloses today. A study of 50 stalkers in north London showed a strong association between violence and previous sexual intimacy with the victims.

But there was no foundation to the popular myth that the typical stalker was a stranger with a crazed obsession.

Of the 20 case histories in which there was sexual intimacy, 70% involved violence. Among these there were five murders, three attempted murders, four cases of grievous bodily harm, and two assaults causing actual bodily harm.

Psychiatrist Frank Farnham, from the Royal Free hospital and University College medical school, London, and two colleagues reporttheir findings in the Lancet medical journal.

The doctors identified stalkers by examining five years of case files from a north London forensic service.

Of the group, 20 stalkers were former sexual partners of their victims, 18 were ac quaintances, and only 12 were total strangers. In total, 22 cases involved violence, and 26 stalkers had a psychotic illness.

There was no significant association between violence and psychosis, the researchers said.

The doctors pointed out that an investigation carried out in the United States had suggested that as many as 8% of women and 2% of men had been stalked at some time.

David James, from the Royal Free Hospital, who helped carry out the new study, stressed that most people did not resort to stalking when a relationship broke down, and called for more government-funded research.

Yorkshire challenge to Disney
Spend, Spend, Spend, the musical based on the life and loves of pools winner Viv Nicholson has been nominated for eight Olivier awards - the same as the £10m Disney spectacular, the Lion King.

The show, which was first performed in Leeds before transferring to the West End, tells how Yorkshire lass Viv, who won £152,000 in 1961, spent every penny on fast cars and faster living.

Now a grandmother, and a teetotal Jehovah's Witness, she wept last night when she heard the news at her home in Castleford. "I can't believe it. I've found it a very emotional experience. The first four of five times I went I felt I was watching someone else's life. But it's fantastic."

Jude Kelly, artistic director of the West Yorkshire Playhouse in Leeds, who commissioned the play, said she felt proud. "It took a regional theatre to believe in a new British musical - stories about ordinary people still matter."

Barbara Dickson and Rachel Leskovac, who play the older and younger Viv, are both nominated for best actress in a musical, and Spend, Spend, Spend is also in the running for best director, best new musical, best supporting actor, best choreographer and best lighting.

But it is the National Theatre and Royal Shakespeare Company that dominate the Oliviers, with the National bagging 21 nominations - six for its latest revival of an American musical, Leonard Bernstein's Candide.

Three of the RSC's eight nominations are for The Winter's Tale, with Antony Sher favourite for best actor in a field that includes Roger Allam for Summerfolk, Henry Goodman for The Merchant Of Venice and Michael Sheen for Look Back In Anger - at the National. Stephen Dillane is in the running for The Real Thing at Donmar Warehouse.

His co-star Jennifer Ehle is up against Maggie Smith in The Lady In The Van for best actress as are Janie Dee for Comic Potential and Alison Steadman for The Memory Of Water.
Fiachra Gibbons

McDonald's coup for Teletubbies
Ronald McDonald is to say "eh-oh" to children's television favourites the Teletubbies after they landed a deal to swap their tubby-toast and custard for burgers and fries at fast food chain McDonald's.

The deal, which will see Tinky Winky, Dipsy, Laa-Laa and Po take on a new role in the US, is regarded asa coup for the Teletubbies. Previously the burger chain has had a long-standing exclusive deal with Disney to promote its characters.

It is believed young diners opting for a McDonald's Happy Meal will get a toy when they pick up their food as part of the Teletubbies Hugs campaign which will begin later this year.

Teletubbies has become a hit in the US since their first airing in April 1998 and now ranks in the top three pre-school children's television shows. They were created by Ragdoll Productions and aired by the BBC. Anne Wood, who co-created the show, was awarded a CBE in the New Year honours list.

A spokeswoman for Itsy Bitsy Entertainment, which markets the Teletubbies in the US, said: "For McDonald's to want to do something with the Teletubbies shows just how big they have become over here."

"We're delighted to be working with the Teletubbies because they are loved by children everywhere and are the perfect addition to our roster of premiere entertainment properties," said R J Milano, a McDonald's vice-president. Colin Blackstock

Boys, 12, spared jury trial
A judge refused yesterday to allow two 12-year-old boys to face a jury trial in the crown court, citing the findings of the European court of human rights last month that the 11-year-old killers of James Bulger did not receive a fair trial when they were tried at Preston crown court in 1993.

The ruling is thought to be the first of its kind.

Judge George Bathurst-Norman told a hearing at Southwark crown court that he did not intend to set a precedent banning children from being tried in the crown court. But after the Strasbourg ruling he had to look at the individual circumstances.

The youngsters, who are accused of indecently assaulting a 13-year-old girl, will now have to be dealt with by a youth court, where powers of punishment are much less.

Allan Levy QC, a child law expert, said: "It's a refreshingly speedy reaction to the Bulger judgment and an implied message to the government to reform the system for trying children as a whole." Clare Dyer

fields.headline: Interest rates go up again
fields.trailText: Soaring house prices and tumbling unemployment triggered the third increase in interest rates in five months yesterday as the Bank of England moved to prevent inflation rising above the government's 2.5% target.
fields.body:
Soaring house prices and tumbling unemployment triggered the third increase in interest rates in five months yesterday as the Bank of England moved to prevent inflation rising above the government's 2.5% target.

Amid fears of a return to the boom conditions of the late 80s in London and the south-east, the Bank's monetary policy committee prompted anger among industrialists and trade unionists by pushing up base rates from 5.5% to 5.75%.

Britain's big mortgage lenders said they would review home-loan rates over the next few days, but are expected to pass on the quarter-point increase to their borrowers. Analysts believe the Bank will increase rates again next month when it has more information about the strength of the economy over the Christmas and New Year period.

In a statement explaining the decision, the Bank said: "Prospective growth in domestic demand remains strong: increases in wealth, labour income and household borrowing all suggest that consumer spending will continue to grow strongly."

Inflation excluding mortgage interest payments is currently 2.2%, but the Bank said labour shortages and supply bottlenecks would put the government's target in jeopardy unless rates were increased immediately.

The announcement coincided with fresh evidence of Britain's two-tier economy, with the Halifax revealing that house prices in Greater London had gone up by almost a third in 1999 - a faster rate of increase than in the 80s Lawson boom - while the clothing firm Dewhirst blamed a squeeze on profits for the loss of 1,000 jobs at its factories in Winsford, Cheshire and Peterlee, County Durham.

The Council of Mortgage Lenders said the Bank's move would help ensure that the "hotspots" in the housing market were kept in check and did not lead to widespread overheating. "Although rising interest rates will never be welcome to homebuyers, they are a price worth paying for low inflation, not only in the wider economy but in the housing market", said Michael Coogan, the CML's director general.

City dealers had anticipated the Bank's decision, and share prices and the pound were unaffected. However, industry said the move would inflict further damage on manufacturers and exporters struggling with the impact of the high pound. Digby Jones, the newly appointed director-general of the CBI, said the decision was "unsurprising but still disappointing". Roger Lyons, general secretary of the MSF union, said: "This is a disaster for manufacturing, particularly for jobs in the north."

fields.headline: Dobson accused of sharp tactics
fields.standfirst: The London mayor: special report
fields.trailText: Glenda Jackson yesterday claimed that her Labour colleague Frank Dobson had asked for her endorsement of his campaign to become London's mayor by suggesting she should ask her supporters to put him as their second preference on ballot forms.
fields.body:
Glenda Jackson yesterday claimed that her Labour colleague Frank Dobson had asked for her endorsement of his campaign to become London's mayor by suggesting she should ask her supporters to put him as their second preference on ballot forms.

The charge of sharp tactics was emphatically denied by Mr Dobson after his former ministerial colleague rebuffed the alleged overture.

Far from declaring that Mr Dobson or Mr Livingstone was her second preference - both have asked for her support - Ms Jackson let it be known that she still aims to win the nomination from Labour's London electoral college next month.

Both sides in the latest row admit that the two candidates talked privately on Wednesday. Ms Jackson claims Mr Dobson offered her a senior position in his "cabinet" in exchange for her asking her supporters to make Mr Dobson their second choice when voting. He also asked her to keep quiet about the conversation, she said. Mr Dobson denies putting any offer to her.

"Even after all these months, they still don't understand Glenda. If they think they can bounce her into an endorsement for Frank then they are in for a nasty shock. This little episode has made an endorsement for Ken a much greater possibility," her spokesman said.

Mr Dobson's team, now staffed with party professionals and pulling in public endorsement from cabinet members such as Robin Cook, claims to be barely five points behind Mr Livingstone in the crucial constituency section, 35% to around 40%, according to its canvass returns. One in five Labour party members in London are allegedly still undecided, and Ms Jackson can count on 2% to 3%.

Mr Dobson is expected to win the MPs' and MEPs' section, although Mr Livingstone is ahead in the trade union third of the electoral college. Privately Ms Jackson's staff know that she will lose, and agree that their rivals will each win one section of the college. But they claim that Mr Livingstone will win the constituency section "by a mile" and that Mr Dobson fears he will come third. That would confirm his defeat.

Ballot papers go out to Labour's 60,000 London members on January 25 and must be returned by February 16. Each voter can list candidates in order of preference: hence the importance of the second vote.

The result is expected by February 21 - more than a month after the Tories' second ballot, which is expected to confirm Steve Norris as the post-Archer candidate on Monday.

The real election for mayor is on May 4.

fields.headline: Myra Hindley back in hospital
fields.trailText: Moors murderer Myra Hindley spent last night in Addenbrokes hospital in Cambridge after undergoing three hours of tests. She was said to be in a stable condition.
fields.body:
Moors murderer Myra Hindley spent last night in Addenbrokes hospital in Cambridge after undergoing three hours of tests. She was said to be in a stable condition.

Hindley, 57, is suffering from a cerebral aneurysm, a potentially fatal brain condition, and is scheduled to undergo further tests today.

She was taken to the hospital last night for pre-arranged consultations with neurosurgeons. It is the third time she has been in hospital since she collapsed in her cell shortly after Christmas.

Keith Day, Addenbrooke's administrative director, said: "The prisoner has completed her diagnostic procedure. This went well and after consultation with the medical team it has been agreed she will remain in Addenbrooke's overnight for further consultation and possible treatment. This will take place tomorrow."

Mr Day said her visit to the hospital had not interefered with the treatment of other patients and that it was up to the consultants to decide what the best form of treatment would be.

The aneurysm is caused by an artery swelling up at the base of the brain. Sudden ruptures of the artery can lead to fatal blood loss or severe brain damage.

The condition is aggravated by stress and smoking.

Hindley, who has spent 33 years in prison, is a 40-a-day smoker and has been dogged by ill health, suffering from angina, osteoporosis, high blood pressure and a fractured thigh.

She and Ian Brady, her fellow Moors murderer and former lover, were given life sentences for the murders of 10-year-old Lesley Ann Downey and 17-year-old Edward Evans in May 1966 after being arrested at their home in Hyde, Greater Manchester.

fields.headline: Former Tory MP joins Labour hopefuls
fields.standfirst: New Labour in power: special report
fields.trailText: A former Tory MP who had to quit his seat nearly a decade ago after being caught by the police for suspected homosexual cruising on Hampstead heath heads the list of more than 700 new Labour candidates approved by Millbank to seek parliamentary seats for the next general election.
fields.body:
A former Tory MP who had to quit his seat nearly a decade ago after being caught by the police for suspected homosexual cruising on Hampstead heath heads the list of more than 700 new Labour candidates approved by Millbank to seek parliamentary seats for the next general election.

Alan Amos, the former Tory MP for Hexham until 1992, reflects both a new tolerance in private sexual matters and a swing to the right and business by the party.

Mr Amos, a former president of Oxford University Conservative Association and a Conservative central office researcher, is a strong supporter of the NHS. He also favours flogging muggers and rapists and is anti-abortion.

Other Labour hopefuls, according to Tribune newspaper, include advisers to City banks, lobbyists, millionaire city accountants and small business supporters. They will be competing against more traditional Labour candidates holding union jobs and council leaders for the expected 300 candidate vacancies in parliamentary seats.

The new broom includes Tommy Hutchinson, political adviser to NatWest bank plc, and former Deloitte partner and Labour finance director, David Pitt Watson. Also highly tipped for a seat is Stephen Alambritis, the press and parliamentary affairs adviser for the Federation of Small Businesses.

Other approved "modernising" candidates include Sion Simon, a journalist on the Spectator magazine; James Purnell, one of Tony Blair's advisers in Downing Street; Valerie Vaz, the former TV presenter and sister of Keith Vaz, the minister for Europe; and Iain Malcolm, adviser to Alan Donnelly, Labour's former leader in the European parliament.

webTitle: Britons among victims as plane crash kills at least 17

fields.headline: Britons among victims as plane crash kills at least 17
fields.trailText: Thirteen Britons were on a plane which crashed off the Libyan coast yesterday killing at least 17 people. The foreign office confirmed last night that a number of Britons were among the dead.
fields.byline: Peter Capella  in Geneva and  Owen Bowcott
fields.body:
Thirteen Britons were on a plane which crashed off the Libyan coast yesterday killing at least 17 people. The foreign office confirmed last night that a number of Britons were among the dead.

The Swiss-registered plane - which was carrying 38 pas sengers, thought to be oil workers, and three crew - came down shortly before it was due to land at Marsa Al-Brega, the centre of the Libyan petrochemical industry, 460 miles east of Tripoli.

A Swiss transport ministry statement said: "Around 12.30 Swiss time (11.30 GMT) the pilot began a normal approach to Brega airport. About five minutes later he reported that both engines had cut out and announced he was attempting an emergency landing... The aircraft hit the water just before the Libyan coast and sank."

Libyan authorities scrambled a rescue operation and later confirmed that 23 people were missing or dead and 18 had been rescued.

Swiss radio said that as well as the Britons, 16 Libyans and two Canadians had been on the scheduled flight from Tripoli. Other passengers were said to be from India, Pakistan, the Philippines and Croatia.

The plane, thought to be a Shorts twin turboprop, was owned by the Swiss company Avista and had been leased by Sirte Oil to ferry workers around Libya. It was the sec ond Swiss aircraft to crash this week. On Monday a commuter plane crashed after take-off from Zurich, killing all 10.

The foreign office last night said that some of the Britons had survived. "We are in the process of trying to inform next of kin," a spokesman said. "Our thoughts and prayers go out to the families of the dead and the survivors."

fields.headline: Fiery protests greet Ocalan's reprieve
fields.standfirst:
Despite growing anger from within Turkey, human rights groups praise Ankara's decision to suspend Kurdish leader's execution
The Kurds: special report
fields.trailText: The 67-year-old mother of an officer killed fighting Kurdish rebels and the brother of a dead soldier set themselves alight yesterday in protest at the Turkish government's decision to delay the execution of the jailed separatist leader Abdullah Ocalan.
fields.body:
The 67-year-old mother of an officer killed fighting Kurdish rebels and the brother of a dead soldier set themselves alight yesterday in protest at the Turkish government's decision to delay the execution of the jailed separatist leader Abdullah Ocalan.

Sevim Oskay, whose army lieutenant son was killed five years ago, and Eyup Temiz both suffered minor burns as bystanders rushed to douse the flames. They were later discharged from hospital.

Their attempted self-immolation in an Istanbul cemetery reflecting the fury felt by many relatives of those who died during the 15-year war in south-east Turkey, came as Europe heaped praise on the prime minister, Bulent Ecevit, for granting the reprieve.

In the past, Mr Ocalan's supporters have more often resorted to setting themselves ablaze in an attempt to draw attention to his fate.

By agreeing to wait for the European Court of Human Rights to review Mr Ocalan's appeal before sending the case to parliament - to approve the death sentence or reduce it to a prison sentence - Mr Ecevit is buying time to persuade his parliamentary allies that executing the Kurdish leader would severely damage Turkey's relationship with the European Union.

No country in western Europe currently allows the death penalty. The European court is expected to find against hanging, although its review could take two years.

Mr Ecevit is determined to avoid a clash with Europe so soon after the Helsinki EU summit last year, which saw Turkey accepted as a candidate for membership.

Ankara's human rights record, in particular its treatment of the country's Kurdish minority in the south-east, has been used in the past by Brussels as an argument for delaying its coveted acceptance by the EU.

"It is the right way to handle this issue in respect of democracy, human rights, and the international commitments of Turkey," said the European Commission spokesman, Jean-Christophe Filori. "It's good news for us," he said.

News of the delay and the commitment to closer relations with the west was also welcomed by Turkey's business community - the stock market jumped by more than 7% during the day.

And President Suleyman Demirel added his voice in support. "This decision is a relief for the country," he said.

Human rights groups in Europe and Turkey congratulated the 74-year-old prime minister on his decision, which the minority rightwing partners in the ruling coalition, the MHP, have opposed.

"While the death penalty exists, Mr Ocalan and all others on Turkey's death row remain at risk," said Kerim Yildiz of the London-based Kurdish Human Rights Project.

"Turkey should follow the example of other European countries by incorporating Protocol 6 of the European convention on human rights [which bans capital punishment] into Turkish law."

Husnu Ondul, the head of Turkey's Human Rights Association, said the decision would spur the country's efforts to improve its poor human rights record, a priority for eventual EU entry talks.

"This is an encouraging decision for all citizens as an example of the protection of human rights and freedoms in the framework of law," he declared.

Mr Ocalan, who founded the Kurdistan Workers' Party (PKK) which has fought for Kuridish autonomy, was seized by Turkish commandos in Kenya last year and flown to Turkey, where he was tried. He was condemned to hang for treason for the war in which more than 30,000 people died.

Turkey has not executed anyone since 1984.

Mr Ecevit personally opposes the death penalty. He largely got his way at a seven-hour meeting on Wednesday night with Devlet Bahceli, his hardline nationalist coalition ally who had sought parliamentary ratification for Mr Ocalan to be hanged.

But Mr Bahceli won a pledge that the Ocalan file will definitely go to parliament for consideration when the European Court issues its ruling.

Mr Ocalan's lawyers said after visiting him in prison yeserday that he was pleased by the decision.

fields.headline: A league of their own
fields.standfirst: Comic geniuses or sewer-minded sickos? As The League of Gentlemen return to the impossibly weird Royston Vasey for a second series of their blackly comic soap opera,  Danny Leigh  meets the men behind the monsters
fields.trailText: Comic geniuses or sewer-minded sickos? As The League of Gentlemen return to the impossibly weird Royston Vasey for a second series of their blackly comic soap opera, Danny Leigh meets the men behind the monsters
fields.body:
Among that rarefied stratum of society whose faces regularly flicker across the nation's TVs, there's a rule of thumb whereby you can tell if anyone is actually taking any notice: use public transport. Or, more accurately, use public transport and wait for the deluge of double-takes and muffled giggles to reassure you of your stranglehold on the public consciousness.

Which, if they cared, would be bad news for The League Of Gentleman.

"Yeah, supposedly if you're on the tube you'll hear this chorus of your catchphrases", explains a rueful Mark Gatiss, one quarter of the unnervingly polite troupe whose mercifully inimitable brand of comedy returns for its second series tonight (BBC 2, 10pm). "That's supposed to be the point at which you know you've become famous. And I can honestly say that's never happened to me. Not once. Never ."

His colleagues - Steve Pemberton, Reece Shearsmith and non-performing writer/producer Jeremy Dyson - shake their heads in unison.

"Me neither."

"Or me."

"But that's good," shrugs Pemberton, "because you don't want people's personalities overshadowing the characters. This way the characters exist in their own right, rather than just being Mark or Reece or me dressed up in a funny costume."

So, no, in an age of faux-celebrity comics forcing their less-than-savoury features on the world at every available opportunity, you probably wouldn't recognise the League of Gentlemen. But you'll recognise said alter-egos; and if you don't, you should perhaps take tonight's opportunity to get acquainted.

Because, while the adjectives most commonly employed around their 60-strong retinue of orthodontically-challenged grotesques are - by their own admission - "warped, disturbing, odd... oh, and sinister, we get sinister a lot", funny doesn't get as many mentions as it should.

Equal parts soap opera and sideshow, the League's Tod Browning-meets-Peak Practice shtick is certainly one of the stranger visions to have crept onto the small screen in recent years; it's also the most nervelessly deadpan since Brass Eye, Chris Morris's late and still lamented one-man battery of the British infotainment industry. Although, having said that, you can see where the warped, disturbing, odd and sinister come in. Set in the fictitious northern outpost of Royston Vasey, home to toad enthusiasts Harvey and Val Denton, misanthropic Job Club maven Pauline and - lest we forget - Tubbs and Edward, the nightmarishly porcine owners of the darkly secretive local shop, the League must come as a shock to anyone for whom the caffeinated antics of Friends represents Friday night's comic blueprint.

And, as such, it's the kind of acquired taste which means, after five years together, only now are the collective Gentlemen coming to terms with the pressures of expectation.

"Obviously, as ourselves, no one knows who we are," Pemberton explains, "but as the League, I think there is a certain level of pressure going into a second series, which isn't something we've ever had to deal with before."

"It's been quite intimidating," agrees Shearsmith, "because now the cat's out of the bag - everyone knows there's this place called Royston Vasey, and everyone knows it's full of these weird characters. So whereas we had the element of surprise before, now we're going to have to surprise people with new characters, and what we do with the old ones."

"So we've made everything bigger this time round," Pemberton interjects. "It's almost epic."

Besides the sheer freakishness of much of the material, meanwhile, there's also been the lack of easy categorisation to contend with (which accounts for the countless well-meaning but misguided comparisons to everything from Monty Python to Twin Peaks littering their press cuttings). Not quite sketch show and several leagues beyond the drab tropes of observational stand-up, theirs is probably not the largest peer group.

"There's always been a host of people we've admired and found funny," Dyson remarks, "but I've always thought if you like and respect someone, you should like and respect them enough to try and avoid ripping them off, even subconsciously."

"And also," Pemberton continues, "a lot of the time what you get with TV is producers assembling these sketch shows, assembling the cast and assembling the writers, and ending up with that fairly anonymous, production-line kind of comedy. Whereas with us, this is nothing but our sense of humour. This is what we find funny. However disturbing people might think that is."

But has there ever been a point at which even they found their cast of inbreeds, failed rock musicians and accident-prone vets just too unsettling, too bleak ?

"God no," the cry goes up.

"The more hearts we break the better," Shearsmith laughs. "I mean, if people are coming away from the show feeling freaked out that's great, because then they're really getting involved with the characters."

And what, bizarre though it may sound, if one of those characters suddenly became hugely, implausibly popular. What if they found themselves responsible for another Loadsamoney, or a deformed, sexually troubled Mr Bean?

They ponder the scenario.

"Then we'd kill them," Gatiss replies with a broad, innocent smile. "Without a shadow of doubt. Whoever they were, as soon as we could, we'd kill them."

fields.headline: Peeling the plums
fields.trailText: Snobs | Meet The Ancestors
fields.body:
In Snobs (ITV) Jean Broke-Smith, who is, of course, my aunt or, possibly, an impenetrable alias, talked us through the well-bred way to peel a banana. "In a good restaurant you should have a knife and fork that is purely for fruit. You cut off each end of the banana with your knife and then, holding on with your fork, you slice the centre with your knife. With the curve of the banana towards you, peel the skin off and it rolls out. Then you gently cut up your little sections of banana."

Golly, as Miss Broke-Smith is apt to say, golly, this is good stuff. If Dora Bryan had known her way around a fruit bowl, she would have been spared a most traumatic meal at Buckingham Palace. Imprudently she took a bunch of grapes and realised too late she was not au fait with the pip position. Did you spit them out and, if so, where? Conscious of Prince Philip's fascinated eye on her, the indomitable woman ate the lot.

Ms Broke-Smith was an etiquette teacher, one of those interesting jobs that were not suggested to you at school. Almost everyone else was a social commentator except Beverley Bloom, who was a self-confessed shopaholic, and Giles Hilton, who was a happily married ex-accountant. I would have liked to be a happily married ex-accountant, but they kept suggesting the executive branch of the civil service. Giles must be a dreaded dinner guest as he not only brings his own Arabica coffee but "jokingly" identifies every spice in the stew. Likewise Jean, who is apt to say "I have a friend, well, acquaintance really" before recounting some frightful faux pas like a gold washbasin. "I couldn't use it. It was just too much!" How fortunate then that it was not a gold loo.

Snobs was made by September Films, who specialise in electronic gossip, snippety bits dovetailed together so contributors can sneer at other contributors behind their backs. The trick, as in all gossip, is to find someone so ineffable that everybody hates them and piles in like a rugger scrum. Jean Broke-Smith was sniffy about Gemma Collins, a bouncy 18-year-old Essex temp, ("I 'ave 'ad elocution lessons on 'ow to speak nicely. You know. Farther's cah's a Jaguah. I can say 'Pass the crudettes, darling!'") Brian Sewell was sniffy about Miss Broke-Smith and her banana and, oh, everything, including snobbery. Mr Sewell ("A Member of a Shop! Its enough to send us all to Marks and Spencer") could go on as Lady Bracknell without rehearsal.

It moved along at a fair old lick giving you no time to argue with the commentary, "We all aspire to the lifestyle of the celebrity-packed, football-kicking glitterati" and "When did you see a daffodil looking down at the chrysanths in the next bed?" Not in the same season.

Here's a useful tip from a bespoke bootmaker. For a high shine, polish your shoes with Dom Perignon. Now will the bespoke tailor be a dear and tell me why, before cutting out a suit, he rubbed his huge scissors across his hair? Was this to oil them or was he just scratching?

A new series of Meet The Ancestors (BBC2) began with the discovery of a Roman tomb in Spitalfields. The coffin, two tons of lead and stone, was so magnificent that a director of the London Museum immediately assumed it must be for a man. The girl rose like an affronted ghost to contradict him. She was in her early twenties and dressed in damask, shot through with pure gold. Damask probably only survives today as table linen. (Hermione Gingold used to have a tongue-twisting revue sketch about two dozen double damask dinner napkins). John Wild, a textile expert, was moved close to poetry describing it. "You've got to imagine somebody walking down the street with this on and the lights shining and, every time they move, you've got a shimmer in the pattern. There is no colour differentiation. Everything is done with the way the light falls and the way the light reflects. It would have looked absolutely fantastic."

So, she walked in beauty. Everything about her suggests beauty, the jet ornaments for her raven hair, the bottles of perfume, Venus scallop shells on her coffin. Her pronounced Roman nose is not to modern taste but it would obviously appeal to a Roman. The oxygen isotopes in her teeth indicate she was Mediterranean by birth so perhaps she came as a bride. The ceremonial splendour of her robe suggests a wedding dress to me and her early death, childbirth. But what do I know? Or, indeed, anyone.

The coffin, two tons of lead and stone, was so magnificent that a director of the London Museum immediately assumed it must be for a man. The girl rose like an affronted ghost to contradict him. She was in her early twenties and dressed in damask, shot through with pure gold. Damask probably only survives today as table linen. (Hermione Gingold used to have a tongue-twisting revue sketch about two dozen double damask dinner napkins). John Wild, a textile expert, was moved close to poetry describing it. "You've got to imagine somebody walking down the street with this on and the lights shining and, every time they move, you've got a shimmer in the pattern. There is no colour differentiation. Everything is done with the way the light falls and the way the light reflects. It would have looked absolutely fantastic." So, she walked in beauty. Everything about her suggests beauty, the jet ornaments for her raven hair, the bottles of perfume, Venus scallop shells on her coffin. Her pronounced Roman nose is not to modern taste but it would obviously appeal to a Roman. The oxygen isotopes in her teeth indicate she was Mediterranean by birth so perhaps she came as a bride. The ceremonial splendour of her robe suggests a wedding dress to me and her early death, childbirth. But what do I know? Or, indeed, anyone.

fields.headline: Behind the screen
fields.standfirst: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.trailText: Janine Gibson's TV gossip
fields.body:
Hurling itself into a quagmire of confusion is practically the raison d' tre of Channel 4. The shenanigans down at Horseferry Road sadly have nothing to do with the Spice Girls, it's a Dutch show called Big Brother.

A cross between MTV's the Real World and Channel 5's Miss World, the high-concept Big Brother places a number of contestants in a house where they live under the constant watch of 100s of tiny fixed cameras. Viewers are encouraged to vote on which house-dweller to evict. The resulting popularity contest continues until one resident is left; said winner being chucked out with a large cash prize.

It sounds odd, but it's huge in Holland. So after winning a blind bid auction, C4 has bought the UK version from the producers Endemol (partners with the Guardian Media Group in production company Bazal which will make the UK show). The only problem being that Endemol is currently embroiled in litigation over Big Brother with Charlie Parsons, who once brought us the Big Breakfast and The Word.

Parsons says Endemol nicked the idea from his even higher concept show Survive! - which involves abandoning seven contestants on an island. C4's deal seems to be in limbo until Endemol and Parsons decide who had what idea when. So in place of Big Brother perhaps representatives of the two companies could be isolated - either in a house, or an island - to slug it out. On camera of course. Last one standing gets the copyright?

By contrast, sticking to the tried and tested at the BBC: after the great success of the last bonnet drama adapted by Andrew Davies from Mrs Gaskell, BBC1 has moved into the 20th century for its next historical commission, due to air in four parts next year. After Wives And Daughters, what else but Sons And Lovers? Meaning, surely, a guaranteed commission for the first person to submit a script to BBC1 entitled Husbands And Mistresses.

fields.headline: Who are you?
fields.standfirst: What the Daewoo ad says about you
fields.trailText: What the Daewoo ad says about you
fields.body:
The ad: This simple commercial looks like it uses genuine security camera footage, shot in an underground car park. We see a bloke suspiciously hanging round a car (a Daewoo) then climbing in and driving off in it, as an earnest voiceover explains that "every year, 1000s of cars are taken from their owners' homes or places of work..." Seconds later, we see the same bloke drive back into the same parking spot in a different car. The voiceover continues "...and replaced by virtually identical ones without anyone noticing."

The jargon: This is one of three new 30-second ads aimed at highlighting different elements of Daewoo's "customer service offering" (sic) in an interesting and arresting manner. This one focuses on the fact that drivers get a free courtesy car, delivered to wherever they want, when they have their Daewoo serviced.

Personality: Far from being boy racers, Daewoo owners and potential owners are rather cautious, conservative, older individuals who want a worry-free drive that will safely get them from A to B rather than any fancy badge motor.

Financial status: You must be fairly affluent, given that you are buying a new car, although you're obviously not in the BMW/Mercedes bracket. You are comfortably off but not rich, says Daewoo's agency Duckworth Finn.

Telling lifestyle detail: You could be a bit anoraky, given Daewoo's various customer safety pledges and the fact they are sold through their own network rather than rip-off franchised dealers. You are also of no particular age group or demographic, but the odds are you're no longer in your twenties and you don't live in Camden.

Other relevant data: The ad was shot on real CCTV cameras in an underground car park in Paddington. It was actually directed by Daniel Kleinman, the man who did the credits to the latest Bond movie.

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: All About Eve | City Of Lost Children | Boyz N The Hood
fields.body:
All About Eve (Joseph L Mankiewicz, 1950) 6pm, Sky Cinema
Mankiewicz was well rewarded for sticking with this pet project, winning Oscars for his screenplay and direction. An acid but lightweight tale about catty Broadway actresses, it is given life by the wittiest of scripts and some terrific performances: Bette Davis's ageing star Margo Channing, who utters the immortal "Fasten your seat belts, it's going to be a bumpy night"; George Sanders as cruel critic Addison de Witt, Anne Baxter as ambitious Eve; and even young Marilyn Monroe in a bit part.

City Of Lost Children (Marc Caro, Jeanne-Pierre Jeunet, 1995) 8pm, FilmFour
From the pair who made Delicatessen, another queasy feast of grotesque comic fantasy. It's set in a weird, watery world gleaned from the dreams of abducted, terrified children, and features two of the actors in Jeunet's Alien Resurrection. Ron Perlman is a former whaling harpooner searching for his kidnapped kid-brother, aided by little Judith Vittet; Dominique Pinon plays six cloned brothers lurking in the fortified oil-rig of evil old inventor Krank (Daniel Emilfork). Add a band of one-eyed stooges called the Cyclops, amazing special effects and a labyrinthine plot, and the result is just extraordinary.

Boyz N The Hood (John Singleton, 1991) 11.30pm, Sky Premier
The story of a youth's struggle on the streets of Los Angeles, where crack, bad cops and gang warfare are rife. Brought up good and proper by dad Larry Fishburne, young Tre Styles (Cuba Gooding Jr, pictured ) avoids violence - until his friends are shot up. It's familiar coming-of-age territory, but Singleton's conviction shows through.

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: The First Pirate | Performance On 3
fields.body:
In 1931 Captain Leonard Plugge established Radio Normandie, the commercial station which first broke John Reith's puritan hold on British radio. Les Woodland tells the hilarious story in The First Pirate (11.0am, Radio 4). Plugge invented the disc jockey to challenge the BBC's gloom-ridden sabbath schedule. He also briefly employed Philip Hope-Wallace, later the Guardian's highly-respected theatre critic, as a children's presenter. Uncle Wally's career ended abruptly when he expressed his robust views on children to what he thought was a dead mike.

A weekend marking the centenary of the German composer Kurt Weill (pictured) opens with Performance On 3 (7.30pm, Radio 3). Transmitted live from the Barbican Centre in London, Sir Andrew Davis leads the BBC Symphony Orchestra and assorted soloists in concert performances of Der Protagonist and Royal Palace, two of the early one-act operas which established Weill's reputation. The interval features memories of Weill from the BBC's vast recorded archive.

fields.headline: Guerrillas force Dakar rally airlift
fields.trailText: Three enormous Antonov-124 planes flew over the Sahara desert yesterday shuttling into Libya more than 1,500 people and vehicles involved in the Dakar-Cairo rally, which had been interrupted by a threatened guerrilla assault.
fields.body:
Three enormous Antonov-124 planes flew over the Sahara desert yesterday shuttling into Libya more than 1,500 people and vehicles involved in the Dakar-Cairo rally, which had been interrupted by a threatened guerrilla assault.

The rally's chief organiser, Hubert Auriol, told France-Info radio that the round-the-clock airlift, stretching across 1,250 miles from the Niger capital Niamey to Sebah in Libya, will require 18 round trips by Sunday at a cost of $4.7m.

The rally was halted in Niamey on Tuesday after warnings from Washington and Paris that 300 Algerian Muslim guerrillas planned to ambush the race in Niger, a section of the race that will now be bypassed.

The guerrillas, thought to be a breakaway wing of the Muslim Armed Islamic Group (GIA), were intent on seeking revenge against the Niger army, which in 1998 was involved in an Algerian campaign to flush them out, Mr Auriol said.

He said the guerrillas were heavily armed and had some 40 four-wheel-drive vehicles, but he stressed that the rally was not in danger as long as it did not try to leave Niamey.

GIA guerrillas have been linked to the slaughter of villagers and the deaths of dozens of foreigners in Algeria's eight-year-old civil strife, which has cost 100,000 lives. The GIA were also blamed for the 1994 Christmas hijacking of an Air France aircraft on its way from Algiers to Marseille.

Roger Kalmanovitz, a race organiser, said the Niger authorities had interpreted the decision to bypass their country as "an insult", claiming that the move had tarnished its international image. "I am not sure we will be welcome here next year," he said.

A statement appeared to echo that sentiment. "The government of Niger takes note of this decision which affects its image," government spokesman Akoli Daouel said "[The cancellation] shows the scant consideration the organisers of the rally have for Niger and its ability to guarantee security on its territory," he said. "Consequently, the Niger authorities reserve judgment [on how it will proceed] in the future."

He said the organisers had disregarded the fact that Niger had mobilised 2,000 troops with appropriate logistics backup "to protect this world event". Reuters

fields.headline: Extra lessons for ministers
fields.trailText: Cabinet ministers are to be sent back to the classroom to learn the basics of economics, accountancy and statistics, as part of a Whitehall-wide drive to improve the quality of government policy-making.
fields.body:
Cabinet ministers are to be sent back to the classroom to learn the basics of economics, accountancy and statistics, as part of a Whitehall-wide drive to improve the quality of government policy-making.

Civil servants are so concerned about the lack of numeracy at the top of the government that they are organising courses to fill in the gaps in ministers' knowledge.

None of the cabinet have degrees in the analytical subjects which advisors believe are the key to better decisions. Unveiling a report yesterday, Gus O'Donnell, head of the government economic service, said its recommendations could lead to an "analytical revolution across government."

Mr O'Donnell said policy had to be made by properly equipped professionals with an understanding of analytical disciplines like economics and statistics. To understand their advice, ministers needed a grasp of the subjects as well.

fields.headline: Abstention policy's deep roots
fields.standfirst:
An article of faith that has been in place since 1905

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein has refused to acknowledge Westminster's jurisdiction over Ireland since it was founded in 1905, which means that its candidates stand on an abstentionist ticket.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein has refused to acknowledge Westminster's jurisdiction over Ireland since it was founded in 1905, which means that its candidates stand on an abstentionist ticket.

This has not stopped republicans from mounting vigorous election campaigns at Westminster elections, both before and after the partition of Ireland in the 1920s.

Sinn Fein notched up its greatest success in the 1918 general election - the last before partition - when it won a massive majority of the vote in Ireland. The IRA has claimed its right to take up arms against Britain from Sinn Fein's success in what was the last all-Irish election.

Republicans also scored a historic first in 1918 when Countess Markiewicz, of the Anglo-Irish Gore-Booth family, became the first woman to be elected to Westminster. She refused to take her seat.

After the partition of Ireland, Sinn Fein became so divorced from the political process - its leader Eamon de Valera set up Fianna Fail in 1927 - that it also boycotted the Irish parliament. Pure republicans in Sinn Fein claimed that the Dail was almost as illegitimate as Westminster because it only covered 26 of Ireland's 32 counties.

Sinn Fein refused to take its seats in the Dail until 1986 when Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness overturned the party's abstentionist policy at an acrimonious ard fheis, or party conference. Their historic move, which only succeeded after a passionate speech by Mr McGuinness, split the party and led its former leader Ruairi O Bradaigh to set up the rival Republican Sinn Fein.

Sinn Fein had to wait until 1997 to see its first TD (MP) in the Dail since de Valera walked out after partition in 1922. Caoimhghin O Caolain was elected in the border seat of Cavan-Monaghan, opening up the prospect of Sinn Fein holding the balance of power in Dublin if it secures another three seats at the next general election.

Across the border in Northern Ireland, Sinn Fein watered down its boycott of Westminster when the party stood on a ticket of "active abstentionism" at the 1997 Westminster election. Under the new policy Gerry Adams, who was elected as MP for West Belfast, and Martin McGuinness, who was elected as MP for Mid Ulster, pledged to use every facility at Westminster short of taking their seats in the chamber.

Despite the party's move towards constitutional politics, there is still no appetite to swear the oath of allegiance to the Queen. If the government removes the reference to the Queen from the oath, which would bring it into line with the one sworn in the Northern Ireland assemby, then Sinn Fein MPs could be seen in the chamber.

Arthur Griffiths, who founded Sinn Fein in 1905, may have taken a more relaxed view. He was a "dual monarchist" who believed that separate monarchs should govern Britain and Ireland.

webTitle: Sinn Fein moves to end boycott

fields.headline: Sinn Fein moves to end boycott
fields.standfirst:
Significant step toward assumption of Westminster role after key concession by Mandelson but fight looms with speaker

Northern Ireland: special report
fields.trailText: Sinn Fein is to take an important step towards abandoning its 95-year-old policy of boycotting Westminster after the government announced yesterday that the party's two MPs are to be allowed to use Commons facilities.
fields.body:
Sinn Fein is to take an important step towards abandoning its 95-year-old policy of boycotting Westminster after the government announced yesterday that the party's two MPs are to be allowed to use Commons facilities.

In a concession to republicans, Peter Mandelson, Northern Ireland secretary, announced that Gerry Adams and Martin McGuinness are to be given up to £100,000 to run offices at the Palace of Westminster.

His move placed the government at odds with the Commons speaker, Betty Boothroyd. Margaret Beckett, leader of the Commons, who will call for Sinn Fein to be admitted to Westminster in a Commons debate, said last night that Ms Boothroyd was opposed to the move.

The speaker banned Mr Adams and Mr McGuinness from the Palace of Westminster soon after their election in 1997 because of their refusal to swear the oath of allegiance to the Queen.

Mr Adams, Sinn Fein president and MP for West Belfast, signalled during the 1997 election campaign that republicans would water down their boycott of Westminster.

Under the policy, which he described as "active abstentionism", Mr Adams said that Sinn Fein would use every facility short of taking seats in the chamber.

But Ms Boothroyd ended Sinn Fein's "active abstentionism" within two weeks of the general election.

The government now believes that the climate has changed.

In a letter to Northern Ireland's political leaders, Mr Mandelson said: "I believe it is now time to look again at how [Sinn Fein] should be treated at Westminster. It will enable Sinn Fein members to associate with a broad spectrum of democratic representatives from across the UK and assist in their development as a party committed to democratic and peaceful means."

Sinn Fein welcomed Mr Mandelson's letter. "It's no less than what we were entitled to from the day and hour our MPs were elected," a spokesman said. However, there will be a passionate debate when MPs consider the government's proposal in a free vote. Andrew Mackay, the shadow Northern Ireland secretary, promised to oppose the move.

Ulster Unionist leader David Trimble meanwhile warned that republicans must finally begin to decommission their arms this month or be in default of ex-US senator Goerge Mitchell's formula for implentation of the Good Friday agreement.

After meeting Tony Blair at Downing Street, Mr Trimble called on republicans to stick to the deal struck during Mr Mitchell's review of the agreement.

Opting in

The Westminster benefits that Sinn Fein will be entitled to include:

 £100,000 contribution to office expenses

 Free telephone lines, postage and stationery

 Right to enter Palace of Westminster without passing security and without showing their security cards to police

They will be denied:

 Access to the chamber because of refusal to swear oath of allegiance to Queen.

 MP's salary of £47,008 and pension rights.

webTitle: McGuinness lesson for Harlem pupils pupils of struggle

fields.headline: McGuinness lesson for Harlem pupils pupils of struggle
fields.trailText: Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's first minister of education, yesterday told a group of African-American schoolboys living in Harlem about oppression, injustice and inequality suffered in Northern Ireland.
fields.body:
Martin McGuinness, Sinn Fein's first minister of education, yesterday told a group of African-American schoolboys living in Harlem about oppression, injustice and inequality suffered in Northern Ireland.

On his first tour of New York as a member of Northern Ireland's power-sharing executive, Mr McGuinness visited a school where 80% of the boys are black and come from single parent families. "We know what it's all about," he told them. "We know about strife and struggle. We have been living under British rule. We suffer the same types of discrimination because we are Irish."

Gerry Adams, the Sinn Fein president who claimed he was only in town to "carry the bags" of the new minister, compared "what's happening at the moment in Ireland" with the lynch mobs and discrimination suffered in America during the civil rights demonstrations of 30 years ago.

"My own life experience shows that we are all the same from Harlem to the Falls Road, to India and Africa," said Mr Adams, who on Wednesday had talks with president Bill Clinton, national security adviser Sandy Berger and US secretary of state Madeleine Albright.

However, the school - founded in 1938 by Brother Edmund Ignatius Rice - teaches Irish politics as part of its global studies class. Andre Davis, 15, said: "I know that the southern part of the country is free but Northern Ireland is still under control."

Mr McGuinness left Harlem in no doubt that he would be back in his new role, however. As he left he said: "It is clear to everybody that we have much to learn from each other."

fields.headline: Norman Ashton
fields.standfirst: Eye specialist's crucial discovery saved the sight of countless babies
fields.trailText: Norman Ashton, who has died aged 86, was an internationally recognised eye specialist whose research prevented blindness in thousands of people. One of his key discoveries showed that excessive use of oxygen in premature babies could cause blindness, as could the puppy dog worm toxocara canis, which was a particular hazard to young children.
fields.body:
Norman Ashton, who has died aged 86, was an internationally recognised eye specialist whose research prevented blindness in thousands of people. One of his key discoveries showed that excessive use of oxygen in premature babies could cause blindness, as could the puppy dog worm toxocara canis, which was a particular hazard to young children.

He was one of the biomedical scientists who developed new techniques for studying eye disease - skills that built the reputation of London's Institute of Ophthalmology as a world centre of excellence in research and training of specialists: the institute also expanded the clinical services it provided to Moorfields Eye Hospital and others.

Ashton fostered important links between American and European research teams, and in 1962 was co-founder with Ry Andersen, of Copenhagen, of what has become the influential European Ophthalmic Pathology Society. He was also a founding member in 1965 of Fight for Sight, the UK charity that continues to fund first-class research into the prevention and treatment of eye disease and injury.

Ashton was born in London and was educated at West Kensington School before studying medicine at King's College, London, and Westminster Hospital Medical School. After qualifying in 1939 he specialised in pathology and worked at the Kent and Canterbury Hospital before military service with the Royal Army Medical Corps in West Africa and Egypt.

In 1948 he was appointed director of pathology at the newly created Institute of Ophthalmology, when research into the underlying pathology of eye disease was in its infancy. He held the post for 30 years until his retirement.

Ashton's pioneering research included studies of the link between damage to the eye from diabetes, and high blood pressure, and the risk for premature babies. He made the crucial discovery that the additional oxygen given to premature babies to compensate for breathing difficulties could prevent the development of the blood vessels of the retina if given in excess. The careful control of oxygen based on his research saved the sight of countless babies.

He even applied his ability to solve a mystery connected with angling. He showed that a sudden failure of experienced fly fishermen to catch trout on a favourite stretch of river was due to an infestation of a fluke that damaged the lens of the eye of fish. It made the fish blind and they couldn't see the fly.

Ashton received many international honours and was elected Fellow of the Royal Society in 1971. He was the first Briton to receive the Helen Keller prize for vision research, in an award in January last year. He held numerous visiting academic posts in America and Europe, served on many medical and research committees and worked tirelessly for medical charities.

He was also a gifted speaker. A favourite anecdote of his colleagues relates to the opening of the Wilmer Eye Institute in Baltimore, when he shared the opening speeches with Bob Hope, who later expressed his gratitude that Ashton was not a professional comedian.

Although ophthalmic research was at the centre of his life, he had plenty of other interests. He was for many years a steward at Westminster Abbey and was a talented painter. He was made a CBE in 1976.

He is survived by two nieces.

 Norman Henry Ashton, pathologist, born September 11 1913; died January 4 2000.
