fields.headline: Harold Jenkins
fields.standfirst: A great Shakespeare scholar, his crowning work was almost 30 years in the making
fields.trailText: Harold Jenkins, who has died aged 90, was one of the foremost Shakespeare scholars of his century. His crowning achievement, an edition of Hamlet, appeared in 1982. It had been commissioned in 1954, and thus constituted, in some ways, a life's work.
fields.body:
Harold Jenkins, who has died aged 90, was one of the foremost Shakespeare scholars of his century. His crowning achievement, an edition of Hamlet, appeared in 1982. It had been commissioned in 1954, and thus constituted, in some ways, a life's work.

Early in his career Jenkins produced two monographs, on the minor writers Henry Chettle and Edward Benlowes, editions of Elizabethan plays, and many scholarly articles, moving towards a concentration on Shakespeare. His dual connection with the Arden Shakespeare, on which his reputation rests, began in the 1950s, first with the commission to edit Hamlet and then with the appointment as joint general editor of the series (with Harold Brooks) in 1958. It was a long, fruitful, and happy collaboration.

The list of editors who benefited from Jenkins' advice contains many of the most distinguished British Shakespeareans of the time, who pay testimony to the extraordinary devotion he put into his task. He was regarded as an exemplary general editor and, with Brooks, enhanced the reputation of the series as the finest multi-part edition of the century.

His own Hamlet, delayed in its appearance because of the time and energy he expended on the work of others, has been described as "majestical" and as "the best edition that can be done". It combines his characteristic acumen, clarity of mind, and firmness of judgment as a textual scholar with a fine critical sensibility not found in all editors. The "Longer notes", which extend to more than 100 pages at the end of the volume, constitute in themselves not only a wealth of scholarship, but also a forceful and persuasive reading of the play, enriched in many places by a lifetime's theatre-going experience.

Jenkins grew up in Shenley, Buckinghamshire, the son of a dairyman. He was the eldest boy in a family of five children and, showing intellectual promise, started school at three. He attended Wolverton grammar school, and then read English at University College, London.

He was always a single-minded and clearly (though not narrowly) focused scholar who developed early on his interest in the literature of the Elizabethan period. His MA thesis, The Life and Work of Henry Chettle, was published in 1934.

After a year at the University of Liverpool in 1935 he became lecturer in English at the University of Witwatersrand, South Africa. Ten years later he returned to London to begin 22 years of teaching at the University of London.

His courtesy and brilliance as a lecturer marked the whole of his career, and no one who has been his student will forget his lectures, which were outstanding for their wit and vivacity, as well as their clarity of analysis.

In 1954 he moved from Universtity College to West field College as the first chair of English, where he reigned supreme until 1967, when he became regius professor of rhetoric and English at the University of Edinburgh, a post he held until retirement in 1971. He spent a year in America as visiting professor at Duke University from 1957-58, and a year at the University of Oslo in 1974. In 1986 he was honoured by the award of the Shakespeare prize of the FVS Foundation of Hamburg, the first time it had gone to a scholar-editor.

All of his scholarly work shares the qualities of insight, critical integrity, and scrupulous attention to detail. He was perhaps unlucky in that the edition appeared in a critical climate no longer so receptive to its peculiar virtues, but it will always constitute a standard against which other editions must measure themselves.

In the course of his career he travelled extensively, often with his wife Gladys, whom he met when they were both students. It was a real marriage of "true minds", which sustained Jenkins for most of his academic career. In his preface to Hamlet he acknowledges her with great warmth, paying tribute to their "daily conversation", which fed constantly into his work. Their intimacy may have been the greater because their marriage was childless.

In 1983 they travelled together to China, a dream re alised, but the next year Gladys was killed in a road accident. Jenkins was devastated, but rebuilt his life with a quiet fortitude.

His nature as a man partly reflected that of his scholarship; he was elegant and fastidious, discriminating in his tastes and his dress, sometimes acerbic, though always measured and polite. But he was also someone who loved congenial company, good conversation, entertaining friends at the Athenaeum, and good food and wine. He was a witty and charming host.

 Harold Jenkins, Shakespeare scholar and editor, born July 19 1909; died January 4 2000

fields.headline: Bill Bowerman
fields.standfirst: Athletics coach whose waffle iron brainwave led to the founding of the global corporation Nike
fields.trailText: The moment Bill Bowerman borrowed his wife's waffle iron to pour in a mixture of latex and rubber was a defining moment in the United States tradition of garage inventors.
fields.body:
The moment Bill Bowerman borrowed his wife's waffle iron to pour in a mixture of latex and rubber was a defining moment in the United States tradition of garage inventors.

Bowerman, who has died aged 88, had his brainwave in 1972, after he had teamed up with Phil Knight, an athlete he trained at the University of Oregon (UO). Together they formed Nike, the shoe and sportswear firm which Knight now heads.

Bowerman was also a key populariser of jogging and coach to the 1972 US track team at the Munich Olympics. The team did poorly, and early in 1973 he retired from coaching - but remained at Nike until June 1999. Four months later the company announced that its shoes would feature his silhouette in his trademark Tyrolean hat along with its famous "Swoosh" emblem.

In his 24 years' coaching at UO, his team was in the top 10 of national college track and field championships 16 times, and he coached 44 US team athletes and 33 Olympic team runners, most often in long distance.

A descendant of the 1840s Oregon Trail pioneers, Bowerman was born in Portland. A school athlete and footballer, he went on to university, served as an army officer in Italy during the second world war, and became UO's athletics coach in 1949. In his 24 years' coaching there, his team was in the top 10 of national college track and field championships 16 times, and he coached 44 US team athletes and 33 Olympic team runners, usually in long distance.

Bowerman had a competitive nature and overlooked no detail, inventing a rubberised asphalt track and examining the shoes of his athletes, which he often hand crafted for an individual fit.

In 1964 Knight suggested to him that they import Japanese running shoes. They both put up $500, and founded Blue Ribbon Sports, but the shoes weren't very good, Bowerman recalled. He specified his own design and it became the Japanese maker's best-selling shoe.

He was still not satisfied. He had calculated that for every ounce removed from a shoe's weight, 200 cumulative pounds would be lifted from a runner's burden over a mile. The waffle iron breakthrough followed. The first batch manufactured was 330 pairs, which he and Knight sold, often from the boot of Knight's car at athletic meetings, for $3.30 a pair.

Athletes began winning with the lighter, springier "waffle" shoes, and by the 1972 Olympics Knight claimed they had shod four of the top 10 marathon finishers. Knight kept selling, Bowerman kept designing, and the Nike corporation was born. A generation soon responded to worldwide television commercials featuring superstars such as basketball's Michael Jordan.

Bowerman became a philanthropist. His foundation supports grassroots athletic facilities across the United States and classical music projects. He is survived by his wife Barbara and three sons.

 William Jay Bowerman, athletic coach and shoemaker, born February 19 1911; died December 25 1999.

fields.headline: Michael Stephen
fields.trailText: Michael Stephen, who has died from cancer aged 50, was an intellectual and activist whose interests covered archaeology, the British Communist Party, the Workers Educational Association and the politics, culture and peoples of Southern Africa.
fields.body:
Michael Stephen, who has died from cancer aged 50, was an intellectual and activist whose interests covered archaeology, the British Communist Party, the Workers Educational Association and the politics, culture and peoples of Southern Africa.

Born in Aberdeen, his early archaeological interests took him to work at the British Museum and then to Southampton university for his first degree.

Already a member of the communist party, he was recruited to teach in the Frelimo revolutionary government in Mozambique. In 1979 he moved, with his second wife June, to Swaziland, where he combined teaching with reconnaissance work for Umkhonto we Sizwe, the armed wing of the African National Congress, showing courage in helping to smuggle ANC leaders across the border into South Africa.

At Oxford his doctorate was on land and politics in Swaziland, and he then became senior lecturer in development studies at Staffordshire university. His more recent writings concerned the plight of post-apartheid South Africa.

He remained a communist, refused to have a television and preferred long walks, political arguments, good food and wine.

Stephen is survived by his third wife Emma Clarence, and two daughters from his earlier marriages.

 Michael Stephen, academic, born November 26 1949; died December 21 1999.

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText:
Krenz jailed for border killings
East Germany's last communist leader, Egon Krenz, 62, arrived at a minimum-security prison in west Berlin yesterday to begin a six-and-a-half-year sentence for his political role in the shootings of people trying to flee to the west.
fields.body:
Krenz jailed for border killings
East Germany's last communist leader, Egon Krenz, 62, arrived at a minimum-security prison in west Berlin yesterday to begin a six-and-a-half-year sentence for his political role in the shootings of people trying to flee to the west.

Krenz, who reported to jail the day after Germany's highest court refused to hear his appeal, is expected to be allowed to spend days out of prison, and to return to his cell at night. He claims his conviction is unconstitutional because he was subject to East German law at the time he served in the communist leadership.
AP, Berlin

Algerian rebel 'to surrender'
The leader of a radical Algerian rebel group was negotiating his surrender yesterday as the country's army appeared willing to extend an amnesty deadline to guerrillas.

Politicians said that Hassan Hattab, head of the Da'wa wal Djihad (Appeal and Struggle), was eager to secure a blanket amnesty similar to the one which the president, Abdelaziz Bouteflika, granted to the rival Islamic Salvation Army on Tuesday.
Reuters, Algiers

Reno calls for Elian solution
The US attorney general, Janet Reno, yesterday appealed to everyone involved in the politically charged custody dispute for Elian Gonzalez to resolve the situation quickly so that the six-year-old Cuban boy "can get on with his life".

Cuban exile leaders met yesterday in Miami to discuss Ms Reno's announcement that Elian's fate would be up to federal officials. Elian is staying with relatives in Miami after being found clinging to an inner tube in the Atlantic.
AP, Washington

Guide in court over 11 deaths
A French court gave a mountain guide a suspended two-year prison sentence yesterday over the deaths in an avalanche of nine French teenagers and two adults during an excursion in 1998.

Daniel Forte, 44, led the party across a steep slope near the ski resort of Les Orres despite warnings of high avalanche risks after a heavy snowfall. Three other people were acquitted.
Reuters, Gap

webTitle: Italy's former Communists win Blair's blessing

fields.headline: Italy's former Communists win Blair's blessing
fields.trailText: What was once the largest Communist party in the west became New Labour's unlikeliest mimic yesterday when it ditched red for blue, state ownership for privatisation and class warfare for pop music.
fields.body:
What was once the largest Communist party in the west became New Labour's unlikeliest mimic yesterday when it ditched red for blue, state ownership for privatisation and class warfare for pop music.

Labour's leader, Tony Blair, sent a message to the annual conference of the Democratic Left, the largest party in Italy's ruling coalition, blessing its transformation into a modernising ally.

Leaders of the Democratic Left are so enchanted by Mr Blair's success that they have imported a British pop star and used an English-language slogan - "I care" - for their four-day conference, which began yesterday in Turin.

The platform's traditional red backdrop has been banished for a more conservative blue setting, from which controversial ideas about spending cuts, privatisation and labour market flexibility will be pitched above the grinding of old guard teeth.

No references to the working class are expected in any speeches, which have been tailored for television. Sting will sing John Lennon's Imagine and, in a deviation from Millbank's manual, Sabrina Ferilli, an actor and Italy's most popular nude pin-up, will make an appearance.

Critics accused the Democratic Left of resorting to gimmicks in a desperate attempt to compete with the lustre of media magnate Silvio Berlusconi, who leads the centre-right coalition that is expected to oust the ruling centre-left administration at the next general election, due within 18 months.

"Considering it was once a very strong party, like those that existed only in Europe, this is ridiculous," said Sandro Roventi, political analyst at Milan's Bocconi university.

"The party simultaneously lost its ideology and its capability of organising. Now it doesn't know what to do."

webTitle: Polls drag Hillary Clinton to lion's den

fields.headline: Polls drag Hillary Clinton to lion's den
fields.standfirst:
First lady finally appears on Letterman talkshow to boost run for New York senate, amid slump in her popularity
Watch David Letterman chat to Hillary Clinton on CBS.com

The Washington Post on Hillary
fields.trailText: Hillary Clinton has taken a crucial step towards the formal launch of her New York senate bid by finally submitting herself to be grilled by the irreverent talk show host David Letterman.
fields.body:
Hillary Clinton has taken a crucial step towards the formal launch of her New York senate bid by finally submitting herself to be grilled by the irreverent talk show host David Letterman.

For much of her eagerly anticipated appearance on Wednesday night - itself the subject of a running gag for three weeks on the ratings-topping show - she and Mr Letterman exchanged gentle one-liners. But Mrs Clinton, newly installed as a New York resident, also took the opportunity to announce: "I am going to run for the senate and I'm officially going to declare."

Her aides disclosed that she will launch her campaign - the first for elective office by a sitting US first lady - on February 6, at an as yet undisclosed New York venue. The launch will be an all-guns-blazing political event, attended both by President Bill Clinton and by the couple's daughter, Chelsea.

Her appearance on the Letterman show came just days after Mrs Clinton moved out of the White House and into the new family home in New York to concentrate on her bid for the November election, and amid polls which show her trailing badly behind her likely Republican rival, the New York mayor, Rudolph Giuliani.

Such pressures only add to the certainty that the race will break all previous spending records for a senate contest, a record currently held by the 1998 New York senate contest between the Republican Al D'Amato and the Democratic victor, Charles Schumer.

Shocking though it may seem to political traditionalists, Mrs Clinton's apparent reluctance to submit herself to 20 minutes of teasing by Mr Letterman, whose late night CBS talk show is broadcast from a theatre on Broadway in the heart of Manhattan, had become increasingly embarrassing for her.

Unlike Mr Giuliani, who would appear every night of the week on any show if he could, Mrs Clinton had fought shy of Mr Letterman's increasingly frenzied attempts to book her. As a result, he spent part of almost every show in the past month complaining about the Clinton campaign's lack of response.

In the end, her aloofness had become such a talking point that it was damaging her further in the opinion polls. A Marist College poll taken last weekend among registered voters showed that by 58% to 24% New Yorkers believed that Mrs Clinton should accept Mr Letterman's invitation.

In the same poll, Mr Giuliani led Mrs Clinton by 49% to 40% in the senate race. Her personal favourability ratings were down four points from the previous month, at 48% to Mr Giuliani's 61%. Within 24 hours of the poll's publication, she and her private pollster, Mark Penn, were on their way to the Letterman show.

After all the badgering, the encounter went off more easily than she and her handlers must have feared. Mrs Clinton gave a poised and unflappable performance. She smiled fixedly at Mr Letterman and told him: "I knew if I were going to run for the senate I would have to sit in this chair and talk to the big guy."

When Mr Letterman observed that "every idiot in the area is going to drive by honking" outside the Clintons' new home in the New York suburb of Chappaqua, Mrs Clinton asked him: "Was that you?"

Apeing a regular Late Show feature, she at one point announced her "top 10 reasons" for appearing, starting with "I lost a bet with Tipper", and continuing: "If Dan Quayle did it, how hard can it be?"

In yet another carefully scripted quote, which echoed the song New York, New York, Mrs Clinton told Mr Letterman: " If I can make it here, I can make it anywhere".

Mr Letterman scrupulously avoided any embarrassing questions about the Monica Lewinsky affair. One of the few overtly serious moments came when Mrs Clinton defended the proposed return of six-year-old Elian Gonzalez from Miami to his father in Cuba.

During commercial breaks the mood got cooler, audience members said, as she studied her cue-cards and Mr Letterman walked around.

"As phoney as a three-dollar bill," was how the columnist Adam Buckman summed up her appearance in Rupert Murdoch's New York Post.

"In the end it must have been the polls," the Washington Post concluded.

Talkshow pantheon moves into election mode

Conan O'Brien

Gangly O'Brien hosts a chat show for NBC nightowls that follows straight after Leno's Los Angeles-based Tonight Show. Rose to prominence as a writer on Saturday Night Live .

Katie Couric

Anchoring NBC's morning news show, Couric, 43, is many women's favourite interviewer - and America's highest paid (in 1998 she signed a $7m annual contract). Yesterday's guest: Donald Trump

Jay Leno

Fronting the Tonight Show at NBC , Leno, 49, has recently interviewed Democrat Bill Bradley, Republican John McCain, and possible runner Donald Trump, who is flirting with the Reform party.

Larry King

All the main presidential hopefuls in the 2000 race have appeared on the interview programme hosted by CNN 's 63-year-old "King of Talk". Last night's guest: Paula Jones

webTitle: US row as network alters news pictures

fields.headline: US row as network alters news pictures
fields.standfirst: CBS
fields.trailText: One of America's main television networks, CBS, has come in for a storm of criticism after it was revealed that the company tampered with news footage broadcast on New Year's Eve, using digital technology to erase the logo of a rival network.
fields.body:
One of America's main television networks, CBS, has come in for a storm of criticism after it was revealed that the company tampered with news footage broadcast on New Year's Eve, using digital technology to erase the logo of a rival network.

CBS's live millennium broadcast from Times Square in New York showed its main presenter, Dan Rather, standing in front of a large billboard flashing his network's symbol to millions of viewers.

But anyone actually in the square that night would have seen that the billboard actually carried the NBC logo.

The criticism of the digital tampering by CBS reflects increasing concerns about the impact of such new technology on live news and on editorial veracity in general.

In a newspaper interview yesterday, Mr Rather said of the film alteration: "There is no excuse for it. I did not grasp the possible ethical implications of this, and that was wrong on my part."

Walter Cronkite, the veteran CBS evening news anchorman in the 1960s and 70s, was even more disparaging. "It's flat-out dishonest. CBS and the rest of the broadcasters must pledge to refrain from the use of the technique in any manner."

But Leslie Moonves, CBS TV's president, insisted: "Any time there's an NBC logo up on our network, we'll block it again."

Kim Akhtar, a CBS spokeswoman, said yesterday that while Mr Rather's nightly news show would be unlikely to use the new technology, the morning news programme would go on using it.

Under a deal with Princeton Video Image, which developed the new technology, CBS has been changing the New York cityscape on its morning news programme since November, with few complaints. The CBS logo flashes on to the screen from obviously impossible locations, such as the back of a horse-drawn carriage in New York's Central Park.

The same firm's technology was used in more than 1,200 live broadcasts around the world last year, including European football games.

webTitle: Miners freed after being entombed with dead

fields.headline: Miners freed after being entombed with dead
fields.standfirst: Rescuers shift 300 tons of earth as four-day drama grips South Africa
fields.trailText: Nine gold miners in South Africa trapped more than a mile underground with the corpses of dead colleagues for four days were finally brought to the surface last night.
fields.body:
Nine gold miners in South Africa trapped more than a mile underground with the corpses of dead colleagues for four days were finally brought to the surface last night.

Rescue teams were still trying to reach the bodies of four men killed in the rock fall at the Orkney shaft, 100 miles south-west of Johannesburg, on Monday.

The fate of two other miners who were seriously injured in the accident was unclear. The survivors had been unable to reach the pair, who have had neither food nor water since an earth tremor brought a tunnel roof down.

The rescued men, who were described by officials as extremely exhausted, were given intravenous drips and taken to waiting ambulances with oxygen masks strapped to their faces. Family and friends waiting at the top of the shaft cheered and clapped as the first of the rescued men appeared.

The nine survived in a pitch black cavity by licking water poured down a compressed air pipe, which was also a conduit for semi-liquid food and air to reduce the stifling heat.

The worst of it for the trapped men was sharing what became a tomb about 18 inches high with their dead colleagues. Mine officials said the stench of their decomposing bodies filled the tunnels.

After getting out of the cavity, "the first thing they wanted was water," said Charmane Russell, the mine's spokeswoman. "They have since been in relatively good spirits, working with the rescuers and quite calm, which is important."

Patrice Motsepe, chairman of the company that owns the mine, African Rainbow Minerals, said he did not hold out much hope for the two injured men.

"A grave concern to us is that these two miners were seriously injured at the time of the seismic event. Information received thus far is not very encouraging," he said.

Rescue teams of 70 men at a time used hammers and chisels to hack their way through rock inch by inch. Over the four days they shifted 300 tons of earth. Explosives could not be used for fear of provoking another fall.

Drills were also used to break through the fallen debris unleashed by the tremor, a mine official said, winches were brought in to play to pull out boulders.

Miners came from across the country to volunteer for the teams. Some of them used shovels and their hands to scoop away dirt and gravel.

"I don't know how we have moved so much rock so fast. We couldn't do this for money, but there are men down there. It could be any of us," one of the rescuers said.

The rescuers made contact through the air pipe on Tuesday evening, after the workers had been trapped for 30 hours.

On Wednesday evening the teams thought they were on the edge of a breakthrough when they were just three yards from the trapped men. But fresh rock falls blocked their progress for another day.

The survivors tried to dig toward their rescuers but the batteries on their headlamps ran flat, and they were working almost blind in the dark. In the end they became too tired, a mine employee said.

The frequency of earth tremors, and the depth of the shafts, make South Africa's mines particularly dangerous. The Orkney mine was the scene of one of the c ountry's worst mining accidents: in 1995, a mine train fell into an elevator shaft on a carriage full of men, killing 104.

At that time the mine was owned by Anglo-American, which sold it in January 1998 to black investors under the post-apartheid government's philosophy of economic empowerment for South Africa's black majority.

fields.headline: Pass notes
fields.standfirst: Charlotte Church
fields.trailText: Charlotte Church
fields.body:
Age: 13.

Not old enough to make executive decisions, then. What do you think mothers are for?

Um, school runs? Not when their daughters are worth £6m. Church's mum, Maria, has reportedly tightened the iron grip she has on young Charlotte's future by firing her manager, Jonathan Shalit.

Been twiddling his thumbs, has he? Not noticeably. Since discovering Church on a TV talent contest, he has brokered a five-LP contract with Sony, an £800,000 book deal and a £300,000 advertising gig with Ford for her.

Sounds like she's getting too big for her boots. Too big for Shalit, more like. Church stands out from the other acts on his books, who include the helmet-haired singer Leo Sayer and docusoap spin-off star Jane McDonald.

Not good enough company for our little starlet? Well, she has hung out with Bill Clinton and the Pope.

Give me Leo Sayer any day. You can have him for a tenner. I think that's what her mum is worried about.

Yeah, it sounds like Charlotte could do with someone to drum her up some extra cash. Come now, she only gets £50 a month pocket money and won't have access to her earnings until she is 22.

I take it the teen sensation will be managed by her mother. Maria says not. However, when her daughter became famous she gave up her job as a council housing officer to act as her PA, and is understood to want a more prominent role in her daughter's career.

Keeping it the family? Yup. Her dad is also on the Sony payroll, combining ordinary paternal duties with official status as her chaperone.

Very cosy. "I like to think Maria and myself have helped to model Charlotte into the person she is today," says James Church.

Do say: "A girl's best friend is her mother."

Don't say: "Didn't the Spice Girls' sacked manager hit them for a £15m payoff?"

Not to be confused with: Charlotte's Web, the Charlatans, church.

webTitle: Would you really rather live in Ludwigshafen than Dublin, London or Seattle?

fields.headline: Would you really rather live in Ludwigshafen than Dublin, London or Seattle?
fields.standfirst: Well, according to a new survey, you would.  Oliver Burkeman and  Elisabeth Ribbans go in search of the hidden charms of Ludwigshafen, self-styled City of Chemicals
fields.trailText: There's nothing playing at Ludwigshafen's Pfalzbau theatre tonight, so Michael Schmid, regional editor of the local daily newspaper Die Rheinpflaz, reckons he'll probably go to the pub for a beer instead. "It's not exactly a swinging city," he says. "Are you sure this league table is correct? Is this some kind of joke?"
fields.body:
There's nothing playing at Ludwigshafen's Pfalzbau theatre tonight, so Michael Schmid, regional editor of the local daily newspaper Die Rheinpflaz, reckons he'll probably go to the pub for a beer instead. "It's not exactly a swinging city," he says. "Are you sure this league table is correct? Is this some kind of joke?"

His assessment is hardly unique. "Ludwigshafen is surprising!" screams one piece of promotional literature for this modern industrial port on the Rhine in south-west Germany, a short hop across the river from Heidelberg - but, until yesterday, sceptics might very reasonably have objected to this judgment. Far from being "surprising!", these uncharitable naysayers might have argued, Ludwigshafen is just about as predictable as northern European cities come - a nondescript industrial town on one of the grimmer banks of the Rhine, famous, beyond Ludwigshafen, for only two things: being the home of former chancellor Helmut Kohl, and of the fume-spewing chimneys of BASF, the largest chemicals company in Europe, which has its headquarters there.

Now, however, there can be little doubt that the city's desperate-sounding tourist officials were right all along, because yesterday Ludwigshafen did something very surprising indeed. In a major survey of the quality of life in 200 cities around the globe, Ludwigshafen bounced in at number 32, beating London, Seattle, Dublin and Atlanta, and ranking not all that far behind Paris, Berlin and Montreal. Amid the survey's roll-call of bustling, metropolitan, culturally throbbing centres of population, little Ludwigshafen seemed slightly out of place.

"It's very close to Frankfurt airport and the political and economic situation is stable," a spokesman for consultants William M Mercer, which carried out the survey, recited monotonously. "The crime rate is very low and there are good hospitals." A very efficient traffic system, too. "You'll find no problem parking here," Schmid points out. Which leaves just one question unanswered: why drive to Ludwigshafen in the first place?

The kindly Insight Guide to Germany generously devotes a single sentence to the city - stating its 170,000 population and pointing out its close proximity to the elegant Baroque city of Mannheim on the opposite shore; the Rough Guide doesn't mention it at all. At the local Radio Regenbogen, based in Mannheim, news of Ludwigshafen's star ranking drew a loud scratching of heads. "Ludwigshafen? Our Ludwigshafen?" said broadcaster Michael Merx. "It has BASF, which is good for jobs, I suppose. But beautiful it is not." And culture? "Well, it has a theatre, but it's mostly guest artists," he sniffs. "Nobody in Mannheim would say, 'Ah, Ludwigshafen - that's a great place to live.'"

They don't say that much in Ludwigshafen itself, either. Heiko Pabst, assistant to the city's mayor, offers the same four-letter key to the advantages it does enjoy. "It's because of BASF," he says. "Because of this, the level of income is very high, and the standard of living for everyone in the city is very good. It's a very modern city, it's a working city, like Atlanta but with lots of trees and bridges. But it's not an exciting place to live. It's very quiet, and you have to go to Mannheim if you want cultural things."

It's not as if Ludwigshafen entirely lacks any claims to fame. The 18th-century poet and dramatist Friedrich Schiller lived there briefly, and the Marxist thinker Ernst Bloch was born in the city; there's Kohl, too - not that the locals care to boast about the scandal-mired ex-Chancellor these days. There's culture, albeit of a limited variety: one wall in the Wilhelm Hack museum was designed by Joan Miró, and yesterday afternoon the interested visitor could peruse a selection of acrylic works in the style of the post-impressionists in the foyer at Ludwigshafen's main branch of Deutsche Bank. The local delicacy is Pfaelzer Saumagen, a dish consisting of stuffed pig's stomach.

And, to be fair, just about every other city on the Rhine had a flying start on Ludwigshafen: it had existed as a major town for barely a century when second world war bombers forced it start all over again. It was rebuilt in a functional manner, with no great pretensions beyond its self-styled image as the "City of Chemicals". BASF has been there since 1865; the taxes the company pays and the 40,000 jobs it provides ensure a good standard of living for the vast majority of Ludwigshafeners; its concern for the environment, forced upon it after a series of chemical industry disasters, means the air is clean, too. There are acres of sporting facilities, while weekend leisure time can be spent bathing in the many nearby lakes, sailing on the Rhine or walking through the beautiful Palatinate forest, a short drive away. "Maybe that's why we're ranked," ponders Schmid. "For the things we can get to, rather than the things we have."

That's the sympathetic version. "It's one of those places where it gets nicer if you travel in either direction away from it," recalls one German banker working in London. "Like Reading."

fields.headline: Who's cooking?
fields.standfirst: Theodore Kyriakou
fields.trailText: Theodore Kyriakou
fields.body:
Age: 40.

Nationality: Greek.

Restaurant: The Real Greek, 15 Hoxton Market, London N1, tel: 0171-739 8212.

Past form: "I was one of the original owners of Livebait before it was sold to the Chez Gerard group. I've worked at St John Stepping Stone in London. The Real Greek opened almost four months ago, and I'm here all the time. I'm the only Greek in the kitchen, and it will take a bit of time to get my chefs familiar with the imported ingredients."

Style of cooking: " The ingredients are Greek, the recipes are 100% Greek, but the look's been revamped."

Signature dishes: "The idea here is to represent a different geographical area of Greece every eight to 10 weeks, so the menu changes. Very good dishes are the beef shin soup; filo pies with spinach and feta; meatballs with rice inside them, wrapped in cabbage leaves."

Bookshelf: "Before I opened here, I spent six months in Greece collecting very old, traditional recipe books. Modern books I use include Baker and Spice, by Dan Lepard and Richard Whittington - very good for pastry and breads. The Richard Corrigan Cookbook and the Good Housekeeping book are good for reference."

Favourite restaurant: "Fung Shing in London's Chinatown has some unusual Cantonese items. A very classic restaurant is Chez Bruce in Wandsworth. For nice, honest food, I go to the Anglesea Arms in Shepherd's Bush.

Favourite food: I don't like food all set up on the plate; I prefer traditional food, cooked on the stove: big casseroles, winter food.

What's in your fridge? I never cook at home. So coffee, cheese, honey, rusks.

What did you have for breakfast? Whatever's in the fridge and a cigar.

Top tip: For a young chef, drop your nose down and don't stick to one restaurant; pick up different styles.

Biggest culinary disaster: I had a catering contract in Tokyo. My interpreter was sick and I had to do the ordering - when it was delivered, half of it was totally wrong.

Career high: Opening Livebait, my first restaurant, and my first cookbook.

 Interview by Claire Phipps

fields.headline: Cruising at new heights
fields.standfirst: Britain is getting its first gay airline. Sounds like double-entendre hell to  Simon Fanshawe, who asks whether we really need one
fields.trailText: Britain is getting its first gay airline. Sounds like double-entendre hell to  Simon Fanshawe, who asks whether we really need one
fields.body:
Staggering news. A man called Martin Langham, who used to be a British Caledonian trolley dolly - cabin crew for those who live in a camp-free world - is starting a "gay-friendly" airline called Freedom Airways.

It's going to fly out of Manchester, which is very homosexual in these post-industrial days when warehouses become bars, banking halls become cafes and gays have become a tool of economic regeneration. It will also leave from Luton.

Now, forgive me if I've made a mistake about the idea of gay-friendly travel, but when was the last time you met a heterosexual male flight attendant? Some years ago, in a restaurant in Brighton, I watched a line of stewardesses descend the stairs in bright-red livery macs, followed by just one steward who was wearing a beige one. When I asked why he wasn't in red he replied defensively: "Because it's not very masculine." That is the last time I, or anyone I know, came across one.

The meal service on Virgin Atlantic is like the late show at the Copacabana. Most of the cabin crew ask the question "Meat or fish?" in a distinctly suggestive way and add with a camp sneer: "Or would sir like the vegetarian alternative?" The implication is that it would be terribly downmarket were one to say yes. So I have always thought flying was a very gay experience.

But according to Langham it's not. He fell asleep on his partner's shoulder flying back from Bali on "a major airline". He was woken by one of the cabin staff and asked not to be so intimate. We're not talking the mile-high club here. We're talking teddy-bear-aah-sleepy-byes.

I once had sex with a Buddhist on a Qantas flight to Australia. Not only did the earth move but I also came back as something entirely different in another life. Now everytime I hit turbulence I think of the Four Noble Truths and the Eightfold Path.

In that case it would have been entirely reasonable for the crew to have intervened. But Langham was just sleeping and the attitude of this airline was outrageous. That is what needs changing and he could just have started a campaign. Instead, he has gone charmingly over the top and become like Victor Kiam, the man in the Remington ads: "I hated the airline so much, I started one of my own."

So do we need a gay airline? We need a gay lobby like Stonewall to tackle disrimination. We need gay bars because, although people say you meet men at dinner parties, you don't. But an airline?

First, several of the top airlines deny that they give any such instructions to cabin staff. Virgin says it wouldn't dream of interfering if two passengers were obviously a couple. The more matronly British Airways had to consult but its spokesman came back and said the same.

However, I don't doubt Langham's experience for a moment. Every gay person has suffered being told, in a double entendre that would moisten Freud's consulting chair, not to shove their sexuality down everybody's throat. He probably bumped up against an airborne version of Anne Widdecombe. Although if he had, he would have been flying Aeroflot or Swissair. Their hostesses look like the heroic members of the People's Union of Agricultural Workers (women's branch) that you see in Soviet art posing next to a socialist realist tractor. But if he's right that some gay people would rather travel with other gays, then good luck to him.

I can imagine nothing worse than travelling on a gay-only airline. It would be double entendre hell for a start. You can imagine what would happen the minute the captain announced that the plane had started to go down. If we landed in the sea some idiot would suggest synchronised swimming to land. And the duty-free would always be fresh out of Calvin Klein by the time it reached Economy.

Some gays and lesbians love queer-only spaces. Me, I find the pressure a bit much. Far more fun to sit and fantasise about the man three rows in front: what he's going to do in Australia when he gets there; what colour we'll paint our bedroom in the house we'll certainly buy when we fall in life-long love; what kind of puppy we'll have. Better that than meet him and find out he's some naff queen from Harlesden, with Capo Di Monte china and three chihuahuas at home.

Although if that's what I am worried about, maybe I should fly Freedom Airlines from Manchester and not Luton. But I'd prefer to fly on a major world airline with everybody else and tell them to get stuffed if they try to stop me loving my boyfriend.

webTitle: I'm a single mother in love but my daughter wants him out of my life

fields.headline: I'm a single mother in love but my daughter wants him out of my life
fields.trailText: I am the single mother of a 10-year-old girl who has regular contact with her father. I have always put her first but do have a social life.
fields.body:
I am the single mother of a 10-year-old girl who has regular contact with her father. I have always put her first but do have a social life.

We have had a reasonably good relationship, although she is strong-willed and rude at times. I have had one or two boyfriends but kept them out of her life. Six months ago I fell in love with a wonderful man and we want to spend our lives together. To start with, we saw each other when my daughter was not around, although she knew I was seeing him. Gradually the three of us spent more time together and they appeared to be getting on quite well. But recently she has started being rude to him. I'm being pulled apart. I understand this would be a big change but other people seem to work it out with children and new partners. He says I should not let my life be run by a 10-year-old. What should I do?

He must be patient
I am also a single parent, though my daughter is 13. She, too, can sometimes be rude - and on occasions appear strongwilled. It is true, though, don't you think, that we can only really be ourselves with those with whom we feel most secure?

You say she has had your undivided attention all her life but she is still only 10. Think how swiftly that time has passed and how soon it will be that she is no longer a child. You are right that other people seem to manage with new partners and children.

However, for every couple that succeeds many others fail. Believe me - because I have been down that path - a relationship between your child and a new partner is never going to be easy. Most especially when that child has reached an age that brings so many natural changes for her. These changes are in themselves difficult enough without the inevitable emotional upheaval of accepting that she has to share you with a live-in third party. Sure, your daughter seemed to get along with your new man fairly well at first, but I would be willing to bet that this was before it became obvious that this man would shortly become a more permanent fixture around your home.

I know this is probably not the sort of thing you were hoping to hear. If, as you stated in your letter, you and your partner are truly in love, then the few more years that it might take for your daughter to come through this difficult time, represents a tiny drop in the bucket, in comparison to the rest of your lives. Right now, though, it is less a case of allowing a 10-year-old to dictate your life than of putting the needs of a child first.

If this man is worthy of your love and the respect of your daughter, he will readily understand. True love is always patient.
Paul Glendenning
Merseyside

Live your own life
It is only natural that your daughter should feel threatened by your new-found happiness - after all, you are both taking a step into the unknown. While you are sure of your new relationship and feel you can spend the rest of your life with this man, your daughter will be feeling very much an outsider, however hard you try to include her. However, I do feel it is very important for you to pursue the relationship with your new partner. Several years ago, I very nearly lost the man I love after we spent our first holiday together with my son from my first marriage. My son behaved extremely badly towards my new partner and we spent most of our holiday apart, vowing to separate when we returned home.

Thankfully, we decided to try again and although my son will never be as close to my second husband as to his own father, I am happy to say that they now get on very well, with a great deal of respect and understanding on both sides.

Yes, it is important that you continue to show your daughter how important she is to you, but it is also important to live your own life and don't let her ruin your chance of a wonderful future. After all, one day your daughter will embark upon her own life, and you might be left wondering why you let her dictate your future as well as her own.
Janet
Edinburgh

She needs reassurance
Of course your little girl is upset - she feels she has been displaced as the focus of your life. Try and see things from her point of view. She is suddenly having to compete for her mother's attention with a man she hardly knows but with whom you are smitten. You say they "appeared to be getting on quite well" at first. That doesn't sound like much of a relationship. Does he like children? Has he much experience of them? How does he relate to her?

He must realise that you are a package and unless he and she start to like each other, it will be setting up trouble for all three if you rush into a commitment.

Can you talk to your daughter and ask her how she feels? Really listen to what she says. Perhaps she is anxious because she thinks that because you love him you will love her less. Rudeness and bad behaviour are often a response to insecurity. Bear this in mind, too, that 10 is the verge of adolescence and all the problems that brings - especially in relation to the male of the species.

Can you talk to your child's father about the situation? Perhaps he could spent extra time with her - and help reassure her.
Sara Rigg
North London

Next week
I am 37, have been married 11 years and have two daughters. Last year I was sacked just as my wife's career took off. Instead of giving me support during my three months of unemployment, she had an affair with a policeman and left me for him.

When I realised that she didn't love me anymore, I asked for a divorce. Almost immediately, she ditched him and came back to me. It became apparent that her heart wasn't in it and in the summer she told me she didn't want to be married any more. After this final rejection I turned my attention to other women for companionship but without much success mainly because, to their credit, they didn't want to be involved with a married man.

I have recently filed for divorce but now my wife says she is being stalked by her ex-lover, and though in favour of separation, she does not want a divorce.

I despair of ever meeting anyone as my wife won't move out and if she did would take our children with her, so if I move out I would really be alone. I have tried everything from dating agencies to singles bars to meet women. I do not work with any eligible women either. I'm certainly not shy or unattractive and realise that one can appear "desperate" to women, yet I seemed to be the one shunned by everyone for my wife's actions, past behaviour and current problems.

I would move out but I believe that the first one to leave loses rights to the house. How can I meet a woman without compromising my children and losing everything I put into our house?

I have tried everything from dating agencies to singles bars to meet women. I do not work with any eligible women either. I'm certainly not shy or unattractive and realise that one can appear "desperate" to women, yet I seemed to be the one shunned by everyone for my wife's actions, past behaviour and current problems. fields.headline: Crunch time
fields.standfirst: The humble salted crisp has fought off all comers to remain our favourite snack - every hour, a million packets are eaten. But as boutique brands boom, a battle is looming between the predictable, mass-produced item and its imperfect, pricey rival
fields.trailText: The humble salted crisp has fought off all comers to remain our favourite snack - every hour, a million packets are eaten. But as boutique brands boom, a battle is looming between the predictable, mass-produced item and its imperfect, pricey rival
fields.body:
Legend has it that one George Crum, chef at the Moon Lake House hotel in Saratoga Springs, New York, was one evening driven to distraction by a particularly picky customer, and set about creating the thinnest potato chips possible (this was 1853, and pre-McDonald's french fries). Fortunately for Crum - and British fans, who scoff about a million packets every hour - the fussy diner was more than satisfied and the crisp was born.

It is unlikely that the super-thin chip would have become Britain's most popular snack without a little extra something. And, in the 1920s, a nod towards consumer choice by a north London crisp fryer, Frank Smith, saw a small blue packet of salt added to every packet. Salt 'n' Shake - and the taste for sodium-loaded crisps - took off; to this day, ready-salted remains the choice of 34% of the UK's crisp eaters, making it easily the biggest-selling flavour.

Since then, manufacturers have made numerous efforts to liven up our snacking habits. Salt-and-vinegar and cheese-and-onion soon became old hat, so they turned to the flavourist, a scientist whose mission is to create ever more outlandish taste combinations. Prawn cocktail? Worcester sauce? Once upon a time there was even a Bovril-flavoured crisp although that, like our penchant for the beef drink itself, has passed into history. And let us not forget hedgehog flavour, which shot to fame in the 80s.

But additions to the savoury snack industry - current UK value: £2.2bn - keep on coming. Pretty much anything, it seems, can be shaped, fried and packaged, and the snack-addicted public will wolf it down. So we have products such as Wotsits made of extruded and baked corn; Quavers, born of a potato starch pellet; and Doritos, corn tortilla chips whose launch in 1994 was the most successful in UK snack history.

For those for whom crisps were a forbidden pleasure came low-fat - well, lower-fat - versions, the latest innovation being a totally fat-free Pringles crisp. Made with the fat substitute Olean, they are currently available only in the US.

Perhaps it's the affection we feel for our national foodstuff, the potato, but crisps are a very British snack - roast beef flavour, anyone? - and one we do rather well. Legendary names such as Smith's and Leicester-based Walkers may have succumbed to the clustering tendencies of modern food companies (Smith's was absorbed by Walkers, which in turn comes under the umbrella of PepsiCo), but even big bosses generally know better than to meddle with long-standing favourites such as Quavers, now in their fourth decade, and the positively geriatric Salt 'n' Shake.

Europe has never fallen for crisps in the way we have - it was only in 1951 that their manufacture began in earnest on the continent, with Heinz Flessner's Stateside Potato Chip company targeting US soldiers posted in Germany.

It is in Britain, too, that the taste for "gourmet" crisps has really caught hold. It is a new trend that threatens to boost considerably the 3.5kg of crisps per head of population that we currently indulge in every year.

The rise of the gourmet, hand-cooked crisp offers a lesson in the curious eating habits of the British public. Mainstream methods of producing crisps have concentrated, unsurprisingly, on speed - 12 minutes from potato to packet - and cost, but also on what are perceived as the consumer's preferences: uniformity of size, flavour, colour; lack of blemishes (especially the rarely sighted but unsettling green crisp); a minimum of broken or folded crisps.

Pringles, priced as an upmarket snack, is perhaps the best example of the processed crisp, manufactured from dehydrated potato flakes, cut into identical shapes before frying, and packed into cans to ensure no breakages. Clone crisps indeed.

The secret behind gourmet crisps such as Kettle Chips and Bensons Organic crisps is that they come complete with natural flaws. "It's their imperfections that make them the beauties they are," says Bensons' commercial director, Adrian Luckham."Manufacturers are waking up to the fact that consumers want a more genuine, less processed crisp."

Capitalising on consumer suspicion of over-processed products and additives such as monosodium glutamate, crisp makers have turned the focus back on to the humble potato. Tricks used to ensure conformity in mass-produced crisps, such as double-washing the sliced potato to get rid of extra starch, and liberally dousing them with artificial flavours, are out. The personal touch - individual batch frying, dashes of natural flavours such as balsamic vinegar - are in.

So the crisp revolution has come full circle, back to George Crum and his hand-fried potato slices, and the picky customer again has the upper hand. Cameron Healy, founder of Kettle Foods, which revived the art of hand-cooking chips as long ago as 1982, says: "I knew that the priority for quality lifestyles and values would be growing into more mass markets as baby boomers matured," and so it has proved, with kettle chips and other posh packets filling the void created when the convenience-food generation grew out of its fondness for Wotsits and Hula Hoops.

Consumers want a more adult snack, and if it fits in with the current fad for food au naturel, so much the better. The golden blush of Kettle Chips appears to vary from packet to packet because, we are told, the sugar content of the potato crop fluctuates during the season. We're more likely, then, to view the occasional blemished crisp in a £1.50 packet of potato chips as evidence of an earthy authenticity; the green crisp in the supermarket economy pack, though, remains suspect.

Manufacturers of these specialist crisps are not only charging a lot for them; they have also striven to make them less ubiquitous than their mass-produced siblings. If customers are going to pay more for their potato slices, then the idea that they are purchasing a "select" product has to be maintained. Hence the Jonathan Crisp brand, available in trendy sandwich bars such as London-based Eat; Brannigans, with "traditional" flavours such as roast beef and mustard, sold in pubs; carrot, parsnip or sweet-potato crisps, sold by Pret a Manger.

Few of these find their way into the average lunchbox at present; gourmet crisps account for less than 10% of the 8.5bn packets sold in the UK each year. But the potential to compete with mass-produced snacks is there, and maybe the posh potato crisp will cease to be just a snob snack and become the next mass munch.

fields.headline: Wonderful, wonderful, Copenhagen
fields.standfirst: There's a lot more to Danish cinema than Dogme, as a new festival shows. Danny Leigh reports
fields.trailText: There's a lot more to Danish cinema than Dogme, as a new festival shows. Danny Leigh reports
fields.body:
On an old army base 15 minutes from central Copenhagen, something is stirring. Peter Åalbæk Jensen, partner-in-crime of the mercurial Lars von Trier at Zentropa Enterprises - producers of, among others, Breaking the Waves, The Idiots and Mifune - glances at a press release detailing the company's achievements. A smirk inches across his face.

"Bullshit and lies," declares the self-proclaimed "spade guy" of Dogme 95, bustling outside into the Danish mid-winter, where the rain daubs the concrete walls of the surrounding soundstages. He scans the hive of buildings around him. "Look at it. Built to withstand a small atomic blast." The man in day-to-day control of Dogme's next step pauses, grinning in the downpour. "Welcome to Film City."

But let's put that on hold for a moment. Because, despite the hubbub created by Dogme's stripping of film-making technique to its bare essentials of actor, camera and - occasionally - script, the story of Danish cinema doesn't begin with Von Trier and Thomas Vinterberg (director of last year's acclaimed Festen) putting pen to paper on the back-to-basics Vows of Chastity in March 1995.

Take the impending Danish film season, of which a healthy slice is devoted to rarely-seen nuggets from the country's celluloid past. There, for example, you'll find The Abyss, the 1910 silent which made a star of its quaintly salacious leading lady, Asta Nielsen; 1961's Harry and the Butler, featuring Festen's malignant patriarch Henning Moritzen; and My Metier, an appropriately intense documentary portrait of Carl Dreyer, Denmark's first globally renowned film-maker.

"Part of the thinking behind the festival," explains Michael Søby, the Danish embassy's exuberant cultural attaché, "is illustrating the continuity of our film industry, from the silent era up to the present and into the future. And, of course, Dogme is a wonderful chapter in that tale. But it's only one chapter."

So, while the plaudits, abuse and all-purpose column inches inspired by Dogme's playful sedition have helped propel Danish film beyond the genteel vistas of arthouse buffery, Denmark has already prepared itself for life after the media. Which, in practical terms, involves ensuring audiences in Århus, Alborg and downtown Odense keep watching movies made in Århus, Alborg and downtown Odense.

"Obviously," Søby continues, "if a country of five million people wants to compete with Hollywood, it has to have a really strong network of producers and distributors, which is why the government is investing so heavily in both. If Danish cinema is to thrive, Danes have to be able to see their own movies." And, yes, that includes the still-newsworthy fruit of Dogme. But it also means everything from twentysomething enfant terrible Nicolas Winding Refn's savage, immaculate Bleeder to the stately costume dramas of Nordisk Film.

Sitting in the company's spruce office space, Nordisk's amiably gruff supremo Erik Crone echoes Søby's thoughts. "Initially, we look to succeed here," he says. "The more local a film is, the better it is, and the better its chances are of doing well abroad. If you deliberately try and make international films, you usually end up with something no one wants to see."

With 30 years in the business, Crone's also aware of the fickle nature of the spotlight; he still remembers the late 70s, when Nordisk was obliged to make ends meet with TV sitcoms. "These days," he shrugs, "the situation is very healthy. But, in a country this small, you can never underestimate the importance of getting by."

Which is - very nearly - where we came in. After all, if Zentropa and its home on the demilitarised sprawl of Film City were built on anything, it was getting by. In 1989, there wasn't much else Lars von Trier or Peter Åalbæk Jensen could do; the former was recovering from the tepid reception afforded his morbid meta-drama Epidemic, and the latter, after a brief initial foray into production, was declaring himself bankrupt.

"So, of course, we decided to start a film company," beams Jensen. "We started stealing from the system. All these German commercials agencies would hire Lars to make their shitty ads, and every time we'd botch the job just to give the bill another zero on the end. And because it was Lars, the big-time movie director, and because it was so expensive, they always assumed this stupid ad was something really special."

It took three years of their "Robin Hood act" to find the money for Von Trier's post-war thriller Europa; another three, and Zentropa was the biggest production company in Scandinavia. Right from the outset, Jensen and Von Trier always had more in common than simultaneous career meltdown. "We were both members of the Danish Communist Party for a long, long time," Jensen begins, a smile never far from his lips, "so Zentropa is based on decentralised Marxist principles. Profits are shared, the tools of production are owned by the people, we operate in small cells across Europe, small guerrilla units which act autonomously but pool resources for major projects...

"We're socialists, you know? We wanted self-sufficiency and survival without bankers." As such, Film City probably represents their ideal home. Occupied after "a bunch of us climbed over the fence" on New Year's Day 1999, it now boasts numerous offices, a three-storey house for screenwriters, a cabin for visiting American film-makers, a restaurant, tennis court ("the only upper-class thing here"), and three full-size soundstages.

What was once the Danish army's fencing hall provides the headquarters for Elektropa, the company's internet off-shoot, through which Von Trier plans to launch his "Film University" website next spring; the on-site cinema complex should be ready by next year.

Jensen admits the walls could do with a fresh coat of paint, but "we've got better things to spend the money on": principally, you imagine, Dancer in the Dark, the elaborate, spectacularly non-Dogme musical Von Trier recently finished shooting at Film City with a budget of around $50m.

Jensen then starts talking about Film City's involvement with the children of the Arebøre suburb just beyond the complex's gates, and how the 101 TV cameras used for a single scene in Dancer in the Dark were handed out at the local high school with the instruction that "if you make anything good, we'll sell it for you".

"We let the kids stay on site to learn media," he explains, "and, Christ, so many of them are so good when they make their films. We let them borrow trucks with $1m worth of equipment loaded in the back, and everything always returns in perfect condition. If you trust these kids, it always pays off - that's the future of Danish movies right there."

It all sounds great; the only strange thing is that I haven't heard the word Dogme all afternoon. Jensen hesitates. "It would be great," he says eventually, "if we could have some real, fierce opposition to Dogme. Because it was never supposed to be the norm." And so says Thomas Vinterberg. Indeed, having spent the last year since Festen's British release making videos for Blur and suffering "writer's pillow" on a screenplay he describes as "an absurd warning", the normally garrulous Vinterberg seems reluctant to even mention the subject.

"I really don't want to act as the Dogme spokesman," he remarks early on, his tone apologetic. "Even saying that makes me embarrassed." His resolve, however, is not long cracking. "I know Dogme's lifted Danish film's profile, and I'm glad about that. I'm also glad it's inspired people, and made people angry. But I'm also disappointed. Because, for me, Dogme was designed to be a rescue action from mediocrity - from my own and from that around me. And now it seems Dogme has become part of the bourgeoisie. I'm proud of what we achieved. But the time comes to move on."

Perhaps predictably, he seizes on the chance to do just that when Film City comes up. Now he's smirking. "Film City is as much mafia as commune. It's 1968, but it's also a businessman with a black book and a Kalashnikov underneath his desk."

Still part of the gang, he's quick to clarify himself. "Which is fine, of course. Peter and Lars have learnt you can't change the world as a bankrupt.

He continues: "I'm not a courageous man, and I'm already terrified of repeating myself. So in 10 years' time, I'm not sure how much worth will be left in the vows for us, for me. And if it just became a cosy retrospective, journeying back to the golden age of Dogme, I think that would be kind of... pathetic." He leans forward half-conspiratorially. "The end of it will be if Mifune is nominated for an Oscar. Because, while that would be fantastic in many ways, it will also be the end of Dogme. They may want us to come and sit at their table, but Hollywood is not Denmark's table, and it can't ever be. Even if it means putting an end to Dogme, we should stay anarchists as long as possible. I guess we'll just have to see how long that is."

 Danish Cinema: Past, Present and Future, runs in London from January 21 to March 5, before visiting venues throughout the UK.

fields.headline: James Hawes
fields.trailText: James Hawes
fields.body:
What was the first film you saw?

Charlie the Lonesome Cougar, a heartwarming Disney animation. Kid falls in love with wild animal; wild animal has to go back to the wild. I bawled the place out.

What is your favourite film?

Ariel by Aki Kaurismäki. And I adore The Third Man. I lived in Vienna for a year and taught right underneath the big wheel.

What was the last film you walked out of?

I never have but came very close at the end of Cyrano de Bergerac. The first half an hour was brilliant but it went on and bloody on.

Your most erotic movie moment?

When I was 14 I went to some movie club in the local library where they allowed me to watch The Night Porter with Dirk Bogarde and Charlotte Rampling. In the sex scene where she gets on top of him, I thought, she cannot be doing that.

What's the most annoying habit in cinemas?

The sight of people queuing up for their hot dogs makes me think, "Who are these people? Why do I bother making movies for them?"

When did you last time snog in a cinema?

During The Mummy in Leicester Square. It's is the sort of film you see when you don't want to drink any more at lunchtime and you don't want to stop being with the person you're with.

Favourite snatch of dialogue?

It's from Ariel. Depressed, middle-aged unemployed person meets traffic warden and it cuts to them in bed having an after-sex cigarette. She: "Oh well, I suppose you'll be off in the morning." He: "No, we'll be together forever now." She: "Oh good." It's wonderfully deadpan Finnish humour.

Which actor would you most like to be?

Gregory Peck because he's a fabulously watchable actor and because I gather he's a liberal democrat kind of guy.

Which actress?

Geena Davis in The Long Kiss Goodbye. Obviously I fancy the pants off her as well.

The last time you hid under your seat?

Every time I've tried to see Alien. It's such a vile idea, and so brilliantly vilely executed, but I don't want to go there.

Last time you cried?

With my three-year-old son on my lap watching Tarzan. I hate Phil Collins but I wept buckets at every song.

James Hawes wrote and co-produced Rancid Aluminium, released on January 21.

fields.headline: Out on a Limbo
fields.standfirst: John Sayles is a film-maker who likes to take risks. He talks to Jonathan Romney
fields.trailText: John Sayles is a film-maker who likes to take risks. He talks to Jonathan Romney
fields.body:
The harshest insult in the book is to call a film-maker "workmanlike", but with American independent John Sayles, it might not be such a put-down after all. Sayles is every inch a workman - an artisan, if you prefer. He talks a clean streak of common sense and goes about directing and writing with as much hard pragmatism as anyone in the industry.

A dry, rangy man who wears his denim sleeves rolled right up as if he means business, Sayles turns up for interview duty looking about ready to balance the account books, maybe fix a few shelves if there's time. He's held down some jobs in his day - hospital worker, ditch digger, writer for Roger Corman and member of the Amalgamated Butcher Workers and Meat Packers of North America - so you know he can be relied on not to regale you with flim-flam about the mystique of cinema.

Sayles has a reputation for telling solid, realist stories with a liberal thrust. He's made films about historic union struggles (Matewan) and corruption in baseball (Eight Men Out). He's made a lesbian coming-out drama (Lianna), a portrait of the 60s generation (Return of the Secaucus Seven, his no-budget first feature), and a sci-fi racial satire (The Brother from Another Planet). But in his last few films, Sayles has increasingly gone out on a narrative limb, rather complicating his old image as a leftwing journalist in film-maker's guise. Sayles is proving a director of extraordinary daring.

Lone Star was a multi-stranded Tex-Mex drama that would slip four decades in a single tracking shot, and Men with Guns was a war story set in Latin America, with Spanish dialogue and a metaphysical twist ending. But Sayles's new film, Limbo, is a real leap into the void. For fear of revealing too much about the Alaskan-set drama, suffice to say that halfway through, it hits us with a left-turn of Psycho proportions, then finally leaves us "well, in limbo. You've never seen so many perplexed brows emerging from a screening." Limbo asks a little more of an audience than we're normally used to, Sayles admits.

"Most movies are meant to be about the illusion of risk. You go through all these twists and turns with these characters you care about, but at the end it's Tom Hanks and Meg Ryan and of course they've got to get together, or it's Harrison Ford and of course he's not going to die. All the time we've got our seat belts on. In this movie, I am asking you to get emotionally involved with the characters but we don't know what's going to happen to them. I don't even give you any warning that it's gonna change from a nice quiet ride to mortal danger."

This is not to say that Limbo is a gratuitous weird-out of the Blair Witch school. Like all Sayles's films, it has a grounding in an extraordinary sense of place and community. Within minutes, we not only know the diverse population of this Alaskan town - from theme-park entrepreneurs to salmon cannery workers - but we've even learned the difference between types of fishing technique, between purse-seining and gill-netting.

Sayles backs his scripts up with hard research, in this case into the community of Juno, south-east Alaska, where the film was shot. "Two things I try to do - one is just meet people and talk to them about their jobs, about their life. The other is very practical - I don't want to invent a location that doesn't exist and have to create it. I don't want to have to put trees up and change the beach, so I say, 'Well what's there?' and try to write that into the script."

Diverse as they are, Sayles's films draw a consistency from the way he works with a regular team - notably composer Mason Daring, a repertory cast that includes Limbo's saturnine co-star David Strathairn, and above all, Sayles's long-time partner Maggie Renzi, who has acted in some of his films and been producer on most of them.

"I couldn't produce a two-car funeral," Sayles admits. Even so, his screenwriting necessarily incorporates a canny edge of book-balancing. "If you really want to make a film, you can rethink it. You find another way to tell a story cheaper - new investors show up miraculously. With Limbo, we just came to Sony Pictures, said here's the script, here's the budget, you know our work, we never go over budget, are you interested? And they said go ahead."

There's a similar give-and-take to his directing. "What you try and do is - OK, we've got this much time and this much money, and we're going to stay within that. The actors aren't going to get to ad lib, but I am going to try and set up a situation where they have a little room to move around, listen to each other and not worry too much about the camera. My stuff is 98% preparation, and then there's that 2% that you try to have happen. That's what's interesting, when you say, 'Well, that isn't the way I wrote it, but let's try these things'."

Sayles learned his dollar sense in the late 70s as a writer for New World Pictures, the Roger Corman factory of low-budget exploiters that produced such alumni as Peter Bogdanovich, Jonathan Demme and Joe Dante. Projects like Piranha and the gangster flick The Lady in Red were object lessons in taking liberties with genre. "On Battle Beyond the Stars, Corman said, 'If you can make Seven Samurai into a western, you can make it into a science fiction film.' He had another idea to make Mutiny on the Bounty in outer space. Sometimes there's some hybrid vigour you can get into a genre that way."

As a director, Sayles may be the most consistently go-it-alone film-maker in America, but his business head allows him to write other people's projects to finance his own work. His most recent jobs include an animation feature, and a story about Orson Welles's adventures in postwar Italy, to be directed by Oliver Parker. Then there are the rewrites, often uncredited, among them Apollo 13 - his brief was to put the hard science back into it. He also wrote a giant-insect sci-fi script called Brother Termite for James Cameron - his diametrical opposite as a film-maker but a fellow Corman graduate. "The great thing working for James is that you can write anything, and if he likes it, he'll find a way to do it - he'll invent technology if he has to."

Long based in Hoboken, New Jersey, Sayles and Renzi now live "in a combination of Hoboken, upstate New York, and the road." Sayles prefers to avoid Los Angeles, "a company town". Although Hollywood values him as a writer, you imagine it might not entirely trust him as a director. "There's kind of a mutual understanding from very early on," he admits, "that most of the things I want to do as a director probably aren't appropriate for a studio to finance. Once in a while there's some common ground, but sometimes I don't even try showing it to them. I almost never get offered movies to direct, but I get quite a few writing offers. Sometimes I turn things down not because the money's bad or I don't need a job at that moment. I just say, 'This is not a movie I'd go see.'"

You can't imagine Hollywood taking, either, to the political content of Sayles's films, or their moral seriousness. He's generally thought of as a liberal or radical, but in fact, Sayles - raised Catholic in Schenectady, upstate New York - has described his politics as "survivalist". "I grew up in an Italian neighbourhood, and there's a very healthy distrust of politics in Italian culture, which is - if you can't control it, try to keep it away from your life as much as possible. There are these big forces and big winds which are going to come through, and if you're not the guy who can be the top dude and control them, you got to watch out for them, or they'll blow your house down.

"Yes, you have to join in every once in a while - but you have to really read the situation before you join up and join a war or a revolution." But in fact, Sayles believes his radical reputation has not adversely affected his relationship with the industry. "In the US, nobody's that worried about that stuff - the film industry is secure enough in its domination of the globe. I'd say that our movies have been avoided by financiers because of their complexity more often than their political stand. That they're politically conscious has not been a problem, but complexity takes you outside a genre, and the minute you're outside of genre, people think, 'Oh where does this fit in, and who's going to go and see it?' "

Where Sayles can really afford not to worry about genre is in his literary writing, a field he established himself in even before he took to screenplays. He has written three novels, the last one being the Cuban epic Los Gusanos (in 1991), and is putting together a new short story collection. It's no surprise to learn that his literary influences are mainly from the American hard-bitten guys, the likes of Ring Lardner, Nelson Algren, Faulkner and Hemingway. "To Have and Have Not - there's some wonderful stuff in that book, but once in a while you want to say 'Shut up, Ernie', he's such a pain in the ass."

Book-writing, of course, is a rare opportunity to forget about book-keeping. For a change, Sayles can allow himself to indulge himself in ways even a James Cameron script might not allow. "I did the Bay of Pigs invasion in Los Gusanos, and I didn't have to worry, I had tanks, I had guns, I had 5,000 troops with full uniforms and boots. I couldn't have afforded that in the movies."

 Limbo opens on January 21.
