fields.headline: Winning with losers
fields.standfirst: William H Macy rose belatedly to fame as blundering Jerry Lundegaard in Fargo, a role he threatened to kill for. He's back in the film Magnolia and heading our way onstage in David Mamet's American Buffalo. John Patterson meets him for 'beer and beer soakage materials'
fields.trailText: William H Macy rose belatedly to fame as blundering Jerry Lundegaard in Fargo, a role he threatened to kill for. He's back in the film Magnolia and heading our way onstage in David Mamet's American Buffalo. John Patterson meets him for 'beer and beer soakage materials'
fields.body:
I 'm waiting for William H Macy outside a restaurant in west Los Angeles, when suddenly he's right there in front of me, no introductions, saying, "You know, if we sit inside, we can have beer." Out comes the hand, "Hi, Bill Macy. I spotted the tape-recorder, figured it was you."

"Alcohol before dark, Bill? You're not from LA, are you?"

"Hell, no."

In we go.

No, William H Macy isn't from Los Angeles. But he's not from North Dakota or Wisconsin either, as fans of his breakthrough movie Fargo might assume. Nor is he originally from Chicago, where he served his long theatrical apprenticeship with David Mamet's famous St Nicholas company, though that is the city called to mind by his always intriguing midwestern face, a once-in-a-lifetime combination of weak and strong features, soft flesh and sudden right angles.

He is surely the world's least ethnic actor - "I'm a Lutheran down to my socks," he once said - which makes him ideal for put-upon white guys, bureaucrats, sleazy private dicks, low-level politicians, salesmen, lawyers and beautiful losers. Since Fargo, his name on a movie has been one of those reassuring elements that tend to suggest the movie in question might actually be worth watching.

Like most actors, Macy is shorter and slighter than he appears on screen, in his case possibly because the camera tends to fetishise his face (and the waves of anxiety that seem perpetually to be breaking across it) at the expense of his body - thus making him seem gigantic. He's about my height, five-nine, five-ten and slender, with small hands. Today he's sporting a moustache which brings the competing planes of his physiognomy into amiable focus.

"We need beer," he tells the waiter as we settle into our spacious red leather booth. "And beer soakage materials, too, like fries or whatever, but mainly beer."

It's a big week for Macy. His latest movie, Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia, has been out for a week's limited release to qualify for the Academy awards, and he's extremely proud of both his own performance and particularly of his director, who's only half Macy's age. "I mean, just where does he get off being so damn talented?" he asks in mock exasperation. He's also preparing to bring a revival of Mamet's 1970s masterpiece, American Buffalo, to the Donmar Warehouse in London, the first American production here since Al Pacino brought it over in 1983.

"This is a sweet project for me," he beams, "because Mamet's such an old pal of mine." Playing the role of Bobby, which Macy himself played in Buffalo's original Chicago production, is fellow Magnolia star and PT Anderson perennial Philip Baker Hall, another of America's great, underused character actors (his Richard Nixon in Robert Altman's Secret Honor is a monumental creation, one that would eat a lesser actor alive).

Macy remembers when he first read the play. He and Mamet had co-founded the St Nicholas Company in the Windy City, having met some years earlier at Goddard College. Mamet was a teaching instructor in theatre who took Macy on as his student assistant (born in 1950, Macy's about four years younger than Mamet). After leaving Goddard and drifting around the country for a while, he and Mamet teamed up again, rented a space and started putting on plays of their own.

"One time Dave just totally disappeared for a month or so and then just as suddenly reappeared. I met him in a bar and said, 'Where the hell have you been?' And he slapped down this huge manuscript, and says, 'Check it out, I just finished it.' That was American Buffalo. Oh, Lord, did I want the role of Bobby - and I got it. American Buffalo got me my Equity card, so to go back and play Teach - what? - 25 years later, that's pretty sweet."

He was instantly gripped by the staccato rhythms and fractured cadences of Mamet's bracingly foul-mouthed dialogue. "With his language, his writing - an excellent analogy is that it's like a sports car, a Porsche or something - it's not the easiest car in the world to drive, but once you've got it down there's so much you can do with it. By the same token, it's difficult to memorise if you're not familiar with his rhythms, be it a Chicago rhythm or a New York City rhythm - and there's a lot of British colloquialisms in his dialogue as well.

"If you're not aware of these rhythms it can be really daunting, but once you know the dialogue perfectly, inside-out, it literally gives you pleasure to speak it. It has so much music in it, the metre is so pleasing that you just love to say it. Whenever I meet another actor who's done Buffalo, we'll start running the lines back and forth, and I don't know of any other play where that's true. 'You did Titus Andronicus? So did I!' Not the same. People love those lines. You get a single word out of place and it all goes to pieces."

Chicago, he remembers, really had it going on in what he now sees were these pioneering days in American theatre. There were numerous theatre groups engaging in friendly competition, principally the Organic Theatre, the city's main alternative stage, which was frequently graced by such soon-to-be-famous actors as Joe Mantegna, now better known as Mamet's onscreen everyman, and Dennis Franz, who played Teach in Michael Corrente's rather flaccid film adaptation of Buffalo in 1996. Chicago also hosted the famous Second City comedy improv troupe, many of whose members - John Belushi, Dan Aykroyd and Bill Murray among them - would change American comedy much as Mamet and his acolytes were reinvigorating post-Albee theatre.

"It was totally new. We approached St Nicholas on a pretty ambitious, professional level. We rented a theatre, and built ourselves a theatre company from next to nothing. And for about 10 years in Chicago it was astounding, because no one did a play for any other reason than to put on a play. In New York you do theatre to get to Broadway. In LA you do a play to get into the movies. In Chicago they did a play to do the play. Someone might say, 'Hey this play might make it all the way to New York.' And people would just laugh and say, 'So what?' It wasn't a stepping-stone to anything."

And considering he was acting, Macy was surprised to find money in his pocket, lots of it. "I was a working actor with a new car, which is unheard of, but I bought a building too. A working actor - with residential property to his name? I remember raising my glass one time in a bar and saying to all my actor buddies, 'Guys, these are the good old days!' "

After a decade in Chicago, though, Macy was starting to burn out, so he moved to New York, where he still got good parts and steady gigs. "But I still felt like I was spinning my wheels. I'd get good roles and good reviews, but after a while I started feeling like I was being taken for granted. In New York I was always playing the WASPy asshole guy, the asshole lawyer or the asshole doctor, and my friends would show up backstage and say, 'Man, I really hated you!' Uh... thanks. Or 'Hi Bill, what a prick you were tonight.' Thanks a lot."

By 1990, having played small roles in a few forgotten movies in the early 80s (Somewhere in Time, anyone?) and an endless stream of commercials and voiceovers, he decided it was time to move to Los Angeles and make a serious bid at getting in the movies. He reasoned that Tinseltown had more to offer than the commercials he was getting (his favourite line was in an ad for Secret deodorant: "Strong enough for a man... but made for a woman").

Until he secured Fargo, Macy kept busy with character roles and more substantial parts in Mamet's movies (he's been in almost all of them and was the star of Oleanna, which most closely recreates the Mamet-Macy onstage dynamic, particularly the shuddering, multiple-interrupted language). Although he didn't register fully in the collective consciousness of audiences until Fargo, he can be spotted in numerous big-cast A-feature movies such as The Client, Mr Holland's Opus, Murder in the First, Searching for Bobby Fischer and, rather more visibly, as a featured performer on ER.

But when Fargo fell into his lap, he knew immediately what it could do for him, and what he could do for it. "I basically said to the Coens, 'This is my role - my role - and I'm just scared you guys are gonna fuck it up and cast someone else.' " When he heard the Coens were continuing their audition process in New York, he got on a plane and showed up again, just to remind them. "I said, 'It's my role and I'll shoot your dogs if you don't give it to me.' " He got it. The dogs lived.

As he gets further and further in over his head, Macy's limitlessly expressive face charts the inexorable upsurge of everything Jerry has hitherto refused to face about his daft plot and, more importantly, about himself.

One can imagine only a tiny number of major actors who would have emitted the anguished squeal Macy gives out when he's finally arrested crawling out of a motel lavatory window. Along with Fargo, Macy was off to the Oscars - the "Independent Oscars", as they were nicknamed that year - with his first supporting actor nomination. I venture to guess there will be more.

"I read Paul Thomas Anderson's Boogie Nights script, which was originally much, much racier, and I thought, 'Oh my God, this is pornography!' There were shots of people blowing each other and fucking, but God it was a good script. All the agents were wary of it, and if Paul hadn't been such a brilliant film-maker it could have been just awful. But I had a great meeting with Paul where I thought I was selling myself to him and halfway through, I realised he was selling himself to me. I went and saw his first movie, Hard Eight, that night and told him that if he wanted to direct the phone book, I'd be there first thing Monday morning."

Mamet and Anderson, he says, both run similar, friendly sets, where egos are kept in their boxes and those who favour screaming as a management technique are off the lot by noon. "They'd both rather be directing a movie than doing anything else, probably including sex, but they maintain this warm environment that lets things get done. I've found that in Hollywood, assholism comes from the top down. If the producer or director is an asshole, then the people at the craft-services table will be assholes too."

With Magnolia opening here in March, and the superhero comedy Mystery Men just released - "too many cooks in that kitchen" is Macy's verdict on the latter, actually very amusing film - Bill Macy is set to become, however briefly, an omnipresent figure in Britain over the next couple of months. He and Mamet have also just wrapped State and Main, a comedy about a Hollywood production on location in Vermont, with Macy playing the director.

"Lord Almighty, did we have fun. They just destroy this poor town," he says of the film, which seems to offer more evidence of Mamet's abiding distaste for Hollywood. "Yeah, you practically have to sedate him to get him to come to LA." Mamet and Macy are also hoping to do a remake of High and Low, Akira Kurosawa's classic 1962 detective thriller (from an Ed McBain novel), about the mistaken kidnapping of a millionaire's chauffeur's son, with Macy playing the chauffeur.

In the end, despite his new-found status in Hollywood, it is for Mamet that Macy reserves his highest praise. "He wasn't just my mentor, he also gave me my career," he says with unaffected feeling and gratitude evident in his voice. "He gave me crucial roles throughout my career. I just wouldn't have made it without him."

 American Buffalo runs at the Donmar Warehouse, London, from January 28 to February 26 (tickets: 0171-369 1732). Magnolia will be released in March.

Since Fargo, his name on a movie has been one of those reassuring elements that tend to suggest the movie in question might actually be worth watching. His latest movie, Paul Thomas Anderson's Magnolia, has been out for a week's limited release to qualify for the Academy awards, and he's extremely proud of both his own performance and particularly of his director, who's only half Macy's age. "I mean, just where does he get off being so damn talented?" he asks in mock exasperation. He's also preparing to bring a revival of Mamet's 1970s masterpiece, American Buffalo, to the Donmar Warehouse in London, the first American production here since Al Pacino brought it over in 1983. "This is a sweet project for me," he beams, "because Mamet's such an old pal of mine." Mamet was a teaching instructor in theatre who took Macy on as his student assistant (born in 1950, Macy's about four years younger than Mamet). fields.headline: Local hero
fields.standfirst: He wrote Britain's biggest hit film but he'd still rather work in Huddersfield than Hollywood. Steve Rose talks to Simon Beaufoy about his directorial debut, a film about visions in Yorkshire
fields.trailText: He wrote Britain's biggest hit film but he'd still rather work in Huddersfield than Hollywood. Steve Rose talks to Simon Beaufoy about his directorial debut, a film about visions in Yorkshire
fields.body:
You can't help but wonder whether Simon Beaufoy shouldn't have just taken the money and run. After The Full Monty, his debut film script, became a global phenomenon in 1997 against all expectations, the gates of Hollywood were wide open to him. Miramax paid a substantial sum for a script they hadn't even seen; he was nominated for a best screenplay Oscar; and his American agent was urging him to do a film version of Run For Your Wife with Hugh Grant and John Cleese.

For a 30-year-old British film-maker with no other feature films to his name, this was a dream start. Yet here he is, three years later, with The Darkest Light, a low-budget film about religious visions and agricultural hardship in North Yorkshire, featuring a cast primarily comprised of unknown actors, children and cattle.

The Darkest Light also represents Beaufoy's directorial debut, in the company of his long-term partner, Billie Eltringham. "It was quite interesting to be offered literally millions of dollars to write stupid films, but in the end I realised that Hollywood was not really my world at all," Beaufoy says. "I never got into cinema to be famous or to make lots of money, which is why it's a huge irony that The Full Monty made such a vast sum. I see films as being different from movies. I'm not into movies. I really genuinely want to say something about my view of the world. I don't know whether that sounds pretentious or not but that's why I got into film-making."

These worthy ambitions were formed at Bournemouth film school, where Beaufoy was studying in the early 90s along with his partners in his company Footprint Films: Eltringham, and The Darkest Light's producer, Mark Blaney. The three have worked together in various configurations since, usually with Beaufoy and Eltringham sharing both writing and directing responsibilities. Their short film and television projects have included Yellow, which starred Ray Winstone, Closer, with Mark Addy, which screened as part of the Brief Encounters series, and the recent Channel 4 drama Kid in the Corner.

Beaufoy's primary ambition was to be a documentary-maker; and it was only when he was refused permission to make a documentary about pylon painters in Pembrokeshire that he crossed over into fiction, combining his research and his experiences with climbers in Sheffield, for the 1998 film Among Giants, starring Pete Postlethwaite and Rachel Griffiths.

Authenticity has been paramount in his screenwriting, he says, which is why all his scripts have been set in and around Yorkshire, where he grew up. "To different extents, I knew how these people operated, which is really crucial. I know how they speak, I know how they drink their tea in the morning. I could never do a story set in New York, say."

The Darkest Light is set even closer to home, among the farming community of north Yorkshire. "I was always puzzled by television's view of farm life there," he says. "There was a lot of James Herriot going on when I was young. It was all fluffy sheep and idyllic farms, but that wasn't the experience of farmers that I'd had - high suicide rates, divorce, loneliness, people rounding up sheep in four-wheel drive vehicles, chemicals. It's not pretty, it's modern and difficult and generally very, very depressing."

The Darkest Light is something of a departure, story-wise, from Beaufoy's earlier projects, in that it blends down-to-earth naturalism with spiritual exploration. The principal characters are children: a farmer's daughter, Catherine; her younger brother Matthew, who has leukaemia; and her friend Uma, a Hindu girl. Playing on the moors one day, Catherine and Uma are witness to a mysterious light, which they both interpret according to their own faiths, thus dividing a community already beleaguered by an outbreak of foot-and-mouth disease.

"The inspiration for the project was hearing they'd built an airport at Knock [in Ireland, where a vision was observed in 1879] because it had attracted so many tourists," he recalls. "I went right back to Medrugoria, Lourdes, Garabandal, those visionary sites. The visions all happened to young children in rural communities in times of civil strife or famine. That's what really interested me; the way that these visions happened when they needed to happen.

"Knowing what I know about what's going on in the countryside with the farming community, those two ideas really clicked with me. At a time when Welsh farmers are putting newly-born calves in telephone boxes and farmers are going bankrupt, this is a community that needs a sense of hope, if ever there was one."

Despite being a self- confessed "woolly agnostic", Beaufoy admits to being fascinated by both the divisive power of faith, and what he perceives as a growing trend towards spiritual questioning in 21st-century society. "We've tried everything in the last century to make us happy; communism, capitalism, Armani jeans, crystals, crop circles, you name it. People no longer believe in established government, established churches, established anything. We'll realise soon that shopping will bring no happiness. Getting Charlie Dimmock to do our garden will not actually provide any long-lasting sense of fulfilment."

The Darkest Light is hardly another Full Monty: Beaufoy is aware that a film which balances alternative perspectives and ends ambivalently, rather than hammering home a message right up to the finish line, is unlikely to be a huge commercial or international success. It's a film, not a movie.

A more easily digestible slice of entertainment is in the pipeline, however: his hairdressing comedy Never Better, the aforementioned script bought unseen by Miramax in the wake of The Full Monty's success. Beaufoy has effectively disowned the project, and regrets the fact that his precious authenticity is about to be snipped into a Hollywood treatment. It is again set in Yorkshire, even closer to home than his previous scripts, but the lead roles will be played by American teen stars Josh Hartnett (of The Faculty) and Rachael Leigh Cook (who starred in last year's She's All That).

"It's become more like New Yorkshire," he smirks. "American stars with flat caps going, 'Eh oop.' But it's about hairdressing in the same way The Full Monty was about stripping. So instead of writing about competition hairdressing I wrote about lesbianism, cancer and divorce. I don't think they really liked it."

 The Darkest Light is released today.

fields.headline: A cut above
fields.standfirst: Donald Cammell's reputation has soared posthumously. Brian Pendreigh meets Frank Mazzola, the editor who has restored the director's last film
fields.trailText: Donald Cammell's reputation has soared posthumously. Brian Pendreigh meets Frank Mazzola, the editor who has restored the director's last film
fields.body:
Donald Cammell's death, in April 1996, was hardly world news. He had directed only three and a half feature films in four decades. Performance, his best known, was co-directed with Nicolas Roeg, who went on to fame and fortune, while Cammell fell into obscurity. End of story.

Except it wasn't. His last film, Wild Side, starred then-unknown actress Anne Heche as a lesbian call girl. Cammell liked to jump around between disparate characters and dislocated scenes. The production company who hired him, Nu Image, didn't. It butchered Wild Side, which went straight to cable in the US and was never seen in the UK. Heche came out and became a star; Cammell put a pistol to his head and pulled the trigger; his editor, Frank Mazzola, who taught James Dean to knife-fight, reached for his knife once more and returned to Wild Side. It was time for justice.

Cammell's work has undergone a significant critical re-evaluation since his death. As early as 1995 Performance appeared at number 28 in an "all-time greats" poll of critics and directors. In 1998 it was the subject of a BFI Film Classics book and the BBC screened a documentary on Cammell. "It's not unexpected," says his widow, China Kong. "Donald always said his work would be appreciated far more after his death." Mazzola spent much of last year using his skills with a knife, re-editing Wild Side to produce a posthumous director's cut. He finished just in time for a world premiere at the Edinburgh film festival in August, and the new version will be released in British cinemas later this year, before screening on Channel 4.

The Edinburgh audience were hugely appreciative, but few had had the chance to see the original Nu Image version and appreciate the extent of Mazzola's rescue operation. I cannot think of two such radically different films being produced from the same raw footage - a point underlined by the fact that Mazzola's version is 20 minutes longer, though it contains fewer scenes. Nu Image's film is an intriguing mess, a flawed minor movie, whereas the new version is an effective companion piece to Performance.

Heche plays a banker who works as a call girl on the side, in which capacity she meets Christopher Walken, who is also involved in the world of finance - "the Leonardo da Vinci of dirty money". Joan Chen, his ex-wife and business partner, opens an account at Heche's bank and before long Heche and Chen are lovers as well. Nu Image's Wild Side is the sort of trashy sex thriller that turns up late at night on Channel 5. Some of the acting - particularly Heche's - is downright bad, as if the cast were just warming up or trying things out. Which is exactly what they were doing. But viewers who saw only this version had no way of knowing there were better takes - and indeed a whole different film - lying on the cutting-room floor.

Mazzola and Cammell met 30 years ago in Hollywood, Mazzola's hometown. His father was one of the Keystone Cops and Mazzola played Crunch in Rebel Without a Cause. The film's knife-fight came from his own experiences. "I used to fight a lot when I was a kid," he says in a lethargic, sun-baked Californian drawl. "This guy pulled a knife on me... I was a boxer and I pulled a leather jacket over my hand, so it wouldn't get cut, and I started feinting the guy and then I hooked him a beautiful shot and just basically beat the crap out of the guy... When I told Nick (director Nicholas Ray) and Jimmy about that, they said 'Would you like to stage the knife fight and do it just the way you told us?' "

Cammell came from a very different world. He was born in the Outlook Tower, next to Edinburgh castle, in 1934, the son of Charles Cammell, a poet who inherited and lost the Cammell Laird shipbuilding fortune. Occultist Aleister Crowley was a family friend, but contrary to popular belief was not Donald's godfather. Donald's brother David, one of the producers of Performance, told me Donald embroidered the truth to impress people. He had an idea for a film called The Performers in which his friend Mick Jagger would play a rock star.

United Artists had made a fortune on the Beatles films and Warner Brothers leapt at the chance to cash in on their biggest rivals. Cinematographer Nicolas Roeg was another friend, who came on board to lend a little technical know-how. Performance was in the can by the time Cammell met Mazzola, but Cammell was having trouble in post-production. Mazzola, who had given up acting to become a film editor, saw it and felt inspired. "I said I have got to work on this film... There was so much magic going on between us, there was so much electricity, I was cutting stuff so fast, it was unbelievable. I would do like three cuts at a time... There was something beautiful about it."

Not everyone agreed. Jagger plays a reclusive rock star, Anita Pallenberg and Michèle Breton his girlfriends and James Fox an east end gangster who turns up on their doorstep. During the perverse power and sex games that follow, the identities of the two male characters begin to merge. It seems the first inkling Warner got that they were not going to get a Rolling Stones version of A Hard Day's Night was when executives attended a preview screening and watched an opening sequence that cut back and forth between a Rolls-Royce in the countryside and a scene of violent sex.

They wanted to destroy the film and sue the makers, but relented after the success of the hippy classic Easy Rider, and Performance developed a cult following. Nevertheless Cammell found it difficult to get backing for other projects and hired himself out as a jobbing director on the sci-fi film Demon Seed, also edited by Mazzola. They made their mark with surreal visuals, despite rows with MGM.

Cammell's only other feature before Wild Side was White of the Eye, in which a woman discovers her husband is a serial killer. He co-wrote it with China Kong, whom he met when she was still at school. After White of the Eye, Cammell turned down numerous directing opportunities, including Pretty Woman.

Cammell and Kong collaborated on numerous scripts and it was Kong who came up with the story for Wild Side in 1994. Unusually, Cammell had little difficulty finding finance - it from Nu Image, a company that specialises in exploitation films, often involving cops or vicious animals. But there were problems. "They didn't want Anne," says Kong. "They wanted somebody else, another type of actress." There were further clashes with producer Elie Cohn and, according to Kong, Cammell threw him off the set.

But it was when studio executives sat down to watch the rough cut that it became apparent - in a scene that echoed the Performance screening - just how wide apart Cammell and Nu Image's expectations were. "We were looking at dailies and laughing at a lot of the stuff," says Mazzola. "When I started cutting, it all held together, so I would play things long... At the running I never heard any laughter. They never saw any humour in the film. "At the end of our rough cut Elie Cohn got up, said 'It's slow,' and walked out."

Cammell received written demands for 30 minutes of cuts, clarification of the storyline, the removal of all the flashbacks and specific amendments to numerous scenes. Before long Cammell and Mazzola were off the movie. Nu Image brought in another editor and Wild Side was televised and subsequently released on video under the directorial credit Franklin Brauner, a relation of Alan Smithee.

Mazzola wanted to protest in the trade press, but Cammell asked him to hold fire because Hamish McAlpine, head of Metro Tartan distributors in London, was involved in discussions with Nu Image over UK rights and Cammell was confident he would "get the film back". Prospects were looking brighter in other areas too: Cammell and Kong were back together after a separation and McAlpine was producing another Cammell film, Thirty Three, a thriller set in Istanbul in the 30s. The script was sent to Bill Pullman, star of Independence Day. He committed to it, and the next day Cammell shot himself.

"I knew things were going to happen the way they happened for a very long time, some 20 years," says Kong, though she still finds it almost impossible to talk about her husband's death. McAlpine believes it was because he was so happy that Cammell decided, like the old Indian chief in Little Big Man, that it was a good day to die. So it was without Cammell that Mazzola returned to the editing room in Hollywood in which he assembled Performance 30 years earlier and picked up on Wild Side where he and Cammell left off. "We knew there were certain scenes that were problems, there were certain sequences weren't quite working properly," he says. "Several weeks before he died we discussed everything that we wanted to do with the film and he assured me that we would have our cut."

Nu Image's pre-credit sequence begins with a shot of what looks like an Airfix aeroplane, before cutting to a man making a ham-fisted pass at Heche, suggesting they go to his place in the Bahamas to "get it on". She writhes and grunts, and then bites his ear, at the same time telling him to fuck off. Finally she slaps him, simultaneously on both cheeks the way Eric Morecambe used to do. It plays like Confessions of an Air Stewardess.

In its opening sequence, the new version rapidly cuts between scenes, in typical Cammell fashion. But subsequently Mazzola lingers much longer over individual scenes. He replaces poorly-acted takes and eliminates awkward sequences and risible lines that Cammell was just trying out. But the biggest difference is the way in which Mazzola allows characters, scenes and humour to develop at their own pace, with extra dialogue and reaction shots. Mazzola says there is only one scene that is the same in both versions.

In the Nu Image version, Walken's performance seems bloated, whereas we now see it as more obviously mannered and comic. Walken decides to rape his chauffeur, for example, and tears off his "Calvins" only to spank him with them instead, shouting that he paid for the underpants, so they are his. Wild Side is weird and funny, and marks a return to the themes of sex and power, dressing up and playing games, that Cammell explored in Performance.

"It is a film that could only have been made by Donald," says Kong. "He was very proud of it." Meanwhile there is continuing interest in their unfilmed screenplays, including one about American bank-robber Machine Gun Kelly which Kong has been discussing with Elliott Kastner, who produced White of the Eye and Robert Altman's The Long Goodbye. David Bailey is attached to direct The Cull, a drama about a traumatised Gulf war veteran in the Scottish Highlands. David Cammell hopes to make The Last Video, the story of a music video-maker who accidentally records the kidnapping of a judge. And McAlpine finally hopes to get Thirty Three before the cameras next year.

The appearance of Wild Side does not mark the end of Donald Cammell's story. It is just the latest chapter in a tale that becomes ever more fascinating.

webTitle: Never mind the width, feel the quality

fields.headline: Never mind the width, feel the quality
fields.trailText: Never mind the width, feel the quality
fields.body:
When bloated studio heads wake up after the excesses of the Christmas and New Year release schedule, the first thing they do, like any penitent, cranium-clutching drunk mourning his latest excesses, is to resolve to be good all year long. No more obscenely expensive, featherbrained package movies whose greatest achievements are their ad campaigns and their ability to separate gullible cinemagoers from their cash.

For the short-term future there will be an upsurge of smaller, more intimate, less in-your-face movies to compensate for the brash and brainless likes of Any Given Sunday and Bicentennial Man. To the distant observer this can look like some cheap Tinseltown version of Lent, although restraint and self-abnegation haven't been Hollywood's strong suits since, oh, at least the Fatty Arbuckle rape case.

It's an illusion. This is a quiet period in movie production anyway, what with weather concerns keeping a lid on certain types of location shooting until the spring thaw comes. The business is traditionally on semi-hiatus, with the stars hibernating in their fat-farms, drying-out clinics and Narcotics Anonymous meetings, or dotting the "i"s and crossing the "t"s on their divorce settlements, paternity suits and aggravated assault plea-bargains. So this is the time when the studios and the major independents start pimping their quality product in advance of the Oscar ceremony, which in the Hollywood calendar occupies a place not unlike that of Easter, or perhaps even the Last Judgment itself.

So while the broad outlines of last week's box office chart were still largely determined by the continued post-holiday momentum of the biggest seasonal hits - Stuart Little, Toy Story, The Talented Mr Ripley, etc - the allegedly upmarket stuff was to be found hovering in the lower reaches of the top 10, or just south of it.

There were three major releases, Magnolia, The Cider House Rules and Snow Falling on Cedars, all of which received limited New York-Los Angeles releases over Christmas to qualify for the Academy Awards. Thus, in preparation for their New Year wide releases, the entire Calendar section of the LA Times over the holidays was smeared with the competing films' initial ecstatic reviews.

Or in some cases, with whatever they could bribe the usual quote-whores into typing. (One of them will be breaking out the phrase "greatest movie of the decade" any day now, just you watch. It's like waiting for the first cuckoo.)

So this was the weekend when "quality" and "prestige" jousted with box office fate and, as usual they took a right spanking. Magnolia only managed to crawl as high as number seven. Snow Falling on Cedars barely made it to the 10 spot, and Lasse Hallström's adaptation of John Irving's novel, The Cider House Rules didn't even register, despite a much-praised performance from Michael Caine as a benign abortionist.

Magnolia has been pushed as a prestige production since the get-go, given the immense critical acclaim afforded Paul Thomas Anderson's second movie, Boogie Nights, which, despite the shower of honours it received, was not a huge financial success.

Anderson recently spoke of receiving some sage advice from Francis Ford Coppola. The veteran movie brat, who's in a position to know, urged Anderson to take advantage of his high tide and make the most ambitious project he had in his back catalogue, because no matter what happened, the opportunity would not come knocking twice. In short: strike while the iron's hot and the goodwill's still flowing freely. Coppola did this himself once, and despite coming home with Apocalypse Now in the can, I think his career has never found its footing since.

Whether or not Magnolia - with its 188-minute running time and Nashville-sized cast - resulted directly from that conversation, no one will deny that it's an extremely ambitious film. I've now seen it three times and wouldn't retract a single one of the superlatives I've uttered about it. An emotional epic constructed from a dozen different storylines unfolding in a single day in the San Fernando Valley, it confronts big emotions and fears head-on and achieves a marvellous ramshackle grandeur, thanks largely to the willingness of director and cast to take huge risks with our sympathies and our patience.

Anyone who's seen Magnolia in a packed movie house will testify to having seen entire rows of people burst spontaneously into tears at certain key moments. Some people love that. Some just hate it. Magnolia divides audiences: no one just half likes it or half hates it - you're 100% insane about it or you walk out cursing everyone involved. Me, I'm in the first group, so anything I say about it must be viewed in the light of my slightly unhinged devotion.

Unhinged devotion did not feature in my reactions to Snow Falling on Cedars. David Guterson's bestselling middlebrow potboiler arrives on the big screen as a lumbering prestige project with hugely inflated Oscar pretensions, one that bends over backwards to convince us of its own seriousness, and snaps its own spine in the process.

Working with elements and issues similar to those that underpinned John Sturges's considerably more succinct Bad Day at Black Rock, director Scott Hicks and co-writer Ron Bass attempt to weave a tapestry of memory and history, personal and national, around a 1950 murder trial on an island in Puget Sound.

The corpse is American. The defendant is a war hero of Japanese descent (Rick Yune) with a claim on land owned by the dead man. The narrator (Ethan Hawke) is also a vet and the town' s newspaper editor, and was once in love with the accused's wife.

The trial, of course, revives the same second world war bigotry and jingoism that saw Japanese-born citizens interned in concentration camps. However, the narrative chronology is so heavily hacked about, its tenses so addled, and the material so thinly spread across so many characters, that you can scarcely keep it straight in your head without going cross-eyed. It can be done, but if the only reward is the headache, why bother?

fields.headline: It's grim out west
fields.standfirst: Alan Parker's film of Angela's Ashes is over the top, sentimental and hysterical. Perfect, says Peter Bradshaw
fields.trailText: Peter Bradshaw: For some it may be over the top by a good few kilometres; but Parker handles this movie with terrific dash and sweep, it has a generous human warmth and crackling dialogue that made me laugh out loud.
fields.body:
From the very moment that the adult Frankie McCourt's voiceover unrolls drolly about that most awful thing, "a miserable Irish Catholic childhood", it is clear that Alan Parker's spacious adaptation of McCourt's bestselling memoir, Angela's Ashes, is going to be a delicious, vulgar, overblown, fattening calorific treat of a film.

Its sentimental excesses and lengthy unflinching grimness accumulate into a kind of sustained and entertaining effrontery, of a piece with the unreliable, semi-fictional nature of the source material.

For some it may be over the top by a good few kilometres; but Parker handles this movie with terrific dash and sweep, it has a generous human warmth and crackling dialogue that made me laugh out loud regularly for two and a half hours.

One does not have to know Limerick to enjoy this film the way I did: although an acquaintance with the Limerick of 2000 lends a frisson to this cracked and lachrymose love song about the Limerick of the 30s and 40s, a time frame that tactfully omits both the city's notorious anti-semitic "boycott" at the beginning of the century, and, at its end, its grim reputation as the "stab city" of crime, and then, finally, its increasing prosperity, a veritable Celtic tiger in receipt of EU funds.

Angela's Ashes delights in immersing us in the terrible poverty of its back lanes of yore, juxtaposed with the undulations of O'Connell Street and Georgian terraces, the fog off the Shannon, the glowering outline of the Castle, the miserable, ubiquitous rain and damp.

Words cannot convey the unmitigated poverty-stricken awfulness of McCourt's childhood, and Parker's film traces every hideous and hilarious contour. Dispensing, largely, with the beer-commercial soft focus and the cliches of flute and fiddle, Parker has brought off an ambitious and engaging film about childhood and identity in the west of Ireland.

McCourt's story begins with an unimaginable mixture of tragedy and shame; feckless and drunk, the family's father, Malachy, a man from the north, fails to provide for his wife and children for their new life in America. Their baby sister Margaret dies in their squalor and they must return to Ireland, enduring the soul-blackening humiliation of seeing the Statue of Liberty receding as they sail away.

Robert Carlyle's performance alternates bantam-cock belligerence for the IRA in his cups, drinking away money for the children's food, with an intense and impotent love for the family he is failing. Emily Watson is a rather more diaphanous presence as the eponymous Angela, Frankie's mother; there is not much for her to do.

Young Frank lives to see two more of his brothers die in their squalid home - in a bug-ridden bed the entire family share - with a ground floor permanently flooded and a communal lavatory outside that stinks "so they need a gas mask". Frank himself survives typhoid and conjunctivitis that almost blinds him.

Death becomes banal; the two boys, Frank and Malachy, numbly accept the marble-faced corpses of their dead siblings in the house while they wait for the undertaker, and dirty stories and conversation carry on regardless. Only when Malachy senior actually has his pint on the tiny coffin wedged in front of him in WJ South's pub, is some complaint raised.

It scarcely seems possible that comedy could arise from all this: but it does, partly hysterical death-of-Little-Nell laughs, but real, feel-good laughs too - and it is a testament to Parker's control over the material that he can bring in this comic mode with such dexterity.

Largely it is to be found in the language of ordinary Limerick life. When Aunt Aggie attempts to brush down Frank's greasy, tufty hair, with painful strokes of her retributive brush, she explodes: "It's the Northern Ireland in you - it attracts the dort! You've hair on you like a Presbyterian!"

So it goes on: Frank grows into adolescence, getting a job writing threatening letters for the local money-lender, and conceiving a humid love of the pictures and a need to indulge in a virtual 24-hour frenzy of communal wanking in the fields about the town - it is here that the influence of Giuseppe Tornatore's Cinema Paradiso is faintly to be found.

The representation of poverty on screen - the actual, moment-by-moment experience of real poverty - is very difficult, and a film-maker is always liable to charges of evasion and distortion. It is arguable that both Parker and McCourt exaggerate the notional severity of poverty for dramatic effect, while in real terms capitulating to the picturesque by mitigating its actual physical, visual circumstances. But there is such life and energy in this film, such pleasingly unselfconscious performances from the three actors playing Frank in various stages of growth, and such unflagging narrative drive and gusto. At two and a half hours, Angela's Ashes is a long film, but I wished it were longer.

Its sentimental excesses and lengthy unflinching grimness accumulate into a kind of sustained and entertaining effrontery, of a piece with the unreliable, semi-fictional nature of the source material. fields.headline: Video releases
fields.standfirst: The War Zone | The Polish Bride | Rogue Trader
fields.trailText: The War Zone | The Polish Bride | Rogue Trader | Wing Commander
fields.body:
The War Zone
Rental and DVD, £19.99
VCI Cert 18
***

Tim Roth's directorial debut is, as you might expect, uncompromising and unflinching. It's also terribly bleak, and is inevitably compared to Gary Oldman's first film as a director, Nil By Mouth. Both actors started under Alan Clarke and Mike Leigh. Both feature fellow Clarke alumnus Ray Winstone as lead actor.

The big difference is that for all the bad behaviour and violence in Nil By Mouth, you felt by the end that you understood its characters and the way their environment had formed them. No such luxury here. The War Zone, scripted by the author of the novel it's based on, Alexander Stuart, provides no back-story and no motivation.

A family moves from London to the Devon coast. They seem normal if uncommunicative but sullen 15-year-old son Tom (Freddie Cunliffe) gradually realises there's something going on between his sister (Lara Belmont) and Dad (Winstone). Sex throughout seems like a joyless compulsion and the saturated colours make the coastline look as cheerless as its characters.

Incest cropped up in last year's darkly witty Happiness but Roth's film recalls only Andrew Birkin's fine The Cement Garden in UK cinema. (Roth cites Bergman and Death in Venice as stylistic influences.) Winstone is predictably good but it's debutant Lara Belmont, wan-faced and vulnerable, who dominates. It's the kind of film that may come back to haunt you when you'd rather it didn't.

The Polish Bride
Retail, £15.99
Artificial Eye Cert 15
***

There's a brief flurry of excitement as a panicking woman escapes. Then The Polish Bride settles into classically slow, undramatic European art movie mode. She takes refuge with a taciturn Dutch farmer. They play draughts silently. They eat apples even more silently. They look at his photo album: "Here's father with the new tractor." Algerian-born director Karim Traidia frames each shot carefully but he allows both tenderness and humour to creep in gradually before a climax all the more explosive for its snail-like build-up. The film won awards at Cannes and Rotterdam.

Rogue Trader
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert 15
**

Nick Leeson's collapse of Barings, the world's oldest private bank was a very big story, but hardly a cinematic one. Writer-director James Dearden and star Ewan McGregor do their best to bring the self-confessed "Watford chancer" to life, comparing his life (frenzy on the trading floor, bad behaviour in bars) with the grandees' silent, elegant boardrooms.

It's an uphill job, though, as Leeson stares at numbers on screens in Singapore and tiger economies turn into paper tigers. As his wife, Lisa, Anna Friel is given a shockingly token part. Did Leeson's book, on which this is based, really give her nothing to do except shopping and sunbathing? While the script reveals little (and maybe market traders are too single-minded to have outside lives) the sums are mind-boggling. Leeson's illegal borrowings to hide initial losses lost £50m in one day and at least £200m in total.

Wing Commander
Rental
Fox Pathé Cert PG
*

A video based on a video game of the same name. Why do people do this? Video game fans would rather interact and the rest of us would prefer something with a little thought between the explosions, sentimentality, spacespeak and sub-John Williams music. What you get here is Top Gun in space, but worse. Saffron Burrows gets the Kelly McGillis role as "Angel" in the oddest sci-fi casting since Paul Verhoeven sent Denise Richards out to battle gargantuan insects in Starship Troopers. Matthew Lillard plays "Maniac". Beam me outta here.

fields.headline: GUS finds unexpected cheer
fields.standfirst: Catalogue chain confirms late boost in Christmas retail sales
fields.trailText: The catalogue shopping group Great Universal Stores has bounced back from a disastrous profit warning in December with better-than-expected Christmas sales.
fields.body:
The catalogue shopping group Great Universal Stores has bounced back from a disastrous profit warning in December with better-than-expected Christmas sales.

The GUS seasonal update was one of several trading updates from retailers yesterday which again showed Christmas was far better than most shopkeepers had dared to hope.

GUS, whose shares lost 45% of their value last year and won the unwelcome distinction of second-worst performer in the FTSE 100, said like-for-like sales at its Argos offshoot were up 6.9% in the 14 weeks to January 8. In the results for the first half of the financial year, announced in December, they were down 3%. Many analysts questioned the wisdom of GUS paying £1.9bn for the business in 1998.

At the home shopping division, which is suffering the same middle-market mauling as Marks & Spencer, the deterioration in like-for-like sales was reined back to 3.5% from the 6.5% decline reported last month.

Chief executive John Peace announced a "root and branch" review of the business and the early retirement of chairman Lord Wolfson. He is to be replaced by Sir Victor Blank, also chairman of the Trinity newspaper group.

Elsewhere, JJB Sports, House of Fraser, furniture group DFS and supermarket chain Safeway reported good trading figures. Safeway said like-for-like sales in the 12 weeks to January 8 were ahead 6.1% and the shares climbed 5.5p to 217.25p.

But there were black spots. Body Shop said its UK sales down 3%. But gains in the US left overall sales flat. Storehouse reported like-for-like Bhs sales down 4.4%, compared to the 9.2% decline reported in the first half of the financial year. Mothercare was down just 0.2%.

Storehouse said the figures showed some progress but analysts have decided the company is near basket-case status and see a bid as the only escape for shareholders.

But analyst Rowan Morgan at stockbroker Teather & Greenwood said the company had "no earnings, no dividend, no management, no pricing power, no credibility and no bidder in the wings".

webTitle: Sir Ernie hands on 'our people' to new steward

fields.headline: Sir Ernie hands on 'our people' to new steward
fields.trailText: Sir Ernest Harrison yesterday headed for the race-course and Highbury, home of his beloved Arsenal, after bringing to a close nearly half a century of brilliant stewardship of Racal - and leaving with a personal fortune of about £25m, writes David Gow.
fields.body:
Sir Ernest Harrison yesterday headed for the race-course and Highbury, home of his beloved Arsenal, after bringing to a close nearly half a century of brilliant stewardship of Racal - and leaving with a personal fortune of about £25m, writes David Gow.

Sir Ernest, known as Ernie to all and sundry, sipped a glass of white wine as he spoke with "mixed emotion" of severing his links with the firm he joined as employee number 13 in October 1951.

Racal, founded a year earlier, then occupied an attic in the offices of the Waterman pen company in London's Kingsway and a 7,000 square feet factory in Isleworth, Middlesex, making radio parts.

After joining as secretary and chief accountant, Sir Ernest took over as chairman and chief executive in 1966 when sales were just £4m. At their peak, almost 10 years ago, they topped £2bn and Racal had about 35,000 staff.

Sir Ernest made his name as an entrepreneur by building up - and selling - Vodafone and Chubb, the security firm.

He cemented his reputation for creating shareholder value late last year by squeezing an extra £200m out of American firm Global Crossing, which outbid Energis with an agreed £1bn offer for Racal Telecom.

Sir Ernest said: "No longer will Racal be a plc but the name will remain, still recognised as a world leader in defence electronics. But life is about reality and doing the best for the whole. We know this is very much in the best interests of Thomson and Racal shareholders - and, most importantly, of our people."

fields.headline: No time for half measures
fields.standfirst: Interest that needs boredom
fields.trailText: Mervyn King would have enjoyed yesterday's announcement that interest rates were going up. Not because the deputy governor of the Bank of England takes a sadistic delight in seeing the cost of mortgages and overdrafts rise but because he has long held that monetary policy should be as boring and predictable as possible. Yesterday's move was as boring and predictable as they come. So, for that matter, was the reaction to the decision, which was condemned by the usual suspects for putting the economy on the road to ruin.
fields.body:
Mervyn King would have enjoyed yesterday's announcement that interest rates were going up. Not because the deputy governor of the Bank of England takes a sadistic delight in seeing the cost of mortgages and overdrafts rise but because he has long held that monetary policy should be as boring and predictable as possible. Yesterday's move was as boring and predictable as they come. So, for that matter, was the reaction to the decision, which was condemned by the usual suspects for putting the economy on the road to ruin.

But even a moment's reflection would indicate that the Bank had little choice. It was right to put up rates and it was right to put them up modestly. Of course, there is an argument for leaving borrowing costs at 5.5% and there is an argument for banging them up by half a point, but neither is specially convincing. Britain's multi-speed economy, with strong regional differences and disparities between the performance of manufacturing and services requires sensitive handling but there is no doubt that the recent evidence has pointed to inflationary pressure building up.

To take one example: the Halifax yesterday reported that house prices rose by 3.4% in the final quarter of 1999 and by 11.5% for the year as a whole. In Greater London, however, they were up by a stonking 28.9% last year, a faster rate of increase than in 1988, the height of the Lawson boom. The south-east has its own peculiar economic characteristics but house prices generally are being underpinned by the tightness of the labour market, where recent months have seen average earnings rise by 4.9%.

As Michael Saunders of Salomon Smith Barney Citibank put it yesterday, real interest rates are running at around 3.75%, in line with the average of the past five years. But this five-year period has seen domestic demand running well above the economy's long-term potential, despite considerable fiscal tightening. As such, real interest rates of 3.75%, although high by global standards, might not be enough to keep the lid on demand. Put another way, says Mr Saunders, Britain is different. "If both the UK and Germany have nominal short rates of 5.5% and the same inflation rate (say, about 2%), then German households probably would buy bonds whereas UK households would go to the nearest estate agent, borrow lots of money, buy houses and set a house price boom in motion."

So, if the housing market is flashing red and the labour market is flashing amber, why not even more Draconian action? If young internet entrepreneurs are becoming stock market millionaires overnight and spending their riches on palaces and Porsches, shouldn't the MPC stop pussy-footing around with quarter-point increases? Well, no.

The other side of the new economy was revealed when Dixons said this week that its profits are being hit by tumbling prices. Dixons is by no means a one-off. The clothing manufacturer Dewhirst announced yesterday that the squeeze on profits was to blame for the loss of 1000 jobs at two plants in the north, in County Durham and Cheshire. Global overcapacity, an unfavourable exchange rate and ingrained customer resistance to paying higher prices mean that the corporate sector is already being squeezed and could be hit hard by an over-aggressive monetary policy. So, too, could consumers, despite the low level of unemployment.

Geoff Dicks of Greenwich NatWest points out that the personal savings ratio is already at a 10-year-low and might start to rise over the coming months as interest rates edge upward and mortgage interest relief is phased out. Whatever happens, consumers are likely to be as eager to spot a bargain as they have been for most of the past 10 years, providing no respite for retailers.

The money markets are in no mood for any of this, and have convinced themselves that rates are inexorably heading for 7.5% or even higher. But longer-term money market rates are normally wrong, and it may be that the two or three quarter-point rises the MPC has in store for us in the first half of this year will be enough.

Anxious times

Last year was another tough one for Fii Group, the shoemaker which has been struggling to make money for as long as anyone can remember. A serious restructuring had to be completed, including the sale of its business supplying Marks & Spencer. But it found a deficit on its pension fund and in the middle of last month out came the obligatory profits warning.

So it has decided to diversify and is exploring "the new Wireless Application Protocol m-commerce arena". This is not a spoof. Shares in Fii doubled to 120p yesterday.

Taken with the transformation of Blakes Clothing into e-xentric the advice to investors is clear: don't bet on companies which are simply losing money, buy shares in those that are threatening to go bust instead.

Anxious times Last year was another tough one for Fii Group, the shoemaker which has been struggling to make money for as long as anyone can remember. A serious restructuring had to be completed, including the sale of its business supplying Marks & Spencer. But it found a deficit on its pension fund and in the middle of last month out came the obligatory profits warning. So it has decided to diversify and is exploring "the new Wireless Application Protocol m-commerce arena". This is not a spoof. Shares in Fii doubled to 120p yesterday. Taken with the transformation of Blakes Clothing into e-xentric the advice to investors is clear: don't bet on companies which are simply losing money, buy shares in those that are threatening to go bust instead.

fields.headline: Thomson nabs Racal for £1.3bn
fields.standfirst: Deal creates third player in Europe
fields.trailText: Thomson-CSF, the French electronics group, yesterday laid claim to being a "formidable" competitor for BAE Systems in the British defence market after sealing an agreed £1.32bn takeover of Racal.
fields.body:
Thomson-CSF, the French electronics group, yesterday laid claim to being a "formidable" competitor for BAE Systems in the British defence market after sealing an agreed £1.32bn takeover of Racal.

The deal, signed late on Wednesday night, will almost certainly see the early sale of Racal's 26.7% stake in national lottery operator Camelot and other, smaller non-defence assets. Cadbury-Schweppes, De La Rue and ICL - Racal's partners in Camelot - are legally bound to be offered the first chance to snap up its share.

Denis Ranque, chairman and chief executive, said the deal made Thomson the third big player in European defence alongside BAE and EADS, the group being formed from the merger of France's Aérospatiale Matra, Germany's Dasa and Spain's Casa.

But Mr Ranque, left on the sidelines of European defence consolidation until yesterday's deal, insisted the combination with Racal would create a better balanced group than either of its much bigger rivals.

"We are involved in both civil and military electronics," he said, pointing out that defence technology would be more and "invaded" by breakthroughs in commercial technology.

The enlarged group will have sales of euro 8bn (£5bn), of which 54% will be in defence electronics, 29% in the fast-growing industrial electronics sector and 17% in avionics. It will employ 64,500 staff worldwide, including 14,500 in Britain where Thomson already employs 6,000. Mr Ranque made plain few, if any jobs would be lost through the takeover.

Under the deal, first mooted in early November last year, Thomson is paying 450p for every Racal share. It said this gave a premium of 4.7% on Wednesday's closing price of 430p but one of 38% on the price before it made its original approach.

Thomson offered 400p a share in November, excluding a 167p special dividend worth £500m - or half the proceeds of the sale of Racal Telecom. This and an interim dividend of 2.1p will be paid out on January 28, netting Racal shareholders £1.82bn overall. Sir Ernest Harrison, chairman and chief executive since 1966, will get around £25m.

Analysts welcomed the deal which, Mr Ranque said, made Thomson the world's largest exporter of defence electronics. Both he and Sir Ernest said it had been explicitly endorsed by Britain's ministry of defence (MoD).

Thomson is vying with BAE, itself formed from the £8bn merger with the then GEC's Marconi defence arm, to build two new aircraft carriers worth £6bn for the MoD.

Mr Ranque claimed that if BAE had been left to dominate the British market it would have been "left wide open to American competition".

"By building this company we are protecting British jobs against American jobs," he said.

The large US defence companies - Lockheed Martin, Boeing and Raytheon - are increasingly trying to penetrate the British and other European markets and to build alliances.

Lockheed underlined this yesterday by appointing Admiral Sir Jock Slater, a former first sea lord renowned for his outspoken attacks on allowing "queers and lesbians" into the navy, as a senior military adviser on a part-time basis.

fields.headline: Station X regroups
fields.standfirst: Wartime base back in business
fields.trailText: Bletchley Park - the former Station X which was home to second world war codebreakers and seat of Britain's communications revolution - is aiming to re-establish itself as the educational heartland of Britain's silicon valley.
fields.body:
Bletchley Park - the former Station X which was home to second world war codebreakers and seat of Britain's communications revolution - is aiming to re-establish itself as the educational heartland of Britain's silicon valley.

It follows the reinstatement yesterday of Christine Large as director of the trust which runs the park. She had been ousted in a board coup late last year by a group of directors who feared she wanted to make Bletchley too "business-like".

Ms Large appealed to the Charity Commission which held an investigation and there was also an internal inquiry, chaired by Richard Southwell QC. A new board of directors yesterday decided to implement the Southwell recommendations in full and to reinstate Ms Large as the most senior executive on the trust.

"We are not planning to become a high-technology business park but a heartland for the communications and technology industries," she said.

Ms Large wants to develop Bletchley, not only as a heritage site telling the story of its wartime triumph and subsequent communications innovation, but also to establish a community education base, to encourage conferences in the mathematics, high technology and communications sectors and to encourage a revival of research and development.

Sir Philip Duncombe, who remains chairman of the board, said Bletchley Park would have "the benefit of valuable skills and much experience to equip it for the 21st century."

Ms Large insisted that anything which the organisation now tried would have to be commercially viable and said the board had already indicated its determination to become more professional by appointing Chris Smith as managing director and Tim Pulverman as operations and finance director. Other board additions are banker Sir Evelyn de Rothschild and Roy MacLaren, the Canadian High Commissioner.

fields.headline: Easdaq uses its time-zone edge
fields.standfirst: US-listed firms trade in Brussels
fields.trailText: Easdaq, the pan-European stock exchange, is to steal a march on New York's Nasdaq index by allowing traders to buy and sell shares in 10 of its American rival's best-known companies before the US market opens.
fields.body:
Easdaq, the pan-European stock exchange, is to steal a march on New York's Nasdaq index by allowing traders to buy and sell shares in 10 of its American rival's best-known companies before the US market opens.

Investors will be able to buy and sell shares in companies such as Microsoft, Yahoo and Amazon.com six hours before the New York market even opens for business from next week.

The move was also seen as a blow to the London stock exchange, which is keen to attract high-technology stocks to its Techmark index.

Easdaq, which is based in Brussels, announced yesterday that it had gained regulatory approval for the 10 technology companies listed on Nasdaq index to be traded on its own exchange.

Nasdaq, a benchmark for technology companies in the United States and one of the world's largest stock markets, has already announced plans to launch its own European exchange later this year.

Nasdaq Europe, seen as a bid to move towards all-day trading, will not be operational for several months.

"We intend to include several more companies before Nasdaq comes in towards the end of this year," said Lauren Ptito at Easdaq yesterday.

Easdaq intends to allow investors to trade in a further 30 companies in the coming months.

These companies, which will come from Israel as well as the US, will remain listed on their domestic exchanges.

Share trading in Europe has become intensely competitive as several exchanges fight for the increased interest from ordinary investors as well as big institutions.

Existing exchanges face increased competition from the fast-growing electronic communications networks as well as each other.

Yesterday's announcement is part of Easdaq's push to expand its role beyond trading in initial public offerings and secondary offerings of the 56 companies listed on its exchange.

The exchange announced its plans to make markets in non-listed companies last year in a bid to raise its profile in the face of fierce competition.

Microsoft, valued at $526bn (£320bn), dwarfs NTL, the largest company currently traded on Easdaq which is valued at 12bn euros (£7.5bn).

The new Easdaq-listed companies also include Cisco Systems, Intel, Oracle, Sun Microsystems, MCI Worldcom, Amgen and Dell.

fields.headline: City briefing
fields.trailText:
Drug rivals confirm talks
Warner-Lambert said yesterday that it would hold merger talks with hostile suitor Pfizer, walking away from its November decision to be acquired by American Home Products.
fields.body:
Drug rivals confirm talks
Warner-Lambert said yesterday that it would hold merger talks with hostile suitor Pfizer, walking away from its November decision to be acquired by American Home Products.

Either combination would create the world's largest drugmaker.

Investors had put pressure on Warner-Lambert executives to re-evaluate their decision to unite with AHP, especially given the rising value of Pfizer's offer.

Pfizer bid for Warner-Lambert on November 4, just hours after AHP and Warner-Lambert announced plans to merge.

BP/Arco deal back on track
Oil groups BP Amoco and Atlantic Richfield said they hoped to persuade the US federal trade commission to set aside its reservations about their merger.

The companies said that they would restart the required 20-day notice of the merger, despite the risk that would prompt the commission to resolve the dispute in the courts.

The notice period was suspended on November 2. The firms said a meeting has been arranged with the commission today to discuss the next steps.

Airbus tops Boeing sales
European aircraft maker Airbus said yesterday it secured 476 orders for airliners in 1999, beating US rival Boeing's total of 391.

Airbus valued the orders at $30.5bn (£18.5bn) and said they represented the second-highest level for the group. "With a 55% market share in 1999, after almost 50% in 1998, Airbus Industrie has confirmed that it is now established on a par with its competitor," Airbus chief executive Noel Forgeard said.

Police search at Holzmann
German builder Philipp Holzmann said yesterday that police were searching its offices throughout Germany in a fraud investigation linked to the firm's near collapse last year.

Holzmann said it welcomed the investigation, which resulted from a legal complaint it filed against unnamed former managers, and was cooperating with investigators.

About 200 police officers and 10 state prosecutors were involved the search, which could last two or three days, Holzmann said.

The Frankfurt state prosecutor's office is leading the investigation into alleged breach of trust and fraud by former Holzmann executives blamed for running up losses of 2.4bn German marks (£764m).

US treasury to buy back debt
The US treasury announced yesterday that it would buy back up to $30bn (£18bn) of government debt this year - the first buy-back programme since the 1970s.

Wall Street had been expecting that the budget surplus would allow the treasury to buy back debt but was surprised by the amount.

fields.headline: The new endangered species
fields.standfirst: Small currencies vanishing as big bucks take over
fields.trailText: Britain may be showing a growing scepticism about the virtues of signing up for the euro but others, from Latin America to the Balkans, are falling over themselves to adopt someone else's currency. Ecuador announced this week that it plans to replace the sucre with the dollar as the country's legal tender. Puerto Rico was a pioneer of dollarisation. Australian and New Zealand dollars hold sway in the South Pacific where the French franc does not act as the local currency.
fields.body:
Britain may be showing a growing scepticism about the virtues of signing up for the euro but others, from Latin America to the Balkans, are falling over themselves to adopt someone else's currency. Ecuador announced this week that it plans to replace the sucre with the dollar as the country's legal tender. Puerto Rico was a pioneer of dollarisation. Australian and New Zealand dollars hold sway in the South Pacific where the French franc does not act as the local currency.

Estonia - already pegged to the German mark - this week began debating adopting the euro when notes and coins are introduced in 2002. Montenegro, still part of Yugoslavia, is already using the mark in parallel with the Yugoslav dinar but there are signs that it may soon switch to just the German currency. Elsewhere in the Balkans, Bosnia uses the mark as its official currency.

Others have regimes where the dependence on an outside currency is less overt but just as great. Argentina and Bulgaria have currency boards where the local currency still circulates but the authorities hold enough dollars or marks to buy up every new peso or lev in circulation.

Ordinary citizens are spurning their own currencies in favour of those proven to hold their value. "There isn't an adult in Moscow who doesn't know the rouble-dollar exchange rate," said one western resident.

In Cuba decades of hostility, not to mention a trade embargo, have not prevented the hegemony of the greenback.

Some economists are predicting that the world's big currencies - the dollar, euro, mark and the yen - will bring the curtain down on small currencies. Nobel prize winner Robert Mundell predicted this week that in 10 years' time the euro zone will have expanded to cover 50 countries, the dollar will have spread throughout Latin America and much of Asia will look towards the yen.

Professor Steve Hanke, from Johns Hopkins University in the US, reckons much of central and eastern Europe will have adopted the euro directly or via a currency board within the next few years.

But why should countries want to give up their own currencies and with it control of monetary policy? Supporters of the change claim a widely held currency delivers stability, an anchor in the battle against inflation. Professor Hanke, who is advising Montenegro and Ecuador on currency strategy, argues that adopting an external currency, directly or indirectly, works. "Currencies in developing countries rarely float in a sea of tranquillity."

He blames weak monetary authorities, tempted to print money as a short-term fix to long-term problems. The solution is to take control of monetary policy away from expediency driven central banks to ones with a track record of providing stability - "either putting a hangman's noose round the central bank (by dollarisation or its mark equivalent) or a straitjacket by adopting a currency board." Countries which have opted for such external discipline have experienced faster growth, lower inflation and lower budget deficits, he says and dismisses criticisms that such options are only available to small countries.

'On-your-own' downside

"The economies of California, Texas and New York together are larger than the whole of Latin America, yet all three are dollarised. Have you ever heard California asking for its own central bank?"

The downside is, as the Federal Reserve makes clear to countries toying with adopting the dollar, that it will set interest rates only in response to economic conditions in the US. Outsiders can't expect the Fed to rescue them if their economies get into difficulties. The message from Washington is "you are on your own". A country with its economy in the doldrums would suffer a further twist of the knife if the Fed were to raise interest rates; a squeeze on both companies and consumers, plus an exchange rate that makes exporters uncompetitive.

Nor can the political consequences of what can be seen as reverse colonialism - surrendering control of economic policy to a powerful but indifferent neighbour - be overlooked. The US approach is in contrast with Europe's single currency zone but only as far as its 11 members, which have a say on the direction of interest rates, are concerned. Non-members either using the mark or tracking the euro are still out in the cold.

But is this all an argument for Britain signing up for the euro or shunning the single currency? Professor Hanke draws a sharp distinction between dollarisation and monetary union. The first involves giving up control of monetary policy. That can be reversed. The second involves surrendering monetary sovereignty. "And the only way out of that is if the whole thing blows up."

fields.headline: Rift opens between rail regulators
fields.trailText: The rail industry's two top regulators are involved in a bitter row for supremacy, which is embarrassing John Prescott - the man who hand-picked them, it emerged last night.
fields.body:
The rail industry's two top regulators are involved in a bitter row for supremacy, which is embarrassing John Prescott - the man who hand-picked them, it emerged last night.

The confrontation between the rail regulator, Tom Winsor, and the chairman of the shadow strategic rail authority, Sir Alastair Morton, was described yesterday as "creative tension" and has led to an angry exchange of letters between the two men.

Government sources dismissed the row as unimportant and made it clear that Mr Winsor and Sir Alastair have clearly defined roles. But they pointed out that Sir Alastair had the ear not only of Mr Prescott but the prime minister, and that Sir Alastair's role was pivotal.

Sources also suggested that Mr Winsor has been advised by ministers to tone down his attack of Railtrack, which is facing a fine of up to £40m from Mr Winsor's office if it does not improve its performance. Mr Winsor is understood to be determined that his independence should not be undermined.

The lack of harmony between Sir Alastair and Mr Winsor first surfaced when the SRA's chairman wrote to Mr Winsor after the Paddington rail crash. He complained to Mr Winsor about the regulator's threat to withdraw Railtrack's licence if it was discovered that Railtrack had not acted safely in the lead up to the crash.

As the person responsible for overseeing the industry's private monopoly, Mr Winsor has become increasingly irked by interference from Sir Alastair. He wrote a strongly worded reply which his office would not reveal yesterday.

Keith Webb, the regulator's director of strategy and planning, said: "It would be remarkable if there was not an occasional piece of creative tension between the main players in the industry. This is part of having an independent regulator."

Differences between the two are likely to be underlined in the coming months when the new SRA is finally set up under the government's new transport legislation. Some of Mr Winsor's powers will be handed over to the SRA, although Mr Winsor will press ahead with his plan to make Railtrack more accountable to the public interest.

Mr Prescott is anxious that the row should be stopped without doing further damage because it has become a talking point in the industry.

The SRA stressed that the two men had not quarrelled, although there had been a difference of opinion.

fields.headline: Focus  Siemens
fields.trailText: Siemens has spent long enough out of favour with investors to be entitled to enjoy its recent run of form on the Frankfurt exchange.
fields.body:
Siemens has spent long enough out of favour with investors to be entitled to enjoy its recent run of form on the Frankfurt exchange.

The shares were up 130% last year and 77% in the past three months alone. Yesterday they clocked up a new all-time high at just short of €135 (£84) before easing back to €133.70.

The latest run-up is being attributed to the forthcoming flotation of Infineon, its semi-conductor subsidiary, where between 25% and 49% of the shares will be sold. The semi-conductor market has picked up dramatically since Siemens closed down its plant on North Tyneside and it believes Infineon could be worth anything between 10bn and 20bn German marks (£3.2bn to £6.4bn).

The Infineon floatation promises to put the seal on a rationalisation programme which over the past year produced better results than analysts had been expecting. Indeed it is investors' conversion - arguably belatedly - to the idea that Siemens is one of Europe's biggest restructuring plays, which has provided most of the fuel for last year's rise.

Some analysts are already tipping Siemens to be a star performer again this year. Others are more cautious, arguing that the group's stock market performance still lags that of some other hi-tech stocks.

Though attention is now focused on Infineon the longer term outlook is likely to depend rather more on the performance of the operating businesses ranging from mobile phones and services to trains and power plants as well as the joint venture in personal computers with Fujitsu. The company would do well to match 1999.
